HEADLINE: The Region;
Connecticut Begrudgingly Considers an Income Tax.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
About 20 years ago, Connecticut politicians tried tinkering with the state's tax system and brought on a political clampdown. They created and passed an income tax for the first time, but within weeks the law was repealed under a storm of public outrage. Tax reformers went underground, and a new generation of income-tax hard-liners within the state's majority Democratic party came to power.
Under Gov. Ella T. Grasso, elected in 1974, and her successor, Gov. William A. O'Neill, who will end 10 years in office next January, every mention of an income tax was greeted with a thundering vow of veto from the State Capitol. Across the state, politicians with higher ambitions took ''the pledge'' as it became known, promising unswerving opposition no matter how they may have actually felt. 
But now it appears the great thaw has begun. For the first time since the 1970's a Democratic candidate for governor has emerged who not only espouses an income tax at every turn but claims to have attracted enough support within the party to force a primary election - and thus force an open debate on the once unspeakable subject.
The candidate, State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., a little-known professor of political science at Connecticut College, advocates coupling a tax on wages with deep cuts in other taxes, especially the sales tax, which at 8 percent is the highest statewide rate in the nation. Connecticut now taxes unearned income like dividends, interest and capital gains, but is one of only 10 states without a tax on wages.
Mr. Cibes has announced that at least 20 percent of the delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which meets here next weekend, had pledged their votes to him, a key threshold in the state election law that would enable him to challenge the party's front-runner, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, in a primary election on Sept. 11. Even Mr. Morrison has conceded Mr. Cibes's gains and the likelihood of a primary.
And that's where it all starts to get a little murky, and the oddities of Connecticut's near obsession with the tax as a political issue start to become apparent. Many of those who would seem most likely to be cheering Mr. Cibes on - especially from the liberal wing of the Democratic party that has chafed against Mr. O'Neill and his adamant stand against an income tax - have not been entirely enthusiastic. Some of them support Mr. Morrison, who has long been identified as one of the more liberal members of the state's Congressional delegation, while others argue that Mr. Cibes's candidacy could in fact be a setback in their efforts to change the tax system.
Because most politicians expect Mr. Cibes to lose in September against Mr. Morrison, who is better known and better financed, the liberals fear that Mr. Cibes's defeat would be interpreted as a rejection of the tax and not simply of the candidate himself. ''Anybody who tries to elaborate tax reform proposals is almost certain to fail,'' said Stanley B. Greenberg, president of Greenberg-Lake Inc., a national Democratic polling firm retained by Mr. Morrison. ''The voters are too cynical, the medium for communication is too simplified, and there are too many people who have an interest in simplifying it.''
Mr. Cibes has seen his candidacy bolstered by what might seem to be one of the most unlikely sources of all: Mr. O'Neill and many of his supporters. Mr. O'Neill, while stressing that he opposes Mr. Cibes's ideas on tax revision, has gone out of his way recently to praise Mr. Cibes as a personal friend and a ''great asset to the Democratic Party.''
Mr. Morrison, among others, has said he thinks that most of Mr. Cibes's convention delegates are in fact former O'Neill supporters who do not believe in an income tax any more than the Governor does and who are supporting Mr. Cibes for other reasons. Revenge is often mentioned: Mr. Morrison was unrelenting in his criticism of Mr. O'Neill in the months before the Governor's withdrawl from the race in March, and many Democrats have yet to forget.
Pollsters say, however, that whatever odd twists may be occurring within the Democratic Party, public opposition to an income tax has not subsided. They say that many residents, still reeling from last year's record $800 million tax increase and perhaps facing another difficult budget next spring, are more suspicious about politicians and taxes than ever before.
According to a poll in April by the state's largest polling organization, the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research at the University of Connecticut, only about 26 percent of the state's residents favored an income tax, down from a record high of 41 percent recorded in early 1989. Seventy percent thought taxes were too high, compared to an average of about 60 percent through most of the 1980's. ''Resistance to tax increases is the strongest I've seen in 20 years of polling,'' said Everett C. Ladd, the center's director.
A key question for Mr. Morrison is how far he can afford to go in opposing an income tax without alienating the liberal Democrats who back his candidacy.
Several weeks ago, for example, Mr. Morrison declared that as governor he would veto any income-tax bill unless it could be shown through a statewide referendum that a majority of state residents supported the idea. Mr. Cibes, who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, immediately declared that his opponent had ''taken the pledge,'' a charge Mr. Morrison denied. Some of Mr. Morrison's supporters said that if he moved much closer toward completely ruling out an income tax they would abandon him. ''There's been some uneasiness,'' said State Representative Miles A. Rapoport, a longtime income-tax advocate who is in Mr. Morrison's camp.
Of the others in the gubernatorial race, only the lone remaining Republican candidate, United States Representive John G. Rowland, has said that he would veto any income-tax package. And the candidate that most polls indicate is the front-runner, former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican who is running as an independent, has appeared to back away from an income tax. Mr. Weicker, while not ruling out an income tax, recently said he would not favor one, at least right now while the state's economy is weak and unemployment is rising. A spokeswoman for Mr. Weicker, Avice Meehan, insisted, however, that all options would remain open.
''He has not taken the pledge,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Aid Can Answer a Soviet Question

 BODY:
Secretary of State James Baker says the United States won't stand in the way of allies who want to offer aid to the Soviet Union. And the Bush Administration is prepared to send technical assistance, but not to extend credits.
That's an improvement on Defense Secretary Cheney's outright opposition to aid. But it doesnanmatch the vision demonstrated by NATO leaders in London on Friday who charted a new course for the alliance and Europe. And it's too little and too slow to bolster Mr. Gorbachev against bitter Old Guard assaults on his foreign policy. 
Given the high stakes that the U.S. has in that policy, President Bush would do better to join other Western leaders in pledging Western economic aid at this week's economic summit meeting in Houston. In return, he'd have every right to expect the Soviet leader to accommodate him by cutting military spending and aid to Cuba.
Mr. Gorbachev faces no sterner challenge from the Old Guard at the Communist Party Congress than the question, Who lost Eastern Europe? Conservative critics like Yegor Ligachev blame Mr. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze for the collapse of socialism in Eastern Europe.
''What socialism?'' Mr. Gorbachev lashes back. ''A variety of the Stalinist authoritarian and bureaucratic system that we ourselves have abandoned.'' Mr. Shevardnadze gives no ground to critics, either: ''It is high time to understand that neither socialism nor friendship, nor good neighborliness, nor respect, can rest on bayonets, tanks or blood.'' And he likens the Old Guard's question to the notorious McCarthyite query in the 1950's, Who lost China?
But the Gorbachev-Shevardnadze defense of new thinking in foreign policy can't rest on rhetoric alone. They need to show the Soviet people that withdrawal from Eastern Europe will yield other benefits, mainly Western economic help.
Mr. Bush says he has a hard time sending a big aid package to the Soviets when they're spending 18 percent of their gross national product on defense and about $5 billion a year on Cuba. That's good bargaining, but he can drive a better bargain by using carrots as well as sticks.
If Mr. Bush wants to encourage the Soviet move to markets, he does that best by joining the allies. That way, he can help direct aid to enterprises that have a chance of promoting competitive markets. Failure to act with the allies could limit U.S. influence in shaping Europe's future.
Prompt and prudent aid from the West, in the expectation of further real reductions in Soviet defense spending and assistance to Cuba, could help Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Shevardnadze defeat the Old Guard and thereby sustain a foreign policy that also benefits the West.

HEADLINE: Taxes in Other Countries Buy More Services

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With tax increases in the air, we are frequently exposed to the statement that United States taxes overall are lower than those of other major industrial countries. This statement is probably based on data in the Statistical Abstract of the United States (tax revenues - selected countries), which show about 30 percent of our gross domestic product (about $5,000 per capita a year) going to taxes, compared with about 38 percent ($3,800 per capita) in Britain. 
These figures are fairly accurate, as far as they go, but to make a comparison between countries, we need to know what citizens get for their taxes, what sort of public safety, public transportation, legal services or health services.
An excellent argument can be made in each case that the United States is deficient. Taking health services as an example, we know that all other major industrial countries deliver basic health services from tax revenues. Those of us lucky enough to have health insurance pay about $1,200 per capita a year, directly or through company benefits. Our expenditures for health care exceed 11 percent of gross domestic product.
Based on the health-services disparity alone and the resultant imputed tax on the individual, it appears that our taxes overall are far higher than those of other major industrial countries.
 
JOHN H. SWEENEY
 Cambridge, Mass., June 25, 1990

HEADLINE: Soviet Rural Life Looked at Through Urban-Colored Glasses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It seems to me, as a specialist on Soviet rural areas and peasant behavior, that your coverage of the Soviet Union is too urban oriented. For instance, your June 24 front-page report on Leningrad notes that ''when state farms in the countryside issued their annual demand for city workers to help weed the fields and bring in the early vegetables, the city announced that it would no longer comply.''
Farmers, administrators and officials alike have complained for years about the difficulties involved in ''shefstvo'' (the system by which factories and other organizations contract with farms to supply labor or machinery for harvesting in return for agricultural products). But if the Leningrad City Council has to negotiate with the Baltic republics for meat, milk and vegetables, it means that the council has not been able to consider agreements with its own local farmers that would yield quicker and more reliable results. 
A report in March in Selskaia zhizn, showed that the state farms in the Leningrad area got only 70 percent of the help they had asked for, so they cut back on planting, and 40,000 tons of vegetables were not delivered to the shops. The farms were also given 20 million rubles less equipment and other industrial machinery than asked for. Assuming that the Leningrad City Council seriously wants to solve the problem of produce supply to the cities, it is going to have to come to grips with the fact that the farmers believe that perestroika has given them only ''remainders'' from the workings of the system.
Contrary to your June 15 front-page report from Moscow on increases in the price of bread, farmers feed bread to their pigs not ''because it is cheaper than animal feed,'' but because fodder is often not available at any price. Less meat is coming to market because many farm families no longer own livestock, and sometimes not even chickens.
State procurement prices are, given the labor involved in production, extremely low, and although an effort is being made to raise them, I question whether simply turning over failing agricultural enterprises to individual peasants or families will really solve the issue of ''socialist slavery'' and ''stoop labor,'' as Piotr S. Filipov of the Leningrad City Council seems to think.
Unless small-scale private farming has access to tractors, spare parts, trucks, gasoline and storage facilities, it's doubtful that small-scale farms have any advantage over the present system.
 
ETHEL DUNN
 Berkeley, Calif., June 24, 1990
 
The writer publishes in The Station Relay: Facts and Views on Daily Life in the Soviet Union, a journal.

HEADLINE: The Conflict Within George Bush

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston, former Washington correspondent and executive editor of The New York Times, is writing his memoirs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Being tired of reading George Bush's lips, I was reading some of my old newspaper clips the other day, and there in the middle of The Times's Op-Ed page of May 2, 1979, was a big headline: ''George Bush for President?''
The first paragraph said: ''By age (55), appearance (handsome), location (Texas) and reputation (exemplary), George Herbert Walker Bush is clearly justified by experience and character to challenge the older leaders of the Republican Party for its Presidential nomination.''
It went on to say that there was something reassuring about his past. Always at the beginning of his many jobs, he was praised for being ''competent,'' ''intelligent,'' ''experienced'' and ''decent.'' Always too, doubts were expressed about whether he could succeed, but there was ''applause for his record at the end.'' 
Well, the doubts remain, but halfway through his first term in the White House, he has convinced more than half the people who answer polls that he knows how to navigate the Potomac, a treacherous stream. Nobody's crazy about him, but nobody's very mad at him either. He knows where the rocks are. He tacks with the wind and he stays afloat.
He's not at all like Ronald Reagan. He works. He reads and listens - but he smudges every line. He doesn't call a spade a spade, but a useful agricultural implement. He didn't say he was wrong and would now ''raise taxes.'' He didn't say that he ''required,'' but that deficit reduction ''required,'' in addition to spending cuts, ''tax revenue increases.'' This could mean more revenue from existing taxes if the economy grows, or better tax collection or (maybe) more revenue from a cut in the capital gains tax. It speaks for itself, he said, but we're still reading his lips.
What is going on here much of the time is not merely a clash between the Democrats and the President but a conflict inside the President. It's a wrestling match between the Gentleman from Connecticut and the Politician from Texas. In the campaign of 1988, the Texas politician prevailed, but lately the conscience of the New England gentleman has been peeping through in one compromise after another, and what has emerged is ''Halfway George.''
President Reagan didn't respond to criticism - seldom ever noticed it, but that's not Mr. Bush's way. He's not impressed by the flatterers who tell him: ''Go to it, George. You can do it!'' But if he's told he can't do it or won't do it, he does it, even if it's wrong.
He was charged with being a ''wimp'' in 1988, so he ran a nasty campaign against Bob Dole in the primaries and then against Michael S. Dukakis. He was told he was being too easy on Lieut. Gen. Manuel Noriega, so he invaded Panama with an Army and a rock-'n'-roll band. This violated all the principles and treaty commitments he had proclaimed as the U.N. envoy. But he got his man, with casualties and costs he minimized, and now he doesn't know what to do with him.
When the primitives of his party complained that he was ungrateful for their support in the election and that maybe he was a closet liberal, he repaid them by dumping Dan Quayle on the country and insisting that this unfortunate baby-boomer was the best-qualified person to be Vice President. Normally a generous man, he didn't even thank the Democrats for nominating Mr. Dukakis.
He is, however, a very good politician. He ducked the press during his campaign, anticipating its questions about his silent partnership with Mr. Reagan and his tricky tactics against Mr. Dukakis, but once in the White House he held more press conferences, gave more interviews and appeared on more TV news programs than any President since the last World War.
President Reagan avoided the Democratic leaders of Congress whenever he could, regarding them as obstacles to his dream of cutting taxes and borrowing his way to prosperity, but George sees them all the time. He listens to their mystifying clarifications. He has them over to the house for dinner, pitches horse-shoes with them, takes them sailing and lets them share the blame for the housing and savings and loan scandals. It's quite an achievement, and it's fun trying to figure out who's ahead, George or his conscience.
Either way he has luck, which is the politician's best friend. He didn't win the cold war; the Communists just came to their senses when he was riding down Pennsylvania Avenue from the inauguration. And in addition to Mikhail Gorbachev as an opponent, he inherited the Democrats just when they had run out of candidates and ideas. He is also lucky in Barbara Bush, who is the most comfortable and appealing First Lady we've had since the foundation of Wellesley's school of manners.
So I don't regret that reckless endorsement of George Herbert Walker Bush in 1979. It wasn't too bad, considering the alternative. He's not very heroic. He beats around the bush. He thinks half a loaf is not only better than no bread but better than a whole bakery, and the American people like him, probably because they're sort of like him: friendly, optimistic, fairly prosperous and not too worried about the people who are left behind.

HEADLINE: The Broad Benefits of a Gasoline Tax Hike

BYLINE: By Charles H. Percy; Charles H. Percy, former Republican Senator from Illinois, is chairman of the Alliance to Save Energy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Do you wish gas prices were as cheap as they were in the ''good old days'' of the 1950's? If so, you might be surprised to learn that you would be hoping for an increase in gas prices. After adjusting for inflation, Americans now spend some 35 cents less per gallon of gasoline than they did in 1950.
The Bush Administration and Congress are searching for ways to reduce the deficit during their continuing budget summit meeting. One of the best solutions would be to boost significantly the current 9.1 cents per gallon Federal tax on gasoline. This single action would simultaneously have three beneficial effects - reducing the budget deficit, strengthening U.S. national security and the balance of trade and improving the environment. 
Yet raising the gasoline tax, perhaps even more so than increasing income taxes, has traditionally been viewed as politically risky. When I introduced legislation more than a decade ago calling for a 30 cent per gallon gas tax, not one senator joined as a co-sponsor. But times may be changing. A new NBC News poll found that, if new revenues are needed, 44 percent of Americans favor raising the gas tax, as opposed to only 26 percent in January.
Had this gas tax hike been enacted in 1978, the situation we face today would be radically different in several ways:
* Increased gasoline prices would have spurred more rapid development of fuel-efficient automobiles and alternatively fueled vehicles such as electric cars.
* Oil consumption would have been reduced by about 600,000 barrels a day, leading in turn to lower oil imports (now climbing to 50 percent of U.S. consumption). Lower oil imports would have enhanced our industrial competitiveness, not to speak of national security. Energy imports accounted for nearly 40 percent of our $109 billion trade deficit last year.
* Air pollution would have been reduced significantly. Although transportation-related emissions make up only a portion of total carbon dioxide emissions, a 30 cent gas tax increase in 1978 would have reduced by over half the increase in total carbon dioxide emissions between 1978 and 1988.
* The Federal treasury would have received more than $250 billion over the past 12 years. These funds could have been used to reduce the deficit or to address other critical needs, such as rebuilding America's transportation infrastructure.
While America did not capitalize on this opportunity 12 years ago, we can now. Current gas prices are rela-tively stable and taxes as a percentage of the pump price are low.
In fact, the percentage of gas prices attributable to Federal taxes has decreased by 35 percent since the early 1960's. The amount Americans paid in Federal gasoline tax for each car they drove has declined from an average of $108 in 1960 to only $52 in 1986, in 1989 dollars. Furthermore, the United States has the lowest total state and Federal tax as a percentage of gasoline prices of the major industrialized countries - 33 percent compared with 45 percent in Japan and 66 percent in West Germany.
What benefits would flow from enacting a 50 cent gas tax today (roughly the same after inflation as the 30 cent proposal of 1978)? Gasoline consumption could be expected to drop by 10 percent in the short term - twice that in the long run - with 250 million fewer tons of carbon dioxide entering the atmosphere each year. The Federal treasury would gain about $40 billion annually.
Since a 50 cent tax hike would be a significant change, it could be phased in over the next five years to give both consumers and the ecomomy time to adjust. With or without a phase-in period, however, the new tax should be indexed to inflation to insure that revenues are not eroded over time, as they have been in the past.
To be sure, any new gas tax is difficult, both for political leaders and their constituents. But if Federal officials are serious about tackling the deficit, trade and environmental problems they must increase the gasoline tax by more than just a few cents.
Increasing the gas tax is good economic, energy and environmental policy. Each day we delay raising gasoline taxes makes future options that much more painful.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

 BODY:

Airline Group Fights German Security Levy
Passengers embarking on planes in West Germany now have to pay a $2 security charge imposed by the West German Government. The levy took effect July 1 and affects all passengers on all airlines at all West German airports.
The move has been criticized by the International Air Transport Association, which represents the world's major international airlines.
''We firmly believe that the cost of maintaining security at airports, like anywhere else in a country, should be borne by the state in question,'' said Guenter O. Eser, the director general of association, at its Geneva headquarters.
Mr. Eser said that the association, which has 190 airline members, was not in favor of governments' using airlines as collecting agencies. In the past, he said, passengers paid airport taxes separately and knew what they were paying for and to whom. Now the levy is hidden in the price of the ticket, with the carriers legally liable for their collection and payment to the government, he said. 
 
A New Guide To Mexico
MEXICO CITY
As the favorite vacation destination of millions of Americans, Mexico is the subject of guidebooks galore, so the question arises: is there the need for another publication in so crowded a field? The answer must be a resounding yes if the work is as high in quality and thorough in detail as the new Michelin green guide to Mexico.
Using the same format as the Michelin guides to Europe, the book presents natural wonders, pre-Hispanic civilizations, colonial constructions and modern museums with a wealth of background information. Lesser known spots like Los Tuxtlas in Veracruz or the coastline of the state of Nayarit also get their due.
Particularly welcome are various tables and graphs. One table lists the main deities of Aztec and Maya mythology along with their attributes and powers; another enumerates the principal Indian groups and their location, language, religion, principal handcrafts and dances. Maps of principal cities and archeological sites are clear and easy to use, and there are color photographs of major churches and Indian temples.
For those interested in learning something about Mexico while sightseeing, this is the book to pack. - LARRY ROHTER
 
Vienna-Prague
Rail Fares Cut
To promote rail travel between Austria and Czechoslovakia, the state railways of the two neighboring countries have temporarily reduced fares by 30 to 40 percent for certain trains linking Vienna with Czechoslovak cities. For example, the round-trip fare between Vienna and Prague in second class is $38.50 (based on 11.7 Austrian schillings to $1) for the 1:29 P.M. train from Vienna's Franz Josef Terminal, reaching Prague at 7:36 P.M. The return trip leaves Prague at 6:13 A.M. and arrives in Vienna at 12:37 P.M. The round trip between Vienna and Bratislava is $12.82. The train leaves Vienna Southeast Terminal at 7:13 A.M., reaching Bratislava at 9 A.M.; on the return it leaves Bratislava at 6:45 P.M., arriving in Vienna at 8:28. Round trip, Vienna-Brno, is $21.40. Departing Vienna North Terminal at 7:37 A.M., the train reaches Brno at 9:59 A.M. It leaves Brno at 6:30 P.M., reaching Vienna at 8:15.
 
Beach Vacations
Gain Popularity
For the first time in three years, oceans and beaches are forecasted to lead the list of most popular destinations for summer travelers in 1990, according to the United States Travel Data Center. More than 329 million summer vacation trips are predicted this year, a 2 percent increase from last summer. Oceans and beaches will account for 27 percent of this total, while planned visits to cities dropped to 20 percent, from 30 percent in 1989.
The rise in ocean and beach destinations may be due to the trend toward shorter vacations. Day trips and overnight trips have become especially popular and are expected to account for 9 percent and 11 percent, respectively, of summer vacation travel.
Despite the rise in shorter vacations, the dropoff in travel to cities is extreme. From 1987 to 1989, summer travel to cities rose 2 percent. The 10 percent drop is the most drastic since 1982, when the travel industry suffered from the recession. Scott M. Dring of the Travel Data Center in Washington, said that the move away from urban areas to more natural settings has its roots in a renewed environmental awareness.
''It seems to be due to an ecology trend,'' Mr. Dring said. ''Earth Day and all the recent concern for the environment has made a real difference. Travel to national parks has also gone up in the past two or three years. Oceans have always been popular, but we haven't seen anything like the past six or seven months. The picture has really changed.''
The trend away from urban vacations has also resulted in increased demand for travel to other outdoor destinations, such as mountain and lake areas, and amusement parks.
 
St. Croix Resort
Resorts Reopening
St. Croix's largest hotel, the 150-room Carambola Beach Resort and Golf Club, is expected to reopen in September, a year after Hurricane Hugo. Repair work now nearing completion has focused on interiors of rooms, the golf course and clubhouse. A stretch of Carambola's beach that was washed away has been restored with truckloads of sand imported from Barbuda. A spokesman for the hotel said that although the interiors of rooms were saturated with seawater, the units suffered little structural damage. About two-thirds of the 1,800 hotel rooms on St. Croix, the island hit hardest by the hurricane, are scheduled to reopen in time for the winter season starting in December, according to the St. Croix Hotel Association. An official of the association said water and electricity supplies were back to normal.
One property that was heavily damaged, the 43-room Caravelle Hotel in Christiansted, reopened in May. Twenty rooms of the Caribbean View Apartments and the 65-room St. Croix by the Sea are expected to open this month. Among resorts scheduled to reopen in the fall are the Colony Cove, Gentle Winds Condominiums, Schooner Bay and the Sugar Beach Condominiums.
Divi Resorts says that it plans to rebuild and expand the Divi St. Croix on the southeast coast.
 
LONDON GALLERIES IN NEW DIGS
The Courtauld Institute Galleries in London have opened in their new home in the newly restored Somerset House in the Strand, which is a 10-minute walk from Trafalgar Square. The new quarters enable the Courtauld's art collection and the Courtauld Institute, Britain's leading center for the study of the history of art, to be housed together. Only 30 percent of the institute's collection could be shown at one time at the Courtauld's old galleries in Bloomsbury. The institute's study section had to operate in a separate building in Portman Square.
Included are such Impressionistic masterpieces as Manet's ''Bar at the Folies-Bergere,'' Van Gogh's ''Self-Portrait With Bandaged Ear'' and Cezanne's ''Card-Players'' and works by Renoir, Monet, Degas, Pissarro, Sisley, Boudin and Gauguin. Also on display are works by Rubens, Van Dyck, Goya, Botticelli, Tiepolo and Rembrandt. Address: Somerset House, the Strand, London WC2 R1LB; telephone: 837 2526. Open Monday to Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., till 8 P.M. on Tuesday; Sunday, 2 to 6 P.M. Closed on holidays. Admission about $4.25. Access for handicapped visitors through the main entrance into the courtyard, turning right for the West Service Door, then ringing for an attendant. Nearest Underground stations: Temple (District Line) and Covent Garden (Piccadilly Line).

HEADLINE: On Language;
O Solecism Mio

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
At the biannual meeting of the Judson Welliver Society, the association of former White House speechwriters, the Kennedy Administration's Ted Sorensen rose to assail my use of biannual in the invitation: ''This word means 'twice a year,' not 'every two years'; either Mr. Safire has erred and should have said biennial, or I have not been invited to all the meetings.''
Kill biannual; the word causes more confusion than it's worth. If you mean twice a year, or twice a month, use semiannual, or semimonthly, or better yet, twice a year, twice a month - that avoids confusion. If you mean every other year, go with biennial as an adjective, or the universally understood every other year if you want to avoid having people show up on the right date but the wrong year.
Let us not correct ourselves out of fear, but let us never fear to correct ourselves. In that spirit, this farrago of corrections: 
 
Who Jests at 'Scarify'?
In a piece about bogies, I referred to ''Old Scratch,'' the devil, as a ''scarifier of children.''
This almost intimidated Richard Walsh of Bedford, Mass.: ''I feel sure that in referring to the bogeyman as a 'scarifier of children,' you were deliberately trying to entrap know-it-alls, but here I go falling for it.'' He went on bravely to write that the verbs to scare and to scarify were unconnected.
This was no entrapment or subtle mail pull; it is a mistake I must have been making all my life. Using the false analogy of horror to horrify, I assumed that another verb for the noun and verb scare was scarify. Wrong.
''To scarify,'' writes Carl Mezoff of Stamford, Conn., ''means 'to make a series of scratches or cuts in the surface of something,' and not, as I assume you had intended, 'to frighten.' '' (Some dictionaries do list scarify as a 1794 slang synonym for scare, but the standard sense of scarify offered by Mr. Mezoff dates back to the 16th century. Pronounce the slang term SCARE-if-y and the standard word SCAR-if-y.) He adds that the highway department will use a machine to scarify, or rough up, the surface of a road that is being blacktopped. Sheldon Flory of New Lebanon, N.Y., points out another sense of ''to scar ritually,'' as is done among some African and other tribal peoples.
 
Sex in the News
In a tirade leveled at Mikhail S. Gorbachev in my daily occupation, I denounced him for sending Western newsmen out of Lithuania before his economic crackdown.
''I'm one of those female 'newsmen' who was denied permission to stay in Lithuania,'' writes Alison Mitchell of the Newsday Moscow bureau. ''So are Esther B. Fein of The New York Times, Anne Imse of The Associated Press, Penny Fishlock of The Daily Telegraph, Bridget Kendall of the BBC and Pilar Bonat of El Pais.
''Now, I'm not a stickler on getting gender out of language,'' Ms. Mitchell advises. ''I don't like chairpersons and Congresspersons - but it does strike me as unnecessary and even inaccurate to use newsmen in such circumstances when there are perfectly good words around like journalists, reporters or correspondents.''
Right; newsmen may be used to refer to male reporters, but leaves uncovered female reporters; the sexist newshens has been banned, and the breezy newsies belongs in an informal category with media types. Using newsmen in that instance seemed to assume that only males were on the journalistic job in Lithuania, which is obviously untrue.
Ms. Mitchell is one of the reporters who were - not was - denied permission to stay. When the pronoun one is followed by a prepositional phrase (of the reporters), we must decide whether the relative clause (starting with who) refers to the one or to the many.
In this case, the Newsday reporter is not seeking to separate herself from the crowd to assert her singularity; on the contrary, she is expressing solidarity with her fellow female journalists, stressing the collective. Since the clause refers to the many, we use the plural verb were.
I am one of the newsmen who try not to offend journalists who are female.
 
Ad Infinitum
This is not the place to come for legal advice. Ignore all advice other than grammatical in this space.
In handing out this year's Bloopie Awards to advertising copywriters, I decided not to knock the car that Nissan Motors has named ''Infiniti,'' because it was not a misspelling of infinity: ''the deliberate substitution of a letter makes it possible to copyright the name.''
''Your statement bristles with error,'' thunders Prof. Phillip Edward Page of the South Texas College of Law in Houston. ''First, copyright law has nothing to do with the case. The protection available, if any, is the legally recognized value of the trademark. Second, misspelling is a merchant's gimmick to catch the eye . . . but is not in any way required to make the trademark protectable.''
From Grand Rapids, Mich., John E. McGarry points out that ''one cannot 'copyright' a name. Copyright is given to the writing of an author under the Copyright Act of 1976. A name does not qualify as a 'writing' under the Copyright Act.''
O.K., the verb I should have used was trademark. What about my notion that a properly spelled word was unlikely to qualify as a trademark?
''Equally erroneous,'' Mr. McGarry says. ''Ordinary words can function as trademarks so long as they are not merely descriptive of the goods. The classic example of this is the mark 'Camel' for cigarettes. The term infinity does not appear to be descriptive of the Nissan automobile or of a quality of the automobile and thus could have been used as the trademark.''
George P. Kramer of Hunton & Williams in New York informs me crisply (all letters from lawyers number the paragraphs; occasionally, an attorney will begin with a more informal ''First. . .'') that Nissan owns trademark number 1,478,618 for ''Infiniti.'' Other companies have trademarks registered ''Infiniti'' for golf clubs and hair-styling mousse.
''Under ordinary circumstances (and there are occasional legal exceptions),'' writes the careful Mr. Kramer, ''you cannot pre-empt an otherwise descriptive or generic word by simply substituting a letter. . . . Strawberry cannot be monopolized if you misspell it as 'strawberri.' ''
 
Heaven the Thought
''Perish Forbid,'' a port manteau of ''Perish the thought'' and ''Heaven forbid,'' was a nice malapropism of the 1940's. I speculated that it might have originated with the radio show ''Duffy's Tavern'' or with ''The Goldbergs.''
''My mother, Gertrude Berg,'' writes Harriet Berg Schwartz of West Nyack, N.Y., ''did not use a thick accent in her portrayal of Molly Goldberg, but made the audience laugh at and with her by using inverted word order, upward inflection and hilarious mispronunciations. 'Perish forbid' sounds like her, but I am not sure if she originated the expression. Of course, 'button your neck' is forever to her credit.''
The answer lies elsewhere. ''Goodman Ace was no plagiarist,'' writes Allan Davis of Levittown, L.I., and Helen R. Chapman of Key West, Fla., agrees: ''Perish forbid you should have forgotten the Easy Aces -Goodman and Jane. It was Jane who used to say, 'Perish forbid!' '' Ms. Chapman was so surprised at my oversight that ''As Jane also was noted for saying, 'You could have knocked me over with a fender!' ''

PUB-DATE: July 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: Death-Defying Acts

BYLINE: By GERALD WEISMANN; Gerald Weissmann is a professor of medicine at New York University Medical Center and the editor of M.D. magazine. His most recent collection of essays is ''The Doctor With Two Heads.''

 BODY:

WRESTLING WITH THE ANGEL
A Memoir of My Triumph Over Illness.
By Max Lerner.
210 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.
 
TAKING HEART
By A. C. Greene.
222 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
At the age of 78, shortly after leading a seminar in San Diego on - so help me - ''Eros and the American Family,'' Max Lerner received ''the news'' from his physician: ''My boy, you have a problem.'' That telephone call was the beginning of Mr. Lerner's tussle with three mortal diseases. His lively and candid journal of the good fight, ''Wrestling With the Angel,'' ends with better news. ''Ten and eight years after my respective tumors,'' he writes, ''my cancer-scarred lymph glands and prostate are still within me, causing little trouble. Six years after my heart attack, I have my heart, still pumping blood through tolerably clear arteries.'' 
That Mr. Lerner is now a feisty octogenarian is due to pluck, luck and the expensive revolution in modern medicine. But ''Wrestling With the Angel'' is more than a series of dispatches from the front lines of the cancer wars; it is also a touching apologia pro vita sua, an anthem of maturity and a very good read. This lifetime student of American civilization describes how his experience with illness permitted him to resolve the conflict between the strains in his - and this country's - temper: between East Coast reason and West Coast sentiment, between scholarly thought and spontaneous feeling, between the facts of science and the hope of healing. Years ago, he had appreciated that his hero, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, faced a similar task: ''There are varied strains in each of us, which it is the task of growth to reconcile and integrate.'' Mr. Lerner faced his maladies both as a ''child of New York and of its fierce intellectual rationalism'' and as one who had recently ''embraced selective elements of the Californian subculture . . . in the antechamber of what was becoming 'behavioral,' or 'holistic,' medicine.'' Both strains in his temper served him well.
His career, like empire, has coursed westward. Educated at Yale and the Robert Brookings Graduate School of Economics and Government in Washington, he was a ''premature anti-Fascist'' of the late 30's and 40's. In his salad days, he became the editor of the progressive magazine The Nation and New York's left-wing newspaper PM. He was also a liberal columnist for The New York Post and a professor of American studies at Williams College and Brandeis University. His dozen books include works on radical humanism, Thorstein Veblen, John Stuart Mill and Alexis de Tocqueville. More recently he has become a columnist for The Los Angeles Times, a house guest of Hugh Hefner's and a sometime convert to the ''California adventurism of will therapies'' at Esalen workshops. Happily, in ''Wrestling With the Angel,'' he reverts to his earlier habits of rigorous thought. As his tribulations increased, he became ever more confident that his will and rational choices were as important as - but not necessarily more important than - the opinions of the experts: ''I would pay due attention to doctors, tests, and all the paraphernalia of medicine. . . . My doctors knew more than I did. But in a crisis of conflicting judgments I would never forget that the final, critical decisions were mine to take.''
Some of these decisions involved choices between chemotherapy and palliation, others between castration and a new experimental hormone for prostate cancer. His youngest son, Adam, an oncologist at Harvard's Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, seems to have got the story just right: ''After unpleasant and debilitating therapy, you emerged alive and apparently still full of a fair measure of pepper.''
Max Lerner, a beneficiary of the new molecular medicine, has little patience for those who would ration its costly products: ''Would I, at my unlikely age, agree to a heart transplant as a last desperate measure? . . . If there were no recourse but an artificial heart, I would embrace it and say, 'Pump away, oh Fabulous Artificer, while it is day, for the night comes when no heart can pump.' ''
A. C. Greene embraced his new heart with similar zest. In ''Taking Heart,'' he tells of his experience as the first patient in the new heart transplant program of the St. Paul Medical Center in Dallas. Readers will appreciate the book's low-keyed lack of self-reference and be vastly informed by a splendid job of science writing. This veteran essayist and commentator on the Texas scene not only spins a compelling tale of touch-and-go at the wrong end of the scalpel, but also provides us with a brisk review of transplantation biology, the nuts and bolts of a transplant program, the mechanics of an actual transplant operation (he went back to observe one after his own) and a fine primer of preventive cardiology.
Mr. Greene's prose is crisp and varies with his experiences. In the operating room he ponders: ''Does one actually die at the apogee of anesthetized sleep? Does the body retain too ancient a memory of death to accommodate medically induced stillness and suppression that mimic death? Is death itself imprinted on our genes?'' When it is all over, and the physical scars have healed, Mr. Greene tells us that ''even now I sometimes take a quick inventory of myself . . . [and] find it hard to get over, hard to grasp . . . the broad impact of restoration, the continuingly joyous outcome of it.''
A generation ago, medical students dared not dream that they would be able to cure lymphoma, arrest prostate cancer and transplant the human heart. Nor would that generation have believed it possible that our Government might withhold medical advances from the old or the poor because of cost. The famous, like Mr. Lerner and Mr. Greene, will always be able to tug at the strings of access, but when humbler folk are threatened by medical rationing (as has been proposed in Oregon), we should worry. Justice Holmes's father pleaded not for the mighty or famous:
 
A few can touch the magic string,
And noisy Fame is proud to win them
Alas for those who never sing,
But die with all their music in them.
 Max Lerner also argues their case: ''If the technology is in place, and the conscious and rational will to live is there, who possesses the moral authority to say who shall have its use and who not?'' That sounds like the old PM.
 
FEAR OF THE KNOWN
 Aging is a stage of life, death a finality. The fear of death is the fear of the unknown as well as the terminal. The fear of aging is the fear of the all too well known. Both prod us into activity. Along with the maladies in its wake, aging forms our early warning system of the approach of death. The fear of death spurs us to invent energies and busyness that will mask its terror from us. The fear of aging - limiting the compass of our lives, diminishing the time that still remains for fruitful functioning - spurs us to fall back and reinvent ourselves, to savor more fully the life that remains. This means to reimagine who and where we are, what we want of the rest of our lives, what we can whittle away as inessential, what becomes central.
To cope with a life-threatening illness at any time, and succeed in overcoming it, has to be in itself a life-changing experience. To be close to death ''powerfully concentrates a man,'' as Dr. Johnson put it. When the illness comes late in life, it adds a touch at once of pathos and piquancy. The pathos is that so few years remain for living with the renewed depth you have achieved. The piquancy is that you are spurred even more to rethink life, to reinvent self, to ask the embracing question: What shall I do with the rest of my life? From ''Wrestling With the Angel.''
 
SURGEONS AT CENTER STAGE
 There is a feeling of drama when the overhead surgical spotlights are switched on, illuminating the stage where the operation will take place and leaving the rest of the room in semidarkness, the way the theater takes on its sudden, mystical aura when the house lights go down and the stage lighting takes over the audience's suspended comprehension. The stage is small, no bigger than the human chest. Whether the curtain is going up or coming down depends on which side of it you are on. It goes up for the group of masked individuals, it comes down for the unseen individual upon whom the play is about to be performed. The stage is small, but the drama is the biggest in the world. It is the battle between life and death. The curtains of anesthesia close in, and the final act begins. . . . Masked and faceless worshipers gather around the altar, uniformly clad in the paper suits called scrubs. The surgeons' heads are encased in close-fitting caps of cloth, with wide masks across nose, mouth, and chin. . . . Along with the institutional greens or tans, rather rapidly a different color can and will be added to the scene when the chest is opened and removal of the organs is begun, and some artery may suddenly give a pop and spray color all over the cast. . . . Red. Blood. The most powerful color the human race is heir to. From ''Taking Heart.''

AS THOUSANDS CHEER: The Life of Irving Berlin, by Laurence Bergreen. (Viking, $24.95.) A vivid and impressive portrait of the phenomenon who was part songwriter and part industry, set against the panorama of 80 years of American show business.

An analysis of 65 mother-daughter pairs in Britain and the United States blows away some old misconceptions - including the belief that adolescents achieve identity through rebellion, turmoil and separation.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1264 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Changeover in the Housing Agency;
Putting a Dinkins Imprint on a Koch Plan

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
The word that leaps from Felice Michetti's lips as she seeks to articulate the special stamp that the administration of David N. Dinkins will put on city-assisted housing programs is affordability.
''There will be more money to lower the rents in the vacant buildings program,'' said Ms. Michetti, the new Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, ''and more money for the small-homes program to bring the prices down.''
The vacant buildings program is the name under which most of the apartments in vacant city-owned buildings, acquired through tax foreclosure, are being gut-rehabilitated for a mixed-income population by small builders using private and city financing. The small-homes program has generated one- and two-family houses and condominiums for moderate- to middle-income buyers. Lower prices will make the houses affordable to more people with incomes of about $30,000 to $35,000. Currently, most buyers cluster in the $35,000-to-$38,000 income range. 
A mastery of housing language is an asset in conversation with the knowledgeable Commissioner Michetti, who has come up through the ranks to head the largest housing development agency in any American city. At 41 years of age, she is the sometimes brusque past master of city housing programs.
She is a native of the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx who went to work in the Bronx office of the Department of City Planning in 1973 and shifted to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development's neighborhood-preservation office on West Tremont Avenue in 1979. Later, she became deputy director of the Office of Property Management, which runs city-owned tax-foreclosed apartments; head of the Housing Development Corporation, the financial arm of the department, and deputy housing commissioner. She is a graduate of Fordham University and its law school.
Admirers consider her exceptional at both conceiving housing-production programs and making them work. Whether she will also play the broader role of advocate for housing in areas that go beyond the disposition of city-owned land and buildings - issues that include zoning, rent-regulation policy and the processes of land-use review - remains to be seen. In the Dinkins administration, it is not clear that anyone will assume that role.
Meanwhile, Ms. Michetti said that an understanding had been reached with South Bronx Churches, a nonprofit housing organization, to develop 400 to 500 housing units on sites in the vicinity of East 163d Street and Jackson Avenue in the Bronx. Trying to establish in the Bronx a low-income, for-sale housing program similar to the one mounted in Brooklyn as the Nehemiah Plan by East Brooklyn Churches, the organization staged a protest when the Koch administration decided to award a more centrally located urban-renewal tract known as Site 404 to a different developer.
Although no memorandum of understanding has yet been signed, South Bronx Churches is expected to develop one-family units in the town house and back-to-back styles on sites it was offered by the Koch administration. The houses probably will be sold at average prices lower than the builder will get for condominium units on Site 404 land - 4.35 acres in the Melrose section near the commercial district at Third Avenue and East 149th Street. There the Procida Construction Corporation plans to build 275 units in three- and four-story walk-ups, to be sold through the New York Housing Partnership.
On another matter, the Real Estate Board of New York has been asked to scale down by about 50 percent the density of what was to have been a 750-unit development called Tibbetts Garden in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, and to find a builder prepared to develop the land on a limited-profit basis.
What this will mean is a redesign to a less-risky walk-up condominium development, probably in three- or three-and-a-half-story buildings, for buyers with incomes in the $30,000 to $55,000 range.
The financial risks for government will be reduced, since construction can be slowed in the event of poor sales. The original plan raised the prospect of a $60,000-a-unit city subsidy for middle-income housing - or more in a ''dead'' sales market.
As for the vacant-building program, Ms. Michetti said, the department will ''shoot for an average rent of $525 a month for a two-bedroom apartment'' in the vacant buildings that remain uncommitted to builders. This is lower than the typical $575 rent in these moderate-income projects; the city intends to add subsidy dollars to make the lower rent possible. Moreover, all of these buildings will have to have a lower-income component - 20 percent at a minimum.
The Commissioner said that the Koch administration's plan to look for revenue from market-rate condominium sales to subsidize new lower-income housing in the Seward Park urban renewal area on the Lower East Side and on large sites in Clinton is being re-evaluated. The Seward Park site was awarded to the Lefrak Organization; the Clinton land went to Milstein Properties.
Ms. Michetti, among other officials, have had reservation about relying on market-rate condominium sales to generate profits to apply to lower-income housing. They feel there is too much uncertainty about how many units would be built and when, and what the rents would be. An alternative plan is to be negotiated with community leaders and the developer.
The four-year capital spending plan envisions outlays of $2.1 billion for housing over the next four years, Commissioner Michetti said. That in effect would be a stepped-up expenditure of city money over what was expected when the plan began in 1986. At that time it was proposed that $4.2 billion in city money be spent or committed over 10 years, and half of it already has been. Under the current plan, the $4.2 billion outlay will be reached in eight years instead of 10.
In the early years the expenditures are mainly for existing programs, including those for the homeless, which means housing that is tenanted by the Department of Social Services. In the later years, more new mixed-income housing is to be financed. There is a $31 million commitment, for example, in fiscal 1993 for planning for the proposed Spring Creek Estates project of Starrett Housing Corporation east of Starrett City in the Spring Creek section of Brooklyn near the Queens line. And there is $50 million over two years for the new rental construction, which would be the first city-assisted new-rental program since one in the mid-80's that was financed by excess revenue from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
In the latter program, 20 percent of the tenants were low-income and 80 percent were at a free-market rate. But builders in some locations could not readily achieve the market-rate rents that made the developments economically viable. Different formulas are likely in the new rental program.
In the end, the Dinkins program basically continues the 10-year plan begun by the Koch administration in 1986, with adjustments. This involves a commitment to complete 47,000 units of gut-rehabilitated housing and 37,000 units of new housing, plus the moderate rehabilitation of occupied apartments through a variety of loan programs.
Its successes have relied on the past failure of privately owned multifamily housing. The abandonment wave of the 70's, set off by a rise in operating costs and mortgage-interest rates after a decade of stagnant rents in the 60's, set the stage for the current costly production programs. The city must hope to avoid a repetition of the cycle.

LENGTH: 577 words

HEADLINE: Grant Aids Laid-off Workers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
WORKERS at the troubled UNC Naval Products in Montville have welcomed a United States Labor Department grant to help their laid-off colleagues. But they say they need contracts, not job training.
The Labor Department announced a $1 million grant in Washington on Monday to help hundreds of workers laid off by UNC after the Navy canceled purchases of nuclear submarine reactors. 
The money, approved by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, will go toward on-the-job training or classroom and vocational training. The grant amounts to $2,650 for each worker, a figure based on the assumption that not all the laid-off workers will participate.
A UNC employee involved in an effort to save the company said that the grant was good news for the roughly 400 workers who have lost their jobs, but that it did not address the deeper problem of keeping UNC from closing its doors.
 
Shift to Single Contractor
''We're very glad to have it,'' said Bernie McKenna, a spokesman for Save Our State, a group of UNC workers lobbying for continued government contracts. ''But on the other hand, what it's doing is helping people who are out of work, and what we want to do is keep people at work.''
In March, the Navy announced that it wanted to rely on a single, Virginia-based contractor for providing nuclear submarine engines. Originally, the Navy preferred buying from two sources to promote competition. But with submarine construction expected to slow, the cost advantages of having two contractors diminished.
UNC announced after the Navy's decision that it would conduct monthly layoffs leading to the closing of its Montville plant on Jan. 1, 1993. A total of 1,135 workers will have lost their jobs by then, according to the Labor Department.
The main focus of effort by UNC executives, employees and members of the Congressional delegation has been working to avoid layoffs by securing business.
The president of UNC, R. Bruce Andrews, said the company is competing for work on an $8 billion supercollider project outside Dallas. Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, whose district includes Montville, has been lobbying the Bush Administration to lift a security ban barring UNC from exporting its submarine engines to friendly nations.
 
Possible Research Role
''I always prefer to see the Government taking a pro-active stance, rather than a reactive one,'' Mr. Gejdenson said. ''Now it's time for the Department of Energy to do the right thing and find new work for UNC's incredibly talented work force before it's too late.''
And Representative John Rowland, Republican of Waterbury, ''has been working with an entity in the Federal Government that may possibly have some work for UNC,'' said a spokesman for Mr. Rowland, David Boomer. ''We're making progress with them.'' UNC employees have said the discussions involve a possible role in the Strategic Defense Initiative that involves research for an anti-missile defense system.
UNC opened a job placement center last winter when layoffs began, and a mini-employment center was established at the plant for job interviews with potential new employers. UNC also has a tuition reimbursement program for current employees.
Because UNC's efforts have focused on professionals and technicians, the Labor Department grant program will be used for vocational and classroom instruction as well as on-the-job training. The Labor Department estimated a 72 percent placement rate.

LENGTH: 1792 words

HEADLINE: Technology Helps the Blind On the Job

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS technology spawns the production of higher-quality, less expensive computer, video and audio products, an increasing number of new tools are being made available to the blind and visually impaired that greatly widen their academic and career opportunities, experts say.
Recent advances in the development of artificial speech synthesizers, the use of optical scanning devices that recognize printed material and the increased presence of personal computers in homes, libraries and schools have all contributed to making otherwise unavailable information accessible to the visually impaired.
The New Jersey Commission for the Blind and Visually Impaired, an 80-year-old state agency based in Newark, is actively involved in monitoring the rapidly changing technology and providing assistance and training for the state's visually handicapped residents. Anthony LaGattuta, assistant regional commissioner for rehabilitation operations in the United States Department of Education, said the New Jersey agency attempted to provide ''the broadest number of services for the visually impaired, from the cradle to the grave.''
The commission's efforts are reflective of a growing awareness of the needs of the handicapped, as evidenced by state and Federal legislation guaranteeing ''barrier-free'' access to public buildings and barring discrimination against the handicapped in education and employment. 
''There has been a revolution in the rights of the handicapped,'' said Winnie Stites, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Human Services. ''And with it there has been a change in resolving many misconceptions about handicapped people over the last few years.''
In the past, Ms. Stites said, a physical handicap was perceived as something that could never be overcome. ''Now we have the resources to enable handicapped people to do the absolute maximum of what they are capable of doing,'' she said.
Gerard P. Boyle, acting director of the commission, said an estimated 70,000 state residents, many of them elderly, have serious visual impairments. For those who are working or in school, the opportunities for career and educational advancement are more plentiful than before.
''The computer field has opened up new horizons for blind people,'' he said. ''It's incredible. There are now blind people in this state in almost every occupation.''
In the past, Mr. Boyle said, the blind had to settle for repetitive, manually oriented jobs. Career opportunities for the visually impaired, if they existed at all, he said, were limited.
Although educational material and popular literature have long been available in Braille and on audiocassettes, the technical information and financial reports that are daily reading for management personnel had to be laboriously converted into a form that a visually impaired person could use.
One of the first products to make such material more easily available was the Navigator, a device manufactured by TeleSensory, a corporation in Mountain View, Calif. The unit, which is attached to a personal computer, provides a one-line tactile Braille display of what appears on the computer's screen.
But because the Braille display itself is essentially a mechanical device, the units are relatively expensive. A Navigator can cost as much as $4,000 without the computer. When these are combined with a printer that makes Braille copies, the complete system's price can be more than $10,000.
 
'Impossible to Keep Up'
But the prohibitive cost of owning such equipment, along with the sophistication of the equipment itself, is rapidly changing.
''There is so much technology out on the market right now, it is impossible to keep up with all of it,'' said John Dehmer, president of the New Jersey Council for the Blind, an advocacy group for the visually impaired.
But the existence of such equipment is not meaningful, Mr. Dehmer said, unless potential employers know of its usefulness and availability. The State Commission for the Blind, he said, attempts to fill that void.
The commission's Technical Aid Center is in Newark and supervised by Carolyn Rhodes, a 43-year-old Maplewood resident who has been blind since birth. The center attempts to educate employers about the expanding abilities of the visually impaired.
''We teach everything, from basic typing skills to how to do a spreadsheet in Lotus,'' Ms. Rhodes said.
The center, she said, is used for both skills training and product evaluation of high-tech devices for the blind.
Along with several Braille display units, the center also has optical character recognition devices, speech synthesizers, visual scanners and closed-circuit television units that can enlarge print by as much as 60 times for those with some residual vision.
The speech synthesizer, Ms. Rhodes said, is the most recent and most useful technological advancement for the visually impaired.
 
Converts Words Into Sounds
''It took me half an hour to do this using the voice synthesizer,'' Ms. Rhodes said, referring to a report she had just written for the commission. ''It would have taken me half a day to do the same thing using a volunteer to help me edit.''
The voice synthesizer consists of a program that is loaded into a personal computer, which then converts the letters and words that appear on the monitor into sounds.
The operator uses the computer keyboard or a separate keypad to send commands to the computer, telling it specifically what to convert to speech. Single letters, words, sentences or even entire documents can be reviewed auditorily. This eliminates the time-consuming and expensive process of producing Braille copies of the material for review and permits instantaneous editing and revision.
Speech synthesis has also made it possible for the blind and visually impaired to run complicated software like financial spreadsheet and word processing programs.
At first, Ms. Rhodes said, the artificial voice systems were often slow and inaccurate and had difficulty ''pronouncing'' technical words and homonyms. The newer systems, however, are about 95 percent accurate, and use phonetics and word context for deciding pronunciation, she said.
 
'Just Me and the Machine'
Solomon Haile Selassie Mekonnen, a blind 33-year-old Ethiopian with master's degrees in law and political science from Columbia University, recently visited the Technical Aid Center to evaluate equipment he needs for Christian missionary work he does for international students.
''This will help me edit and publish the mission's newsletter myself,'' he said. ''I can make a million corrections if I want, because it's just me and the machine.''
Without the computer, he said, he would need another person to read what he had written to insure that it was accurate. ''I just wish I had found this earlier,'' he said.
During his school years, he said, he would have to rely on other people to proofread his papers and to read non-Braille text for him. ''It was a nightmare,'' he said. But another new device spawned by the computer revolution has made even reading ''normal'' text possible for the blind.
 
Scanners and Computers
Optical scanners like the Xerox-Kurzweil Personal Reader can read books, magazines and even some newsprint, and then convert that information into speech, Braille or large print. The device is either an independent unit or a computer-based peripheral that is connected to a speech synthesizer, printer or video monitor.
Jay Leventhal, a resource specialist with the National Technology Center of the American Foundation for the Blind in Manhattan, said new optical scanning units had been introduced that worked through the personal computer itself and used the computer's speaker and monitor for output.
''That cuts the price from about $10,000 to $3,000,'' Mr. Leventhal said.
Braille printers are also coming down in price, he said. ''There have been a cluster in the $3,000 to $5,000 range,'' he said, ''but one just came on the market and it's around $1,300.''
But lower prices, he said, are no guarantee that everyone who can use such a machine can afford one.
''Unfortunately,'' he said, ''many visually impaired people are still unemployed.''
Ms. Rhodes agrees. She said that finding ''quality'' jobs for the blind sometimes required more than just training on sophisticated equipment. As a result, she said, the commission will sometimes contribute toward the purchase of necessary equipment if the prospective employer will ''meet the commission halfway.''
 
Seen as a 'Joint Venture'
''If a company hires someone as a word processor, it would at least have to provide that person with a computer,'' she said. So if a prospective employer is willing to provide some of the basic equipment, and if the client has a specific need and no resources of his or her own, the commission will sometimes purchase the necessary equipment, she said. ''We see it as a joint venture,'' Ms. Rhodes said. But the main impediment that the blind face in obtaining satisfactory employment, experts say, is not necessarily training or economics; it is society's perception of the ability of the blind to function in a sighted world.
Changing that perception, said Leslie Ryan, a teacher with the commission for 15 years, can occur only as the visually impaired themselves minimize their limitations and accentuate their abilities, and that, she said, begins in infancy. Ms. Ryan, who this year was named a Teacher of the Year by the commission, has clients as young as 6 months old.
 
Can Be Socially Isolated
Too often, she said, visually impaired children are socially isolated and understimulated, even by well-intentioned parents. But a child's earliest years often determine that child's future self-image.
The sooner small children are encouraged to move about in the world, to take risks and to make use of whatever residual vision they may have, she said, the better they are later able to function when they begin school and attempt to socialize with sighted children.
And once a child is in school, she said, the commission will supply the child's family with whatever equipment and support necessary to insure the child's success.
One device that the commission provides for young children, she said, is a closed-circuit television that enlarges printed material so that a child with some residual vision can learn to read. As the units become smaller and less expensive, they become easier to use and more readily available.
''We deliver the machines, we set them up and we train the child on them,'' Ms. Ryan said. ''We take advantage of every resource that's available to us. We want to give these children every opportunity to be the best that they can possibly be.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; Carolyn Rhodes, supervisor of the Technical Aid Center in Newark, helping Solomon Haile Selassie Mekonnen to familiarize himself with a computer equipped with a Braille display unit (Photographs by William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

LENGTH: 802 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Annual Camden Show Offers a Lively Selection of 44 Works

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
THIS city looks better than it did 10 years ago, but not as prosperous as it appears in William Hoffman's painting of it - one of 44 works that are now on view in the Stedman Gallery on the Rutgers-Camden campus.
The show is titled ''Ninth Annual City of Camden Art Exhibition, and it was juried by David Ahlsted, a painter who teaches at Stockton State College, and by Alison Weld, formerly the curator-director of the Robeson Center Gallery at Rutgers-Newark and now assistant curator at the State Museum in Trenton.
Getting back to Mr. Hoffman's canvas, it is an impressionistic bird's-eye view that centers on Camden's City Hall skyscraper and takes in the surrounding buildings and trees. But it doesn't reach far enough to encompass the blocks of small battered houses that lack even a candy store for consolation. ''It's a hard time with so many unemployed,'' commented a resident who could have been one of them. 
But then the view also seems to omit Rutgers, which is a serene enclave of brick buildings and trees with the sky blue Benjamin Franklin Bridge for a backdrop.
Even so, it was no surprise to find that only one of the show's 40 artists comes from Camden and that more than half of them are from Pennsylvania, mostly Philadelphia. Perhaps as a result of this, the selection, though lively, is less charged than would be its equivalent drawn from the other end of the state.
There are some exceptions, however. One of them is Esther Rose Fisher's ''Toxicity No. 3,'' a large gray monotype where clouds like boulders dribble blackness over a vaguely defined urban landscape.
Another is R. L. Washington's ''Point of View,'' an interior with lurid yellow walls and a floor of bare wood beams. On a sofa sit three black youths, two of them engrossed in the television to their left, one deep in a book. Keeping them company from the floor is a large, fluffy yellow cat with an extremely pink nose. The scene is crudely painted by an untrained hand, but the action, such as it is, is beautifully observed; so are the personalities, the cat's included.
It is a smart jury that can spot R. L. Washington and remain open to the virtuosity of Gilbert Lewis's gouache portrait of a boy, theatrically illuminated by artificial light. Presumably, Mr. Lewis gets help from photographs, but in this case not enough to interfere with his color, which is radiant, especially in the treatment of the subject's eyes.
Other good but pastily colored examples of realism include a still life of paper bags, a milk carton and assorted breads and pastries by Jeffrey Filbert (the one contender from Camden) and Phyllis Laver's study of a man leaning on a desk.
Figuration otherwise runs from the trendy - Karen Smith's giant variation on a cup outlined in black and modeled in various reds - to the stylized and idiosyncratic. In this category are a vivid beach scene, crammed with bathers under a sun that is a flaming disk, by Jack Gerber; Laura Bockno's nighttime view of a huge man's head and one shoulder highlighted in yellow against a lake bordered by a cliff with buildings on it; a study of a child playing with crayons and paper in a doorway by Marlene Baron-Summers, and Lauren Holden's Precisionist composition of buildings lying low beside pylons tethered with wires.
Compared with these works, Elizabeth Heller's ''Nightfall: Manayunk,'' an ink and pastel drawing that suggests a citadel with trees, seems positively abstract.
The best of the abstractions is Rita Simienski-Smith's large untitled watercolor of angular and ribbony shapes on a gray ground blotched with black and gold that harmonizes nicely with the texture of the gallery's aggregate walls. The design and its quiet colors, meanwhile, recall Gladys Nilsson's compositions of weird personages.
Installed in a Plexiglas case, Annette Tannenbaum's assemblage of beads, sequins and camp memorabilia is punkily titled ''I'm Gonna Be Bad/Guns-n-Roses,'' but it seems like a sparse Alfonso Ossorio. Apropos similarities, Jackie Morfesis's large black-and-white drawing of a nestlike shape with an aureole of smudged gray hangs opposite Ken Hohing's black-and-white photograph of an actual bird's nest containing tinted eggs and superimposed on a sky filled with clouds.
A photographer in color, Clarence Guienze, focuses on what appears to be a glass jar containing a champagne-colored candle. Bisecting the mass is a vertical of light that, with the help of some well-maneuvered shadows, turns the pot and its contents into a female torso.
The show's one sculpture is Ted Warchal's modeled relief of a small shelf bearing a few unidentifiable objects and neatly titled ''Shelf Life.''
The show runs through July 21. The gallery, on Third Street off Cooper Street, is open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday through Saturday.

GRAPHIC: Photo; ''Portrait: December'' by Gilbert Lewis in the ''Ninth Annual City of Camden Art Exhibition.'' (Stedman Art Gallery)

HEADLINE: Emergency Room Remains Open

 BODY:
As I read your article ''Community Hospitals Adapt to Changes'' (May 27), I found it to be quite enjoyable and unfortunately accurate in describing the financial plight of most of New York States' community hospitals. There is a real financial crisis in the hospital industry due to reimbursement patterns of Medicaid, Medicare and third-party payers.

I am hoping that some of our summer vacation residents will not be misled by your statement. Our Emergency Room is indeed Alive and Well, operating 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.

HEADLINE: Business Says Enough Is Enough

 BODY:
Re: ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us'' (May 27).
I wonder who the ''Us'' are that Richard Amper refers to. Is it the unemployed electrician, or the former engineer turned salesman? Or is it the young computer technician who is leaving my employ to move to North Carolina? Or is it my middle-aged neighbor who is moving to Florida? 
The topic of idle conversation I hear repeated more often these days is focused on moving away. Somehow in my conversations with all these people the issue of pine barrens or drinking water didn't surface. In fact, their main concern was economic. Are these people part of Mr. Amper's ''Us''?
The fine points that Mike LoGrande made were that we are tampering with Long Island's economy. We are in a severe economic crisis - and the sooner we face up to it the better. No one is arguing about turning back the clock on environmental concerns; what is being voiced by the business community is that enough is enough.
Mr. Amper's lawsuit isn't unique - it is a continuation of a decade of private and public policy on Long Island that has led us to the brink of economic disaster.
Exclusionary zoning and anti-development attitudes and policies such as Mr. Amper's have disenfranchised our youngsters, and many others, by making it impossible for them to stay here. By cutting off the entry level buyer we have thrown the entire marketplace into a tailspin - and the loss of these young people has put a severe crimp on the resources that enable Long Island business to grow.
History tells us to beware of those who create a scapegoat to further their message. Mr. Amper tells Long Island that ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us.'' Yes Mr. Amper, the building industry is hurting, but you know what all of us on Long Island are hurting. What about ''you'' and your groups? Aren't ''you'' part of ''US?''
 
JEROLD L. AXELROD
Architect
 Commack
