HEADLINE: State Is Disappointed By Gambling Revenues

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
GAMBLING revenues for the 1990 fiscal year, which ended last week, were disappointing, state officials said. But they expressed hope that several changes in the state lottery would increase the state's take this year.
''What I'm trying to do is get the lottery back to its basics,'' said Gregory P. Ziemak, lottery unit chief for the State Division of Special Revenues. ''The message I'm trying to get across is it's fun to play and fun to win.''
But Mr. Ziemak acknowledged that the state might be nearing the saturation point in lottery sales, and the operators of private parimutuel centers - including those that offer off-track betting, greyhound races and jai alai - are facing an even tougher time this year, with increased competition from the lottery, more people traveling to Atlantic City's casinos and the possibility of two casinos opening on Indian reservations in Connecticut. 
Operators of the parimutuels have asked the legislature for relief, in the form of video slot machines, which they claim would boost both their revenues and the amount that they turn over to the state.
''The parimutuels need the video slots,'' said Patrick J. Sullivan, a lobbyist for the state's three jai alai frontons. ''If you're going to a jai alai fronton to gamble anyway, why shouldn't the state help out the parimutuels and itself by giving them that opportunity?''
 
Decline in Revenues
Legalized gambling came to Connecticut in the form of the lottery in 1972. Today, in addition to 2,550 computer terminals that sell daily and lotto numbers, there are 14 storefront off-track betting centers, 3 jai alai frontons, a greyhound racetrack, and a theater in New Haven where bets can be placed on televised horse races. Another theater for simulcast races is under construction in Windsor Locks.
But gaming revenues transferred to the state general fund declined to $260 million in the 1989 fiscal year from $265 million in 1988. Though the books have not been closed on 1990, another drop is likely because of the problems of the parimutuels. State officials said 50 percent of the gaming revenue comes from the lottery, 20 percent from off-track betting and the rest from the other parimutuel operations.
Jai alai was hit by a strike in April 1988 that is still not over, though 70 percent of the players have returned to work. But the picket lines have affected attendance, said Buddy Berenson, owner of the Hartford fronton.
Mr. Berenson said that business at his fronton had been relatively flat compared with 1989. At the Plainfield dog track, business was reported down by 14 to 18 percent, and there there was no strike.
''There are a lot of other factors at work besides the strike,'' Mr. Berenson said.
More troubling are the weak economy and an Indian bingo hall that opened in Ledyard and attracted many high-stakes players, he said.
''And the major problem is the lottery keeps getting bigger and bigger, and there are only so many dollars in the gambling pocket,'' Mr. Berenson said.
 
Buses to Casinos
Mr. Sullivan said Connecticut gaming establishments also estimated that $400 million to $500 million a year is wagered by state residents in Atlantic City casinos.
''There are 300-plus busloads a day going down there from Connecticut in the summer,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
Mr. Berenson said the parimutuels are particularly disturbed by the prospect of two casinos opening in Connecticut. The Mashantucket Pequot Indians have applied to open a casino in Ledyard next to their bingo hall, and a tribe in Colchester has hired a Meriden contractor to build and operate a casino there.
Those casinos would pay nothing to the state, Mr. Berenson said, while private parimutuels hand over tens of millions of dollars a year.
''Anyplace casinos have opened, parimutuels cannot survive,'' Mr. Berenson said. But he said that 80 percent of the people who go to casinos play slot machines. If frontons, dog tracks and off-track betting centers were allowed to operate slot machines, he said, they would be able to recapture much of the casino and bingo business.
''I think they're the only way to save the parimutuel industry in Connecticut,'' Mr. Berenson said. ''If we were given the video machines, we could at least defend ourselves. Otherwise, the state is going to lose an awful lot of revenue.''
Mr. Berenson said legislators sympathetic to the problem introduced a bill that would have allowed the video slots this year, but it was blocked by Gov. William A. O'Neill. Next year, Mr. O'Neill will be gone, the state will be facing an estimated budget shortfall of $400 million to $1 billion, and the legislators have promised to reintroduce the bill.
 
Reversing Drop in Lottery
Mr. Berenson said he expects no relief from the lottery, which is capturing the majority of money spent on gambling in Connecticut now.
''That's the state's prime source of revenue from gambling, and I would not expect them to cut back,'' Mr. Berenson said. ''I would like them to, but I don't expect it.''
The special revenue unit has taken a number of steps to reverse a decline in lottery sales, to $495 million in the 1989 fiscal year from $514 million in 1988.
The amount turned over to the treasury from lottery sales dropped to $219 million from $225 million over the same period.
In February, the state began offering two instant lottery games, up from one, and two weeks ago introduced a third. Mr. Ziemak said sales in instant tickets had increased by 30 percent over last year.
Massachusetts now sells more instant tickets than lotto tickets, Mr. Ziemak said, ''and while we're not in that league at the moment, there's a lot of room for growth in that game, and we intend to see some increases.''
The number of outlets for daily and lotto numbers has also risen, to 2,550 today from 1,950 three years ago. The change to a field of 44 numbers from a field of 40 for the lotto game decreased the chance of winning but increased the size of the jackpots. Four of the top 10 jackpots have come since the change last October.
''The key to higher lotto sales is higher jackpots,'' Mr. Ziemak said. At the same time the payout was increased to about 53 percent of the ''handle'' from 50 percent.
 
More but Less
A spokesman for special revenues, Edward Harrigan, said the changes had apparently stopped the decline in lottery sales. Estimates are that the games turned over a record $228 million to the treasury for the 1990 fiscal year.
''We're talking about money that was made, and on that basis it was the best year we've ever had,'' Mr. Harrigan said.
The revenues unit actually estimated earlier in the year that it would turn over almost $234 million to the treasury.
''Six million dollars is a lot of money,'' Mr. Harrigan said. ''But when you're up that high, in the hundreds of millions of dollars, that's pretty close.''
But the state's budget depended on even more, said State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., Democrat of New London, chairman of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee.
Mr. Cibes said the budget for 1990 anticipated changes in the lottery games would increase the state's gaming take from the $270 million predicted by the Office of Fiscal Analysis to as much as $290 million.
A bill giving the state and local police more money for drug education and enforcement was passed on those predictions, Mr. Cibes said.
''Fortunately, we did not tie the drug bill to special revenues, as had been proposed,'' Mr. Cibes said. ''In the end, we took the money out of the general fund.''
Mr. Ziemak also said there are questions about how long the state can sustain increases in its gaming take.
''When you're a mature lottery state, such as we are, there is a point of diminishing returns,'' Mr. Ziemak said. ''I think we are approaching the time when we have to consider whether we need more outlets for the lottery, and how many.''
Studies to determine whether the state has saturated the market with lottery sales outlets are under way, he said, but it is difficult to determine saturation because the number of stores in the state, the population, and the number of outlets are constantly changing.
''We're definitely not at a point where we're losing money on any of our terminals,'' Mr. Ziemak said. ''But we have to use common sense about expansion.''

PUB-DATE: July 9, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 2256 words

HEADLINE: Americans' Support for Israel: Solid, but Not the Rock It Was

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAGINAW, Mich.

 BODY:
Like many Americans, Donald Power long counted himself an admirer of Israel. A Federal labor mediator who lives here in Saginaw, he marveled at the courage and spirit of the small nation, a fledgling democracy so imperiled yet so determined to survive.
But in recent years, Mr. Power says, his regard for Israel has waned. He has come, increasingly, to see the Middle Eastern nation as arrogant and even oppressive in the way it has handled the protests by Palestinians on the West Bank and how it has dealt with its Arab neighbors.
''I don't think they deserve all the support and the aid we give them,'' Mr. Power said. ''Maybe it's time to say, 'We're tired, we're poor, we have our own people without homes.' '' 
 
An Erosion Is Detected
Mr. Power's concerns are not unusual; they are reflected in a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken last month and in discussions with Americans in many cities in recent weeks. And these soundings all show some erosion in Americans' regard for Israel, a keystone of the special relationship that country has enjoyed with Washington since its founding in 1948. There is still an enduring core of support for Israel, especially when considered in relation to its Arab neighbors, but Americans no longer side strongly with Israel against the Palestinians within its borders.
The majority of Americans who say they favor sustained financial and military aid to Israel has been reduced, and a growing minority now advocates more sympathy for the concerns of Palestinians inside Israel.
Supporters of Israel in Congress and among Jewish organizations acknowledge that Israel's backing within the United States is not as deep as it once was, reflecting a tangle of factors, like Israel's role in putting down protests on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip, and the perception that Israel is no longer so strategically important, given the fading of the Soviet threat.
Foreign aid decisions by Congress do not always follow every twist in popular opinion, and influential pro-Israel lobbying groups have helped to shore up official support for Israel despite the changes in public mood. The House of Representatives, for example, voted overwhelmingly last month to keep aid to Israel at current levels, estimated to be nearly $4 billion annually.
David A. Harris, the director of the Office of Government and International Affairs for the American Jewish Committee in Washington, said some of the slippage was, perhaps, predictable. ''We created a mythical image for Israel that neither Israel, despite all of its remarkable achievements, nor any other nation could ever live up to,'' he said.
Some Jewish groups also argue that erosion in support is only temporary, mirroring, among other things, what they describe as unfair reporting that depicts Israel as the villain on the West Bank. ''There is a cause to be watchful,'' said Stanley B. Horowitz, president and chief professional officer of the United Jewish Appeal. ''But the values which we share with Israel are so strong, I am not deeply worried. Support for Israel will shoot up again.''
 
Why Some Still Back Israel to the Hilt
According to the results of the Times/CBS News Poll, conducted by telephone June 5 to 8 among 1,084 people, 61 percent advocated sustaining or increasing levels of aid to Israel. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. In a Washington Post/ ABC News Poll in 1989, 72 percent favored keeping aid at or above the same level.
This continuing, though diminished, majority support was reflected in the view of Elmer G. Daniels, a Jewish businessman interviewed in suburban Baltimore. ''I would do virtually anything to assist Israel,'' Mr. Daniels said. ''It is the only democracy in the region, and the only country that has been, without equivocation, an ally of the U.S., representing our interests there.''
But 47 percent of those questioned in the Times/CBS News Poll, say they now support giving the Palestinians a homeland in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, a proposal that the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir opposes. In a 1988 Los Angeles Times poll, 40 percent favored a Palestinian homeland.
The slippage in United States opinion is even more dramatic when it comes to internal or domestic turmoil in Israel. In a 1988 Times/CBS News Poll, when asked whether the United States should be more sympathetic to the concerns of Palestinians in Israel, the American public said no by a 2-to-1 ratio, but in last month's poll American public opinion was split.
When it comes to Israel's external security, however, Americans continue to favor Israel over its Arab neighbors by a wide margin: 40 percent in the latest poll say they are more in sympathy with Israel, while 19 percent say they are more in sympathy with the Arab nations. But even that is a reduced advantage compared with past surveys. The Roper Organization, asking the same question, showed as high as a 5-to-1 advantage for Israel in the 1970's.
Despite the growing willingness to show sympathy toward the Palestinians, however, many of those interviewed said they still harbored sharp suspicions, particularly about Yasir Arafat and some of the Arab leaders.
Gene Mossner, a lawyer in Saginaw, said he regarded the Israeli Government as stubborn and intractable, but he did not trust the Palestinian leadership either. ''My sympathy is toward the people, but I am not sure about Arafat or many of the others,'' he said. ''There are no moderates on either side.''
 
Rumbles of Change In Politicians' Ears
These shifts in public opinion have not gone unnoticed in Congress. Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the second-ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said that, while Americans still support a close relationship with Israel, ''there is a more of a doubt, in some areas, a resentment, of our high levels of assistance of Israel.''
Israel is the most obvious target of those broadly opposed to foreign aid, he said, because it receives more help than any other country.
''I don't think there is a seismic change,'' Mr. Hamilton said. ''But none the less, there are clearly changes taking place both within the American Jewish commuity and the public in general.''
In April, the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, provoked a sharp debate when he said his colleagues should be willing to consider cuts in American aid to Israel.
Mr. Dole said at the time that some of his fellow senators are privately as critical of Israeli policy as he is. ''I know people, and I know they won't say it out loud,'' he said. ''But they'll grab you in the cloakroom and tell you: 'You're right. I can't say it because I'm running,' or 'When I've been here as long as you have, I'll be able to say it.' ''
In part, the volatility in American public opinion toward Israel reflects the more turbulent relations between the Israeli Government and the Bush Administration, which has taken a more adversarial role in trying to fashion a Middle East settlement.
In Saginaw, Dr. Senen L. R. Asuan, a physician from the Philippines, said he shared the frustration of the Bush Administration. ''Israel has behaved like a spoiled child,'' he said. ''It could ask anything under the sun and Uncle Sam would give it the money.''
Thomas Murphy, a production worker from Garfield, N.J., said he once was a strong backer of Israel. ''But they aren't the little boy on the block anymore who need our help,'' Mr. Murphy said. ''They have the right to exist, but not to expand their borders. Just as the Arabs once threatened to push them into the sea, now they are trying to push the Arabs off their land.''
Charles Victor McTeer, a civil rights lawyer from Greenville, Miss., says the United States ought not to give so much support to a Government that refuses to negotiate with its adversary. ''It's easy for me, as a black American, to make a leap between Israel and the Palestinians on the West Bank, and South Africa and its black majority,'' Mr. McTeer said. ''At least the South Africans are talking.''
 
Shifts Around Globe Alter Views in U.S.
Behind the ambivalent mood is a flood of contradictory images that come out of Israel itself these days: Israeli soldiers firing on young Palestinian protesters on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip; armed guerillas from an extremist Palestinian faction mounting an unsuccessful speedboat assault on crowded holiday beaches; the sharp and sometimes angry political divisions within Israel itself over what should be done with the occupied territories.
But more and more, America's changing opinions about Israel are also being shaped by events far beyond Middle East. For some, the end of the cold war and the fading of the Soviet threat has raised doubts about the need to subsidize Israel, and other foreign clients, to the degree America has in the past.
There are those who argue that money ought to be spent inside the United States. ''You are asking a country that is broke right today, billions of dollars broke, to bail out these foreign governments,'' said Chet Latty, a bricklayer in Saginaw. ''How can we think of channeling money into Africa and East Germany and Israel?''
Toni Christian, a postal worker in Towson, Md., had a similar response: ''I definitely think we should give Israel less money because of economic problems in the United States.''
Some pro-Israel groups say such views reflect a kind of nascent isolationism among Americans. ''There is a growing preoccupation with domestic issues at the expense of overseas concerns, driven largely by the perception of a waning external threat to U.S. security from the Soviet Union,'' said Mr. Harris of the American Jewish Committee.
He described American public opinion as being too impatient with the complicated details and nuances of Middle East politics. ''We often find ourselves having to confront simple and ultimately false analogies that attempt to compare, for example, South Africa with the Middle East, or Nelson Mandela with Yasir Arafat,'' Mr. Harris said.
Mr. Harris said pro-Israel groups need to stress that American strategic interests remain at risk in much of the third world. ''In a perverse way, Saddam Hussein in Iraq has reminded all of us of the kinds of serious threats that still endure in the Middle East,'' he said.
 
Optimism Is Linked To Appeal's Success
Mr. Horowitz of the United Jewish Appeal said that, despite disagreements over Israeli policies among Jews and non-Jews, there is still strong support for Israel demonstrated by the willingness of Jewish donors and others to contribute money on Israel's behalf.
The most telling measure of this, he said, is the United Jewish Appeal's current giving campaing, which he said will raise more than $1 billion, a record, that will go to help resettle Soviet Jews in Israel.
As polls taken by the American Jewish Committee, among others, have shown, there is tension among Jews about Israeli policy. Glenn Nudell, a student at Towson State University near Baltimore, said he favored reducing aid to Israel. He said he questions the mentality ''that the Palestinians are evil and the Jews are good.''
''I'm Jewish, and I don't think the Palestinians are evil,'' Mr. Nudell said. ''I think Shamir and the rightist Government have got it all wrong.''
Among some Jews who were interviewed, the notion that public support for Israel had declined raised what they described as the troubling specter of anti-Semitism. ''I think there are people who, in their hearts, do not want the Jewish state to survive,'' said Seymour Attman, the owner of Attman's Delicatessen in Pikesville, Md. ''I think it has something to do with anti-Semitism.''
But Darren M. Margolis, another student at Towson State, said he thought Americans simply expected too much from Israel. ''It is not fair,'' he said, ''that we are trying to hold up Israel to a standard which applies to no other country.''
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted from June 5 to June 8 with 1,084 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were choses so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in eighter direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reportes are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results. The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduct other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TO SEND PEOPLE, NOT CASH, TO ASSIST SOVIETS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 8

 BODY:
President Bush plans to tell the United States' six main industrial allies this week that he is prepared to send teams of experts to the Soviet Union to help it rebuild rail and communications networks, grain storage sites, food distribution systems and other essential services, senior White House officials said today.
Disclosing this on the eve of the three-day economic summit meeting here of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial countries, the White House officials emphasized that Mr. Bush continued to oppose a move for large financial aid to the Soviet Union, as proposed by West Germany and France.
Mr. Bush's view is that the allies should agree in principle to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev bring about economic changes in the Soviet Union, but that each should act individually.
 
'Different Political Imperatives'
''Each country has different political imperatives,'' one official said. ''The President is happy to have each one help the Soviet Union in complementary ways.'' 
Whatever their differences, a top American official said today, the leaders were determined to avoid a shouting match over Soviet assistance. The leaders do not want to increase pressure on Mr. Gorbachev because the news from the Communist Party Congress in Moscow last week convinced them that the Soviet leader was even weaker politically than they had thought.
Consequently, aid to the Soviet Union is likely to take a back seat to other matters when this first post-cold war economic summit meeting opens here on Monday, officials from the United States, Japan, Britain, West Germany, Italy, France and Canada said.
 
Contrast With London Meeting
President Bush will find himself at odds with the leaders of the industrial allies on central points involving international trade and protection of the environment, and this could set off some fireworks. As a result, the tone may be in sharp contrast with the NATO meeting in London last week, where the allied leaders basically adopted the course Mr. Bush charted for military policy and East-West relations.
Here, the President seems likely to fail in what his aides describe as his primary mission - to persuade the other countries to abolish or at least limit their farm subsidies.
Mr. Bush maintains that worldwide economic growth depends on the successful completion of the current round of trade talks and that those talks are doomed unless agriculture policies in the industrial countries are changed.
And Mr. Bush is, as a Canadian diplomat here said, ''all alone'' in his reluctance to adopt an international strategy for dealing with global warming.
On aid to the Soviet Union, Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman, said Mr. Bush did plan to discuss with the other leaders the letter he received from Mr. Gorbachev last week requesting economic assistance from the allies. The letter was seen by top diplomats as underscoring Mr. Gorbachev's political difficulties.
Mr. Fitzwater said the letter repeated topics raised in discussions Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev had in Washington this spring and did not ''raise any new issues or requests.''
The leaders understand that they have different domestic political needs when it comes to dealing with the Soviet Union, the officials said.
For his part, Mr. Bush wants to avoid the fire from the right wing of the Republican Party that he would surely receive if he asked for money for the Soviet Union when that country was continuing to aid Cuba. On the other hand, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who has pledged more than $3 billion to the Soviet Union, is eager for Soviet acquiescence in a unified Germany's membership in NATO.
 
Special Paris-Moscow Link
And President Francois Mitterrand of France wants to build a special relationship between Paris and Moscow.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada opposes direct financial assistance to the Soviet Union, but he broke slightly with the United States today by saying that Canada might support some forms of credit for Moscow.
Neither the agriculture nor the environment issue is likely to be settled here this week. ''Detailed and complicated negotiations cannot take place at summits,'' said Henry R. Nau, a professor at George Washington University, who was Ronald Reagan's personal representative at several summit meetings in the early 1980's.
But the three days of talks will focus such attention on the disagreements that Mr. Bush, the host of the meeting, will be hard pressed to maintain the harmony of London.
The leaders of the Group of Seven nations began arriving here over the weekend.
 
Sessions With Each Leader
In addition to group meetings and dinners, President Bush plans to hold one-on-one sessions with each of the leaders. He met Saturday with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and today with Mr. Mulroney.
The group has been meeting once a year since 1975, when the main topic was the explosion of worldwide oil prices. As world economic problems have changed over the years, so have the topics of the meetings.
Administration officials say President Bush wants international trade to be the main emphasis of the Houston meeting. ''From the President's point of view, there is nothing more important than the Uruguay Round,'' said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, speaking of the current trade liberalization talks that began in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986 and are scheduled to wind up in December.
If the industrial countries do not lift their farm subsidies, the Administration fears, many developing countries will abandon the trade talks. Agricultural products are their main contribution to the world's markets. The result, American officials say, could be a breakdown of the free trade system. The allies, according to this view, might then divide into protectionist blocs, and the consequence would be to stifle world economic growth.
The European Community sets high tariffs on meat, fruits, vegetables and feed grains, subsidizes exports to make them more competitive overseas and gives generous support payments to farmers. Japan prohibits the importation of rice and keeps its domestic rice prices at many times the world market price.
 
Potent Political Force
Farmers in those countries are a potent political force. There are 10 million farmers in the European Community countries compared with two million in the United States, although the entire population in Europe is only slightly larger.
The United States and Canada, where farming is the most efficient in the world, are prepared to lift their trade restrictions, officials say, if the other countries go along. But a senior official of the European Community said he did not expect any concessions on this point.
 
Japanese Loans to China
TOKYO, Monday, July 9 (Reuters) - Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said today that Japan would unfreeze loans to China some time after this week's summit of industrialized democracies in Houston.
Kyodo News Agency quoted Mr. Sakamoto as telling a news conference here, ''I think loans to China will be resumed on Japan's own decision, in good time, after the Houston summit.''

HEADLINE: 2/ Loaf Is Family Heartbreak in Egypt

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, July 7

 BODY:
In a tangled part of town called Boulaq, all narrow streets and gimcrack homes and children beyond counting, a man called Hamid told a story the other day that said much about the problems confronting President Hosni Mubarak in the Arab world's most populous nation.
A year ago, Hamid said, there were two kinds of bread on the market, one costing the equivalent of 0.8 United States cents a loaf, the other - a newly introduced and supposedly higher-quality product - costing the equivalent of 2 cents. The authorities, who set the bread prices, slowly withdrew the cheaper variety.
For the Government, the change was just one step in trying to cope with the troubles facing a people growing in numbers faster than the land or the economy can sustain - poverty, debt, inflation and a persistent challenge from Islamic fundamentalists.
For Hamid, the extra 1.2 cents a loaf had an impact far beyond what one might think. Each family member usually gets one of the flat, dish-like loaves with each meal, so the bread expense for a family of six more than doubled, to the equivalent of $10 a month. This is a quarter of Hamid's income. 
Add the other basics - sugar for the tea, coffee, cooking oil, beans and vegetables - and together they might cost the rest of one family member's salary. Only on special days, Hamid said, would there be delights like fish or meat at a dollar or two a pound.
 
Deepening Economic Crisis
''If you are earning in a month only the same as an American spends on one meal, then you realize what our problems are and why small amounts matter,'' said Hamid.
His story reflected a much wider malaise. Since President Mubarak came to power in October 1981, when Islamic fundamentalists assassinated President Anwar el-Sadat, Egypt has confronted a deepening economic crisis that has brought soaring prices and unpredictable shortages to a fast-growing population that now exceeds 55 million.
The population grows by a million every eight months, according to estimates - an expansion that adds to the troubles whose roots spread through Egypt's recent history.
In the 1950's and 1960's, President Gamal Abdel Nasser, the charismatic champion of Arab nationalism, nationalized many enterprises and implanted a heavily bureaucratized, centralized economy whose clumsy paternalism still deadens individual initiative.
 
Dependence on U.S. Aid
Mr. Sadat opened up the economy, diverting money into individual pockets, but did little to fundamentally reorganize the economic system. Since then, falling prices for petroleum have meant less direct revenue from Egypt's relatively small oil industry, and also less demand in major oil-producing Arab countries for Egyptian teachers, engineers and other workers.
The remittances from people working abroad, along with Suez Canal transit fees, tourism and the oil exports provide almost all of Egypt's hard currency.
Then came a new problem related to Cairo's dependence on $2.1 billion to $2.3 billion a year in American aid. Of the total, $1.3 billion is set aside for military assistance and the rest is economic aid.
The package was intended to cement Egypt's peace with Israel and reward Cairo. But as the Egyptian armed forces switched from Soviet to American weapons, Cairo ran up debts in excess of $4.5 billion. Countries that do not pay the interest on military loans forfeit all United States assistance.
This year, about $600 million in interest on the military debt comes due. So, to meet the obligation and to qualify for further United States aid, the cash-strapped authorities must divert funds from other debt payments.
 
Strain of Loan Payments
With equal desperation, the Government is trying to stretch its income of $6 billion to finance imports that cost $10 billion and include more than half the country's food.
Egypt's overall foreign debt is more than $50 billion, and the crisis means that Cairo is reneging on commitments to other countries as it seeks to meet its military obligation to the United States.
''Aid from other donors is being largely suspended due to the failure by Egypt to repay loans due,'' the Western economist said. That is where the spiral tightens further.
Like many other third-world countries, Egypt has no option but to look to the International Monetary Fund, which demands market-oriented economic changes in return for its imprimatur on new credits. But the ambiguous offer of free-market salvation, in turn, implies further living cost increases and risks of unrest.
Mr. Mubarak, seeking to cast himself as the people's champion, has called the I.M.F. a ''quack doctor'' and ''the Fund of Misery.'' But in his annual May Day speech, he said, ''There is no way out and we will have to endure.''
He exhorted the Egyptians to be more productive.
The appeal inspired a newspaper cartoonist to depict an animated idle factory telling a couple with too many children that Egyptians had the wrong idea of what ''productivity'' meant.
The I.M.F.'s terms for an economic package mean higher prices because they gnaw away the state subsidies on bread and other necessities that have formed a kind of social-welfare system since President Nasser's time.
 
Fear of Food Riots
In the quest for book-balancing changes acceptable to the I.M.F., the authorities have already cut some subsidies on sugar, kerosene, bottled gas, gasoline, cigarettes and rice - and, by stealth, bread. The cost of living has increased between a quarter and a third over the last year, according to Western figures, while wages have not.
''Always at the back of the Government's mind,'' an Egyptian economist said, explaining the authorities' reluctance to meet the I.M.F. terms, ''are the food price riots of 1977,'' when cuts in subsidies provoked major disorder.
In a recent interview in The New Yorker, Mr. Mubarak spoke of his plight. ''I could make big headlines by removing the subsidies on bread, and a loaf of bread would double in price,'' he said. ''You know what would happen? It would make hell in the country. This is the nature of Egypt.''
The comment acknowledged the political challenge from Islamic movements, whose faith is the faith of the bulk of the population.
''The Muslim Brotherhood is an Islamic solution for all the people of the country, a political solution,'' said Seif el-Islam Hassan el-Banna, a prominent Muslim Brotherhood activist and son of the organization's founder. ''What we say is: 'There is an alternative to what's happening now. Islam is the solution.' ''
Mr. Mubarak's words also suggested the special status of bread in Egypt, and the central role it plays as much in the Government's thinking as on the tables of people like Hamid. Wheat From the U.S. The flat, hollow loaves of bread are the very core of most Egyptians' diet. The seven million tons of wheat consumed by the country each year puts it among the world's biggest per capita consumers of wheat. But Egypt grows only a fraction of the wheat it consumes. More than half of it comes from the United States, and between a third and a quarter of that is financed by concessionary aid programs.
It is symptomatic of the skewed economy that wheat prices for the consumer are kept low but corn prices are not. So people find it cheaper to feed their chickens with wheat or bread than with corn.
The Government has been negotiating with the I.M.F. for almost three years without clear results, reflecting its concerns about the repercussions of removing the subsidies that shelter Hamid and Abdel Aziz and millions of others from higher prices.
 
Life Is Getting Harder
''The last year has been particularly tough for the man in the street,'' said Galal Amin, an economist at the American University in Cairo. ''The rate of inflation is really unprecedented and they are feeling it more than ever.''
Meanwhile, he warned, there is continuous growth in ''the conspicuous wealth of a small number of people.''
''All the Egyptians I know work in two places and if the day was longer than 24 hours, they would look for a third job,'' said Amer Abdel Hamid, a 32-year-old college graduate who earns about $50 a month from his job in state-run radio, and up to $350 as an after-hours freelance writer. He is not the only one to improvise.
''A year ago you paid a little baksheesh to avoid a parking ticket,'' a professor said, using the Egyptian term that denotes something less than a bribe and something more than a tip. ''Now you pay a little baksheesh to park legally.''

HEADLINE: Greece and U.S. Sign 8-Year Pact Exchanging Arms Aid for Extended Use of Bases

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 8

 BODY:
Greece's new Conservative Government and the United States signed an eight-year agreement here today providing Greece with more than $1 billion worth of arms in return for the continued operation of American military bases in this country.
Greece, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, will also get $350 million in military credits in the first year of the accord, starting October 1990.
The Greek Foreign Minister, Antonis Samaras, who signed the agreement in the presence of the visiting American Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, said the accord put an end to troubled relations between the two countries and inaugurated a ''new era of national reason in our relations with the United States.''
But the Socialist Party of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and the Communists charged that the accord made Greece subservient to United States global interests. 
 
Greece's Rights 'Safeguarded'
The accord supplants a five-year bases agreement signed in 1983 by Mr. Papandreou's Socialist Government, which expired in December 1988. Mr. Samaras said the Greek Government had ''unshakable faith in the fact that our sovereign rights have been safeguarded, our national interests improved and the economic benefits multiplied.''
The agreement was signed only three months after the Conservatives were voted into office, succeeding successive weak coalition governments that emerged from inconclusive elections last year after the scandal-racked Papandreou Government lost power. The speed with which the Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis struck the deal contrasted with the 17 rounds of inconclusive talks held previously between Washington and Mr. Papandreou's Government. Mr. Papandreou often used threats to close the bases to fan nationalist fervor and stir popular support.
The accord is subject to approval by the 300-member Greek Parliament, where the Conservatives hold a bare majority of 151 seats.
Mr. Samaras said the accord represented the fulfillment of the new administration's three-tiered foreign policy program. He described the three goals as improving relations with the European Community, beginning procedures toward the settlement of the dispute with Turkey over Cyprus and opening a ''new era of national reason'' with Washington.
Mr. Cheney said, ''This document provides a firm foundation for continuing our bilateral defense relationship on mutually acceptable and beneficial terms and will contribute to the strength of NATO.''
 
U.S. Keeping 2 Crete Bases
Under the accord, the United States is to keep two large bases on the southern Mediterranean island of Crete, which is strategically close to Libya and the Middle East in general. They are the naval and air base at Souda Bay, which is large enough to accommodate the entire Mediterranean Sixth Fleet, and the communications base at Gournes, Herakleion. Washington will also maintain a series of other communications relay installations in four parts of Greece, and the right to conduct certain back-up military activities elsewhere in the country, subject to approval by the Greek Government.
Two other bases in the Athens area, the Hellenikon air base and the communications bases at Nea Makri, are to be shut down this year as part of Washington's earlier decision to reduce its military presence in Europe due to developments in Eastern Europe. A number of other, smaller military installations will also close down. But the aircraft and installations for reconnaisance flights conducted from Athens will now be transferred to Crete, Mr. Samaras said.
Under the accord Washington is to provide Greece with 28 Phantom F-4E fighter aircraft, 28 A-7 Corsair long-distance fighter-bombers, 6 P-3A support aircraft and 4 guided-missile-carrying destroyers of the Charles F. Adams class. Mr. Samaras said this material, worth more than $1 billion, would came from stocks made available through reductions in America's arsenal of conventional weapons. He said Greece henceforth would be included among those countries to receive such equipment regularly. The United States also wrote off a $50 million military debt owed by Greece.
The Greek Foreign Minister also said the accord included two new provisions vital for Greek interests. The first, he said, was a commitment by the United States to ''actively participate'' in efforts to prevent an attack against Greek territory or to resolve the crisis should such an attack occur. The second, he said, was a commitment to provide military supplies, much of it at no cost, at levels that would maintain the 7-to-10 ratio of American military aid to Greece and Turkey, respectively. Turkey is also a member of NATO. Both provisions have long been sought by Greece, which fears an attack from Turkey of the sort that led to the 1974 Turkish invasion and continuing occupation of northern Cyprus. But the accord does not mention Turkey by name.
 
No Tilt, U.S. Says
WASHINGTON, July 8 (Special to The New York Times) - A State Department official said today that the agreement with Greece was not intended to alarm Turkey and ''does not represent a change of policy or tilt.''
''The Turks will have to speak for themselves on this, but we have assured them that the agreement is not aimed at any third country,'' said the official, who asked to remain unidentified.
He said that Congress would be notified of the executive agreement, but that it did not require Congressional approval.

HEADLINE: A Better Neighbor Policy

 BODY:
Revolution is sweeping Latin America and Washington, sensibly, wants to encourage it. For too long, Washington has subordinated vital hemispheric concerns to ideological contests in Central America. President Bush's new economic program for the Americas signals a positive shift in priorities that can benefit Americans from Point Barrow to Tierra del Fuego.
Mr. Bush's comprehensive package includes trade, investment, debt and environmental programs. It builds constructively on existing elements, like the Brady debt relief plan and debt-for-nature swaps in Bolivia and Costa Rica. Right now, it's only words; but the words go in precisely the right direction. 
Latin America already is being transformed by changes almost as far-reaching as those convulsing Eastern Europe. Generals have been replaced by elected democrats. Statist economies are yielding to freer markets. National budgets are being pried loose from the grip of politically entrenched oligarchs, opening the fiscal space needed to check inflation, improve public services and encourage private development.
But Latin reformers, like those in Eastern Europe, must overcome a legacy of economic insularity, environmental devastation, capital scarcity and foreign debt. Leaders like Carlos Salinas in Mexico, Fernando Collor in Brazil and Carlos Menem in Argentina know that the antidote to dependency is not some new form of international welfare. But what they and Mr. Bush recognize is that a temporary infusion of outside support is urgently needed to support wrenching transitions. Here's some of what Mr. Bush proposes: Trade. A generation of flawed development policies and a decade of debt crisis have cost Latin America its fair share of expanded world trade. Mr. Bush correctly prescribes wider trade patterns and lower tariffs.
Yet the rhetorical centerpiece of his package, a hemispheric free trade zone, is of doubtful merit. Global free trade, not competing regional trade blocs, is the most effective way to expand international commerce. But Mr. Bush recognizes that a hemispheric market is a distant vision, at best. And his proposals for the present are just right: freer admission of Latin American products to the U.S. and support for Latin positions in world trade talks.
The key trade issues are agricultural. Grain exporters like Argentina are victims of Europe's protectionism. Sugar growers like the Dominican Republic suffer from U.S. quotas. And U.S. duties against cut flowers hurt Colombia's efforts to wean its economy from dependence on drugs.
Investment. Years of economic mismanagement have encouraged the flight of Latin American domestic savings into foreign banks. And a decade of debt crisis and recession has cut off much of the region from new foreign investment. Mr. Bush proposes that the U.S., Europe and Japan each contribute $100 million a year to a new regional investment fund. He also proposes new investment lending by the Inter-American Development Bank.
Only countries pursuing economic reform would qualify. And the idea is to provide seed money and increase domestic confidence, not to replace private investment. Still, $300 million a year, spread over a continent and a half, seems not enough.
Debt. Diverting export earnings and tax revenues to debt service leaves little for domestic development and social needs. Mr. Bush proposes to expand the Brady debt reduction plan with new resources from the Inter-American Development Bank. He would break new ground by forgiving some debt owed directly to governments. And he would encourage more debt swaps at discounted prices. All are good ideas.
Environment. The land hunger of the rural poor and the reckless pursuit of industrialization have ravaged Latin America's forests, threatened plant and animal species and poisoned urban environments. The debt crisis itself provides a partial answer. Debt-for-nature swaps allow environmentally minded donors to multiply the effect of contributions by taking advantage of the deep debt discounts now prevailing in resale markets. Mr. Bush would encourage such swaps for debt owed to Washington.
By promoting Latin America's growth in these ways, the Bush plan reinforces U.S. prosperity and security. With the cold war over, it makes sense to reorient U.S. policy from fighting Communism to integrating Latin America's economy into the developed world. Some of the President's ideas need adjustment, and fuller funding. But his basic approach is sound.

HEADLINE: West Side Co-op Acts Under Law and Contract

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report that New York City housing officials have moved to take over a subsidized middle-income housing cooperative on Manhattan's Upper West Side (news article, June 27) is incomplete. What is not made clear is that when 303 West 66th Street was chartered under the Redevelopment Companies Law in 1959, both the statute and a contract with the city gave the cooperative the right to reconstitute as a Business Corporation Law (private) co-op after 25 years.
The 25-year period ended June 30, 1986, with the expiration of the city contract, and since then the Lincoln Guild Housing Corporation, owner of the cooperative, has attempted to claim its contractual and statutory rights. The State Attorney General first threw up delaying roadblocks. After we had cleared these, a very small group of dissident stockholders, aided and abetted by West Side special-interest groups, have used the courts and the city bureaucracy further to delay the reconstitution promised by statute and contract. 
All references to the ethics and morality of removing 303 from its status as a redevelopment company and of ''moral abuses, as opposed to legal abuses,'' cannot obscure the legal, ethical and moral abuses perpetrated by the Attorney General, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the dissidents and the courts in denying to the overwhelming majority of tenant-stockholders (about 90 percent, according to our surveys) their legal and contractual rights.
If the State Legislature and the city did not want us to exercise our rights to reconstitution, they should not have included the 25-year time limit. But, since they did, it seems a violation of free-enterprise and our economic rights to renege at this late date.
It may be of interest to note that the tax abatement on each apartment is a small fraction of the rent. Our low rent is the result of prudent management, significant voluntary service from stockholders and a paid-up mortgage.
 
SAMUEL WEINBAUM, President
Lincoln Guild Housing Corporation
 New York, June 28, 1990

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
The Hazy Future Of Trying to Plan For the Future

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Skeptics say strategic planning is for people you can't trust with the present.
But with New York City again facing an uncertain future, it's arguable whether officials consumed by real crises can be trusted to plan for potential ones.
Years of lobbying finally led to the creation of a modest Office of Strategic Planning within New York's Department of City Planning in 1988. Last week, it was scrapped for a savings of about $500,000 - largely a victim of unforeseen budget gaps. 
''We no longer exist,'' said the office's former director, Ben-Ami Friedman.
Five years ago, William J. Dean, the chairman of a coalition of civic, philanthropic and planning groups called the Civic Affairs Forum, warned that without strategic planning, ''the city will, at best, fall far short of its potential. At worst, it will be overwhelmed by market forces, outwitted by international and interregional and intermunicipal competition and be defenseless against its internal weaknesses - the inertia of 'business as usual' and the local politics of 'not in my backyard.' ''
Two years later, that warning was echoed by Mayor Edward I. Koch's Commission on the Year 2000, headed by Robert F. Wagner Jr. A strategic planning office was created late in 1988, but it only got going the following spring.
Beset by turf battles, it never achieved its potential. But it made a start. It identified 26 issues that needed to be addressed and singled out these seven:
* Finding markets for recycled materials that the city hopes to separate at the rate of 7,180 tons a day by 1994 and 11,000 tons a day by 1997, up from 1,430 tons a day this year.
* Expanding day-care centers, particulary for preschool children eligible for publicly funded programs, to help meet an existing shortage of about 200,000 spaces and to anticipate demand for up to 17,000 more generated by Federal job and training mandates for parents on welfare.
* Increasing home-care services for the frail elderly to meet a demand that is expected to rise from 53,000 cases in 1988 to 93,000 in 10 years.
* Bringing more unemployed black and Hispanic youths into the labor force.
* Expanding a volunteer corps to help teen-agers become self-reliant adults while peforming community service.
* Intervening earlier to deter juvenile delinquency and providing more alternative detention programs to reduce recidivism.
* Reducing solid waste, projected to grow from 27,000 tons a day two years ago to 31,000 tons a day in the year 2000.
Mr. Friedman's office dealt with the first priority in detail. A 12-agency task force explored potential markets for waste paper, plastics, textiles and metal cans and reported in March on how and where they could be recycled to produce jobs and tax revenue.
Three months later, the planning office itself was out of business - unbeknown to Mr. Dean, to Mr. Wagner and to Eric Lane, who was counsel to the Charter Revision Commission, which redefined the city's planning responsibilities. The charter requires the city's Planning Department to appoint a deputy executive director for strategic planning and to help the Mayor in preparing a quadrennial strategic policy statement, due in November; a biennial 10-year public works agenda, and an annual statement on economic and social indicators.
''I came here to do planning,'' says Richard L. Schaffer, who is chairman of the Planning Commission and directs the Planning Department, which, he said, includes a fresh look at strategic planning.
He recruited Sigurd Grava, director of Columbia University's urban planning program, to integrate the charter requirements in what Dr. Grava called ''a continuous activity that could be called strategic planning.'' However it is defined, Dr. Grava cautioned, ''it's what you make of it.''
Perhaps nobody could have anticipated problems like AIDS or crack. But pragmatic planners with their heads in the clouds and their feet on the ground might better prepare the city for a period of recurring budget crises. While New York is being revitalized by new immigrants, a new economic engine to drive the city out of its slump - like the financial services industry did a decade or so ago - has yet to be identified, much less encouraged.
Vision cannot be mandated. But Mr. Wagner and others express concern that the reconstituted commission will become so consumed with the processes of reviewing individual projects that it may lose sight of larger issues as the millenium approaches.
With 2000 only 10 years away, planning, itself, is facing an uncertain future.

HEADLINE: In the Zodiac Case, Still More Riddles Than Clues

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Four months after the gunman who calls himself the Zodiac shot his first victim, the largest police task force assembled in New York City since the Son of Sam murders is still baffled by the central riddle of the case: how the gunman knows the astrological signs of his victims.
Investigators believe that if they can learn how the Zodiac came to know the birth dates of the men he has stalked and shot, they will have found a trail to the killer. But as they have dug into the past of the victims, in particular the first three, the police have failed to come up with any common thread.
''That's the mystery,'' said Chief of Detectives Joseph R. Borrelli. ''That's what we are trying to unravel.'' 
The police believe the gunman obtained the victim's birth dates either in casual conversations long enough before the first three shootings for the victims to forget, or by somehow gaining access to personal information about them.
Since one wounded victim said the gunman fired and ran, Chief Borrelli said, investigators have ruled out the possibility that the Zodiac rifled their pockets for identification after shooting them.
Only the last victim - a homeless man shot in Central Park - has recalled being asked his birthday by a stranger.
Detectives have had the other victims scour their memories for anyone who might have asked their birth dates or been given that information. The list of possibilities is long - census takers, bank tellers and even clerks at video stores or other places where applications are filled out.
But no one figure has surfaced who has links to each of the first three victims.
Since March 8, the Zodiac gunman has shot four men, all at close range, all in the early morning hours on a Thursday.
The last three shootings have occurred 21 days apart, leading the police to believe the gunman may strike again this Thursday in the early morning hours, three weeks after the latest shooting.
The first three victims were shot in a nine-block radius in the East New York section of Brooklyn and neighboring Woodhaven, Queens. The shooting in Central Park, on June 21, came after the police flooded East New York with officers.
Three of the victims survived the attacks. One, a 78-year-old Brooklyn man, Joseph Proce, later died of his wounds.
Each of the victims had a different astrological sign. The gunman scrawled the symbols for the signs of his first three victims in a pie-shaped picture in a note found at the scene of the third shooting. The same diagram appeared on two letters sent to news organizations a week later.
 
No Order Is Seen
After the last shooting, a fourth astrological sign, corresponding to the fourth victim's birth date, was added to the circle in a note left nearby and in a letter sent the following day to The New York Post. The gunman has attacked, in order, a Scorpio, a Gemini, a Taurus and a Cancer, the police said.
Astrologers say the series represents no particular order of signs and does not correspond to the months in which the victims were shot.
A task force of more than 50 detectives based in a two-story brick building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard has culled through the more than 1,800 tips called into a Zodiac phone line and pursued those that seem promising, Chief Borrelli said. They have interviewed at least 36 people but dismissed all of them as possible suspects.
''We haven't gotten one suspect we're zeroing in on,'' Chief Borrelli said. ''So far we haven't been able to put anything together that ties the victims together.''
 
Many Theories
While little is known about the gunman, there has been a wealth of speculation about him by journalists, criminal psychologists and astrologers. One columnist, Mike McAlary of The Daily News, has theorized that the gunman is laying a map of the constellation Orion across the city to choose the sites of the shootings - the first three in a roughly straight line corresponding to Orion's belt, the Central Park shooting being roughly where Orion's club would be.
But Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown in a recent interview called such theories ''pure speculation.''
There have also been theories that the gunman identifies with the mythical hunter Orion, and that his first victim was a Scorpio because in mythology it was a giant scorpion that killed Orion. Some newspapers have consulted handwriting experts, who say their analyses of the gunman's scrawl - it slants different ways, T's are crossed low and many words are underlined - show that he fears failure and authority, was traumatized as a child, grew up in poverty and is desperate for attention. #2 Mangled Bullets The police have few pieces of hard evidence: the six cryptic letters written in ballpoint pen on a type of paper without a watermark, which is commonly used in New York schools, one partial fingerprint found on a letter at the last shooting that seems to have no match in state or Federal fingerprint files and two mangled bullets.
The gunman has preyed on vulnerable men. On March 8, Mario Orozco, a 50-year-old man who used a cane because of a congenital limp, was shot in the back at Atlantic and Sheridan Avenues. On March 29, Jermaine Montenesdro, a 34-year-old factory worker, was attacked at Nichols and Jamaica Avenues while walking drunkenly to his father's home. On May 31, Mr. Proce, who used a cane, was shot in front of his house on 87th Road in Woodhaven. The last victim, Larry Parham, a 30-year-old homeless man, was attacked while sleeping on a bench on Literary Walk in Central Park.
Detectives also have a vague description of the Zodiac from Mr. Proce, who before he died said the gunman was an unkempt black man in his 30's, about 6 feet tall and 180 pounds, with a mustache and beard. While the other victims have said they cannot identify their attacker, Mr. Parham has given a description of the man who asked him his birth date several hours before the shooting, the details of which matched Mr. Proce's.
Ballistics tests show that the two recovered bullets were fired from the same gun, which could be .380-caliber or 9-millimeter, which are nearly identical calibers, the police said. The soft-lead bullets, one recovered from Mr. Proce's stomach and the other from the bench Mr. Parham slept on, bore scratches that showed they came out of the same pistol barrel.
 
No Cartridges Found
But they did not have the diagonal rifling grooves that typically appear on bullets that have been fired. The police believe that the gunman either made the gun from a piece of pipe or filed down the spiral ridges in the gun barrel that give a bullet its spin and make the diagonal grooves.
In the other two cases, surgeons decided not to remove the bullets.
No cartridges were found at the shooting scenes, although most .380-caliber and 9-millimeter weapons are semiautomatics that eject spent shells after firing. The absence of cartridges supports the theory that the gun is homemade and fires a single round, ballistics experts said. Regular weapons spit out shells up to 10 feet away, experts said, and it would be hard for a man in a hurry to find them in the dark.
In a letter to The Post, the gunman said ''all shoot with a .380 RNL or 9 mm no grooves on bullets.''
The police believe ''RNL'' stands for ''round nose lead,'' a kind of bullet usually used for target practice. The recovered slugs are round nose lead bullets, the police said.
 
Probably a Copycat
A psychological profile of the killer prepared by detectives describes him as a loner desperate for attention who has little education, lives alone, is probably unemployed and probably lives in the neighborhood where the first three shootings took place.
Chief Borrelli said the gunman is believed to be getting his ideas from a 1986 book called ''Zodiac'' about the San Francisco Zodiac killer. Although that killer was never captured, Chief Borrelli said investigators think the New York gunman is not the same person.
The book, by Robert Graysmith, is a detailed account of a string of at least six murders committed in California in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Someone who said he was the killer sent letters to local newspapers claiming responsibility for 37 killings and taunting the police to catch him.
The letters included in the book began with a phrase similar to the one that begins the six letters in the New York case - ''This is the Zodiac.''
The New York gunman has claimed to be the man who terrorized San Francisco. In a letter to The Post, in which he also claimed responsibility for the June 21st shooting, he wrote: ''You are wrong . . . it is one of the same Zodiac one Zodiac.''
The letter contains a drawing of a hooded executioner with a cross-hairs diagram on his shirt. It is identical to a drawing in the book which has not been printed elsewhere, investigators said.
 
Not as Cruel
Candice Skrapec, a psychology professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who is an expert on serial killers, said the New York gunman may believe he is carrying on the unfinished work of the San Francisco killer.
But she said the New York gunman's psychological makeup is very different. The San Francisco Zodiac was sadistic, often torturing or sexually abusing his victims, sometimes using a knife, she said.
The New York gunman prefers to shoot vulnerable men from behind and then flee. Rather than cruelty, his motive seems to be ''a need for attention, a need to command our respect,'' Ms. Skrapec said.
Ms. Skrapec said the gunman may have a delusional obsession with astrology and may identify strongly with the figure of Orion, the hunter.
''He creates a scheme for himself that reflects these astrological motifs,'' said Ms. Skrapec. ''When we look at it, it may seem to be irrational; but for him it's probably charged with meaning.''
Mr. Graysmith said the New York gunman's twisted logic bears little similarity to that of the San Francisco killer, who usually killed his victims near bodies of water under a full moon. That Zodiac, who is believed to be white and an arms expert, did not choose his victims according to their astrological signs, Mr. Graysmith said.
Henry Weingarten, director of the New York Astrology Center, said the New York gunman seems to have only a cursory understanding of astrology. The gunman has not picked the times of his shootings according to an astrological pattern or attacked people with signs associated with the time of year.
''He's not a sophisticated astrologer,'' Mr. Weingarten said. ''He uses the signs the way a child would illustrate a grade school paper, with pretty pictures.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: New York Told To Base Raises On Job Needs

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
As New York City begins contract negotiations with its largest municipal union today, a civic group says it should end the pattern of roughly comparable raises for all unions, in favor of a two-year freeze for uniformed workers and substantial pay increases for jobs with a shortage of applicants.
The recommendations of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group financed largely by businesses in the city, would markedly alter the past practices of the city and its work force, most of whose contracts either expired last month or will expire by this fall.
Negotiating new settlements with employees from teachers to police officers is a major challenge for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who was elected last year with heavy union backing. In the face of a stagnant local economy and an uncertain future, the city budget, which was adopted July 1, assumes annual wage increases of 1.5 percent, a figure the unions have dismissed as unacceptable. 
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the budget commission, said the pending negotiations and the city's fiscal difficulties called for innovations - and average increases below the inflation rate.
 
Unions Oppose Wage Freeze
''This has been a closed system for a long time,'' he said. ''Some of the rules of the game ought to be changed, in our view.''
Richard A. Levine, the commission's chairman, said, ''It is time for municipal wage policy to address the problem that some employees are overpaid and others are underpaid.''
Among the positions that the commission said should perhaps receive higher-than-average raises were engineers, lawyers, computer analysts and health professionals. Wage increases for civilian jobs that are not hard to fill should be held to about 1.5 percent, the commission said.
But the heads of the major uniformed unions quickly denounced the idea of a wage freeze. Phil Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, called it ''totally unrealistic,'' while Edward Ostrowski, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said it showed an ''elitist, ivory-tower attitude.''
 
Cool Analysis but Hot Politics
Louis A. Sforza, president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, said, ''Once again, the Citizens Budget Commission is looking to balance the budget on the backs of working people.''
To be sure, the commission's report was animated by the cool utilitarian analysis that typifies its studies on such subjects, and senior city officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that some proposals were clearly politically unworkable. But they also said that some ideas, like giving extra rewards to workers who agree to productivity increases, or who could command much higher salaries in business, were intriguing.
District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest city employees union with 140,000 civilian members, begins negotiations today, and Mr. Dinkins is to go to union headquarters this morning for a ceremonial handshake of good faith.
Union officials said that that show of cordiality, after years of antagonism from the administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, augured well for the bargaining, although a spokesman for the local, Edward Handman, said a wage freeze and a 1.5 percent increase were unrealistic.
But Mr. Handman was more conciliatory on the notion of rewards for hard-to-fill jobs.
''They have put their finger on a sensitive point that is not adequately discussed,'' he said. ''The fact is that there are many jobs, in the professions particularly, that are not being addressed and the city is having trouble recruiting and retaining these people. So in principle that is correct. Such people have to start being compensated adequately to compete with a market that is taking them away.''
In recent years, contract settlements with the city's unions have also sometimes included ''equity funds,'' lumps of money to be distributed in varying amounts to workers in jobs with high turnover and vacancies.
Arguing for a freeze in uniformed workers' salaries, the budget commission noted that there are far more qualified applicants for each available post than can be hired. In recent Civil Service exams for entry-level jobs, for example, 84 people passed the test for sanitation worker for every one hired. The ratio was 37 to 1 for firefighters, 10 to 1 for police officers and 8 to 1 for correction officers.
 
Harder Negotiations Forecast
The commission acknowledged that freezing wages or granting increases below the rate of inflation would mean declining pay in real terms. But it said that salaries of most workers had risen significantly in real terms since 1983, putting them at adjusted income levels on a par with those at the onset of the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's.
With the city's fiscal condition again more precarious, the commission said, the city should restrict wage increases, even to less than the inflation rate in some cases, or even higher taxes and greater service cuts would be forced.
The commission acknowledged that adjusting raises based on particular positions would make negotations harder.
''To obtain the high quality work force the city deserves without wasting taxpayers' money, the next round of settlements should treat workers far more diversely than has been the practice in the past,'' its report said. ''This is more difficult than bargaining across-the-board increases, but it is essential for promoting efficient municipal government.''
Eric J. Schmertz, the city's labor relations commissioner, said in a statement that it was too early in the negotiating process to assess the commission's proposals.

HEADLINE: New Life for Hoboken's Ghost Waterfront? Vote to Decide

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Brick and steel, bit by bit, the 90-year-old piers built here by German steamship lines to last for ages are reluctantly coming down, opening this Hudson River waterfront to a future filled with uncertainty.
As huge jackhammers strain to undo the Germans' fastidiousness - these fireproof piers replaced earlier ones destroyed in a fire in 1900 - Hoboken residents prepare to vote tomorrow on what the waterfront and the city itself should become.
Hoboken's mayor and other city officials want the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to help build a huge new complex of offices, stores, apartments and a park that will reflect a sophisticated new urbanity.
On the other side, a coalition of city residents, who in a similar vote last year unsuccessfully tried to have the piers turned into a 30-acre park, oppose the Port Authority plan. They say they will accept development, but only on a small scale in keeping with the city's 19th-century streetscape. 
The vote comes less than two weeks after the announcement that another waterfront fixture, the Maxwell House coffee plant, the last major smokestack industry on the river's edge, will close in 18 months.
 
Drastic Change in the Offing
Whatever the voters decide, it is certain that this city's relationship to its waterfront, one that in many ways shaped Hoboken's character, is in for a drastic change.
''It's sad to see it go,'' Donald Barrett, a retired Hoboken longshoreman, said of the pier during a recent trip to watch a wrecker's ball bounce off the doomed waterfront buildings. ''While it was here, it was home. But I don't think it means that much to the city any more.''
Once the waterfront was a place of pungent sights and smells that flavored the entire community. Here the community merges with the waterfront. East-west streets lead directly to the river, people live across the street from the docks and a long ball hit at the Little League field can plop down close to Pier C. At first this closeness was a splendid advantage. When the city was settled, the river's edge served as a gentle docking place for the world's first steam ferry and for harried New Yorkers looking to wile away a hot summer's afternoon. It was under such conditions that the first baseball game was supposed to have been played on the Elysian Fields, just above the waterfront, in 1846. In 1861 the first commercial piers were built, and soon seamen, merchants and immigrants started to fill Hoboken's streets.
By 1917 prosperous Germans ran the waterfront and City Hall, and many public- school classes were taught in German.
Then World War I broke out, and the United States Government seized the piers and the huge German-built ships docked there. Fearing spies and saboteurs, the Government placed the entire city under martial law, and a few old residents still remember seeing soldiers marching up First Street toward the port. More than a million doughboys set sail from here, vowing as they left to be in ''heaven, hell or Hoboken'' by Christmas.
It was in the 1950's, when its piers, shipyards and gloomy factories were bustling, that the waterfront defined Hoboken as a rough-and-tumble working-class town, a port of call where streets echoed with a dozen languages and cultures.
So well developed was that persona that Hoboken was selected as the film set for ''On the Waterfront,'' which etched indelibly onto millions of minds what a waterfront looked and sounded like.
 
No Room to Expand
Thoroughly modernized by the Port Authority in the early 1950's, the Hoboken piers were undone by progress and the long steel boxes called containers in which nearly all overseas cargo is now transported. The containers are highly efficient but voracious in their need for space. Hoboken's early advantage turned into a drawback because there was no room to expand.
So in 1971 the cargo-handling companies simply picked up and left for Port Newark-Elizabeth, now one of the world's busiest container ports. Hoboken's piers have been silent since, a backlot movie prop.
The Port Authority, which has a long-term lease for use of the piers, has been interested in developing them for the last decade. The agency got legislation passed in both New York and New Jersey that allows it to get involved in such a project, but then it had to overcome deep community opposition.
Finally last year, thinking all challenges had been met, the agency prepared to sign a final agreement with the city when a group of advocates gathered enough signatures to have the contract put before a public referendum for approval.
 
Problems of Bigness Feared
''It's just too big,'' said Susan O'Kane, a member of the Coalition for a Better Waterfront, the citizen group opposed to the Port Authority contract. ''Hoboken is just a little 19th-century town with 25-foot-wide streets that can't possibly absorb the traffic generated by development.''
If the plan is defeated tomorrow, the city will have to begin negotiations all over again. But planning officials are optimistic that voters will approve it and that something can be done with the waterfront.
Peggy E. Thomas, director of Hoboken's Community Development Agency, says it is unfortunate that a whole era is passing, and she believes that Hoboken will never be as cohesive a community as it was before. Change is unavoidable, she said, but in some ways it will be change for the better. For 90 years a three-block-long brick warehouse on River Street - called the headhouse - has blocked people from reaching or even seeing the river.
''The headhouse connected the waterfront to the city through work,'' Ms. Thomas said. ''Taking it down will connect them in a different way.''
 
Adjustment to Change Predicted
Mayor Patrick Pasculli, a lifelong Hoboken resident, said the city had been hit hard by the loss of the working docks and by more recent losses, like Maxwell House, but would recover.
''Just as a fine actor is able to adjust to many different roles, the city of Hoboken is resilient and will adjust to its new role, whatever that may be,'' Mr. Pasculli said. If the Port Authority plan is voted, a few bollards and cleats from the old docks will be salvaged and reused, and a monument to the World War I embarkation will be set up in the new complex. Otherwise all the history on the waterfront will be erased.
In its place will be residential and commercial buildings, one 25 stories high. The plan includes a marina, a fishing pier and a tree-lined promenade, all designed to open up the river to the people, something that has not been possible on a large scale since the days of the original Elysian Fields.
 
Lure of the River
Of course, some people have always found their way down to the water. On a recent hot afternoon, about a dozen people were on the crumpled concrete deck of what used to be the Stevens Institute of Technology pier on Frank Sinatra Drive, below Castle Point. Some fished; one man caught a blue fish as long as his arm. Another had a cooler of beer strapped to his bicycle, to share with two friends.
Carlos Marti, a 33-year-old industrial presser, said he liked to go down to the river to relax. He watched the tugs and other boats pass by in the brown river, and in spite of overflowing garbage cans and all the dirt, he felt in the air a little bit of the freedom that open waters have always represented.
Mr. Marti said he did not know anything about the history of the waterfront or what it once meant to the city. He only knew that when it got hot enough to make asphalt streets mushy, the breeze remained cool on the river.
''They should put something here for the people to use,'' he said. ''We got no other place to go.''
