HEADLINE: $16 Billion Transportation Plan Proposed in Albany

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 6

 BODY:
A $16 billion program over the next 20 years to improve transportation in the Hudson Valley was proposed this week by a special task force of the State Department of Transportation.
It said that amount, and probably more, was needed to maintain and improve roads, bridges, mass transit resources and airports in the seven counties just north of New York City -Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange, Ulster, Dutchess and Columbia.
Calling the region the fastest growing in New York State, the task force forecast a travel increase of 68 percent by the year 2010, but noted that the existing transportation resources could not handle that growth. 
''Things are only going to get worse,'' said Russell W. Robbins, project manager for the draft plan, which was compiled at the department's regional office in Poughkeepsie. The plan is called ''21st Century Mobility: Moving People and Goods.''
 
Major Bottlenecks Already
Already, the plan said, the region is congested. It cited major bottlenecks in Westchester and Rockland Counties; lesser, although serious, congestion in Putnam, Orange and Dutchess Counties, and increasing problems in the more rural Ulster and Columbia Counties.
As the worst examples of road congestion, it cited Interstate 287 in Westchester and Rockland Counties, the Tappan Zee Bridge, Route 9 south of Poughkeepsie in Dutchess County and Route 211 east of Middletown in Orange County.
''The majority of traffic congestion is directly attributable to the limited capacity of the region's highways and Hudson River bridge crossings to meet the increased demands of single-occupancy motor vehicle traffic in the A.M. and P.M. peak commuter hours,'' the report said.
Mr. Robbins said that the plan recognized that building new roads was not possible. Instead, it proposed a three-point program to preserve the existing transportation system, to rebuild and widen major traffic arteries and to try to move more people on existing roads, bridges and mass transit systems by car-pooling, vans and trains. $3 Billion in Repairs ''Our first priority is to preserve and renew the present infrastructure,'' Mr. Robbins said.
That program is now under way, with money from the $3 billion 1988 Transportation Bond Issue causing temporary traffic dislocations on many of the region's major roads and bridges.
Although the draft plan estimated the cost for transportation improvements in the valley at a minimum of $16 billion over the next 20 years, ''The actual cost will be higher,'' the report said.
''This does not include operating needs, right of way or engineering and accounting for inflation,'' it said.
At a time of budget-cutting nationally and statewide, Mr. Robbins and other transportation experts conceded that such a large amount of money would not be available from either the Federal or state governments.
''Where are we going to find that money?'' said David Murray, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation. ''We simply do not know.''
Mr. Murray said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had ruled out another bond issue for transportation.
Mr. Robbins said one option was to increase the gasoline tax to provide dedicated money for transportation improvements. California recently voted a 9-cents-a-gallon tax for such purposes.
''Tax increases are obviously not popular,'' he said, ''but I think people are more receptive to new taxes if they can see the end results.''
The draft plan will be presented at public hearings in New Paltz on July 19 and in White Plains on July 24. After that, it will be modified, if necessary, Mr. Robbins said, and sent to the State Legislature and county legislatures.

HEADLINE: Zebra Mussel Threatens Economy and Ecology

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Julie Kuberka stood on the edge of the Hudson River here, pulling in a laundry line cord with a white plastic tile at its end. Her assistant, Jennifer Curnow, sealed the tile in a plastic freezer bag, ready to be sent back to a laboratory for analysis.
The two women were searching for clues to the whereabouts of the zebra mussel, a recent aquatic invader from Europe that is spreading rapidly into the waterways of New York State from the Great Lakes.
''No, we haven't found anything yet,'' Ms. Kuberka said, after inspecting the tile for traces of the shellfish, which has become one of the major environmental pests in New York. She put her gear into a station wagon, and left for another area of investigation along the Erie Canal. 
Despite the indication that the prolific but inedible shellfish has not yet reached the Hudson River, it has been found in five new locations in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River so far this year, according to the state's clearinghouse on zebra mussel information.
 
On the St. Lawrence River
''It went like wildfire,'' said Charles R. O'Neill Jr., a scientist at the clearinghouse, which is located at the State University College at Brockport. ''It is spreading faster than we thought.''
Mr. O'Neill said mussels had been found recently at Duluth at the western end of Lake Superior, the Snell and Eisenhower Locks on the St. Lawrence River, a cement plant dock in Kingston, Ontario, and the Bay of Quinte at the northeastern end of Lake Ontario.
Earlier, the mussel had been found throughout Lake Erie, off Green Bay in Lake Michigan, in the Niagara River, the Welland Canal and Lake Ontario.
Mr. O'Neill and David B. MacNeil have been collecting data on zebra mussels ever since they were first detected in the United States two years ago. They are members of the Sea Grant Institute, a state and Federal program that studies coastal water problems and runs the clearinghouse.
 
Loss of Business
They and other marine biologists and electric utility companies are worried about the spread of the mussel because of its potential for severe economic losses as well as ecological damage.
Huge clusters of the fast-growing shellfish can clog the pipes of power plants, drinking water systems and factories that take water from the lakes. The mussel also devours microscopic plants at the base of the food chain for fresh water fish, which could eventually kill off fish life.
According to a projection by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, the expanding mussel population could cost nearly $500 million a year in added expenses for public utilities, water companies and industrial centers and loss of business in sport fishing, marinas and motels along the inland waterways of the nation.
The zebra mussel, named because of its dark brown stripes on a light tannish shell, was first noticed in the United States in 1988 in Lake St. Clair, east of Detroit. Experts believe it arrived when ships traveling from Europe through the St. Lawrence River and the Great Lakes dumped their ballast water.
Without any natural enemies, the mussels attached themselves to the hulls of commercial and recreational boats, navigational buoys, docks, ladders, and plastic bottles as well as to intake pipes.
 
Constant Source of Food
Already a major environmental problem, the small bivalves have an affinity for water intake pipes, which afford a constant source of flowing water with food for them. They multiply in the pipes, clogging them. They and their larvae spread rapidly by hitchhiking in bilge water and on the underwater surfaces of boats.
One of its major methods of spreading is in or on recreational boats that are used in one body of water and then taken to another, Mr. O'Neill said. He cited a recent case of a sports boat in Lake Chautauqua, which had been transported overland from Lake Ontario, with several zebra mussels on its hull. ''I'd lay odds that the mussels will be found in the lake soon,'' he said.
To monitor the spread of the mussel, the state's electric power industry, through its Empire State Electric Energy Research Corporation, contracted with Acres International Corporation, a private company in Amherst, N.Y., to trace the advance of the musssel in New York.
 
Collecting Water Samples
Under that contract, Ms. Kuberka and Ms. Curnow visit 22 stations once a month collecting water samples from the Chemung, Mohawk, Susquehanna, Delaware and Hudson Rivers, the Erie Canal and the Finger Lakes.
''There's nothing we can identify as a zebra mussel yet, but we have to send our samples to a laboratory for analysis,'' Ms. Kuberka said, as she finished her work the other day at a Niagara Mohawk power station south of Albany.
But Mr. O'Neill and his colleagues at the state clearinghouse in Brockport are convinced that it is only a matter of time before the zebra mussel makes its way into all the major waterways of New York and neighboring states.
''I expect to see it soon in the Erie Canal,'' he said. ''Once in the canal, it is a threat to the Mohawk and Hudson Rivers as well as the Genesee and Oswego Rivers and other waters in the state.''

HEADLINE: Henry J. Kuss Jr., 67, Negotiator Of Billions in U.S. Weapons Sales

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Henry J. Kuss Jr., an international military consultant who was the Defense Department's chief arms salesman in the 1960's, died of cancer Friday at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va., a family spokesman said. He was 67 years old and lived in McLean, Va.
Mr. Kuss was often called the most successful arms salesman in history, filling foreign orders totaling $15 billion over seven years. But he was modest about his selling talents, providing this assessment in 1967:
''We literally don't have to do a thing. We haven't had to go out and promote a sale since we started. We just make it known that it's possible to buy. If a country says to us, they can buy an item cheaper in another part of the world, then we say, 'Go ahead and buy it.' We just tell them they'd better make sure it's really cheaper.'' 
Associates said Mr. Kuss was a skillful negotiator who was adept at marketing the standardization, high quality and lower unit costs of American equipment. In 1965, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara presented him with the Meritorious Civilian Service Medal for his ''unparalleled ability as a negotiator.''
 
Studied Needs of NATO
Mr. Kuss was in charge of arms sales from 1962 to 1969. He had ample preparation for those duties, as a weapons technician for the Navy and in carrying out major studies of the long-range military needs of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the Defense Department. He was a resolute cold warrior dedicated to containing the spread of Communism.
After leaving the Government in 1969, Mr. Kuss founded two international consulting concerns, the American Trade and Finance Company and Calcussearch Inc. In 1985, the two companies were merged into DGA International, with Mr. Kuss staying on as a general associate.
Henry John Kuss Jr. was born on Nov. 10, 1922, in the Astoria section of Queens. He studied economics and mathematics at Holy Cross and St. John's universities and was a supply officer in the Navy in World War II.
He was a former vice president of the Howard Hughes Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., a member of the McLean Citizens Association and a president of the Potomac Hills Citizens Association.
Surviving are his wife, Johanna; two daughters, Linda Musick, of Burke, Va., and Karen Childs, of Augusta, Ga.; two brothers, Russell, of Burke, and Richard, of Los Angeles, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
For Lawyers, Few Big-Fee Deals

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
The rate of growth at many leading law firms slowed considerably in 1989, but the legal business was nonetheless highly profitable, a study scheduled to be released today has found.
Lawyers at the nation's largest firms said the latest figures reflect an economic climate in which premium billings from Wall Street deals have become a rarity.
But that has been offset somewhat by the continuing growth of litigation and new business from large corporate bankruptcies and the expansion of deals overseas.
 
Change in Strategy
''Every firm that has had a mergers and acquisitions practice has seen some slowdown in growth,'' said William M. Friedrich, a partner at Shearman & Sterling, New York's second-largest law firm, and the fourth largest in revenues, with $281 million. ''But we, like a number of other firms, have a corporate workout group that is substantially busier.'' He added that a significant number of lawyers who had previously worked full time in corporate finance are now spending more time on helping financially troubled companies. 
The study of the 100 firms with the largest revenues was conducted by The American Lawyer, a trade publication. It calculated that the average revenues per lawyer at the 100 firms increased in 1989 by 6.3 percent, compared with a 13 percent gain in 1988.
Total revenues for the firms rose to $12.4 billion, from $10.6 billion a year earlier. The study also concludes that 49 firms had revenues of more than $100 million in 1989. A similar study conducted for 1988 found that 37 firms had revenues above $100 million.
The method of measuring profitability on a per-partner basis does not necessarily reflect how much the partners took home because in many instances it does not account for deductions for such purposes as firm equity, pension plans or charitable contributions.
The latest figures do not reflect the declining business in mergers and acquisitions this year, and appear somewhat more optimistic for 1989 at a significant number of firms that are on a cash basis of accounting.
Using this method, these firms recognized profits last year for deals that actually occurred in 1988. Some of the biggest corporate deals that arose in the last quarter of 1988 - including the $25 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco, the $13 billion acquisition by the Phillip Morris Companies of Kraft Inc. and the $5.7 billion purchase of the Pillsbury Company by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. -were largely billed in 1989.
The figures also do not accurately reflect the fourth quarter of 1989, a particularly slow period for Wall Street deals. Results from the quarter are expected to show up in legal billings for 1990.
''I was at a conference on legal management a few weeks ago and among the participants there was a considerable amount of gloom and doom about earnings,'' said Richard Pogue, managing partner at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, which with $320 million in revenues was ranked No. 3 in the study.
Mr. Pogue said that the flat economic growth generally had translated into less business for many law firms, adding that many in-house legal departments had been more aggressively trying to keep outside costs down.
Hardest hit by the Wall Street slowdown were the large New York firms, whose revenues per partner grew by 8.1 percent in 1989, after a gain of 15.1 percent a year earlier. The New York firms also suffered from a downturn in commercial real estate deals.
The Wall Street slump affects law firms in several ways. It means that they get less business from corporations that are interested in acquiring others and from those that are the targets of unsolicited bids. It also translates into less legal business from the investment houses, which in past years have provided a steady flow of business for many of the nation's most profitable law firms.
Changes in the market for high-yield ''junk bonds,'' in tax laws and in state takeover laws have made tender offers more difficult, and relatively high stock prices have made many companies too expensive to be attractive targets. Nonetheless, 9 of the 10 most profitable law firms in 1989 - measured on a per-partner basis - are based in New York, and most of them had large departments handling corporate mergers.
For 1989, like 1988, Cravath, Swaine & Moore had the highest profits per partner, at $1.76 million. Following were Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, at $1.59 million per partner; Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, at $1.51 million, and Sullivan & Cromwell, at $1.21 million.
Since then, Cahill, Gordon has lost its most lucrative client, Drexel, Burnham Lambert Inc., which earlier this year collapsed and had to file for bankruptcy protection. The investment firm is said to have accounted for more than a quarter of the firm's annual revenues. Cahill is now one of Drexel's many creditors.
The growing number of large and complex bankruptcies has provided steady, but less lucrative business for many law firms, causing several to strengthen their reorganization departments.
The latest sign of the growing popularity of reorganization work among large firms was seen last month in the announcement by Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler that it had acquired a prominent bankruptcy boutique, Levin & Weintraub, Crames & Edelman. Other major firms that have recently bolstered their reorganization practices include Willkie Farr & Gallagher of New York and O'Melveny & Myers of Los Angeles.
Another area of growth for legal business has been the savings and loan debacle, in which the Government is spending hundreds of millions of dollars retaining private law firms to augment its work. A number of firms are also profiting by representing collapsing savings and loans and their acquirers.
Among the firms that made significant advances in raising their average revenues per lawyer were Morgan, Lewis & Bockius of Philadelphia, Arnold & Porter of Washington, and Sidley & Austin of Chicago. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, New York's largest firm, continued to dominate the list of revenue earners, with $517 million in 1989, up from $440 million in 1988. The firm ranked fifth on the list of profits per partner, at almost $1.2 million. < In conducting the study, The American Lawyer said it solicited information from more than 120 law firms, and most of them cooperated. Whenever a firm would not disclose information, the magazine said, it made an ''informed estimate.'' The magazine warned of the ''increasingly troubling possibility'' that some firms that cooperated may have ''fudged the numbers upward.''
For the first time, the magazine also rated the firms by the amount of pro bono, or free public work, based upon the number of lawyers and the number of hours devoted for such service. None of the 10 firms with the strongest revenues received a rating better than ''good.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Chile and U.S. to Begin Talks on Freeing Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Chile, one of the lowest-tariff countries in Latin America, will open negotiations with Washington this week about establishing a free trade zone with the United States, Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley said Friday.
''Our national interest is to have access to expanded markets,'' he said at a news conference after two days of meetings with senior Bush Administration officials and the heads of international lending organizations.
Mr. Foxley, a former economics professor, is the first Latin American cabinet official to visit Washington since a June 27 initiative by President Bush that set as its goal a free trade system for all the Western Hemisphere. 
 
Working With Mexico
The United States already has free trade pacts with Israel and Canada, and last month, President Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari, Mexico's President, announced that his nation and the United States would begin work on a similar pact.
In addition to the offer to work toward trade without barriers, Mr. Bush said that as part of his initiative, the United States was prepared to forgive a substantial portion of the $12 billion that Latin American countries owe the United States Government.
He also announced plans for creation of a $300 million fund to encourage Latin nations to open their economies to foreign investment. The President pledged $100 million as the American share and said he would call on Japan and the European Community to contribute the other $200 million.
With relatively strong economic growth and low inflation, Chile, which has pursued free-market economic policies since the mid-1980's, can enter ''with sure footing'' into free trade agreements with the United States and other countries, Mr. Foxley stressed.
 
A Favored Country
Mr. Foxley was making his first visit to Washington since Chile's new democratic Government under President Patricio Aylwin took office on March 11. Bush economists cite Chile as one of their favorite countries.
The vist came as Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, and Argentina's President, Carlos Saul Menem, are developing their own plans for greater economic integration.
Argentina and Brazil are expected to sign at least 20 trade-related agreements during the current state visit by the Brazilian President to the Argentine capital.
Mr. Foxley said that he welcomed the moves by Chile's two neighbors. ''We believe that we will sooner or later converge on a Latin American integration scheme that may well be more closely related to the U.S. market than we have ever envisioned before,'' he told the news conference at the Chilean Embassy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Brazil Backing Computer Imports

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8

 BODY:
The office of an American multinational company here recently received a knock on the door of the sort dreaded by business executives across Brazil: it was the computer police.
''They went wild when they saw 'Made in Taiwan,' '' recalled the American representative of the company, who insisted that he be identified only by his first name, John. ''They threatened to call a van and take away our fax and our word processors.''
Such scenes may soon be a thing of the past as Brazil, the world's sixth largest computer market, drops tariffs and liberalizes its economy. To make Brazilian industry more competitive and to fight inflation by making goods less expensive, the new Government of President Fernando Collor de Mello plans to do away with protectionist legislation gradually. 
 
Booming PC Market
During the 1980's, such laws hindered joint ventures with foreign computer manufacturers, tightly restricted imports and made this booming personal computer market the largest in the third world and the lucrative preserve of domestic manufacturers.
''We are effectively very backward because of this senseless nationalism,'' Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the Economy Minister, said Tuesday about Brazil's computer restrictions. ''We will be more pragmatic in this area, more open to foreign capital, to imports and to joint ventures.
''The computer problem effectively blocked Brazilian industry from modernizing,'' Miss Cardoso told Brazilian reporters last week. ''It does not make any sense to retain this cyst, which is the computer market reserve.''
Next month, the Government is to send Congress a bill to phase out gradually the controls on imports and on joint ventures. But the domestic computer industry, which employs 60,000 people, is expected to ally with nationalist lawmakers to fight the opening of the market.
''We are opening in exchange for nothing,'' Fernando Gasparian, a Sao Paulo deputy, said Thursday. ''An opening could kill our computer industry.''
To date, the only concrete step by the Goverment occurred two weeks ago, when it removed a $960 million limit on 1990 computer imports. Last year, the 31 multinational computer companies here had revenues including imports of $1.5 billion. In contrast, Brazil's 324 domestic computer industry companies had revenues last year of $3.6 billion.
The law cost Brazilian consumers about $600 million a year because of higher domestic manufacturing costs, said Jose Goldemberg, Secretary of Science and Technology.
 
Lag in Competitiveness
The new Government, which took power on March 15, has also been spurred by studies that indicate that during the 1980's, Brazil's industry lagged behind many major nations of the third world in terms of competitiveness.
In the late 1980's, computer controls became the single largest trade dispute between Brazil and the United States. After investigating Brazil's Informatics Law for ''unfair trade practices,'' the Reagan Administration imposed punitive tariffs on a series of Brazilian exports in 1987.
The tariffs were lifted last week after Robert A. Mosbacher, the United States Commerce Secretary, visited here. Mr. Mosbacher praised Brazil's ''ambitious program of open markets.''
The mood these days is a far cry from that of 1984, when Brazil's Congress overwhelmingly voted to reserve the market for micro- and minicomputers for national manufacturers for eight years. Sovereignty and national security were the bywords of an odd, if effective, alliance forged among the military, left-wing nationalists and businesses seeking protection from international competition.
In 1986, Jose Sarney, then the President, declared computer restrictions ''fundamental for our survival as a sovereign nation.''
In this nationalist environment, the computer police - actually treasury agents - started zealously enforcing restrictions.
Last year, police seized 20 Apple and Macintosh computers from classrooms at the American School in Brasilia. In May, Federal police conducting an anti-hijacking search of passengers on the Rio-Sao Paulo air shuttle detained one man carrying a Japanese laptop. Last week, Federal police near Brazil's border with Argentina seized a van loaded with fax machines, computers, computer parts and televisions.
 
Incentives to Smuggle
The incentive to smuggle is great. In the United States, a facsimile machine can be bought for $600; its Brazilian-made equivalent costs $4,000. Brazilian personal computers, often made of pirated technology, generally cost double the international prices of their foreign equivalents.
After six years of limited access to the world computer revolution, Brazilian public opinion is increasingly skeptical about the high domestic prices and about Brazil's ability to match computer research and development going on overseas. Manoel F. Thompson Motta, vice president of the Brazilian Association for the Development of the Capital Goods Industry, complained in a speech two weeks ago about how Brazilian computers were ''excessively expensive and technologically out of date when compared to their foreign equivalents.''
''This factor blocks increased competitiveness of Brazilian products in the foreign market,'' Mr. Motta said.
 
Relaxed Regulations
Even without new legislation, growing complaints have forced greater flexibility from the Special Informatics Secretariat, a high court of computer affairs. In the last six months, the secretariat has allowed three American companies - the International Business Machines Corporation, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation - to enter into joint ventures with Brazilian manufacturers.
After a battle with the United States over the Microsoft Corporation's right to sell software here, a law went into effect in 1988 extending copyright protection to software. The Government is now discussing allowing foreign companies to distribute software here.
And in modern offices where secretaries look through door peepholes to check for computer inspectors, there is growing optimism.
''I think we are cooked on the fax, but we can keep the word processors,'' John said after the raid by the computer police. ''They are going around heavily this month because they know their time is running out.''

HEADLINE: Each Country's Agenda at the Economic Summit Meeting

 BODY:
UNITED STATES
A key aim of the Americans will be to persuade industrial parnters, especially the Europeans, to phase out trade-distorting farm subsidies and import quotas. The agricultural dispute threatens to scuttle the four-year-old Uruguay Round of negotiations to liberalize the world trading system under the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Bush Administration will oppose giving direct financial aid to Moscow, until there is geniune evidence of economic change in the Soviet union. The United States will also resist efforts to set a timetable for reducing emissionsof carbon dioxide and other gases. 
JAPAN
The Japanese will push for a resumption of loans and aid to China. Tokyo argues that continuing the economic sanctions against Beijing, which came after the massacre of striking students around Tiananmen Square last year, will only make the Chinese leadership increasingly isolated. Japan opposes direct aid to Moscow, because of the long-running territorial issue of four northern islands, which the Soviets have occupied since the last days of World War II. Tokyo will also try to resist dropping import curbs that protect its rice farmers.
WEST GERMANY
Financial support to the Soviet Union is at the top of the German agenda. It is pushing for a Western aid package for the faltering Soviet economy of up to $20 billion. Bonn hopes financial aid to the Soviets will ease Moscow's qualms about German political unification. On the environment, Bonn will press for curbs on emission sof carbon dioxide and other gases, along the lines of its commitment to reduce carbon dioxide emissions some 25 percent by 2005.
FRANCE
The French, like the Germans, will push for emergency aid to the Soviet Union. The Mitterrand Government is also seeking support from its industrial partners to offer debtr relief for a broad range of developing nations. The French will resist the American push to lower subsidies and import curbs that protect European farmers. And France will seek a new commitment on the environment urging reductions in emissions of carbon dioxide.
BRITAIN
The British expect the drive for a Western pledge of financial aid for the Soviet Union to be the key issue. Like the Americans, the British will resist. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher believes the West should first offer Moscow economic and technical advice on how to build a market economy before it gives President Mikhail S. Gorbachev money. Mrs. Thatcher has been somehwat subdued in international gatherings recently, partly because of her lagging popular support and economic difficulties at home, where inflation and interest rates are high.
ITALY
Italy is concerned that financing developing nations will suffer in the rush to help Eastern Europe. The Italians, like the French, will push for a commitment to new financing arrangements for less-developed nations, especially so-called middle-income developing countries. Rome does support aid for the Soviet Union, especially since Rome's trade ties with Moscow are expanding.
CANADA
On the key issue of assistance to the Soviet Union, Canada shares the cautious stance of the United States, Japan and Britain. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney will use the summit meeting to try to assure his industrial partners that the recent consitutional crisis over the status of Quebec will not cripple Canada and that its economy remains sound and attractive to foreign investment. Canada also supports the American initiative to deal with the farm-subsidy issue in an effort to further open up world trade.

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: Sandinista Protests Turn Violent; 4 Are Reported Killed in Managua

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 9

 BODY:
A faltering strike by Sandinista-led Government employees abruptly turned into a violent political showdown today as Sandinista workers and students built barricades and burned vehicles at major intersections throughout the capital, bringing it to a standstill.
Anti-Sandinista crowds, armed with sticks, machetes and firearms, reacted by attacking several workplaces occupied by the strikers, forcing riot police officers to intervene with clubs and tear gas. Hospitals reported that at least 4 men were killed by gunfire and that 42 people were injured in the violence.
In the course of the day, Sandinista-led workers expanded their shutdown of vital services, cutting off phone and power lines, occupying state-run radio and television stations, closing the national airport and border crossings, and blocking all major arteries in and out of the lakeside capital. 
 
Newspaper Is Blockaded
The major pro-Government newspaper, La Prensa, which is owned by the family of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, was surrounded by a crowd of armed Sandinista supporters, who prevented workers from entering. Outlying cities like Leon, in the north, were also paralyzed by Sandinista protests.
In an emergency address to the nation tonight, President Chamorro assailed the barricades as an ''unconstitutional subversion of public order'' and appealed for calm. She said she had ordered the army, which is still led by many Sandinistas, and the police to clear the streets of all obstacles.
But as Mrs. Chamorro spoke, strikers worked by the light of bonfires on blacked-out city streets to build new barricades, and there was no clear indication of how the Government, which broke off talks with the striking unions on Friday, intended to address what has now become the most serious crisis in its 10 weeks of power.
In a statement late today, the Sandinista leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, blamed Government economic policies for the strike and asserted that his party was making every effort to resolve the crisis. He accused ''extremist supporters'' of Mrs. Chamorro and warned against any Government attempts to break the strike.
''This conflict cannot be resolved by force,'' Mr. Ortega declared. ''Any such attempt would be an invitation to general chaos.''
 
Strikers' Demands Are Broad
In the past, the Government has shown itself willing to grant wage concessions to the striking Sandinista unions, but negotiations in the present strike have been made more difficult by the scope of the strikers' demands. These range from concessions on transportation fares to full participation in Government budgetary decisions. [In Washington, a State Department spokeswoman, Sandra McCarty, described the strike as politically motivated. ''Nicaragua desperately needs a breathing space to get economic reconstruction under way, but the Sandinistas appear determined not to allow that space,'' she said.
''They are putting their own political interests ahead of Nicaragua's recovery.''] Since defeating Mr. Ortega in elections on Feb. 25, Mrs. Chamorro has made conspicuous efforts to avoid an outright confrontation with the Sandinista leadership over political power. She has dealt gingerly with previous Sandinista job actions, and allowed a chief architect of Sandinista rule, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, Daniel's brother, to remain as her highest-ranking military officer.
But the Government has been kept off-balance by continued high inflation and economic crises, which have inflamed political tensions and drawn it into deepening conflict with Sandinista-led unions that dominate the Government work force.
The present strike, which has been publicly endorsed by former President Ortega and other senior Sandinista political leaders, is the second major work stoppage brought against Mrs. Chamorro's Government. The first, in mid-May, ended in broad Government concessions after a weeklong standoff in which public transportation, telephone service and other key Government sectors were paralyzed.
Although neither strike has appeared to enjoy wide public support, unhappiness over the inconvenience caused by the first walkout diminished the force of the present strike when it began in scattered ministries and Government-owned industries a week ago. That weak response is believed to have encouraged a firm stand by the Government, which declared the strike illegal and, on Friday, announced that public employees who did not return to work this morning would be subject to dismissal.
Reacting to that announcement, Sandinista workers and student groups began scattered protests over the weekend. On Sunday night, coordinated groups of armed men and women seized dozens of intersections and key traffic points throughout the city, setting fire to mounds of tires and building barricades to stop transportation.
 
Barricades Reminiscent of '79
This morning, smoke from the burning tires created a caustic haze at intersection after intersection where bands of well-organized Sandinista youths and workers were reinforcing the distinctive paving-stone barriers, which became famous during the 1979 Sandinista revolution against the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
The barricades are built from octagonal paving stones that were once made by a factory owned by the Somoza family, and have long been a symbol of Sandinista heroism. A drawing of such a barricade appears in the logotype of the official Sandinista party newspaper, Barricada, which is named in honor of the fortifications.
Consciously evoking images of the revolution, many strikers wore red-and-black Sandinista kerchiefs across their faces to hide their identities, and assembled makeshift collections of weapons, from pistols to knives to iron rods with grips fashioned from electrical tape.
 
Strikers Rigidly Organized
At most barricades, the strikers were rigidly organized, with leaders wearing armbands and demanding identification documents from approaching journalists and other outsiders, just as Sandinista guerrillas did when they were a clandestine insurgent force a decade ago.
They appeared to have provoked an almost immediate reaction from pro-Government Nicaraguans in many neighborhoods as anti-Sandinista crowds formed to assault and dismantle the roadblocks. Fighting was particularly heavy on the road to the Managua Airport, east of the capital, where at least one man was killed by gunfire. But in several areas, the anti-Sandinista crowd succeeded in removing the obstacles and repairing the roads.
At several points, riot troops were called in to separate the factions. The troops, trained and equipped under the Sandinista Government, appeared to obey orders and maintain rigid discipline. But in most cases they limited themselves to halting the violence, and appeared under orders not to intervene on one side or the other.

HEADLINE: THE HOUSTON SUMMIT;
U.S. PUSHES TO END FARMING SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 9

 BODY:
The leaders of the seven richest Western nations began their 16th annual summit conference in the tropical heat of Houston this afternoon, with an intractable dispute over trade policy threatening to disrupt the unity of the three-day meeting.
At an opening ceremony punctuated by the thunder of howitzers and a brassy chorus of national anthems, President Bush asserted that ''a new world of freedom lays before us'' and urged his summit partners to join him in insuring that it becomes ''a world where peace endures, where commerce has conscience and where all that seems possible is possible.''
But offstage the United States, supported by Canada, was fighting hard to break down European resistance to Mr. Bush's proposals for the eventual elimination of agricultural subsidies, which he sees as a major threat to free trade. 
The environment also proved a disruptive topic, one on which the United States appeared to be isolated. The Europeans accused the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, of blocking any effort for an accord on how to combat global warming. Only a year ago, in Paris, the environment was the dominant topic, but here it has been shoved from center stage. [Page A10.] On the issue of eliminating farm subsidies, American officials threatened that Washington would walk out of the current round of international trade negotiations, effectively bringing it to an end, unless the Europeans committed themselves here, in specific language in the communique to be issued at the end of the summit meeting, to negotiate in good faith on an agreed timetable.
According to key negotiators for three countries, the dispute led to the exchange of unusually bitter words between Mr. Bush and Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community, on Sunday night.
In discussing the elimination of farm subsidies, Mr. Sununu said: ''It is crucial. It is critical. It should and must be done now.''
Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter said of the European nations: ''They simply have not been engaged in the process. We cannot negotiate with ourselves.'' The subsidies make it difficult for food items produced cheaply in countries like the United States and Australia and in the third world to penetrate major markets.
 
'Farmers Would Go Bust'
Guy Legras, the director-general of agriculture of the European Community, said that Europeans were willing to negotiate, however much the Americans might insist that they were not. But he argued that any elimination of subsidies, however gradual, would create such price fluctuations that ''the farmers would go bust.''
Bill Brock, a former special trade representative in the Reagan administration who is here in an unofficial capacity, painted the direst picture, predicting that not only the United States but all the world's underdeveloped countries would walk out of the trade negotiations if farm subsidies were not ended ''because they have nothing else to sell but agricultural products.'' The result of such a walkout, he said, would be ''rampant protectionism and economic decline.''
The negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round, began more than four years ago in Punta del Este, Uruguay, under the auspices of the 105-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The next meeting is scheduled for Geneva on July 23, and the round is due to be completed during the first week in December at talks in Brussels.
Aid to the Soviet Union appeared to be receding as a potentially disruptive issue at the summit meeting, with Mr. Bush, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreeing in effect to disagree, and each country offering a different kind of aid for its own domestic political reasons without criticizing the other. Mr. Sununu, speaking at a pre-summit briefing earlier today, said the United States continued to oppose huge direct financial aid, like the $15 billion proposed by Mr. Kohl, but would favor sending teams of experts to work on such problems as grain storage, the banking structure, transportation and other items.
''The approach is one in which we understand that others may have a different sequence of decisions and timing of decisions to be made,'' Mr. Sununu said.
According to members of the Canadian delegation, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney suggested that the summit nations send a team to the Soviet Union to evaluate the scope of that nation's economic needs. Mr. Bush, whose aides have said he was eager to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in ways that would not involve sending direct aid, appears to have taken up the idea with some enthusiasm.
After a rodeo Sunday night, several meetings between pairs of leaders and other preliminary events, the summit conference began shortly after noon with the opening ceremonies. Mr. Kohl, Mr. Mitterrand and Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy arrived only this morning, Mr. Kohl and Mr. Andreotti having stayed in Rome for Sunday's World Cup final in which West Germany defeated Argentina by 1 to 0. Mr. Bush, the man of all sports, congratulated Mr. Kohl and informed the somewhat incredulous German that he had played intercollegiate soccer for Yale University in 1945.
 
First Meeting for Kaifu
The late arrivals, along with Mr. Delors, Mr. Mulroney, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, attending his first such meeting, were greeted by President Bush in the Academic Quadrangle at Rice University. The temperature was near 100 degrees as they stood on a covered platform in front of Lovett Hall, the Romanesque revival administration building designed by Ralph Adams Cram and built in 1912. Air conditioners had been built into the platform's floor to afford a measure of relief.
Mr. Bush, in his chattiest form, had a word or two in German for Chancellor Kohl and a phrase or two in French for President Mitterrand as they moved inside, into the building's Founders Room, for their first working session, which lasted about two hours. The leaders sat around a huge oval desk, wearing headphones for simultaneous translations.
After Mr. Bush outlined the main topics facing the conference, he urged his guests to speak their minds freely and frankly, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said. Those presentations occupied most of the session, the spokesman said, and ''demonstrated that there are differences, to be sure.''
 
Warning From Thatcher
Mrs. Thatcher was said by British officials to have been particularly pointed in warning against the emergence of three trade blocs - Europe, the Western Hemisphere and the Pacific - which, she warned, would be ''a step backward'' and ''politically stifling.''
Tonight, all the leaders attended a working dinner at Bayou Bend, once the home of a philanthropist, Ima Hogg, and now a museum of American decorative arts. The food, which included tortilla soup and grilled red snapper with basil lime sauce, was prepared by three of the region's premier chefs: Robert Del Grande of Cafe Annie and Robert McGrath of the Four Seasons Hotel, both in Houston, and Dean Fearing of the Mansion on Turtle Creek, in Dallas.
A senior member of the Italian delegation said that talk at the dinner, which was dominated by discussion of aid to the Soviet Union, had centered on a new proposal by the United States. Outlined by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the proposal sought to establish some common ground between the United States on one hand and France and West Germany on the other.
Negotiators for the seven nations went into session just before midnight to explore the possibilities of a compromise based on the Baker paper.
The United States had sought all day, in a series of public briefings and background conversations, to keep the pressure on the Europeans on the issue of agricultural subsidies. But by the end of the day, David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said there had been ''no progress in closing the gap.''
The most intransigent of the Europeans was said to be Mr. Kohl. On a continent with generally inefficient agriculture, the West Germans have the poorest agriculture. Small farms dependent upon subsidies are especially predominant in Bavaria, an area crucial to Mr. Kohl's electoral coalition. He faces elections on Dec. 2, just when the final meetings of the Uruguay round are due to be taking place in Brussels.
American officials took some pains to indicate that they were ''not naive enough,'' as one put it, to expect a detailed settlement here. But they said they needed a firm agreement on a timetable or Congressional pressure for protectionist legislation would soon resume.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that success in the trade talks would provide the world with ''an economic renaissance for the 21st century.'' Failure, she asserted, would mean that ''the world will have a dangerous decline in economic prosperity.''

HEADLINE: New York Is Reportedly Chosen For '92 Democratic Convention

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
The Democratic Party will hold its 1992 Presidential convention at Madison Square Garden, Democrats in New York and Washington said yesterday.
The Democratic chairman, Ronald H. Brown, has made the final selection between New York and New Orleans, the two remaining competitors, and is to announce his decision officially tomorrow, his spokeswoman, Ginny Terzanno, said.
Various officials said Mr. Brown had decided to take the party back to New York, his hometown and the site of the Democratic conventions that nominated the party's last President, Jimmy Carter, in 1976, and the last incumbent President to be defeated, Jimmy Carter, in 1980.
New York's quest for the convention was bolstered in the last few days by the Louisiana Legislature, which passed the strictest anti-abortion law in the country and set off protests from many Democrats against having the convention in New Orleans. 
Mr. Brown said in an interview a few days ago that the abortion dispute would be a factor in his decision. But many Democrats said they also felt that he had personally favored New York all along.
The decision was a victory for Mr. Brown's close friend Mayor David N. Dinkins, who lobbied vigorously for the convention. Mr. Dinkins had traveled to Indianapolis at one point to buttonhole party officials at a national meeting and sent a videotape on the joys of New York to every Democratic state chairman.
 
Celebration Set for Tomorrow
Mr. Dinkins also made great inroads with his argument that a convention in New York would be far more effective than one in New Orleans in raising money for the party.
City Hall officials said that they had not been officially notified of the decision, but that they were confident of the results. They are planning a celebration tomorrow for the announcement.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been invited to the celebration. But a mayoral aide said City Hall hoped that he would not attend, to avoid any impression that the New York convention might serve as a platform for whatever Presidential ambitions Mr. Cuomo may harbor.
Although the political effect of holding the convention in New York is difficult to predict two years in advance, city officials have not been shy about predicting its economic impact. Aides to Mr. Dinkins said the convention could mean $100 million in spending in the city, as well as adding gleam to its image.
''We're very, very happy,'' a vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Jack MacBean, said. ''It's not only a great prestige item for the city. The other conventions brought a great deal of publicity to New York City. At the last convention in 1980, the Texas delegation unfurled a banner that said, 'Texas Loves New York.'
''The publicity is of incalculable value. It focuses attention on New York City for months and even years to come. It's not necessarily the largest convention to come to New York City. But no other convention is covered extensively as this.''
Indeed, the main purpose of the modern political convention is to generate television coverage.
Although concerns have been expressed in both parties that New York would be a difficult place logistically to run a modern convention, Mr. Brown has repeatedly said he was confident that the Garden, far smaller than the Superdome in New Orleans, would be adequate for the crush of broadcasters and newspaper reporters, a group that has grown far larger than it was at the 1980 convention.
 
Negotiations on Dates
The city has promised to spend just over $20 million on construction at the Garden and on police protection outside, among other activities. Twenty thousand hotel rooms have been set aside for the convention.
The 1976 convention generated $20 million in economic activity and the 1980 convention $30 million, according to the Mayor's office. The 1984 convention in San Francisco generated $55 million and the 1988 meeting in Atlanta totaled $70 million.
The 1992 convention will be in mid-July. The exact dates depend in part on discussions about revising its basic format. The Democrats are considering cutting the convention to three days or holding it over the weekend, to counter complaints from the television networks that the convention does not deserve days of prime-time coverage.
Many Democrats have said they believed that from the outset Mr. Brown wanted to have the convention in New York as a gesture toward Mr. Dinkins, who as a district leader in Harlem was a friend of Mr. Brown and his late father, manager of the historic Hotel Theresa on 125th Street.
In the closing days of negotiations, New Orleans was dealt a severe blow when the Louisiana Legislature passed the strictest anti-abortion measure in the country. Gov. Buddy Roemer vetoed one version. He was sent another on Sunday night.
 
'Some Other Dynamics'
Supporters of abortion rights argued that the Democrats should hardly go to a state with such strong anti-abortion attitudes when the party was stressing its support for abortion rights as an important issue that distinguishes Democrats from Republicans.
''We know what New Orleans has to offer,'' a spokeswoman for that city, Jinx Brusard, said. ''We also know there are some other dynamics that are involved.''
Ms. Brusard cited the belief among top Democrats that they could raise more money in New York than in New Orleans and that there was ''a bit of concern regarding what has been happening in our State Legislature.''
Some Democrats, particularly those of a conservative bent, had expressed concern that New York, with its image of crime and racial strife, might not be an ideal site for the convention either. Bruce Reed, policy director of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group that tries to steer the party to what it calls the mainstream, said:
''The important question for 1992 is what kind of candidate does the Democratic Party nominate, not which city does the honors. Atlanta couldn't save our last nominee. New York is not going to do in our next one.''
The head of the Hotel Association of New York City, Joseph E. Spinnato, said the decision would be a particular help for the hotel business in the city, because the State Legislature has recently increased by 5 percentage points the tax on most hotel rooms.
''Now the tax rate is 20.5 percent,'' Mr. Spinnato said. ''This could have had an impact on the Democratic National Convention and on other conventions. Other cities have a lot to offer at inexpensive rates.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald H. Brown, Democratic national chairman, who is said to have selected the site for the party's 1992 convention. (The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
51 Albanians Fly to Prague and Quickly Receive Political Asylum

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Tuesday, July 10

 BODY:
Fifty-one Albanians who had sought refuge in the Czechoslovak Embassy in Tirana, the Albanian capital, were flown to Prague early this morning, where they were granted political asylum, officials here and in Tirana said.
The 51 are among an estimated 6,000 Albanians who have crowded into about a dozen Western embassies in Tirana in recent weeks seeking to flee Eastern Europe's last Stalinist Government. They are the first of those seeking refuge to leave the country.
Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry officials said late Monday that the 51 Albanians in the embassy in Tirana had been issued passports and had left the country. Albania has promised that all those now in foreign embassies would be given passports. 
The Prague Government sent a Tupolev-154 jet used by President Vaclav Havel to pick up the refugees - 49 men and 2 women.
The Czechoslovak Deputy Foreign Minister, Vojtech Wagner, said that clothing and some money were secured for the emigrants, the official press agency reported.
On arrival here, the Albanians walked briskly down the steps of the plane. Most of them appeared to be in their early 20's and wore casual dress like short-sleeved shirts or T-shirts. The first man to disembark carried a picture of President Havel.
The Albanians answered no questions posed by journalists. They boarded a bus provided by the Government, to be driven to Government-supplied accommodations.
Mr. Wagner indicated that he thought most would not stay long. ''What will happen later on cannot be said, because with the exception of two of them, all want to go somewhere else,'' the agency quoted him as saying. Most of the Albanians are expected to seek entry to Australia, the United States or West European countries. [In Washington, a State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said he had no information about requests for travel to the United States and had no comment on what American policy would be on such requests, The Associated Press reported. There is no United States Embassy in Tirana.] Those seeking asylum, some dodging police bullets, began taking refuge on June 28. The Albanian authorities pledged on Saturday that they would receive travel papers.
 
Beginnings of Change
Albania's Communist leader, Ramiz Alia, has begun this year to institute some cautious economic changes in an attempt to alleviate shortages and raise the standard of living by creating incentives for workers and farmers.
For 45 years, travel out of Albania has been virtually impossible. But Albanian leaders have sought better ties abroad since 1985, and they recently began to carry out reforms.
A package of new regulations that took effect last Tuesday entitles all Albanians over the age of 16 to have passports.
About 3,000 of those seeking asylum have been on the grounds of the West German Embassy in Tirana.
Hanns Schumacher, spokesman for the West German Foreign Ministry, said in Bonn that a United Nations envoy was representing the West German, Italian, French and Greek embassies in talks with the Tirana Government.
In addition to those Albanians in the Czechoslovak, West German, Hungarian and French embassies, about 1,000 are in the Italian Embassy and 30 are in the Greek Embassy.
Western officials have complained that the Albanian authorities have not granted them permission to fly in badly needed supplies to care for the refugees. But the embassy is badly overcrowded, with the emigrants sleeping in corridors and a garden, in conditions described by diplomats as deteriorating.
The French Foreign Ministry in Paris said that the formalities of obtaining passports for the 550 refugees at its embassy in Tirana were moving rapidly and that ''we hope they will be finished by the end of the day.''

HEADLINE: THE HOUSTON SUMMIT;
Europeans Accuse the U.S. of Balking on Plans to Combat Global Warming

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 9

 BODY:
Senior European officials at the economic summit conference accused the United States today of frustrating their efforts to reach a new accord to combat global warming.
The European officials, including members of the British, French and Italian delegations who asked not to be identified, angrily complained that John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, had taken the leading role in organizing American opposition to the global warming initiative.
Asked at a news briefing this morning why the United States was resisting a West German proposal to set a target for reducing gases that cause global warming, Mr. Sununu replied, ''The issue is being addressed with a level of haste.'' He added, ''There seems to be some propensity to deal with the issue without putting all the data on the table.'' 
In a letter sent to summit leaders last month, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called for ''internationally binding regulations with ''radical measures to limit'' gas emissions that contribute to the greenhouse effect.
Chancellor Kohl said: ''We must view the threat of climate change as a global challenge to all mankind. The world expects the seven summit countries to come up with far-reaching, specific proposals.''
Mr. Sununu insisted today that the Bush Administration had endorsed limits on some emissions through the Clean Air Act, but he opposed new emission limits, contending that they would require major changes in the American way of life and the nation's industrial structure.
He noted, for instance, that because the United States was much larger than Japan or any of the European nations it had a greater reliance on cars and trucks to transport people and products.
Commenting on Mr. Sununu's position, James T. B. Tripp, general counsel of the Environmental Defense Fund, a Washington-based advocacy group, said, ''These statements may serve to explain why United States per capita consumption of fossil fuels is so high compared to Western Europe and Japan, but they are not legitimate excuses for United States refusal to limit carbon dioxide emissions and take steps to use energy much more efficiently.''
Although President Bush has mustered allies to support his views on the two other major issues being addressed at the summit talks - aid to the Soviet Union and international trade - he now stands alone on the third area of the agenda, the environment.
As the summit meeting's official sessions began today, European officials worried that the United States would block their effort to win a commitment to stabilize and then reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that contribute to the greenhouse effect. Many scientists believe that these gases trap heat from the sun that would otherwise escape back into space. The trapped gases then produce a gradual warming of the earth's atmosphere.
 
Pledges Made by Others
Except for the United States, all the industrial nations represented at the summit meeting have now pledged to stabilize greenhouse gas emissions, at least by early in the next century.
Even Britain and Japan, which formerly sided with Washington in insisting that more scientific and economic information was needed before taking action, are developing plans to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. West Germany has taken the lead, with a goal of reducing such emissions by 25 percent in the next 15 years.
President Bush's apparent determination to block a global warming initiative at this summit meeting stands in sharp contrast to his embrace of major environmental commitments at last year's economic summit talks in Paris.
In the final communique of that meeting, the national leaders declared that ''decisive action is urgently needed to understand and protect the earth's ecological balance.''
On the issue of global warming the communique stated, ''We strongly advocate common efforts to limit emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, which threaten to induce climate change, endangering the environment and ultimately the economy.''
Even as the summit delegations began gathering here this weekend, European officials hoped that the Houston talks would build on the rhetoric of the Paris communique. But at a meeting Sunday night American officials raised a series of paralyzing objections, a European participant said.
''We had thought we were making progress,'' the European official said today, ''but at last night's meeting it was discouragingly obvious that Sununu was back in the ascendancy, and the United States was yielding nothing.''
European officials said that the first sign that President Bush would resist a global warming initiative came when William K. Reilly, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, was left behind in Washington. Mr. Reilly was a prominent member of the Bush delegation to the Paris talks.
In Mr. Reilly's absence the role of chief adviser on environmental matters has been assumed by Mr. Sununu, who has publicly disagreed with Mr. Reilly on assessments of environmental dangers. At the news briefing this morning, Mr. Sununu rejected the kind of joint commitment to specific limitations on gas emissions that the West Germans among others are pressing the meeting to adopt.
He said, ''There is a concern that this idea of a permanent cap in perpetuity does not understand not only our growth needs, but the growth needs of the developing countries of the world.''
He added, ''So what we are seeking is a commitment that is broader, a commitment that would allow both the industrialized countries and the developing countries to address the broad issue of greenhouse gases without picking them one by one, setting caps on them individually.''

HEADLINE: Americans Voicing Anxiety on Japan As Concern in Tokyo Seems to Soften

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
The American public's concern over the economic might of Japan appears to have risen sharply, heightening sentiment for limits on foreign investments, as Americans worry more about Japanese economic power than about Soviet military power.
This surge in anxiety is occurring even as Japanese attitudes toward the United States, while tinged with resentment, appear to be softening somewhat on trade issues.
The findings are the results of a matched pair of public opinion polls conducted in the United States by the New York Times and CBS News and in Japan by the Tokyo Broadcasting System.
The surveys revealed the complex and ambivalent domestic attitudes that both President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu must contend with as they try to manage what many analysts now describe as each country's most important bilateral relationship.
 
Pointing at Each Other
While leaders from seven industrialized nations are seated at the economic summit table in Houston this week, Americans and Japanese point squarely at each other in the public opinion surveys when asked to identify their country's strongest competitor. 
Substantial majorities in both countries continue to express friendly attitudes toward the other. Indeed, the 75 percent of Americans who say their overall feelings toward Japan are generally friendly represents a slight rise from the 67 percent registered in January. Sixty-six percent of Japanese said their current feelings toward the United States were generally friendly, also a slight rise from the 57 percent measured a year ago, when that question was last asked in Japan.
Yet this generally friendly attitude coexists with increasing anxieties in the United States, particularly about economics, and bad feelings in both countries that seem largely cultural.
 
Attitudes on Investment
Sixty-four percent of Americans, up from 45 percent in 1987, now say that investment by the Japanese in the United States poses a threat to American economic independence. Sixty-one percent favor restrictions on foreign investments in American real estate, up from 53 percent in a May 1988 CBS News poll.
Americans do not find European investment nearly as disturbing, the survey found. even though there is more of it. Only 37 percent of Americans said they thought that increasing European investment was a threat.
This disparity has led some Japanese to perceive racism in America's reaction to Japan's trading success. Seven of ten Japanese in the current survey said they thought Americans looked down on them. Nearly half of the Americans said they thought Japanese looked down on Americans.
Tetsuya Tsukushi, anchor for TBS in Tokyo, said he and his colleagues were struck by the ambivalence in American attitudes.
''We are a little bit surprised so many people do not want to have Japanese investment,'' he said in a telephone interview from Tokyo after broadcasting the poll results last night. ''It's much more of a protectionist flavor. At the same time, much more than we expected, Americans have high regard for Japanese ability and Japanese people.''
Attitudes among the Japanese were similarly complex, he said, comparing the relationship between the two countries to a marriage. ''They cannot divorce because of mutual interest,'' he said. ''The question is what kind of marriage will continue. Which is the husband and which is the wife?'' This, he said, was an analogy that would make more sense to the Japanese, where marriage is not thought of as quite the ''equal partnership'' many Americans say it is.
The poll in the United States was conducted among 1,084 Americans reached by telephone from June 5 to June 8. In Japan, 1,468 people were interviewed in person from May 31 to June 7. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points for each poll.
 
Less Fear of Moscow
Many of the same questions were asked in both countries. Asked to identify their own country's strongest competitor, 57 percent of Japanese picked the United States and 58 percent of Americans picked Japan.
Among Americans, the second most often mentioned country was the Soviet Union, cited by 19 percent. A separate question showed that, by 58 to 26 percent, Americans now view the economic power of Japan as a greater threat to American security than the military power of the Soviet Union. Only a year and a half ago, a Washington Post/ABC News poll found that 50 percent of Americans saw the Soviet Union as the greater threat, while 44 percent at that time cited Japan. Subsequent Post/ABC News polls showed that Japan had emerged as the greater perceived threat by the beginning of 1990.
Among the Japanese, West Germany and South Korea were cited next most often as Japan's chief competitor, picked by 6 percent each.
American optimism has clearly declined. In a CBS News Poll a year ago, 47 percent of Americans said the United States would be the No. 1 economic power in the next century and 38 percent picked Japan. But in the current survey 50 percent of Americans picked Japan and 32 percent picked the United States.
But this was not matched by a rise in Japanese confidence, according to Tokyo Broadcasting System polls. Forty-five percent of the Japanese picked Japan a year ago to be the No. 1 power of the next century, and that declined to 39 percent in the current survey. Forty-two percent of Japanese said the United States would be the No. 1 power, statistically unchanged from the 40 percent who said that last year.
Protectionist sentiment was clearly evident in the United States. One of four Americans said they thought the United States should restrict Japanesse goods ''a great deal.''
By contrast, only 3 percent of Japanese said the same about American goods. Indeed, the Japanese attitude toward American trade seemed generally to have softened somewhat. In 1987, a time of intense complaint in the United States about Japanese products, 77 percent of the Japanese said America was blaming Japan for its own economic problems and only 16 percent said Japanese companies were competing unfairly.
But in the latest survey, the number of Japanese who said their country was being blamed for America's economic problems declined to 68 percent and the number who agreed that Japanese companies compete unfairly rose to 26 percent.
Sharp differences remain in the views of the two nations' people. For example, asked if the Japanese Government had made enough of an effort to correct the trade imbalance with the United States, 10 percent of Americans and 63 percent of Japanese said it had. Fifty-two percent of Americans and 61 percent of Japanese say no when asked if the cold war is over.
Prime Minister Kaifu said before his arrival at the economic summit meeting in Houston that he opposed aid to the Soviet Union until the two countries resolve a dispute over four islands the Soviets seized from Japan at the end of World War II.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News/ Tokyo Broadcasting System Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 5 to 8 with 1,084 adults throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, and on personal interviews conducted May 31 to June 7 with 1,468 adults throughout Japan.
In the United States the sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted telephone numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and the number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In Japan, the survey was conducted by the Nihon Research Center under supervision of the Tokyo Broadcasting System. Personal interviews were conducted in communities throughout the country to yield a statistically representative sample of the Japanese public.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults, or all adult Japanese.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the polls.

HEADLINE: Thornburgh and Sessions Assailed for Traveling on Confiscated Jets

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
A Congressional report criticizes Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for their official travel aboard three executive jets seized from drug traffickers.
The report, to be issued Tuesday by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, says the Justice Department failed to determine whether the use of the planes for travel by the two officials was economical.
The report contended that the department should have compared the cost of the planes to commercial flights or other forms of secure air travel, like private air charters, asserting that such a financial analysis is required under Government budget policies.
Spokesmen for Mr. Thornburgh and Mr. Sessions defended the use of the planes on security grounds. The report noted that Justice Department officials had told the accounting office that the Attorney General had received ''numerous threats against his life.'' 
The report does not charge that either official used the planes for unauthorized purposes. But it said Mr. Thornburgh and Mr. Sessions followed different practices in reimbursing the Government for travel on the planes by their family members.
 
F.B.I. Policies Cited
Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia, said Friday in a letter to the two officials that he requested the report because the use of the planes appeared to interfere with F.B.I. policies that restrict the use of confiscated planes to ''law-enforcement purposes, including narcotics control and counterterrorism efforts.''
The Government acquired the planes under a program that allows Federal law-enforcement agencies to seize boats, planes and vehicles used in the transportation of drugs. The planes were turned over to the F.B.I., which operates a fleet of 84 aircraft.
The issue of air travel has been a source of irritation in the Justice Department in the past. Shortly after Mr. Thornburgh became Attorney General in August 1988, he cut back on employee travel in a move that seemed intended as a statement of frugality after the heavily criticized travels of Edwin Meese 3d, Mr. Thornburgh's predecessor.
In its review, the accounting office examined flight reports, travel vouchers and other documents to compile a record of travel by Mr. Thornburgh and Mr. Sessions from August 1988 to July 1989. In that period, the two men used the planes for a total of 75 trips. ''Most of their trips were to give speeches, attend meetings or visit field locations,'' the report said.
 
Security Concerns Noted
A Justice Department spokesman noted that the report recognized that security concerns effectively ruled out flights on commercial aircraft. ''The noncommercial flights are used for the personal security of the Attorney General and the F.B.I. Director and for security of documents and communications,'' the spokesman said.
Both the Justice Department and the F.B.I. submitted financial data to the accounting office in May showing that the use of the confiscated planes was cheaper than the use of leased aircraft. The department's analysis showed that the Government saved about $460,000 a year using the seized aircraft.
But the G.A.O. report rejected both comparisons, saying they were incomplete and excluded certain costs. The department has agreed to prepare a fuller financial assessment.
The Attorney General paid the Government $1,032 for himself and his family members on three personal trips. Last April he reimbursed a total of $2,128 for eight trips by his wife on Government aircraft.
Department policies do not require such payments, the report said, noting that Mr. Thornburgh's wife, Ginny, perferred to pay for her travel ''in an exercise of caution and to protect against unfair publicity.''
 
Wife With Sessions on 15 Trips
The F.B.I. Director reimbursed the Government $280 for personal travel aboard the Government planes that he and his wife, Alice, used. A member of the Director's staff said that Mr. Sessions did not use the confiscated planes for private business and that his wife, who joined him on 15 of his trips, only accompanied him in connection with his official business.
Last year Mr. Thornburgh was criticized when he and five aides flew to a legal convention in Honolulu aboard an otherwise empty Government Boeing 727. At the time a Justice Department spokesman defended the flight, saying it was the cheapest that could be made on a Government aircraft that was both available and could make the round-trip flight from San Francisco to Hawaii.
The accounting office did not address the cost of that flight because it took place after the period studied in the report.
