HEADLINE: A Summit Challenge: Farm Subsidies

 BODY:
The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks. If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the third world, they will hear this: Open up markets, or forget about new trade rules on services and intellectual property. That message, so critical to trade and growth, needs to be heard. 
If the Houston summit participants follow the European Community, which offers a vague and not very stringent approach to subsidies, the Uruguay Round will fail. But if they take heed of the U.S. position, that developed countries should end their protectionist farm policies, there's a good chance of a new trade pact, with benefits for almost all.
Disagreements over farm subsidies won't be resolved in Houston. But the leaders can make a crucial start with a ringing declaration to their trade negotiators to phase down farm subsidies.
None of the participants arrived in Houston with clean hands. Japan bars rice imports; the U.S. blocks sugar imports from desperately poor Latin American neighbors. Western Europe, however, is the worst sinner. It protects inefficient farmers by blocking imports and keeping internal prices high. It then dumps the enormous surpluses on foreign markets by subsidizing exports.
This bailout costs European taxpayers and consumers a whopping $100 billion a year. And low-cost third world farmers are wiped out by the influx of artificially cheap European exports and blocked access to Europe's markets. The monumentally wasteful system is testimony to the political power of Europe's 10 million farmers.
The Bush Administration is fighting to turn all this around. Mr. Bush is pressuring Japan and the E.C. to phase out protectionist farm policies. This would hurt protected growers, but help overall U.S. exports. Countries still could provide farmers with income supplements unrelated to production - welfare. But subsidies or any other interference with market prices would end.
The Administration's specific recommendation is to convert protectionist policies into tariffs, which would be phased down. The advantage of tariffs is that they are visible and easily monitored. ''Tariffication'' is how industrialized countries eliminated barriers to trading manufactured goods; it's also the best way to handle farm goods.
The Europeans prefer to work with an ''aggregate measure'' of protectionism, as yet undefined, which they would lower. That would allow them, for example, to reduce some tariffs and raise others. The problem is that an aggregate measure would be hard to interpret and could easily disguise the impact of specific protectionist policies.
The Uruguay Round is beginning to take on the flavor of trade union bargaining. Everyone waits until the midnight deadline to compromise. But delay here could be fatal. The issues are too complicated for a last-minute compromise; and there are scores of countries, each with its own internal constituency, to placate.
The leaders meeting in Houston don't need to resolve all the details. But they do have to stand up to farm blocs and give the orders to make the Uruguay Round succeed.

HEADLINE: Still a Cold War for Aliens

 BODY:
For 38 years, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed the U.S. to bar foreign visitors whose ideas the Government finds offensive. The number of visitors kept out each year varies, but the Government maintains a list of more than 350,000 people to be excluded. At a time when world tensions are easing, that's an astounding victory of narrow-mindedness over good sense. 
Passed in 1952, the McCarran-Walter Act reflects the hysteria of the McCarthy era. One of the most troublesome of the law's 33 exclusionary provisions allows the Government to bar visitors or migrants who would advocate ''economic, international and governmental doctrines of world Communism'' and other subversive activities.
Those foreigners deemed inadmissible are put on a ''lookout'' list, formally known as the National Automated Immigration Lookout System, or Nails, and kept by the State Department and Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Last month the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, a civil liberties group, received an edited copy of the list under the Freedom of Information Act. Although names and occupations were omitted, the list contained 353,324 entries, of which 238,140 had been added since 1980. Duplication accounts for some inflation in the total, but the Lawyers Committee estimates that at least 300,000 individuals have been denied visas, the vast majority because of their ideological beliefs.
An overhaul of McCarran-Walter is still pending in Congress. But earlier this year, President Bush signed into law a sensible prohibition on excluding visitors solely because of ''past, current or expected beliefs, statements or associations'' that the Constitution protects for American citizens. In practice, however, visitors seeking visas must first declare whether they have, or have ever had, Communist affiliations. Only then may they obtain a waiver for admission.
That undermines the spirit of the new law. If the State Department and the I.N.S. were faithful to that spirit, they would eliminate such background questions. And for those seeking to stay for longer periods, the Government ought to purge the ''lookout'' list on a regular basis. Until the Government thus acknowledges a changing world, McCarran-Walter's fearful ghosts will reign triumphant.

TYPE: Editorial

COMPANY: HUMAN RIGHTS (69%); HUMAN RIGHTS FIRST (56%); HUMAN RIGHTS FIRST (56%);

HEADLINE: Make Farm Programs Work as They Should;
For Truly Free Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Get Fat Farmers Off Welfare'' (editorial, June 19), which backs the proposals of Representatives Dick Armey of Texas and Charles Schumer of New York to curb the agricultural support program, is commendable. But because the West is encouraging Eastern European countries to adopt a market economy without modifications, perhaps the United States should itself attempt to operate such an unsubsidized economy. There would be no national deficit if we withdrew all agricultural subsidies and endorsed, as national policy, a free market economy.
We subsidize everything from growing tobacco (while we also spend more than a $100 million warning against its health hazards), peanuts, soybeans and sugar to production of milk and withdrawal of land from production. Because most subsidy money goes to agribusiness, rather than to small family farms, little distress and dislocation would be caused.
Perhaps the United States is the model that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has in mind when the Soviet President speaks rather enigmatically of a ''controlled market economy.'' Let us put into effect the ''free market economy'' that we advocate for Eastern Europe.
 
A. L. MCLEOD
 Trenton, June 22, 1990

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
U.S. Takes the Lead

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Just when the noise level of complaints about lack of American vision in response to the new needs of Europe was reaching screech point, the Bush Administration came up with an impressive new plan.
Despite allied grumbles, it won warm support because it goes a long way toward meeting problems opened by German unification and collapse of the Warsaw Pact. Presumably, resentment at Washington will evaporate as governments get on with remodeling NATO.
Last year's NATO summit meeting produced the same sense of Administration drift, mounting tension and -at the last minute - Bush proposals that brought accord. This time there wasn't even a quick tour by special envoys to brief allied leaders on what was coming in London. There were just letters and phone calls from the President, which made Europeans feel shut out of the preparations. 
Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James Baker like this kind of personal diplomacy, but it has a price. It contributes to fears that the new ''special relationship'' is the Washington-Bonn axis, and that both Britain and France are being left in the cold. The French sniff that the U.S. is foolishly backing any whim of Chancellor Kohl of West Germany, although it is Paris that has been pushing hardest for Mr. Kohl's scheme to buy Moscow's blessing.
President Mitterrand of France didn't want a NATO meeting until late in the year (and there may be another in December) so as to work out what he calls ''the European identity in security affairs.'' It's not clear what he means, but Paris has reversed gears for the time being.
For at least six months, France was edging toward formal involvement with NATO's military structure, which would make it much easier to solve problems of reform. Now, miffed, Mr. Mitterrand is saying France's defense is entirely independent. Further, in tart asides, French officials suggest the U.S. is blocking useful change. ''The Americans always get annoyed when Europe starts to emancipate herself,'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said recently.
This kind of jockeying for position and spurts of personal pique are probably to be expected in a period of difficult diplomacy launching a new basis for allied relations. Too bad there wasn't more finesse, but the underlying agreement is solid.
The Europeans want NATO to continue and they want Americans in Europe, even as they also want to offer Mikhail Gorbachev the assurances he says he needs to accept new German arrangements.
There is strong evidence supporting Britain's Foreign Minister, Douglas Hurd, when he said in a newspaper interview, ''I've never known a time when there was less anti-Americanism in Europe, whether in Britain or on the Continent.'' His judgment that ''American engagement is absolutely fundamental to stability'' is widely shared.
The Soviets are coming around to the same view, but it costs them, particularly in Mr. Gorbachev's tense internal politics. There is evident difference between the Foreign Ministry and the military establishment, smarting at Eastern Europe's ''loss.''
Soviet diplomats are aware that they caused some of their own problems, by arguing too insistently that a united Germany in NATO was unacceptable. Now they need a way to back out, and Mr. Bush is providing that. He has wisely said or done nothing to humiliate them.
The grievance of most Soviet officers is not leaving Germany but having no housing, no jobs to go home to. The idea of staying on is not as attractive as the military planners claim. Already there have been attacks on their soldiers, and the East German Defense Minister said some had been disarmed to prevent retaliation, which could lead to grave incidents.
There is a good chance that the new NATO plan can be the keystone for a series of agreements with the East and adjustments in the West to construct the transition Europe needs after the cold war. The long term, the ideal of a workable all-European security pact, isn't the problem now. It is getting there.
After floundering, Washington has produced some sensible and sensitive ideas to carry out Mr. Bush's pledge of going ''beyond containment.'' The proposal to send experts, not just a flood of billions, to help the Soviets make their railroads, their grain storage system, their food distribution work is another example of identifying the critical needs and addressing them. This is the way to proceed, concretely. Leave the grand designs to historians' hindsight. Even with rumpled edges, this is statesmanship.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Unions Loath To Strike Daily News

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Six months after the opening of what both sides knew would be difficult contract talks, the 10 unions at The Daily News remain far from a settlement with the management. But in recent weeks, they appear to have won some maneuvering room.
Despite the entry of a Federal mediator in talks involving three important unions, there has been little progress in meeting the proposals of The News for up to $70 million in labor savings, as well as accepting a ''management rights'' provision that would allow the publisher free rein to make huge cuts in staffing and other changes.
The publisher, James Hoge, who ended all union contracts in the spring, has said that only through ''regaining management rights to hire, supervise and assign work'' can the 71-year-old newspaper hope to survive in the competitive tabloid market in New York City.
But the unions, backed by funds and advice from the Washington office of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have managed to defy their own predictions of a confrontation by July 1, the deadline they asserted that management had set to provoke a strike. 
 
Move by Cuomo Administration
The unions may not have acquired any advantages at the bargaining table, labor leaders say, but they have clearly won additional time to generate some leverage.
The unions' cautious optimism was bolstered last week when the Cuomo administration, alarmed by signs that a major clash might be imminent at The News, began laying the groundwork for a possible state inquiry into the dispute. At the same time, the unions have been talking about organizing an advertising and reader boycott of the paper.
From organized labor's perspective, the stakes are high. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., which recently brought in a veteran labor lawyer from Detroit to help coordinate bargaining strategy and organize the boycott, views the confrontation at The News as a struggle of the same symbolic dimensions as the air-traffic controllers' strike of the early 80's. That walkout was ultimately broken by the Reagan Administration.
George McDonald, president of the mailers' union and head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group for the 2,400 full-time union workers at The News, said he was convinced that the unions' tactic of refusing to strike, combined with what may be precedent-setting management setbacks in the Greyhound bus walkout, might have forced The News to rethink the timing, if not the substance, of its strategy.
The unions said they believed that the newspaper's original plan was patterned on past incidents - some at news organizations owned by The News's parent, the Tribune Company of Chicago - in which unions were broken after having been provoked into striking. In the last 10 years, the tactic, used in a variety of industries, has frequently turned the unions' most effective weapon, the strike, into an instrument for their own destruction.
For months, union leaders at The News had asserted that management hoped to provoke a strike no later than July 1, probably by declaring an impasse in the stalled talks and posting new work rules like halving the 410-member complement of pressmen.
The union leadership has had its hands full trying to maintain discipline in the face of potentially provocative actions, including what the unions said were management's deployment of aggressive out-of-town security guards in its three printing plants and the layoffs of scores of workers.
 
Tactic to Provoke
The layoffs, beginning early last month, were for what management said were strictly economic reasons, which are permitted under the terms of some of the contracts that expired on March 30. But union leaders, including Barry Lipton, president of largest union at The News, the 700-member Newspaper Guild unit, asserted that the layoffs were another tactic to provoke, and finance, a walkout.
Spokesmen for The News insisted that there was no master plan for provoking a confrontation.
''The unions' predictions about when we're going to reach impasse have been pretty miserable,'' the chief spokesman for the paper, John T. Sloan, said. ''First it was March 31. Then something was going to happen in April. Then it was Memorial Day. Then Father's Day.''
But people with first-hand knowledge of the management thinking said the strategy called for The News to declare an impasse and impose new work rules no later than June 25.
The company's hope, those people said, was that this would spark a walkout, especially if the new working conditions were posted for traditionally militant unions like the pressmen or the 688 deliverers. That would allow The News to make good on a vow to continue publishing with replacement workers, having shed itself of what it has called financially ruinous union contracts.
 
Finding Against Greyhound
The unions' only real hope in the face of such a move would be a finding by the Federal Government and the courts that The News had not negotiated in good faith before declaring an impasse. The unions' faith in such a possibility was bolstered a few months ago in an incident that labor analysts say could parallel future developments at The News.
Greyhound Lines broke off talks with its 6,300 drivers late last winter and began hiring more than 3,000 permanent replacement workers. In May, the National Labor Relations Board filed a complaint that the company's actions constituted an unfair labor practice, a finding that could make Greyhound liable for $13 million in back pay for every month the strike continues.
If such an accusation were made against The News and upheld by the courts, the newspaper would have to pay millions of dollars in back wages, benefits and interest to workers affected by the collapse of contract talks.
Union officials said they hoped they could sustain such a charge against The News because of the broad language of its proposed management-rights clause to set hours and working conditions without bargaining.
''It's their duty under Federal labor law to bargain on wages, hours and working conditions,'' said Theodore W. Kheel, a veteran labor lawyer who is the unions' chief adviser. ''If they say, 'Starting tomorrow we're changing the delivery routes, so we'll have 68 fewer drivers,' without having first bargained in good faith to impasse, then I think they would be committing an unfair labor practice.''
But such a finding, by the labor board, could take years to sustain in court and run up a fortune in legal fees.
''It's a lawyer's dream,'' Mr. Kheel said. ''But still, the Tribune Company has to be concerned, principally in light of the Greyhound experience, that the N.L.R.B. might hold that any such action came without bargaining in good faith on specific items.''
Asked about that, an executive of The News declined to discuss whether the Greyhound case had prompted a re-evaluation of strategy. The executive, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, acknowledged:
''Some have speculated that the unions have done things that we did not anticipate. And there are a lot of rumblings and rumors now that as a result we are looking at other areas such as additional economic layoffs'' that could result from the closing of individual printing presses or even a plant, possibly in Garden City, L.I.
 
'Evaluating Various Options'
''I can't confirm or deny that we're going to shut down a press or a plant or whatever,'' Mr. Sloan said. ''But I can say that we are carefully evaluating various options in both the production and distribution side of our business.''
Yesterday, an aide to Mr. Sloan, Virginia Woo, said The News opposed a state inquiry into the situation, citing a statement by Mr. Sloan in the July 2 issue of Crain's New York Business saying, ''Our position is that the best approach to solve our problems is face-to-face negotiations with our 10 unions, not an outside party.''
A state board, mandated under a seldom-invoked 39-year-old statute, could involve a 60-day cooling-off period, which the unions hope would make it difficult, if not impossible, for The News to declare an impasse over the summer, when low advertising revenues would make a strike strategically advantageous for management.
City Labor Relations Commissioner Eric J. Schmerz said he strongly supported creating a board of inquiry.
''The law is designed to provide a procedural forum to aid parties who are not doing very well in direct negotiations,'' Mr. Schmerz said. ''This is a major dispute that could turn into a very serious confrontation. A legendary newspaper's existence is involved, along with the jobs of thousands of workers and the economy of the city.''
Union leaders acknowledged that they suffered from a distinct lack of leverage at the bargaining table and that they faced a formidable foe in the chief negotiator for The News, Robert Ballow (pronounced ba-LOO), a tough-talking lawyer from Nashville with a long record of success in fighting newspaper unions.
Underlying the unions' fears are financial projections suggesting that losses by The News could force the Tribune Company to close the newspaper. Last month Merrill Lynch & Company estimated that The News could lose $45 million this year, a sum that the financial house said would force the paper to reorganize ''to generate a reasonable return, or it will cease to be a factor in the earnings'' of the company. Apparently the implication is that The News will have to win its struggle against the unions or else be sold or closed.
In an effort to forestall the point at which management might seek to declare an impasse, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has advised the unions to slow the negotiations, on the ground that Mr. Ballow is purportedly ''there for the express purpose of not negotiating,'' said a confidential memorandum on June 17 that bears the initials of an A.F.L.-C.I.O. strategist in Washington, Joe Uehlein.
Mr. Sloan said it was apparent that the footdragging at the bargaining table had begun long ago, citing detailed statistics demonstrating how many times various union negotiators had arrived late, taken long lunch hours or otherwise sought to keep the talks moving at what he called a glacial pace.

HEADLINE: New York City Spurs Anti-Apartheid Fight

 BODY:
A New York City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would further limit city business with banks or companies that have ties to South Africa and seek to reward banks that put pressure on the apartheid government there.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has long urged the measure and testified at a hearing of the Government Operations Committee. The full Council is expected to approve the measure today.
The bill would expand existing laws that bar the city from doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa and would establish a rating system to judge the posture of banks in dealing with South Africa. When choosing among banks with comparable services at comparable cost, the bill would direct city agencies to deposit or invest city funds in banks with the highest ratings.
City officials conceded that the handful of banks without ties to South Africa would not be large enough to handle most city transactions, but they said the measure would prompt discussion and perhaps changes in the practices of bigger banks.

HEADLINE: New Microbial Agents May Help Kill Crop Pests

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ARMIES of bugs and microbes, their powers enhanced in some cases by genetic engineering, are being unleashed in fields and laboratories in a widening effort to control destructive agricultural pests without resorting to chemical pesticides.
The effort includes a major expansion of the classical form of biological control, in which insects' natural enemies are imported and set loose in the fields. More and more farmers are now deploying mass-produced battalions of pest-killing insects and parasites, and the number of biological agents available to them has more than doubled over the last decade.
But beyond that, researchers are deciphering the ways in which a wide variety of microorganisms kill or suppress other microbes, weeds, fungi and insects that destroy crops and diminish agricultural yields. They are using this knowledge to custom-design better new biological agents through genetic engineering. 
Although biological control accounts for only about 1 percent of the $20 billion spent globally on pest control each year, research is rising sharply.
''There's a big information explosion,'' said Dr. R. James Cook of the Department of Agriculture's biological control research unit at Washington State University, who headed a 1987 study of the subject by the National Academy of Sciences. Ten years ago, he said, perhaps 1 percent of the 500 or so scientific papers presented at annual meetings of plant pathologists dealt with biological control; today, 25 to 30 percent do.
Eleven microbial pest-control agents have been approved for commercial use by the Environmental Protection Agency since 1980; five of the approvals have come in the last two years, and at least three more are expected this year. About half of all applications from pesticide manufacturers for permission to do field research now involve biological controls, said William Schneider, a microbiologist in the agency's office of pesticides - an ''almost exponential'' rate of growth.
On one research frontier, scientists are isolating and mass-producing genes from one strain of bacteria that produces an antibiotic that kills disease organisms. They are transferring the genes to other varieties of bacteria, creating new strains that can use the same antibiotic.
By such gene transfers, they hope to tailor-make microorganisms that can control diseases in environments where none otherwise would; to enhance the potency of control microbes; to make a single strain of microbe effective against more than one pest, and to design control microbes that will commit suicide after doing their job. In a parallel effort, they are also trying to incorporate disease-resistant genes in the crops themselves, and some of these agents are expected to be commercially available in the next five years.
Scientists are also delving into the enormously complex ecology of the soil to understand the teeming microbial communities whose interactions partly determine the health of crops. Biological control is primarily an exercise in manipulating this largely unexplored micro-environment. There, microbes and higher forms engage in a constant struggle, in which organisms harmful to crops are often held in check naturally; humans are seeking to enhance, augment and guide the process.
 
Fungus 1, Moth 0
In a striking display of pest control occuring spontaneously in nature, a wild fungus first identified only a year ago has greatly reduced the defoliation of Northeastern forests this summer by what scientists had feared would be one of the most destructive gypsy moth infestations in years. A lot remains unknown about the fungus, but scientists hope they can ultimately understand it well enough to adopt it as a weapon against gypsy moths in many parts of the country.
The resurgence of interest and research is being driven by a number of pressures. Many scientists and environmentalists believe that chemical pesticides are contaminating the environment. They say, furthermore, that production of the chemicals depends too heavily on energy from fossil fuels to be indefinitely sustained, and that some chemical pesticides are losing their effectiveness as pests develop resistance to them. And an aroused public, fearing dangerous residues in foods, is turning thumbs down on chemical pesticides.
Some experts believe that biology will eventually overtake chemistry as the predominant means of pest control. ''It's going to have to,'' said Lester E. Ehler, a professor of entomology at the University of California at Davis. But he and many others say biological agents are not a total answer.
''It's dangerous to rely solely on biological control because it doesn't always work,'' said Dr. Ehler. Ideally, he and other scientists say, biological controls should be used as part of an integrated approach that also involves crop rotation, new strains of disease-resistant crops and some chemical pesticides - with chemicals used sparingly, as a last resort.
''It is not a quick-fix silver bullet,'' Dr. Cook said of biological pest control. As promising as it is for a broad range of plant diseases and insect pests, it is much less so for weeds and some fungi.
On the other hand, he said, chemical pesticides fail to control many diseases, particularly root diseases of field crops. ''I see biological control as filling a major gap that has simply been left by the inadequacies of chemical control,'' he said.
 
Microbes Have Their Limits
Whatever their inadequacies, synthetic chemical controls have ruled modern agriculture since World War II. Overshadowed by the chemicals, research on biological languished until the 1980's. Part of the difficulty has been the limitations inherent in biological control.
A microbe might work in one part of the country but not another, or in one season but not another. And although biological agents tend to be more stable and longer-lasting, they generally do not bring about the dramatic kill that chemical pesticides can; rather, they hold the pests within tolerable bounds. All this makes companies reluctant to stand behind guarantees.
Biological agents have a big economic drawback as well: unlike chemical pesticides, they do not control a broad spectrum of pests. A given agent works against one pest on one crop and may require only one application. This creates a narrow ''niche market'' that many large manufacturers find unprofitable.
Much of the resurgent research is aimed at overcoming these limitations.
For a century, farmers have been practicing ''classical'' biological control: the loosing of predatory insects, parasites and nematodes against insect pests and weeds. Today, about 50 such agents are sold in the United States. This is more than double the number available a decade ago, Dr. Ehler said, ''and the list is growing year by year.''
''A farmer can call up a supplier and say, 'I need 50,000 parasites,' and put them out,'' he went on. In one of the best examples so far, he said, mites that afflict California strawberries have been successfully and routinely countered by turning predatory mites loose against them.
''Growers have started opting for biological control,'' Dr. Ehler said. ''It's been available for 30 years, but they've only recently started using it because they've been forced into it by problems with pesticides.''
 
The Scientific Obstacles
Even so, there are scientific obstacles. Two-thirds of all natural enemies introduced as classical control agents have failed to become established, said Dr. Ehler. The challenge, he added, is to predict what will work and what will not.
But even greater challenges confront scientists who are trying to turn microorganisms against crop diseases. Researchers at the University of Wisconsin have lately discovered a new control agent, bacillus cereus UW85, and are unraveling the mechanism through which it suppresses the fungus phytophthora, which attacks the roots of alfalfa and soybeans.
They have found that late in its growth cycle, UW85 produces an antibiotic that attacks the fungus. So they applied bacteria of the right age to soybean seeds and planted them.
The results were mixed, said Jo Handelsman, the leader of the project. Over four seasons, soybean yields increased by as much as 42 percent in some fields but not at all in others. ''It works very well in the upper Midwest, but does not seem to work in the South,'' she went on. ''In Missouri and Mississippi, it was a total and complete washout.''
Researchers in the Department of Agriculture laboratory at Washington State University have had a similar experience with a bacterium that controls a fungal disease called take-all. A major pathogen for wheat crops around the world, take-all can cut crop yields in half and is not well controlled by chemical pesticides.
But again, said Dr. Cook of the laboratory, ''we have a certain number of failures because the organisms do not like the environment we put them in.''
 
Custom-Made Bacteria
One way to overcome such inconsistencies may be through genetic engineering. So the Washington researchers are trying to customize bacteria for given environments. They have discovered the mechanism through which the bacterium works: an antibiotic, phenazine-1-carboxylic acid, that it produces on wheat roots. In studies conducted by Dr. Linda Thomashow and Dr. L. S. Pierson, the gene responsible for producing the antibiotic has been isolated and cloned, and is now being inserted into other bacteria.
A next step would be to insert the antibiotic gene into bacteria that would flourish in environments where the original antifungal bacterium cannot. It might also be inserted into bacteria that control other diseases. Some researchers envision the genetic engineering of microorganisms that would attack a variety of pests, as chemical pesticides now do.
Other researchers foresee using genetic techniques to make biological control agents more powerful. ''What we'd like to be able to do is increase the virulence'' of an agent, said Olen C. Yoder, a plant pathologist at Cornell University, ''but retain its specificity so that it would never harm anything but the target.'' Furthermore, he said, it should be possible to construct biological agents so that they ''do their job and then commit suicide so that they don't persist in the environment,'' where there is a remote chance they could exchange genetic material with natural organisms.
Other researchers are inserting pest-control genes into plants. At the Monsanto Company in St. Louis, for example, scientists are routinely introducing genes into nearly three dozen vegetable crops, hoping to enable them to repel insects. Commercial introduction of some of the agents is planned for the mid-1990's.
 
Against 'Magic Bullets'
Some scientists warn against such strategies, especially if they are viewed as magic bullets to be used in disregard of the ecology of the fields, much as chemical pesticides have been. ''That's a simple-minded solution,'' said Dr. Majorie Hoy, an entomologist at the University of California at Berkeley. Introducing pest-control genes into plants might work, she said, ''but it certainly can induce resistance in pests, and it can have negative effects on beneficial insects.''
Many scientists see the proper use of biological controls as being inseparable from a broader strategy of manipulation of the microenvironment of the soil and the field. So some are focusing their research on understanding the ''communities'' of microbes, harmful and beneficial, whose interactions in large part determine the health of crops.
Chemical pesticides tend to destroy these communities, but researchers are finding that the communities themselves, if left to function freely, can hold plant diseases in check through natural competition. ''It's there, but it's not breaking out as a disease or a pest,'' said Stephen Gliessman, an agricultural ecologist at the University of California at Santa Cruz.
 
When the Chemicals Stop
Chemical pesticides wipe out not only pests but also the beneficial organisms that compete with them. In a three-year-old study of the ecology of plots of strawberries, a group headed by Dr. Gliessman is looking at what happens when the use of chemical pesticides ceases. ''We predicted that we were going to get a buildup of pathogens, fungi primarily, that would force us to abandon the soil after a couple of years,'' he said.
The disease organisms did multiply. But to the researchers' surprise, so did a whole range of other microorganisms that began to function as a balanced whole, with no one strain of organism winning out. ''It's the diversity and the numbers that keep pathogens in check,'' said Dr. Gliessman.
The next step is to try to identify the ways in which the organisms interact, with an eye toward manipulating the microecology so that beneficial organisms, genetically engineered and otherwise, can operate in it effectively and permanently.
''In biological control, we talk about a balance,'' said Dr. Hoy. ''You maintain some pests at low levels to maintain the beneficials; they've got to eat something.''

HEADLINE: In Hong Kong, a New Confidence

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 9

 BODY:
To the list of fictional acts of derring-do attributed to the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, the popular cartoon characters, many in this British colony now add a real feat: helping rescue the Hong Kong stock market.
The stock of the Hong Kong company that manufactures these toy characters, Playmates International Holdings, became a standout this year and helped to fuel a stock market rally.
Playmates' demonstration of entrepreneurial flair was followed by two other developments that warmed Hong Kong's chill: President Bush's decision at the end of May not to suspend China's most-favored-nation status in trade, and China's decision to permit Fang Lizhi, the dissident who fled to the United States Embassy after the military crackdown in Beijing on June 4, 1989, to emigrate to Britain. The move was viewed as an indicator of a more open China.
 
Stocks Rebound
As a result, share prices in this beleaguered capitalist enclave, which plummeted after the crackdown, have rebounded sharply. They rose nearly 5 percent in June. Today, the key market indicator, the Hang Seng index, surged to a post-crash high of 3,385, up more than 44 percent from the period a year ago. 
Many in Hong Kong still expect the worst when China regains control over Hong Kong in 1997. But resilient entrepreneurs here interpreted the success of the pizza-munching turtles as a sign that there are opportunities in the short time left to do what they do best: make money.
Playmates International is among the stock market's hottest performers. Its stock closed at $14.40 a share (Hong Kong) today, or $1.84 in United States currency, up from $1.60 (Hong Kong) at the beginning of the year.
''That was when Hong Kong started to feel good about itself again,'' Eric A. Rasmussen, an economist here for Jardine Fleming Broking, a regional securities firm, said of Playmates' success. ''People felt they could still do it.''
Nonetheless, he added, ''One shock from a stupid move from China and the market could drop right through the floor.''
 
A Different Kind of Rally
He and several other economists also pointed out that this rally in Hong Kong has been different from others. The money fueling it is coming primarily from Hong Kong and other Asian investors, including Taiwan and Japanese institutions. Western capital has played a less important role than in the past.
These changes make Hong Kong less of a financial bridge between the West and Asia, its traditional role, and more of a regional hub. ''Hong Kong has become more of an Asian financial center rather than a global financial center,'' said Alan A. McLean, chief economist at the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, the colony's dominant financial institution.
Much of the investment in Hong Kong is going into factories that take advantage of China's low wages. Hong Kong's economy has been slowly merging with that of neighboring Guangdong Province in China, economists say. For instance, two million Chinese work in Hong Kong-run factories on the mainland, Mr. McLean said, nearly triple the 780,000 who work in factories in the colony. More than 80 percent of Hong Kong's re-exports, the fastest-growing sector of the territory's trade, are coming from or going to China. A re-export is merchandise imported and then shortly exported to a third country, usually with new packaging and in only slightly altered form.
 
Tourism Hurt
But these links cannot counter the pessimism many in Hong Kong feel when they consider life under Communist rule. Stung by the harsh face the Chinese Government showed in last year's crackdown, Hong Kong's economy posted no growth in the first half of this year, and inflation is close to double-digit levels. Tourism and hotel occupancy are down significantly.
More than 1,000 people a week are emigrating from Hong Kong, in part to avoid living under Communist rule, causing a serious brain drain. Now there is a worry that commercial fraud, already a problem, may flourish as many accountants depart.
Improbable as it may seem, these serious problems have not completely squelched the territory's economic spirit. Nearly every conversation in Hong Kong is interrupted by the sound of jackhammers or other construction equipment as old buildings fall and new ones go up at a furious pace.
From the top of the new 70-story Bank of China tower, the famous harbor looks like a spoiled child's bathtub full of toys. The water last week was jammed with ferries, lighters, tugs, dozens of container vessels and an American aircraft carrier.
Making the best of a bad situation, one company has even been marketing Rice Paddy Babies, toy dolls dressed up as Chinese and described as Hong Kong residents seeking to emigrate and looking for ''sponsors.''
The stock market's sudden surge is regarded as similarly opportunistic. ''We have been surprised by the strength of the market,'' said Mr. McLean of the Hongkong Bank. ''We thought it would take the whole year to get back where it is.''
 
Many Are Cautious
Pleased as many are with the market's new life, there remains an unmistakable undercurrent of caution.
''It's a difficult feeling to come to grips with,'' said Philip L. Tose, chairman of Peregrine Capital Ltd., a merchant bank. ''Sure, things are bubbly on the surface, but you crack that surface and just underneath there are real problems. Confidence today is very shallow. We are going to have more shocks in Hong Kong.''
Mr. Tose is among those who have benefited most from Hong Kong's revival. He founded Peregrine with some partners in January 1989 after leaving the securities unit here of Citicorp. The company weathered the stock crash after the June 4 crackdown in China, and went on to conclude two takeovers and several asset sales, reaping tens of millions of dollars in windfall profits and a listing on the Hong Kong stock market.
''We've made much, much more money than we thought we would,'' Mr. Tose acknowledged. ''Frankly, luck is better than brains. But there's still a lot to do here.''
He added: ''Everyone was deeply shocked by what happened last June, and that won't go away. People are skeptical now, but on the whole they want to stay here. Hong Kong is a great place to do business.''
 
Trading Status Stressed
Many also emphasize the importance of President Bush's decision on China's trading status in rebuilding confidence in Hong Kong. There had been pressure on the United States to suspend favored-nation status for China because of the country's reported human rights violations. Many members of Congress, which must confirm the President's decision, still express those concerns.
The most-favored-nation listing sharply reduces tariffs and duties charged on products originating in China. Since so much of China's trade flows through the colony or is produced in Hong Kong-owned factories, a crimp in China's exports to the United States would have hit hard here.
What heartened many was the role Hong Kong played in the Administration's decision. ''Were it not for Hong Kong, most people would have been in favor of suspension,'' said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who held hearings on the matter in Congress and was in Hong Kong last week.
''For the first time since last June 4, we believe Beijing saw Hong Kong as a political asset, not just an economic asset,'' added John Kamm, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, which fought to keep the favored-trade status for China.
But perhaps the most comforting aspect of the decision was that it suggested that politics was taking a back seat to basic economic interests, analysts here said.
''The real question for people here is whether they feel China or the United States will be pragmatic,'' said Mr. Rasmussen, the economist. ''They don't trust ideologies.''

LENGTH: 1188 words

HEADLINE: Telling Nation's Fortune: Does Consensus See All?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEDONA, Ariz.

 BODY:
In the mid-1970's, as Robert J. Eggert was about to retire as chief economist for RCA, he figured the company would want to continue his practice of conducting regular private surveys of what economic forecasters thought about the future. After all, he had begun the surveys with the encouragement of RCA's chairman, David Sarnoff.
Mr. Eggert was wrong - and mildly offended - but, as it turns out, hardly sorry. He took the idea with him and in the last 14 years the erstwhile agriculture specialist has built his Blue Chip Consensus newsletter into a publication that provides a six-figure income and has made him the nation's best-known tabulator of prevailing business sentiment. 
 
Polls 51 Analysts
From an office overlooking spectacular red-sandstone buttes here in north-central Arizona, Mr. Eggert, who is 76 years old, polls his stable of 51 business, bank and academic analysts at the end of each month on the outlook for the gross national product, inflation and a dozen other economic gauges. He mails the results to reach his roughly 1,500 subscribers by about the 10th of the next month.
The newest report, dated Tuesday, July 10, finds the consensus predicting that the G.N.P. will expand 1.9 percent this year, the same pace that had been forecast last month. That is two-tenths of a point higher than the 1.7 percent consensus given when the group took its first stab at 1990 growth in January of 1989.
Such a lackluster output has been predicted for more than four years now. The top of Blue Chip's cover has been yellow - indicating caution -since the spring of 1986. The top of the cover may also be red or green, depending on the analysts' view.
As it happens, the Government's first-quarter figure for the annual rate of expansion - after a large downward and a large upward revision - was 1.9 percent. The Government's first estimate for the second quarter will come out on July 27.
The latest issue also forecasts that G.N.P. will grow 2.2 percent next year, a tenth of a point lower than expected last month. If that comes to pass, an economy that looks fragile today will set a record late next year for uninterrupted expansion, breaking the 1961-69 mark, which was helped by the Vietnam War.
But like many other economists, Mr. Eggert's group has for several years predicted a recession just over the horizon. After seeing the economy move ahead for nearly eight years, the group sees the so-called inevitable downturn two years from now, in 1992. In most past surveys, a recession was seen in the following year.
 
Record Hard to Assess
It is hard to verify conclusively, but Mr. Eggert calls his newsletter's record a good one, with an average miss on inflation-adjusted G.N.P. during his first 13 years of one percentage point.
In the 1977-83 period, the difference between the G.N.P. as predicted in October and the actual outcome 14 months later averaged 1.1 points. This included an embarrassment in 1982, when the consensus failed to anticipate the 1981-82 recession, the worst of the postwar era. Blue Chip predicted a 2.2 gain and the result was a 2.5 percent decline - a 4.7-point disparity.
For the 1984-89 period, the performance improved to an average miss of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
In seven years Blue Chip was too low, in five too high and in 1980 it hit G.N.P. right on the nose. G.N.P. is generally considered the most important single broad indicator of economic strength.
While the markets do not quiver in anticipation of the Eggert surveys, which cost subscribers $439 a year, there appears good reason to take them seriously. Considerable evidence in economic literature indicates that over time, the consensus of a large group of forecasters outperforms the predictions of any individual.
''The consensus seems to have that uncanny ability,'' said Mr. Eggert, who has been forecasting one thing or another, including livestock prices and automobile sales - since 1936. He includes his own independently calculated predictions in the survey.
 
Missed 1981-82 Recession
But many of Blue Chip's readers say they do not rely heavily on the numbers it publishes. Some use the 8-to-10-page survey mainly as a benchmark against which to measure their own views or to see what people they hold in particular esteem are saying.
That list includes such Blue Chip Consensus participants as Stuart G. Hoffman, head economist for the Pittsburgh National Bank.
''You can scan the list of those with a good track record and see how they stack up,'' Mr. Hoffman said, adding that he also looks at the forecasts of some other people or institutions that have been wrong, hoping they have a different outlook than he does.
This is one of the features that sets Blue Chip apart from most other forecast tabulations, like the quarterly finds of the National Association of Business Economists, whose respondents are more numerous but anonymous. Another publication, the twice-yearly Livingston Survey, identifies its participants but reports their aggregate expectations.
 
Some Criticism
But despite Blue Chip's frequency and specificity, some subscribers, like Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, are not totally enthusiastic. In Mr. Platt's case that is partly because the consensus figures shift so slowly that he says they fail to pick up, for example, quarter-to-quarter swings vital to people managing stock or bond portfolios.
He says he feels no need to be reassured that he is swimming with the crowd. ''Being part of the consensus is not a major factor in my thinking,'' Mr. Platt said. Mr. Eggert, who grudgingly succumbed to requests and added quarterly breakdowns about 10 years ago, says he is not fond of them himself. Another disagreeable practice, he says, is the increased use, particularly at the White House, of presentations showing economic performance from fourth-quarter to fourth-quarter rather than year-to-year, which he says further complicates analysis.
 
Policy Counters Excesses
Critics also suggest that the records of Mr. Eggert and other consensus-reliant forecasters may appear more praiseworthy than is deserved. This is because Government policy makers are constantly tugging at the economy in ways that tend to counter excesses, pulling actual results back toward the consensus.
Mr. Eggert draws on a long career as a college professor, associate director of marketing for the American Meat Institute, wartime Government price controller, and forecaster and market researcher for the Ford Motor Company leading up to his eight-year stint at RCA.
He says Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation chairman, was not the father of the Mustang when he was at Ford. Mr. Eggert says that his wife suggested the Mustang name after reading a book on horses and that he did much of the market research for the hugely successful car aimed at a new generation of youthful car buyers.
When not polling his ''cooperators'' by telephone or facsimile machine, which allows Mr. Eggert to boast of the highest telephone bill in this town of 12,000, he is breeding quarter horses, making speeches or playing tennis.

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Berry of Dominion Resources;
Electricity Use Expected to Rise

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Because of the heat last week, the demand for electricity rose so greatly in Washington that the local power company blacked out parts of its territory, again raising the question of whether electricity supplies are adequate.
Dominion Resources Inc. of Richmond sees the question from two sides; its utility subsidiary, the Virginia Electric Power Company, serves much of eastern Virginia and North Carolina and sometimes supplies excess power to Washington, while an unregulated subsidiary, Dominion Energy, builds independent power plants around the country and sells the electricity to utilities. The company's chairman and chief executive officer, William W. Berry, talked about what will be built, and why.
Q. Virginia Electric has predicted it will need 40 percent more power by 2000. Why? 
A. We have a very vibrant economy down here that's been going strong for seven or eight years steady, with very robust growth, in the 4 percent range per year. We're expecting the 2.5 percent range in the 90's.
Q. Will you build or buy from independent producers?
A. We're going to do both. A big block of it will come from independents. We're buying and building, choosing at any particular time which of those two would be the best deal.
Q. The current law bars utility holding companies from having majority interest in a large number of independent power producers.
What is the effect of barring companies like yours from full ownership?
A. The cost of electricity will be higher than it needs to be. Economical projects that would have succeeded in the marketplace will not be there. So the next best project will be purchased, and it will cost more.
Q. Is building those plants a good business?
A. The competition is ferocious. Utilities that go out for bids are getting 9 or 10 times the offers that they need. It started out with very high returns, a very profitable business with the early independent contracts. Then everybody and his brother runs into the marketplace, and profit margins tighten up. Some people fail, other folks gobble them up. There certainly is a shakeout going on in independent power plants right now. But that may be good news for utility customers.
Q. Should all utilities be soliciting bids from independent producers?
A. A utility would be foolish not to test the marketplace. That doesn't mean they should blindly go out and buy from an independent. We've had cases in Virginia where bids offered were higher than what we thought we could build it for, and we in fact built it for less than we estimated. But certainly it is prudent management to test that market and find out what prices are. It puts a market test on utility construction. Then they go back to the state regulator and say we can build it cheaper than anybody else.
Q. Can't energy efficiency cut the need for new plants?
A. We are not getting as much conservation as we should, because we are not showing the customer the right price. In many places, we are underpricing electricity. We are selling at the historical cost, instead of the marginal cost. You can have current marginal costs that are considerably above prices that are based on history. There are two solutions to that. You can change the price of electricity, or devise some mechanism to encourage that conservation outside of price. The second is more complicated, but probably politically more acceptable.
Q. How do you encourage conservation apart from price?
A. You can do it with information, for example, with an Energy Saver Home certification program. Builders promote that, if the house is certified by Virginia Power as being energy efficient. Or, you can make the direct subsidy. I can give you $100 if you get more efficient refrigerator. But making that fair to everyone is complicated. The second problem is people don't invest in measures that make sense because the market is inefficient. The best example is a renter who is not paying electric bills.
Q. Should we be trying harder to conserve?
A. Yes. In the second half of the 90's, prices are going up again, and you're going to see a lot of conservation. It's too bad we're out of sync. We should be seeing that conservation now.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William W. Berry (Dominion Resources)

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Rose By $3.9 Billion in May

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Americans took out $3.9 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in May, 10 times the amount incurred only a month earlier, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.5 percent, up from the previous month's six-tenths of 1 percent growth rate. Net new debt in April totaled $390 million. 
It was the highest annual rate of increase since a 7.5 percent rate in October, when Americans borrowed $4.4 billion more than they paid off.
The May increase was concentrated in credit card debt, which rose $3.1 billion, or an annual rate of 18.5 percent.
Consumers, who account for about two-thirds of United States economic activity, had appeared to be more cautious in their borrowing and spending in recent months.
Analysts had attributed the slower pace to high interest rates, waning confidence because of adverse economic news and to the high level of debt already held by many Americans.
 
Annualized Rate of Credit
The annualized rate of credit growth for the first five months of 1990 was 3 percent, down from the 7.6 percent for all of 1989 and 8.5 percent for 1988.
At the same time, Americans' savings rate - savings as a percentage of disposable income - has been pegged above 6 percent for several months after dropping to a low of 3.2 percent for all of 1987.
Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said varying methods of computing economic statistics were used by different government agencies and occasionally produced different results.
The Commerce Department's retail sales reports, which have fallen for three consecutive months, do not include services, like health care, and have a smaller survey sample than the Fed's consumer credit reports, Mr. Benz said.
He also said that April borrowing was weak and that the May borrowing was ''somewhat of a payback.''
''Consumers are not dying,'' Mr. Benz said. ''Perhaps they're a little more cautious, definitely slowing, but by no means do we have a recession scenario.''
Automobile loans continued to decline in May, but at a slower rate, They dropped $87 million, a four-tenths of 1 percent rate of decline, compared with a net decline of $2 billion in automobile debt the previous month.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $533 million, a 3.1 percent annual rate, after a 4 percent annual growth rate in April.
Borrowing for mobile homes increased $325 million, a 17.2 percent annual rate of growth, after a three-tenths of 1 percent decline the previous month.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of May at $724.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Lease Improves Trump's Financial Picture

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The long-term lease that Donald J. Trump signed yesterday with Galeries Lafayette is worth between $50 and $65 million, bankers said.
The 25-year lease for 80,000 square feet in Trump Tower, which represents the largest retail real estate deal in New York this year, is substantially more profitable for the developer than the previous lease that was held by Bonwit Teller, which closed earlier this year.
But while nearly double the annual value of the Bonwit lease, the new contract has several protective clauses for Galeries Lafayette. It also offers the retailer free rent for the first year. 
Galeries Lafayette's rent for the prime retail space is structured on a sliding scale, with the first five years costing more than $6 million annually and gradually rising to about $9 million annually thereafter, the bankers said. It has the option to renew the agreement after 15 years. Bonwit was paying Mr. Trump about $3.5 million annually and that sum was scheduled to increase to about $4.2 million next year.
The French retailer will not move into the space until sometime next fall, but according to the Trump Organization, it will take possession of the space within a few days. According to the Trump Organization, Galeries Lafayette will spend eight or nine months redesigning the space and will pay for all improvements.
 
A Strengthened Market
The Bonwit Teller lease was signed in September 1979, while New York was in a financial crisis and the local real estate market was extremely depressed. In part, the higher rent for Galeries Lafayette reflects an improved New York real estate market.
While the Bonwit lease left Mr. Trump with the rights of approval over almost everything concerned with the space, like lighting or exterior design, the lease negotiated by the French retailer is structured to minimize Mr. Trump's control. It stipulates that Galeries Lafayette can remain in the space even if Mr. Trump has to file for bankruptcy protection or sell Trump Tower.
Bankers said that the French retailer was concerned that the developer might have been forced into personal bankruptcy during his cash shortage last month, while negotiations on the lease were going on.
At a news conference yesterday morning, Georges Meyer, the chairman of Galeries Lafayette, praised Salomon Brothers and Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz for putting the deal together.
The Galeries Lafayette lease helps improve the developer's financial condition because he can borrow between $50 million and $65 million against the lease and because it adds income to the Trump Tower property against which the banks can better secure their loans to the developer.
David Sklar, a vice president of the Trump Organization, said Mr. Trump had turned down other more lucrative offers for the space.
''We had several choices and we opted to go with Galeries because we thought it would be more exciting than other stores in the New York area,'' Mr. Sklar said.

HEADLINE: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 9

 BODY:
Eager to give its corporate clients worldwide an opportunity to deal in futures and options, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation of Japan said today that it would form a venture with the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd., one of this country's leading traders of options and futures.
A spokesman for the 50-50 venture, Michael Weiser, said that broadly speaking Chicago Research would contribute expertise, Mitsubishi Trust would contribute most of the $150 million in start-up capital and both organizations would contribute personnel. But all the terms of the joint venture, which will focus on futures and options contracts in interest rates and currencies, were not disclosed.
 
Changes for Both
The deal will enhance Mitsubishi Trust's ability to compete globally with other banks that already offer futures and options, and at the same time will make Chicago Research a different sort of firm. Until now a proprietary firm - that is, one that traded principally for its own account - Chicago Research, after the joint venture, will be working with outsiders, chiefly corporations and other institutional investors. 
Malcolm Hanney, a Chicago Research executive vice president, added that the deal ''will provide Chicago Research serious access to the Japanese market and corporate business in Japan.''
The joint venture appeared to be unusual in a number of ways.
Although Japanese financial institutions have entered into business arrangements with United States financial institutions in the past - Sumitomo Life, for instance, owns part of Goldman, Sachs; Nippon Life owns part of Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Yasuda Life owns part of Paine Webber - the Japanese have been passive investors in those deals. Similarly, in a highly publicized joint venture operating in Japan, Wells Fargo is a passive investor in a money management joint venture with the Nikko Securities Corporation.
 
Active Japanese Involvement
In the Chicago Research-Mitsubishi Trust joint venture, by comparison, both partners will have exactly 50 percent ownership. Moreover, the Japanese are expected to send representatives to Chicago to be actively involved in policy making.
Additionally, this appeared to mark the first time that the Japanese were formally joining forces with an American firm that dealt strictly in futures and options in this country. Another major futures and options trading firm based here, O'Connor & Associates, a direct competitor of Chicago Research, has a link with the Swiss Bank Corporation.
For its part, Mitsubishi Trust has been eager to learn more about and participate in the options and futures fields. Many of its corporate clients do business globally and would like to use futures and options for protection against swings in interest and currency rates. But Mitsubishi Trust does not own a seat on either the Chicago Board of Trade or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the two principal futures exchanges here. Mitsubishi Bank, which does own a seat on the Mercantile Exchange, is a separate organization.
 
'Seeking Out Expertise'
''They are seeking out expertise, and this will significantly enhance their ability in these areas,'' said Mr. Hanney, the Chicago Research executive vice president, referring to Mitsubishi Trust.
The joint venture will solidify what has been an informal but increasingly close-knit relationship between Mitsubishi Trust and Chicago Research. The two first started talking about doing business together in April 1987, when Mitsubishi provided Chicago Research with $37 million in capital by purchasing subordinated bonds. Those bonds were rolled over last year, when Mitsubishi increased its money outstanding to Chicago Research to $45 million.
A Mitsubishi Trust official in New York, Makoto Oikawa, referred requests for comment to Mitsubishi Trust's headquarters in Tokyo. Because the announcement was made in the middle of the night in Japan, there was no answer there.

HEADLINE: Sallie Mae Prices $600 Million Issue

 BODY:
The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced a $600 million issue yesterday in its regular monthy sale. The Government-sponsored public corporation usually sells short-term floating-rate notes on the Monday before the second Thursday of each month, The notes, due Jan. 10, 1991, were priced at par to yield 25 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill and are expected to begin trading today. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Sallie Mae said the interest rate, which is to be adjusted on the day after each Treasury bill auction, would be paid at maturity.
The notes are being offered in the United States and in the Eurodollar market through various securities-dealer selling groups managed by Sallie Mae.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day As Pound Continues to Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed in light domestic trading yesterday as currency traders kept a close watch on the economic summit meeting in Houston but had little news to act upon.
Gold prices, meanwhile, fell. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped $2.90 from late Friday to settle at $358.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $357.40, off $2.80. 
Currency dealers said trading in the British pound yesterday was the most active feature of the foreign exchange markets.
Sterling was helped by continued expectation that Britain would soon join Europe's exchange rate mechanism. The mechanism limits exchange rate movements, and the markets expect it will strengthen the currency.
The pound was also supported by comments from Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, that the recent strength of the pound was no fluke but reflected the currency's true value. He spoke at the Houston meeting of the leaders of the seven richest industrial nations.
''Sterling remains extremely strong across the board,'' said Robert Hatcher, a corporate currency dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York.
In London, a pound was quoted at $1.8055, up strongly from late Friday's $1.7865. The pound had not been above $1.8000 in London since Jan. 4, 1989. Later, in New York trading, a pound cost $1.8080, compared with $1.7865 late Friday.
Against the Japanese currency, a dollar bought 151.15 yen in New York trading, down from 151.70 yen late Friday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar had closed at 150.70 yen, down 0.25 yen from Friday's close. And in London, it was quoted at 151.10 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.6528 West German marks, up from 1.6515; 1.3965 Swiss francs, down from 1.3983; 5.5460 French francs, up from 5.5435; 1,211.25 Italian lire, down from 1,211.50, and 1.1586 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1619.
Gold in London was quoted at a late bid of $358.15 an ounce, down from late Friday's $361.25. In Zurich, gold was quoted at $357.90 an ounce, down from $361.25 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Graduates Find Tighter Job Market

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THIS year's college graduates are having a harder time finding jobs than did the class of 1989, say Lee J. Svete, director of the office of career planning at St. Lawrence University, a liberal arts college in Canton, N.Y., and Vicki Lynn, director of the career development center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy.
Mr. Svete said last week that he believed that the job market had not been so competitive since 1982, although he added that ''I have no statistics yet to back my statement.''
The difficulties at some Wall Street firms have had ''a domino effect'' on other companies that had hired regularly on campus in the past, he said.
A few years ago Mrs. Lynn was pleasantly surprised at the large demand for Rensselaer graduates by Wall Street firms. Now, she says, job openings there have almost vanished, except for a small demand from J. P. Morgan & Company, and some other large commercial banks. 
''Overall demand has been slow or flat this year with a few exceptions,'' she said last week.
Of the 800 members of the Rensselaer graduating class, the 30 chemical engineering majors fared the best, Mrs. Lynn said, adding that ''they received multiple offers and all have found good jobs at $35,000 and more.'' Also, there is a nationwide shortage and strong demand for civil engineers, she said, because of the need to repair the nation's infrastructure - bridges and roads mainly.
Many big companies that traditionally hire young engineers from schools like Rensselaer have been virtually out of the recruiting market this year, she said, citing electronics and computer companies.
''I.B.M. did virtually no recruiting here and Digital Equipment pulled back, as did many of the Route 128 companies in Massachusetts like Prime Computer and Wang Laboratories,'' she said. Similarly, Eastman Kodak, in past years a large recruiter, as well as Xerox, did little recruiting on Rensselaer's campus, she added.
However, among the more traditional recruiters, General Electric offered jobs to 15 seniors this spring, and United Technologies, despite cuts in military spending, took eight seniors.
''The whole hiring picture has changed, and the bulk of the recruiting this year has come from firms that did not have much visibility in previous years with us,'' Mrs. Lynn said.
For example, the Andersen Consulting Company, an affiliate of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, has been ''scooping up all the graduates who might have gone in former years to I.B.M. -about 30 of them this spring,'' according to Mrs. Lynn.
Most openings at Andersen Consulting called for systems analysts to help solve business problems for clients. Mrs. Lynn said the students liked the idea of joining Andersen because many graduates in previous years had reached the partner level in the consulting firm.
She believes that graduates in recent years tend to stress the quality of life and interest in free time more than they did formerly, and they have less drive for working on a fast track with a big company.
''I saw a 1989 graduate the other day,'' Mrs. Lynn said. ''He had a 3.5 grade point average and had been very active on campus. He came for counseling, saying he was unhappy at I.B.M. and now wants to teach at the high school level.'' As a chemical engineer graduate he could teach physics, mathematics and chemistry, she added.
In fact, she said, Rensselaer had recently developed a teaching component so that its engineers or scientists could take courses to fulfill state teaching requirememts.
At St. Lawrence University, one antidote to the more competitive job market is the emphasis on double majors, according to Mr. Svete. He cited the example of a 1989 graduate, a psychology major, who now worked for Chicago's Brookfield Zoo.
He said the number of double majors had increased almost every year. In an annual follow-up survey of the class of 1989 he found that 79, or more than 14 percent of the class of 553 students, had taken double majors. ''Double majors are on the rise, especially for liberal arts graduates,'' he said, ''because they offer more flexiblity.''
His study, ''What Happened to the Class of 1989?,'' showed that 32 percent obtained jobs through direct application to employers and 29 percent found jobs with the help of personal contacts. He thinks the personal contact route, especially contacts with alumni, will be a growing source of jobs in the future. He plans a survey of the class of 1990 this fall.
At Rensselaer, Mrs. Lynn stresses meetings with parents so as to tell them how their sons and daughters should approach the job market. About 69 percent of the students get in contact with her career office before graduation, she said, but she would like to see 100 percent, starting in the freshman year.
''Career planning should be mandatory,'' she said, explaining that her office can inform students of prospects for certain careers, tell them about research projects where they can gain experience and advise on summer jobs and on how to meet alumni who can help.
