HEADLINE: United Parcel to Alter Its Trucks In Los Angeles to Use Natural Gas

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 10

 BODY:
The United Parcel Service said today that it planned to convert its 2,700 delivery trucks in the smog-choked Los Angeles area to run on cleaner-burning natural gas in the first major step by a company to comply with strict new vehicle-emissions laws here.
The action by United Parcel, which operates one of the nation's largest truck fleets, was applauded by local officials as evidence that the region's new anti-smog rules, the nation's toughest, can be met on schedule and as evidence that Southern California can be a model for nationwide efforts to improve air quality.
''This is a major breakthrough in alternative fuels that we think will be a harbinger of things to come,'' Mayor Tom Bradley said at a news conference announcing the company's plan.
 
Plan for the Next Century
The Los Angeles basin has more than 7.5 million vehicles and suffers from the worst smog problem in the country, with air quality failing to meet Federal standards more than half the days of the year. Air quality regulators last year approved a plan calling for 40 percent of cars and 70 percent of trucks in the region to run on cleaner fuels like natural gas, methanol and electricity by 1998. By 2007, the plan calls for all vehicles to use such alternative fuels. 
United Parcel will begin by converting 20 trucks in conjunction with the Southern California Gas Company and operating them, starting early next year, in downtown Los Angeles. Assuming the initial conversions work as expected, the company and Government officials said, United Parcel would convert the rest of its more than 2,000 gasoline-powered trucks in the next five years, followed by several hundred diesel-powered vehicles.
Siro DeGasperis, a vice president of United Parcel, said the company eventually plans to convert to natural gas all its trucks in cities with air problems. He said such a shift would involve about half the company's total fleet of more than 100,000 distinctive brown trucks. There was no timetable for the changeover, he said.
Conversion involves installing three cylinders capable of holding 15 gallons of compressed natural gas, enough to drive 60 to 80 miles on city streets, within the daily range of a United Parcel truck in an urban area. The system also requires regulators to reduce the pressure of the gas as it is fed first into a device that mixes the natural gas with air and then into the truck's standard gasoline engine.
 
Test Program in Brooklyn
United Parcel has been running a test program in Brooklyn with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, involving 10 natural gas-fueled vehicles, and plans to expand the program into Manhattan in conjunction with the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. Mr. DeGasperis said the company is also planning projects soon in Dallas and Houston.
''Ultimately, nationwide, our goal is to experiment and expand the program to most urban areas with an air quality problem,'' he said.
In the Brooklyn test, each of the 10 vehicles cost $3,000 to $3,500 to convert to natural gas, with the bulk of the cost paid by Brooklyn Union Gas, Mr. DeGasperis said. He said United Parcel is negotiating with Southern California Gas about sharing the cost of converting the trucks in the Los Angeles program.
The company also said it is working with the Acurex Corporation of San Francisco to develop a new natural gas-fueled engine specifically for its vehicles.
In the mid 1970's there were shortages of natural gas in the United States that led to rationing in some Northern and Eastern cities during winter months. But after natural gas prices were deregulated in the Carter Administration, exploration and drilling picked up so much that by the mid-1980's there was an abundant supply of natural gas.
Industry executives say supplies should remain more than adequate in coming years, even if natural gas becomes the alternative fuel of choice for vehicles. Among its advantages as a vehicle fuel, natural gas does not need to undergo any refining or processing, as methanol does, and it does not require any further technical breakthroughs, as electric-powered cars do. In addition, natural gas already has a widespread distribution network, with lines running into many homes and businesses.
 
Experiments With Buses
Spurred by California's regulations and the increasingly tough Federal rules, state and local governments, the automobile industry, oil companies and suppliers of electricity and natural gas are all working on programs to develop less-polluting vehicles.
A number of public transit authorities in California are experimenting with buses fueled by methanol, an alcohol-based fuel. The General Motors Corporation is developing an electric car that could be on sale here by the end of the decade if consumers show sufficient interest and if some technical hurdles can be overcome. And General Motors is expected to announce within the next several weeks that it will build trucks specifically designed to run on natural gas, eliminating the need for costly conversions from traditional gasoline and diesel engines.
There are currently about 30,000 vehicles in the United States that can run on natural gas, most of them operated by gas companies and other businesses with large fleets of vehicles that return to a central maintenance and refueling station each night. Many were converted from gasoline in the 1970's, when high gasoline prices made natural gas an attractive alternative on economic grounds.
But most of the research in the field is now driven by air quality concerns rather than fuel prices. Natural gas costs about 25 percent less per mile than gasoline.
Based on its test program in Brooklyn, which began a year ago, United Parcel said use of natural gas significantly reduced emissions of the gases that cause smog. Emissions of carbon monoxide were reduced by 85 percent, nitrogen oxide by 25 percent, carbon dioxide by 23 percent and hydrocarbons by 13 percent.
In another move intended to cut the pollution on California's roads, the Ford Motor Company plans to announce Wednesday that it will give a $700 rebate to residents of the Los Angeles area who trade in older cars without pollution equipment when they buy certain new models of the company's cars.
Company officials acknowledge that the program, which will affect only about 1,000 vehicles, is largely a symbolic gesture that will have little effect on air pollution.
To qualify for the Ford plan, the vehicles must have been manufactured before 1971, and they must be registered to residents of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino or Ventura counties.
The $700 certificates issued by Ford will be good toward the purchase of one of the company's smaller models, including Escort and Festiva.

HEADLINE: THE HOUSTON SUMMIT;
SUMMIT IS DIVIDED ON AID TO MOSCOW

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 10

 BODY:
The leaders of seven major industrial democracies effectively agreed today to go their own way on the matter of aid to the Soviet Union, European and American officials said tonight.
Failing to establish a unified approach to the aid issue in hard-fought negotiations on the second day of the economic summit meeting here, the leaders instead agreed to establish a joint task force and to study the question and make non-binding recommendations by the end of the year.
The industrial nations also issued a political declaration today, which included an acknowledgement of recent lessening of repression in China and an agreement to ease sanctions imposed last year if the progress continues. [The text of the political declaration is on page A4.] The action on Soviet aid cleared the way for West Germany and other European countries to give President Mikhail S. Gorbachev an immediate reward for his liberalization efforts, even though the United States has continued to argue against quick moves to financial aid, British and West German officials said. 
 
Role by Big Lending Agencies
The study task force, to be coordinated by the International Monetary Fund with the assistance of four other lending and development institutions, will issue its findings by the end of the year. The summit nations will be free to accept or reject them, the European officials said.
A senior White House official said the study would be ''a good mechanism for forcing change in the Soviet Union.''
The official said the Bush Administration had not committed itself to embarking on financial aid, regardless of what the task force reported. He added, ''They could say that lending money to these people is stuffing money down a rat hole.''
An economic statement to be released Wednesday will include the details of the Soviet aid agreement and other matters.
The position taken on China was the result of a heated negotiating session among top officials that lasted until 1:30 A.M. today, as the Japanesse insisted on the need to reward Chinese moves toward liberalization and the French, among others, argued for maintaining the tough line adopted after last year's crackdown on the democracy movement, Japanese and French officials said.
 
Fight Over Farm Subsidies
On another contentious topic, agricultural policy, the leaders and their advisers continued to debate well into the night over the extent to which the countries would agree to reduce their farm subsidies.
As the three-day meeting passed its midpoint, officials of the seven nations raced to find broad diplomatic formulas that would maintain the appearance of a collective approach while permitting individual leaders to pursue their divergent courses.
On China, the talks appeared to have succeeded by adopting a vaguely worded compromise while deferring action on concrete steps.
On the Soviet Union, which was the leaders' major preoccupation, the search for a consensus produced a joint effort to study the Soviet Union's problems, rather than dictating specific means to address those problems.
And on agricultural subsidies, which became the most time-consuming issue, the national leaders fought a battle over economic prerogatives and the protection of their rural domestic constituencies.
 
U.S. Presses View
President Bush made a commitment for a worldwide reduction in farm subsidies his highest priority at the economic summit meeting. Officials from other countries said they were surprised by the force with which Mr. Bush pressed the view that agricultural price supports should be lowered and eventually abolished.
The Americans maintain that if the industrial countries do not lift their farm subsidies - tariffs and quotas on imports, subsidies for exports and price supports for farmers - the current round of trade-liberalization talks will break down.
The result, Mr. Bush has told the other leaders, would be to stifle worldwide economic growth. But the European countries, which subsidize farmers much more generously than do the United States and Canada, continued to balk today at making firm commitments to change their policies.
Mrs. Thatcher offered a European proposal this morning that became the basis for the day's debate, but it proved unacceptable to Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.
The Thatcher proposal would have committed each country to reducing its total farm subsidies but would have set no timetable for doing so.
British and West German officials said throughout the day that they hoped the plan would lead to a breakthrough.
 
Comment by Brady
But United States officials rejected the proposal, as they have in other forums over the years, on the ground that it would not lead to abolition of export subsidies. The Americans view those as the worst form of agriculture protection.
As the staff experts worked late in search of a face-saving compromise, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady declared: ''The European Community has a well-defined position. The United States has a well-defined position. Those positions basically haven't changed in essence.''
Concluding almost two weeks of discussions that began at the NATO conference in London last week, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed to take distinctly different approaches to Soviet aid, officials of both nations said.
Whatever formula emerges will permit West Germany to offer Moscow immediate and direct financial assistance as the price of Soviet acquiesence to rapid reunification of Germany while the United States continues to insist that only technical assistance, but not cash, are appropriate until Moscow is firmly committed to reorganizing its economy on a free-market basis.
Presenting the meeting's political declaration this afternoon, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d insisted that all seven nations supported the process of economic and political liberalization in the Soviet Union, ''so I would hope and believe that with respect to the question of economic assistance to the Soviet Union, a way could be found for a positive response and reaction to the request that has come from the Soviet Union.''
But, he added, ''We still have to resolve the questions of the scope and degree and extent of assistance to the Soviet Union.''
 
German Aid to Soviets
Secretary Brady said tonight of German plans to begin an aid program for the Soviet Union, ''There was no discussion on their part of slowing down or reducing their aid to the Soviet Union.''
A senior German negotiator described the following timetable for future decision-making: A study of the Soviet economy commissioned by the 12-nation European Community at its meeting in Dublin last month will be delivered in October.
Then, the study commissioned today will be delivered at the end of the year. The group of seven nations meeting here will only formulate collective policies after both studies have been completed, and in the meantime each will pursue its own initiatives.
Chancellor Kohl came to the Houston talks promoting a $15 billion package of aid to the Soviet Union that would begin soon. President Bush said that while he would not try to stop the Germans or criticize them, the United States did not favor financial assistance until economic reforms progressed enough to create a working market economy. Instead, American negotiators promoted technical assistance as the best form of aid.
On Monday night, Mr. Baker attempted to break the impasse by presenting the concept of a study commission to a dinner meeting of foreign ministers. He suggested that the two Washington-based lending institutions should evaluate Soviet progress in moving toward a market economy.
 
French Are Cautious
At a full session of the conference this morning, President Francois Mitterrand of France and other European leaders expressed reservations about giving the two banks such an important role, because they often impose very strict conditions on governements receiving aid.
President Mitterrand's spokesman, Hubert Vedrine, explained France's reservations this afternoon, saying, ''We have to remember that the Soviet Union is a sovereign country that can easily be humiliated and we must avoid that.''
Other European officials expressed concern that the formula proposed by Mr. Baker could potentially give the United States too strong a role because of its influence over the two international banks.
As a result, the seven foreign ministers were directed to meet this afternoon to resolve the question. After four hours they emerged with the task-force plan. In addition to the IMF and the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development based in London and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development based in Paris will take part in the study. Also, the European Community study group will collaborate with the summit task force. How Cordial? Mr. Vedrine said tonight, ''This is a summit where there is a good deal of work being done because the major issues were not resolved in advance and some still are not.''
Asked by a reporter whether this could be described as a summit of ''cordial misunderstanding,'' he responded, ''I will leave that to you.''
Cordial misuderstanding perhaps most appropriately described the handling of China. Radically different assessments of what is happening in that nation were offered by different Governments here, and in the end the summit leaders agreed to a hastily formulated statement that allowed each to pursue its own China policy.
The one paragraph in the political declaration begins by stating, ''We acknowledge some of the recent developments in China, but believe that the prospects for closer cooperation will be enhanced by renewed political and economic reform, particularly in the field of human rights.''
A senior Canadian official who took part in drafting of the statement said that positive developments like the release of the dissident leader Fang Lizhi ''are not enough to constitute a clearly visible trend.''
Taizo Watanabe, chief Japanese spokesman, said this afternoon that his Government wanted the summit ''to send a message to China that it should make further reforms and that they would be appreciated by the West.''
As a result, European officials said the meeting adopted language proposed by the Japanese stating that Chinese reform efforts would be kept under review ''for future adjustments to respond to further positive developments in China.''
Mr. Watanabe said that Japan took this statement to mean that it could now proceed with a previously planned five-year, $5.2 billion loan program to China.

GRAPHIC: Photo: On their way to lunch during a break in their meetings yesterday in Houston were, from the left, Jacques Delors of the European Community, Prime Ministers Giulio Andreotti of Italy, Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and Margaret Thatcher of Britain, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, President Francois Mitterrand of France, President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Ads That Bash the Japanese: Just Jokes or Veiled Racism?

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
American advertisers are stepping up their attacks on Japan and its people, attempting to thwart sales of Japanese products through commercials that feature ominous references to the late Emperor Hirohito, photographs of Samurai warriors, exaggerated accents and veiled ridicule of the Japanese physique.
Some advertisers say their commercials are meant to be humorous; others say they are seriously trying to exploit economic tensions between Japan and the United States to sell products. In either case, worried business executives and others with a special interest in Japanese-American relations say these marketers are crossing the thin line separating business competition from nationalism and even racism.
''People are concerned about the whole tone of the relationship,'' said John Wheeler, the vice president of the Japan Society, a private organization devoted to enhancing understanding between the two countries. ''There's so much at stake that these glib, facile cheap shots don't help.'' 
One current television commercial for Pontiac dealers in the New York metropolitan area opens with an announcer darkly projecting the future. ''Imagine a few years from now,'' he intones. ''It's December, and the whole family's going to see the big Christmas tree at Hirohito Center.''
''Go on,'' he says. ''Keep buying Japanese cars.''
The five commercials in the Pontiac series conclude with two words, written in stark white letters against the black screen: ''Enough already.''
Seigi Hinata, the director of the Japan Information Center at the Japanese Consulate General in New York, said, ''I can tell you that since Mitsubishi bought a part of Rockefeller Center, we have been seeing sentiments against Japan, and the Japanese in general.''
Mitsubishi acquired 51 percent of the New York landmark for $846 million late last year.
Most of the ads have been running on local television and radio stations throughout the country, as well as in newspapers and magazines, some since spring. The majority come from American automobile dealers, especially in the Northeast, who are being hurt by Japanese auto makers.
Local automobile dealer associations are independent of the auto manufacturers, and are generally free to hire their own ad agencies and develop advertising strategies without interference. In most cases, the manufacturers have neither commissioned nor approved of the Japan-bashing ads. The dealers believe they work, but some manufacturers apparently fear they might offend consumers.
Philip Guarascio, the head of advertising for the General Motors Corporation, the parent of Pontiac, would not comment directly on the issue, but questioned the ads' effectiveness. ''When you do comparative advertising, it should meet a certain set of standards, based on consumer needs,'' he said. ''And consumer needs tend to be positive in nature, not negative. To the degree you veer from that, you run risks.''
Japanese car makers produced a record 28 percent of all automobiles sold in the United States during the first half of 1990, up four percentage points from the comparable period last year. The market share for American-made autos dropped four percentage points, to 65 percent.
A commercial in the New York area for the Tri-State Oldsmobile Dealers compares the average height of American men with the shorter average height of Japanese men. The ad, which promotes the Cutlass Ciera, concludes, ''That's why our car is built for our size families, not theirs.''
The spate of anti-Japanese advertisements began last winter with a controversial campaign for Chrysler that featured the auto company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, complaining that consumers refused to believe that American cars could be as good as Japanese cars. But those commercials concentrated heavily on specific product attributes, and held Japanese manufacturing up as a standard of excellence. The ads worrying Japanese officials and scholars are less product-specific, and include references to the Japanese people and their culture.
Anti-Japanese ads have not gone unnoticed or uncriticized. In the spring, a consortium of Bell telephone operating companies placed a newspaper ad to promote legislation that would allow them to enter the information-generation business. The headline read: ''First it was consumer electronics. Then it was the automobile industry. Is our telecommunications industry next?'' Underneath was a photograph of a stern Samurai fighter, crouched and seemingly ready to pounce.
The ad was pulled and the agency, J. Walter Thompson, was dismissed after the Japanese Embassy complained about it, a Thompson spokeswoman said.
And Americans who do business with the Japanese say such advertisements could harm America's economic interests.
William Zeckendorf Jr., the chairman of the Zeckendorf Company, one of the nation's largest real estate developers, said Japanese investment had become increasingly important for American developers as domestic financing has tightened. He called anti-Japanese ads inappropriate. ''We need their financing,'' Mr. Zeckendorf said.
 
Imagery During War Recalled
Several scholars say the pictures and sentiments in these ads are uncomfortably similar to the anti-Japanese imagery that flooded American popular culture during World War II.
In his 1986 book, ''War Without Mercy: Race and Power in the Pacific War,'' John W. Dower, a historian at the University of California at San Diego, wrote that American mass-media portrayals of the Japanese as ''subhuman, inhuman, lesser human, superhuman'' were so pervasive during the war that they ''remain latent, capable of being revived by both sides in times of crisis and tension.''
Gerald L. Curtis, the director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia University, expressed concern that anti-Japanese ads were contributing to a cycle of escalating tensions between Japan and the United States.
The advertisers responsible for the ads say they are not meant to offend any group. Brett Shevack defended the Oldsmobile dealers' commercial created by his agency, Partners & Shevack.
''We think it is legitimate to bring in the differing heights because we did it with a sense of humor,'' Mr. Shevack said.
The executive director of the New York-New Jersey-Fairfield County Pontiac Dealers Advertising Association, Robert G. Conroy, said of his group's ''Enough Already'' ads: ''We don't think of them as anti-Japanese. We think of them as pro-American.'' Still, appealing to American nationalism was a conscious part of Pontiac's strategy, said David Deutsch, who runs Deutsch Advertising, the Pontiac dealers' ad agency.
''People are saying, 'We're buying all these Japanese products and they won't let ours in their country,'' he said. '' 'Enough already,' as we say it in the commercials, is our interpretation of the feelings people have.''
Mr. Conroy said he believed that the Pontiac dealers' commercials, which are aimed at men and women between the ages of 26 and 40 with annual household incomes of around $40,000, have been effective. Preliminary sales figures for June, he said, indicate that Pontiac sales among the 86 dealers in his association were the same as last June, despite a 38 percent drop in Pontiac sales in the Northeast during the first half of 1990.
Asked what he would consider going too far in a commercial, Mr. Conroy responded, ''When we mention Pearl Harbor, I guess.''

HEADLINE: Citing Extra Costs at 5 Airports, American Adds Ticket Surcharge

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
American Airlines, reacting to what it calls ''excessive charges'' imposed by five airports, plans to add ticket surcharges of $1 to $4 beginning next week for its flights from those airports.
Some consumer groups are objecting, saying the charges are another example, albeit an unusual one, of how airlines have tried to pass on costs to passengers.
American, the nation's largest airline, said yesterday that it was adding the surcharges on flights from LaGuardia Airport, Newark International Airport and airports in New Orleans, West Palm Beach, Fla., and Fort Myers, Fla. The airline is complaining that the fees it is charged for construction and other projects at these airports are excessive. 
More Than $4 Million crease American's revenues by more than $4 million each year, At La Guardia, the issue centers on the type of floor covering the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is using in a $14 million construction project in a terminal area shared by many airlines. American said the Port Authority had chosen a more expensive material than necessary. A Port Authority spokesman, Bill Cahill, said no other carrier had objected to the project.
Airlines have adopted similar surcharges in the past to pass on costs of fuel, security and other expenses, but rarely have they designated specific airports.
Robert Crandall, president of American, has a reputation for making bold moves - sometimes ruffling passengers' feathers and sometimes caressing them. It was American, for example, that began the frequent-flier program in the early 1980's that is now an industry staple.
Passengers already pay an 8 percent tax on all airline tickets, which is funneled into the Aviation Trust Fund for airport expansion, new air-traffic-control equipment and other improvements. The fund currently has a $6 billion surplus, but critics complain, that the Bush Administration has not used the money in order to help mask the budget deficit.
Legislation that would permit airports to impose a passenger facility charge, about $3, is under consideration in the House of Representatives. The bill, which has the support of the Administration, has mixed support from the airlines. Among its supporters is Mr. Crandall.
Some critics contend that Mr. Crandall is testing the waters with the new surcharges. The surcharges are small enough that they are not expected to significantly affect American's competitive position.
American expects to carry 1.5 million passengers from La Guardia and 455,900 at Newark this year. Based on those projections, the surcharges will generate $1.5 million annually at La Guardia, where the charge will be $1, and $1.8 million at Newark, where the fee will be $4., The surcharge will generate $685,000 at New Orleans, where the cost will be $1.50; $201,000 at West Palm Beach, where the fee will be $1, and $221,000 at Fort Myers, where the surcharge will also be $1.
At Newark, where American is expanding from three to six gates, the Port Authority is charging a higher gate fee than it did Northwest Airlines, which previously used the gates. At New Orleans, American added the surcharge because of what it called ''excessively high landing fees.'' At the two Florida airports, American made general objections to the fees it was charged.
David Shipley, a spokesman for US Air, which also has many flights from Newark and La Guardia, said it had no plans to adopt a similar surcharge, as did Neil Monroe, a spokesman for Delta Air Lines. A spokesman for United Airlines declined to comment.
Some consumer groups and passengers objected strenuously to news of the impending charges, which are scheduled to take effect on Sunday, and some airport officials accused American of using the surcharges as an excuse to raise profits.
''I find it offensive,'' said Chris Witkowski, executive director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a consumer group based in Washington. Mr. Witkowski said he feared that airlines ''will start assessing surcharges for every expense.''
David Livingston, president of Airline Passengers of North America, a consumer group, also objected. ''Every time the price of a legal pad goes up, you don't automatically pass it on to the client,'' he said.
 
'Need to Recover Costs'
Al Becker, a spokesman for American, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, said the surcharges were necessary and were intended merely to compensate for what the airline viewed as excessive airport fees. ''We are running a responsible business here and we need to recover costs,'' he added.
The surcharges will be included in the total fare quoted to consumers, both in telephone inquiries and in advertising.
They will be listed separately, however, on the ticket, and the specific reason for the surcharge will not be listed because of a lack of space, said Tim Smith, another American spokesman.
The surcharges will be added only once on a round-trip ticket and do not apply to connecting passengers.
Robert Inman, properties manager for West Palm Beach Airport, said American was attempting to ''make the public think'' that the surcharge was the airport's fault. He said that the fees American pays at West Palm Beach will actually drop by 14 percent beginning in October.
 
Less Than 10 Percent of Costs
Airports charge the carriers landing fees, based on airplane weight, and monthly rental fees for gates, terminal space and other facilities. These charges account for less than 10 percent of an airline's expenses, said Lee Howard, chairman of Airline Economics, a consulting firm. In recent years, as one or two airlines have come to dominate each airport, the carriers have enjoyed greater influence with airports in negotiating fees, and now have veto power over major expansion projects.
David Blackshear, director of airports for New Orleans, said that while the fees there were among the highest in the country, they were needed to generate the money for airport improvements. ''This is a gimmick to justify increased fares,'' he added. Mr. Blackshear, like other airport officials, said American had yet to inform him of its surcharge plan.
In the early 1980's, when fuel prices soared, many airlines imposed fuel surcharges. More recently, some airlines have imposed fuel surcharges of $5 or less at airports where the costs of the fuel they buy are inflated by local taxes. Such surcharges are not normally shown separately on a ticket. In addition, some airlines, such as Pan American World Airways, add a $5 security surcharge on international flights.
In 1986, American imposed a surcharge at Las Vegas over a dispute with the local authorities over the cost of renting terminal space. Eventually, an agreement was reached with airport officials and the extra fees were dropped.

HEADLINE: For British Politician, Faded Dream Dies

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 8

 BODY:
Dr. David Owen turned 52 years old a few days ago, a month after the failure of his decadelong attempt to create a European-style Social Democratic Party outside the British Labor movement.
''The S.D.P. ended its days as it began,'' its leader said in his office in Parliament the other day, meaning that his party had bowed out of national politics in early June rather than scramble to find a niche further to the right.
His critics, including many of his former allies, believe that much of the failure springs from his own arrogance, a characterization he rejects. But that he has arrived at a dead end is something he does not deny. 
''I expect to be leaving politics at the next election,'' he said, and though he left open the possibility that he might run in his Plymouth Devonport parliamentary constituency, the polls show that he is in trouble even there. ''I think the odds are that it's over,'' he said.
 
Seeking a New Career
He said that he thought it unlikely that the Labor Party would make him an attractive offer to return to the fold, and he said he had been too long away from his medical specialty, the chemistry of the brain, to return to that.
''I'm young enough to have a completely new career outside,'' he said. He talks as if he were reading the want ads, or ready to take one out himself -executive seeks attractive offers from British, American or European companies with a strong interest in international affairs.
Politics is the roughest and most unforgiving business, and few thought a decade ago that the brilliant and self-confident Cambridge-educated doctor, only 38 when he became Foreign Secretary in the Labor Government in 1976, would finish in a political dead end.
Defeat by Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives in 1979 turned the Labor Party inward, and in 1981, exasperated by its sharp turn away from Europe, NATO and the realities of the market economy, Dr. Owen and three other Labor notables known as the Gang of Four broke away to form the Social Democrats. #3 Members of Parliament In the mid-1980's, their party seemed to be riding the wave of the future, and in alliance with the old Liberal Party, they seemed to have a good chance of relegating Labor to history. But the alliance fractured after the 1987 elections, the other members of the Gang - William Rodgers, Shirley Williams and Roy Jenkins, now Chancellor of Oxford University - fell away.
When Labor returned to the center ground with new defense and social policies last year, Dr. Owen suddenly seemed to be running a one-man party that had no future.
Early last month, he admitted it. ''We still kept the shell, legally,'' he explained, and with three Members of Parliament the Social Democrats still exist in Westminster. ''But on a membership of 6,000 people you just can't support a national party,'' he acknowledged.
It was only one of many disappointments.
 
Joined for Gaitskell
He said he joined the Labor Party in 1959 to help Hugh Gaitskell, in his struggle against Clause 4 of the party's 1918 constitution calling for ''common ownership of the means of production'' and against the growing movement in support of unilateral nuclear disarmament. ''But Gaitskell turned against British membership in the European Community, and it broke my heart,'' he said.
Critical British commentators have also treated his relationship with the Gang of Four and the Liberals, who changed their name to Liberal Democrats last year, as a series of lovers' quarrels provoked by his refusals to compromise at important points.
Dr. Owen said: ''It was a fatal flaw in the S.D.P.'s history that Roy Jenkins and the other prominent members of the steering committee never said that they thought we should have joint membership with the Liberal Party until after we formed the S.D.P. It was the subject that never dared to speak its name.''
With the strains, and the differences, kept under wraps, the Alliance won 25.4 percent of the vote in the 1983 election, while Labor's share sank to 27.6 under the left-wing leadership of Michael Foot. Though Dr. Owen replaced Roy Jenkins (now Lord Jenkins) as leader after that, he said the damage had been done and that within the Alliance, ''by 1985 the best seats were going to the Liberals.''
 
Surprised by Kinnock
In 1987, the alliance won 22.6 percent, and the Liberals moved to absorb their smaller partners. When Dr. Owen contested the takeover, the alliance was dead, and instead of taking the center ground from Labor, Social Democrats and Liberals were losing it to Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives.
Dr. Owen said the big surprise for him was Neil Kinnock, the former ban-the-bomb campaigner who became Labor's leader in 1983, lost to Mrs. Thatcher in 1987, and has since led his party out of the unilateralist, hard-line socialist desert to a wide lead over the Conservatives in public opinion polls for more than a year.
''I did not expect him to sign up for three British Trident nuclear submarines,'' Dr. Owen said of Mr. Kinnock. ''Whatever one says, it required courage for Neil Kinnock to eat his words. The question now is whether people accept that he really believes these things, and can they hold the center vote for 18 months'' - when he believes Mrs. Thatcher will call the next election.
At the end of the day, he also believes he can take some credit for Labor's transformation. ''If we hadn't done this, the Labor Party wouldn't have changed so fast,'' he said. ''But it isn't a continental social democratic party -not yet.''

HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR BUSH DECLINES IN POLL

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
In the first public opinion survey to be released since President Bush abandoned his ''no new taxes'' pledge, the Gallup Organization reports that just over half the public disapproves of his new stand while 4 out of 10 approve.
The poll found that Americans were less worried about Mr. Bush's willingness to raise taxes than about other financial matters. Fifty-eight percent said they disapproved of his handling of the savings and loan crisis and 64 percent said they disapproved of his handling of the Federal deficit.
The combination of the President's reversal on taxes and rising disapproval on domestic matters, including the environment, education and the drug war, pushed his overall performance rating down to its lowest level in a year, according to George Gallup Jr. and Dr. Frank Newport, who conducted the survey over the weekend. 
 
A Quarter Disapprove
Still, Mr. Bush remains at least as popular as most modern Presidents at similar points in their terms. Democrats said the poll supported their contention that Mr. Bush's political strength was shaky, but Republicans called the erosion modest and noted that it was heaviest among groups whose support for a Republican President had been surprisingly high until now, notably blacks.
The telephone survey of 1,240 adults found that 63 percent said they approved of the job Mr. Bush was doing; that is down from 69 percent in June and the record 80 percent approval he reached in January, shortly after the invasion of Panama.
It was his lowest rating since May 1989, when 56 percent approved of his performance and 22 percent disapproved. In the latest survey, 24 percent expressed disapproval of Mr. Bush's handling of his job, the highest level of disapproval since he took office. The margin of sampling error for each poll was plus or minus three percentage points.
 
No Mention of Campaign Vow
While some Republican Congressional candidates have been furious with Mr. Bush for abandoning the no-tax pledge that figured so strongly in his 1988 campaign, his political aides say the issue will fade and add that the public will understand that he did what was necessary.
The Gallup question on taxes was worded in a way that may have minimized disapproval with Mr. Bush's position. Making no mention of campaign promises, it asked, ''Do you approve or disapprove of President Bush's recent announcement that he would consider increasing taxes if necessary to reduce the deficit?'' About 54 percent said they disapproved and 41 percent said they approved.
Despite his recent drop, Mr. Bush's standing remains higher than that of his two immediate predecessors after a year and a half in office. During a deep recession in July 1982, Ronald Reagan received a job approval rating of only 42 percent in a Gallup Poll. In July 1978, Jimmy Carter's approval rating was 40 percent.
Gallup noted that Mr. Bush's approval rating was similar to that of three other Presidents at a similar point: Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon.
Mr. Bush's standing on foreign policy remains strong, Gallup said. Eighty-two percent of the public approved of his handling of relations with the Soviet Union, and 62 percent expressed overall approval of his handling of foreign policy.
Asked to cite Mr. Bush's greatest achievement, 37 percent mentioned foreign policy, particularly the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. In February, 18 percent mentioned the Panama invasion and 9 percent mentioned the war on drugs. But by last week both had faded, with only 3 percent mentioning Panama and 4 percent mentioning drugs.
 
G.O.P.'s Forecast: Sunny
The survey matches the findings of recent polls conducted for Republican candidates. A Republican who has analyzed the data said Mr. Bush was losing support among people who had no clear reason to be with him in the first place.
Among blacks, Gallup said, approval of Mr. Bush's performance fell to 42 percent in July from 58 percent in February, while disapproval rose from 28 percent to 42 percent. The margin of sampling error for subgroups is larger than for the population as a whole.
The survey said Mr. Bush's support fell noticeably among conservative Democrats. Gallup said this was significant because these voters often support Republican Presidential candidates.
But Robert Teeter, a poll taker whose clients include the Republican National Committee, said the falloff he had noted was among low-income whites, who tend to be more strongly Democratic in any case. Selection Research (Gallup)

HEADLINE: Budget Talks Resume Amid Brewing Dispute Over Cuts in Military

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
After a break of almost two weeks for the Fourth of July recess, White House and Congressional budget negotiators resumed their bargaining today amid a brewing dispute among Democrats over military spending.
The dispute is twofold: not only how much to cut military costs, but also whether those cuts should fall more heavily on personnel or on weapons programs. It pits Senator Sam Nunn, the conservative Georgian who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, against Democratic colleagues in both the Senate and the House of Representatives who favor deeper Pentagon cuts than he has recommended.
Senator Nunn has proposed that the Pentagon spend $10.5 billion less next year than in the current fiscal year, after adjustment for inflation. That cut would be more than three times the one recommended by the Bush Administration, and about what the House approved in a budget bill adopted in May. 
But liberal Democrats in both houses favor Pentagon cuts of at least $13 billion, and the budget negotiators, looking for ways to slash $50 billion to $60 billion from next year's Federal deficit, have yet to reach a compromise.
 
Two Military Spending Plans
''I suspect that if anything comes out of this summit at all, then we are going to have to cut $13 billion,'' said Senator Jim Exon, a Nebraska Democrat who serves on the Armed Services and the Budget committees in the Senate. ''If we can't get to $13 billion, then we are not doing our job.''
Enter Senator Nunn, whose Armed Services Committee today began drafting the legislation that sets annual program guidelines for the military. Impatient with the pace of the budget negotiations, he has directed his subcommittee chairmen to come up with two military spending plans: one following his recommendations, the other assuming the $13 billion in cuts.
But liberal Democrats charge that Mr. Nunn is rigging the numbers to show that Draconian cuts in personnel would be needed to meet the Budget Committee's recommended spending level. ''Senator Nunn is not setting the defense numbers for the negotiators,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee and is a member of the negotiating team.
The spending figures Senator Nunn has proposed would reduce troop strength next year by 100,000 from the current 2.1 million. Congressional officials familiar with today's closed deliberations of the Armed Services Committee say the figures Mr. Nunn is using to illustrate the deeper spending cuts that liberals favor would reduce troop strength by 285,000.
 
Politically Sensitive Cuts
''We're going to show that you can get it out of personnel or procurement,'' Mr. Nunn said, defending his methodology. The problem, he added, is that if the cuts come from procurement, lawmakers would have to slash the long-term military budget well below the levels that even liberals are recommending.
Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the senior Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said a cut of $13 billion in military spending would be ''devastating to the all-volunteer force and extremely unfair to the men and women who have made a commitment to serve.''
Personnel cuts are the most politically sensitive in the military budget, and liberals insist that the savings they seek could be achieved less painfully with cuts in major weapons programs like the B-2 bomber or the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile defense system. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has already called for a reduction in purchases of the B-2 to nearly half of the 132 planes the Pentagon had sought.
But many Congressional Democrats, and some Republicans, favor outright cancellation of the program. Mr. Cheney, who cut short a trip to Europe and the Near East this week to participate in the budget deliberations, is expected to meet with the negotiators when talks resume on Wednesday.
In a related development today, the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, reiterated President Bush's support for a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. In testimony before a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee, Mr. Darman said such an amendment would provide a strong incentive for the White House and Congress to reach ''a politically negotiated settlement'' on the budget.
The proposed amendment is scheduled to come before the House next week.

Mr. Darman supports the amendment. At right was Representative Patricia Schroeder. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For New York, Happier Days

 BODY:
The Democrats could not have picked a better time for the announcement expected today that they'll hold their 1992 convention in New York City. Much of the news emanating from the city lately has focused on racial strife, crime and a growing impatience of New Yorkers about life in their city. But as the Democrats' impending choice demonstrates, New York remains a vibrant political capital. Mayor David Dinkins deserves a salute for his energy in making that choice happen. 
New York is a media center. It is, especially for Democrats, a fund-raising center. It certainly knows how to throw a party, as it has demonstrated so many times - with the Bicentennial and Operation Sail (1976), Liberty Weekend (1986), the 1976 and 1980 Democratic National Conventions and the recent celebrations for Nelson Mandela.
Such events always boost the economy and, perhaps more important, the city's morale and stature. The Bicentennial celebration and 1976 Democratic convention went a long way toward repairing the city's image when it was struggling with fiscal disaster. Despite its problems, the city is in better shape today, but Mayor Dinkins may well have had that summer in mind when he began his successful campaign for the 1992 convention.
Many factors led to the Democratic National Committee's choice. It helped that Ron Brown, the national chairman, is from New York and an old friend of the Mayor's. It helped, too, that the Louisiana legislature passed the strictest anti-abortion bill in the country, turning many Democrats against the other convention finalist, New Orleans.
But it's likely that, without Mr. Dinkins, the 1992 Democratic Convention would be somewhere other than in New York City. The Mayor put his charm and energies behind the city's effort months ago, when the idea of wooing the Democrats seemed a long shot and the city's efforts were flagging because City Hall was in transition. Mr. Dinkins did a superb job of persuasion, making a more personal, persistent pitch than his competitors did.
City officials, working with a host committee, put together an attractive proposal for the Democrats. The planning should help in 1992, as will a renovation of Madison Square Garden. The building's new shape will make the convention floor less cramped than in 1980. The city also plans to use the Javits Convention Center and the Fashion Institute of Technology for party caucuses and media space.
With the rise of the primary election campaigns, the nominating conventions no longer choose nominees. But thanks to the Dinkins drive, the Democrats have made a clear choice of where to ratify their nominee. For New York City, that means happier days are here again.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: What Fundamentalism Offers Arab World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In attributing the victory of the Islamic Salvation Front in Algeria's regional elections to deteriorating economic conditions alone (''Militant Muslims Grow Stronger as Algeria's Economy Weakens,'' front page, June 25), you ignore the more pervasive causes of the Islamic revival in much of the Arab world.
What brought the fundamentalists to the fore in Algeria and elsewhere is the prevailing stasis in the condition of Arab society. The dual goals of modernization and democratization without, however, disturbing the traditional mores and juristic imperatives of Islam have long eluded Arab regimes. In the early 1960's, while Amar Ouzegane, a leading National Liberation Front fighter and minister in the first Algerian Government after independence, was incarcerated by the French in Fresnes prison, he wrote ''Le Meilleur Combat'' (''The More Worthy Struggle''), an incisive search for Algeria's national ethos. 
In it he criticized the Algerian Communist Party, to which he once belonged, for failing to realize that a modern-day rebel could quite normally be at the same time a student of the Koran, Marxism and the principles of objective criticism. A stimulating thought, but in reality the incompatibilities are quite obvious.
Nor did ideological alternatives abound. Soviet Communism was shunned as too alien and materialistic, while the more familiar Western capitalism was burdened by the offenses of colonialism, of which the tragedy of Palestine continues to fester.
At a recent colloquium organized by the leading Cairo daily, Al-Ahram, Egyptian educators and authors gathered to consider the effects on Muslim society of the changes taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The consensus that emerged was not unpredictable: The reconciliation between East and West - now that Communism has disintegrated and Western culture has prevailed - presents the Muslim world with a fatal challenge that only a revitalized Islam can meet and overcome.
It seems to me that the merchants of the Aguiba marketplace in Algiers and their more illustrious compatriots in Cairo have, in their own quite different ways, spoken the same basic message.
 
GEORGE N. SFEIR
Cupertino, Calif., June 26, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Increases Voted on Rent-Stabilized Units

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In a decision that dissatisfied both landlords and tenants, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night approved rent increases of 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases in rent-stabilized apartments.
Leases on about two-thirds of New York's 840,000 rent-stabilized apartments are expected to be renewed under the guidelines, which will affect leases signed between Oct. 1 of this year and Sept. 30 of next year.
The board also voted to allow owners to increase the rent by an additional 5 percent after a tenant leaves a rent-stabilized unit, and it decided to do away with a surcharge on apartments that rent at very low rates. The surcharge, which has generally been $5 or $10 a month, was dubbed the ''poor tax'' by tenant leaders because it primarily affected low-income tenants. 
The vote came after an unusually raucous three-hour session in the auditorium at One Police Plaza, during which at least 300 landlords and 100 to 200 tenants chanted, demonstrated and generally tried to silence board members with whom they disagreed. The meeting was halted a half-dozen times because board members could not hear one another amid the uproar.
 
Rent-Controlled Apartments
The rent increases were approved by a vote of 5-to-4. The board's two landlord representatives and two tenant representatives all voted against the rent increases. The five nonpartisan representatives, all of them appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins, voted in favor.
Rent stabilization generally covers apartments in buildings constructed between 1947 and 1974 and those built after 1974 with city tax abatements.
There are another 140,000 apartments in the city that are governed by rent control. These are in buildings constructed before 1947. By law, owners cannot raise rents on rent-controlled apartments by more than 7.5 percent a year. The maximum increase permitted each year for such units is set by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
In May, the Rent Board proposed increases of 3 percent on one-year leases and 5 percent on two-year leases for rent-stabilized apartments. The proposal, if approved, would have been the lowest increases ever granted.
 
'It's a Disaster'
Landlord representatives contended in public hearings last month and again last night that the proposed increases would not come close to meeting their increased costs over the last year, including sharply higher property taxes and additional fuel and labor costs.
After the board approved the increases of 4.5 and 7 percent, John J. Gilbert 3d, the president of the largest owner's group, the Rent Stabilization Association, said that it would not be enough even to pay for many owners' increased property-tax bills. ''It's a disaster,'' he said.
Tenants insisted that rents should be frozen because increases granted in previous years had been unconscionably high.
''The owners don't need rent increases,'' said Michael McKee, the director of the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition. The approved rent increase ''is going to be a burden to many tenants,'' he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Protesters at last night's meeting of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rinfret and London Slug It Out as Cuomo Steps Deftly Aside

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was campaigning upstate yesterday, two opponents spent most of a half hour in a Manhattan television studio challenging each other's credentials and credibility.
''It's sort of like putting on Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark,'' said Michael Kinsley, a senior editor of New Republic magazine, in introducing the candidates on William F. Buckley's ''Firing Line'' program. The taped program was to be the first involving all three candidates, but the Governor declined to participate.
His two opponents, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican, and Herbert London, the Conservative, participated with a vengeance on and off the air that belied the fact that Republicans had tried to persuade Mr. London to be Mr. Rinfret's running mate for lieutenant governor. 
 
Strong Differences Apparent
Their sniping could help Mr. Cuomo win a third term by dividing the anti-Cuomo vote. Mr. London and Conservative leaders have said that a major goal is to become the principal alternative to Mr. Cuomo and what Mr. London calls the ''Demrep Party.''
The candidates' strong differences also pointed up what many believe is an ideological struggle in the Republican Party between what Mr. London called ''Rockefeller Republicans'' and ''Reagan Republicans.'' Mr. Rinfret's chief sponsor, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader, is considered one of the state's more liberal Republicans.
Mr. Rinfret, an economist, said Mr. London, a New York University dean, was trying to ''destroy'' the Republican Party, while Mr. London said Mr. Rinfret had ''no particular interest or knowledge about the issues of the campaign.''
''Herb is off on the wrong foot,'' said Mr. Rinfret. ''He and I have a common enemy, and the enemy is Cuomo, not each other.''
He said the Republican Party was ''rather courageous, rather daring and rather innovative'' in going ''outside the party'' to nominate him.
 
'Political Amnesia' Charged
Mr. London, who was a Manhattan Republican district leader until his recent resignation, chided Mr. Rinfret for having ''political amnesia'' in saying that he was an enrolled Republican who voted last year, when Board of Elections records show otherwise, and for denying that he had asked Mr. London to be his lieutenant-governor running mate at a three-hour Memorial Day meeting in Mr. Rinfret's Fifth Avenue apartment.
Mr. Rinfret said the purpose of the meeting was ''just to say hello to each other.''
Mr. London said he wanted to change the Republican Party leadership, including the State Senate's Republican leadership, which he said was responsible, along with Mr. Cuomo, for the state's fiscal problems. Despite that criticism, almost all Republican state senators, including the majority leader, Senator Ralph J. Marino, have been endorsed by the Conservative Party.
Trying to outdo each other as fiscal conservatives, Mr. Rinfret appeared to disagree with President Bush. Saying ''a mistake has been made in not controlling spending at the Federal level and trying to make up in a tax increase,'' the candidate added that the Bush tax program was still veiled in ''a fog.''
 
Cuomo on Campaign Trail
While his opponents were battling each other, Mr. Cuomo was touring plants in Big Flats and Horseheads, participating in a tree-planting ceremony in Elmira and speaking to the New York Sheriffs Association convention in Corning.
In the ''Firing Line'' debate, Mr. London accused Mr. Rinfret of ''excoriating'' President Reagan for his 1982 tax cuts. Mr. Rinfret replied that Mr. London was ''loaded with misknowledge'' and that he had favored the tax reduction but had warned against ''mega deficits.''
The tone of the program was set at the outset when Mr. Kinsley, in introducing Mr. Rinfret, referred to questions about Mr. Rinfret's claim to hold a doctorate, while emphasizing that Mr. London had ''earned'' a doctorate. Mr. Rinfret smiled wanly but did not respond.
Mr. Buckley, responding to a Kinsley question, declined to endorse either candidate. But a June 25 editorial in the National Review, the magazine Mr. Buckley edits, questioned Mr. Rinfret's credentials and said that state Republican leaders had nominated ''pushover nobodies'' for governor. Noting Mr. London's candidacy, the National Review continued: ''Real Republicans won't have to think very hard about whom to vote for.''
The ''Firing Line'' program will be aired on the last weekend of the month.

HEADLINE: Many Drug Dealers Found With Jobs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Many street-level drug dealers in the District of Columbia hold legitimate jobs and spend less than four hours a day hustling cocaine, heroin and other drugs, a study made public yesterday says.
The $300,000 study, financed by the Rockefeller Foundation and the Rand Corporation, found that the dealers typically earn $30 an hour from drug sales with annual incomes averaging $24,000 to $43,000, the study found.
David Tell, the deputy chief of staff to William J. Bennett, the Director of National Drug Control Policy, said that while the people who wrote the study cautioned against extrapolating their findings nationally, their work ''tends to confirm the operative assumptions of a lot of experts.''
 
Study Based on 186 People
The study was based on criminal records, police statistics and interviews with 186 people from 18 to 40 years old who identified themselves as dealers and who had been convicted and placed on probation for drug offenses and other crimes. 
The study did not include those with long criminal histories and those who managed to elude the police. It also did not include juveniles who have been arrested in increasing numbers for drug-selling offenses.
The researchers said their estimates on income might be somewhat low because of some of the people omitted from the study. They also noted that because the last data were gathered in 1988, the study does not reflect what is believed to be a slight decline in drug activity in Washington and, presumably, a drop in dealers' incomes.
The study estimated that there are some 24,000 street-level drug dealers in Washington, about 4 percent of the total population, including about 11,600 dealers who sold drugs a few hours a day and nearly 13,000 who sold one day a week or less.
Two-thirds of those whose records were reviewed and three-quarters of those interviewed said they had held legitimate jobs while they sold drugs. Several worked as deliverymen, office clerks, cooks and construction laborers. One said he was a letter carrier and another said he had been the assistant manager of a pharmacy.
 
Results Surprise Researchers
The researchers said they had not expected to find so many dealers legitimately employed and had not thought to include in their survey a question about why the dealers chose to work at regular jobs that paid an average of $7 an hour instead of devoting all their time to the more lucrative drug trade.
But Peter Reuter, a 45-year-old economist who was the principal researcher, said in an interview that he believed the nature of the drug market dictated dealers' working hours. Sales are most lively from about 6 P.M. to 10 P.M. daily, he said, and on weekends.
''You can't say I'm making $30 an hour so let me work 50 hours,'' Mr. Reuter said. ''because the market doesn't support that. It's hard to turn drug selling into a primary job in terms of time.''
In a briefing on the study yesterday in Washington. Karen Hastie Williams, the chairwoman of a civic organization called the Committee on Strategies to Reduce Chronic Poverty, which had requested the study, said her group had hoped ''to identify employment and training strategies to convince drug dealers to end their involvement in the underground economy and join the legitimate work force.''
But, she said, ''the findings indicate that a job alone does not offer enough of an incentive to lure current adult dealers away from the trade.''
 
How to Stop the Dealing
Ms. Williams said the committee has concluded that instead of trying to convert drug dealers, the ''only way to reduce drug dealing'' is to persuade Americans to stop buying.
Mr. Reuter said: ''Even creation of considerably higher paying legitimate jobs probably wouldn't get us very far. Dealers would still have smaller total incomes than they can earn now by supplementing their regular wages with drug selling.''
Another disincentive to leave the trade, the researchers found, was that more than three-quarters of the dealers used drugs themselves and through their work, were able to get discounts to sustain their habits. They reported typically spending $400 a month on drugs in addition to what they withheld from sales.

HEADLINE: Education;
The Lessons Learned When College Officials Run Public Schools

BYLINE: SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHELSEA, MASS.

 BODY:
A year after Boston University became the first college to run an entire public school system, the schools of this poor, largely immigrant community are catching up but are not yet in the vanguard of public education.
This closely watched educational experiment offers lessons both sobering and encouraging to a nation struggling to revive failing schools. The experiment is encountering the perils of local politics, the promise of new ideas, the importance of money and a continuing debate about the merits of top-down versus bottom-up management.
 
Money Still Lacking
While Boston University managers have hired a widely praised bilingual Superintendent and started some promising test programs, they have so fair failed to raise enough money to tackle the most ambitious and innovative part of their program: transforming schools into health- and family-education centers to reach preschoolers and parents.
Boston University set as its goal nothing less than the transformation of Chelsea schools, now among the worst in the state. Plagued by high dropout and pregnancy rates and rock-bottom standardized test scores, Chelsea schools were also starved of money by a town with one of the lowest average incomes in Massachusetts. 
The university and its president, John Silber, outlined sweeping plans for Chelsea. The goal is to place day care centers, preschool programs, health clinics and adult education programs in each school; develop individual learning plans for each student; pair each child in a single-parent family with an adult mentor; offer more training opportunities for teachers; begin moral education courses to combat teen-age pregnancy, and replace school buildings dating before 1908.
 
A 10-Year Agreement
The School Committee of Chelsea, just across the Mystic River from Boston, signed a 10-year contract with the university, retaining the power to override most major decisions by a two-thirds majority and to dismiss the university by a simple majority vote.
In this first year, university managers have offered teachers their first opportunities for further training and installed computers in offices and classrooms. In the fall, all-day kindergarten will begin and a health clinic will open in a high school reorganized to combat low attendance and high dropout rates with individual attention.
But Mr. Silber, whose criticism of Chelsea schools and prescriptions for cures drew national attention and Chelsea indignation, is now focused on his gubernatorial race. And Boston University is paying dearly for what several Chelsea groups see as an arrogant and authoritarian stance, with protracted political battles, two lawsuits and a teachers' contract signed on the second-to-last day of school, after eight months of negotiations.
 
'Another Layer of Bureaucracy'
Both admirers and detractors say it is too early to judge whether Chelsea schools, and the 3,650 children they serve, have actually improved. But they offer widely differing forecasts.
''We felt most strongly that since the Chelsea school system is 52 percent Latino students, if some change is going to take place, involving parents would be something new,'' said Juan R. Vega, a plaintiff in a lawsuit charging that Boston University's agreement with Chelsea's School Committee is unconstitutional. ''But we just ended up with another layer of bureaucracy.''
By contrast, Maria Ayala, who joined a Boston University program that teaches Spanish-speaking parents to read English books to their children, said: ''Things are better for my kids and for me too. Sometimes my daughter tells me something in English, I don't understand. So now I do.''
The other day, Mrs. Ayala sat in a classroom reading Robert McCloskey's classic children's books, slowly repeating the English words and, in Spanish, discussing their meaning. The theme for that week was ducks, in honor of ''Make Way for Ducklings,'' Mr. McCloskey's best-loved story. Downstairs, her children listened as a teacher read a book about ducks and played alphabet games that would help prepare them to read.
 
Literacy Program a Success
This intergenerational literacy program is one of the university's clear success stories in a tumultuous year that underscores just how difficult it is to change a school system.
Diana Lam, Chelsea's new Superintendent, arrived in September to find schools in what she called ''a time warp.'' There were no office computers, no central list of parents. Teachers were not allowed time off from their classrooms to learn other teaching methods. The newest school building dated from 1908. More than half of Chelsea's parents, many of whom are immigrants from Latin America or Southeast Asia, do not speak English at home and do not have a high school diploma.
She and the Boston University management team also had to face teachers demoralized by the university's widely publicized condemnation of Chelsea schools. In addition, they had to contend with Hispanic organizations; long shut out of local politics, they also felt excluded from the Boston University agreement. Meanwhile, School Committee members were shocked to discover that the agreement they had signed stripped them of long-held powers, and parents did not understand what the changes meant for their children.
Money remains an obstacle. Under the terms of its agreement with Chelsea, Boston University pledged to raise money from foundations and other donors for special programs, while Chelsea would pay teachers' salaries and other regular school costs.
 
Failures in Raising Money
But Boston University has raised only $2.1 million of the $3 million budgeted for this past year, partly because a Massachusetts recession has curbed donors' generosity. Only about $1 million of the money raised was actually available this past school year, and most was spent on computers and pilot programs like after-school classes.
In addition, from an expected school budget of $14 million, officials had to cut $686,000 because Chelsea's aldermen refused to ask voters for more taxes.
Peter R. Greer, Boston University's dean of education and the overseer of the Chelsea project, said the budget cuts would probably mean laying off some teachers, enlarging class sizes and delaying a planned alternative school for older high school students.
 
'That Hurts Me the Most'
More troubling is the lag in fund raising, which has stalled what Mr. Greer calls the centerpiece of the university's program: establishing clinics and day care centers so that preschoolers are physically and intellectually ready to start school at age 5, and drawing up individual lesson plans for each school student. ''That hurts me the most,'' he said.
Within these constraints, the new managers tried to put their mark on Chelsea. To raise teachers' morale, Ms. Lam offered small grants for teachers to try new projects, convened a teachers' advisory board, compiled a calendar and booklet honoring teachers, and tried teaching a third-grade class.
The new contract raises teachers' pay, which had been among the lowest in the state, to $21,640 at the start by September 1991, from $18,000. Many teachers said the raises were not enough.
To reach out to parents, Ms. Lam held drop-in coffees, played host to a Spanish and English cable television program, asked parents to evaluate the schools in writing and sent newsletters written in the languages of the parents: Spanish, Khmer, Vietnamese and English.
 
Seminars on Theories
Boston University education school professors offered several seminars on educational theories and techniques that are standard training in many school systems, but were firsts in Chelsea: how to teach children from different cultures, how to ''mainstream'' Spanish-speaking pupils in English-speaking classrooms, how to help children learn from each other, what's new in early childhood education. Elementary school teachers could also take week-long sabbaticals to observe teachers in well-regarded programs nearby.
''I've been here 17 years, and this is the first year we've had this,'' said Brenda Berkeley, a first-grade bilingual teacher who found the workshops invaluable. ''It's exciting working with B.U., and I look forward to the next year with them.''
Ms. Lam also took aim at the high school after she encountered a teacher with his arms full of pink slips showing how many eighth graders cut class that morning alone. She asked that starting in the second semester, teachers form a team to teach eighth graders only, so that these students would get more attention. When she learned that almost half the high school students had failed two or more courses in the first quarter, she called on volunteers to act as coaches and organized after-school alternative courses for credit.
Saying that they had been ineffective, she replaced the popular high school principal, as well as four teachers, at the end of the year. This fall, the high school will be divided into a traditional school and a ''Renaissance school,'' in which students can enroll to work more closely with teachers on interdisciplinary subjects.
 
'The Patient Was Bleeding'
Mr. Vega and teachers' union representatives accuse her of acting too hastily and arbitrarily. But she said: ''We couldn't afford to wait because we would lose these kids. The patient was bleeding.''
The debate about these decisions reflects broader, unresolved questions that continue to hobble the Chelsea experiment. Is strong management from the top, the model Boston University negotiated, the most effective way to change a system, or must consensus be laboriously built up from the bottom, as in the school-based management programs now in vogue among educators?
Mr. Greer said that he regretted failing to consult and placate many interest groups initially, but that he and Ms. Lam had since reached out only to find many groups whose priority is political power, not educational progress.
''Our management contract is set up to allow us to really lead, not to be arrogant dictators, but to avoid what Boston goes through, dealing with every group, every faction, and then nothing gets done,'' he said. ''We seek their ideas, but this is not a 50-50 partnership. We're putting our reputation and money on the line and the kids can't wait.''
 
'Colonial Relationship'
Michael Heichman, a teachers' union official who has taught in Chelsea for 20 years, said he supported many of the changes, but resented Boston University's attitude. ''This is a colonial kind of relationship,'' he said. ''If they had come in a cooperative way, involved teachers and the community more, I think they would be further ahead. My hope is they will see the light and start repairing the damage.''
Ms. Lam said sometimes the calls for involvement were arbitrary. She said she once tried, for example, to call each school committee member to tell them about a personnel appointment she wanted to make. Some did not return her calls, she said, yet were angry that she had not told them about the decision in advance.
Mr. Greer said he hoped that suspicions would fade next year as more programs got under way and more children felt the effect of Boston University's changes. Despite the grumbling, all sides say they want change.
''People are waiting to see,'' said Carmen Hernandez, whose two children attend Chelsea schools. ''I'm not too worried about the fact that the schools committee lost power. The committee has always been in charge and we did need help. Parents expected change to be fast, and it didn't happen real quick. But I feel optimistic.''

HEADLINE: More South Africa Sanctions

 BODY:
A tougher and expanded South African sanctions bill was unanimously adopted by the New York City Council yesterday. The bill will expand existing laws that bar the city from doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa and will establish a rating system to judge the posture of banks in dealing with South Africa. When choosing among banks with comparable services at comparable cost, the law will direct city agencies to deposit or invest city funds in banks with the highest rating.
