HEADLINE: Market Place;
Who Should Set Margin Levels?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
With the financial futures industry fearing for its future, and some parts of the securities industry warning of a financial crisis unless there is reform, pressure is building for Congress to control just how much risk speculators can take when they use the futures market to bet on whether stock prices will rise or fall.
A major issue in the debate over the Administration's proposal for changes in regulation of financial markets, on which the Senate Banking Committee will resume hearings today, is whether the Government should set limits on margins - the amount of money an investor must put up to take a position in the market.
 
Redesigning the Ship
''Any financial regulatory system has to be designed so that the ship is strong enough to remain afloat in a storm, not just on a bright sunny day,'' said Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. ''The current margin system for futures doesn't pass that test with the level of certainty and assurance that we would like.''
Those opposed to changes in margin requirements assert that they may destroy the financial futures markets by robbing them of the liquidity needed to operate and may drive business to overseas markets. 
''Put a tax on us by raising margins, and see how long it takes to lose another industry to foreign countries,'' said William J. Brodsky, the president and chief executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
The debate in some ways recalls the debates that followed the crash of 1929, which led to Federal regulation of stock market margins. Beginning in 1934, they were set by the Federal Reserve and now stand at 50 percent, although professional traders can effectively cut that in half. Investors in stock index futures, however, although they effectively own stocks, put up far less, as little as 3 percent of the value of the underlying stocks.
The bill backed by the Treasury Department would transfer authority over the stock index futures market to the S.E.C. The proposal is bitterly opposed by the futures markets and by the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, which now regulates the markets but can rule on margins only in emergencies.
As the hearings begin, some in the securities industry who favor the bill see an uphill struggle. ''The President needs to really push this bill if it is going to pass,'' said one executive, who asked not to be identified.
Exchanges now set margins in the futures markets, and they have varied sharply. In 1987 and 1989, the margins required for some buyers of stock index contracts at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell to as low as 2.2 percent, while margins at the New York Financial Exchange dipped below 2 percent.
Stock index futures contracts are based on the value of the stocks in an underlying index, with the Standard & Poor's 500, traded at the Chicago Merc, being the most popular. The contract can trade for more or less than the value of the stocks until a certain date, when it expires and is guaranteed to be worth the same as the underlying index. In general, a buyer of such a contract will profit if stock prices rise while he holds it. The seller will profit if prices fall.
Although both stock and futures markets use the term margin, the concepts are different. When an investor buys stock, the entire amount is paid to the seller, although the buyer may borrow up to half the amount from a brokerage firm as a margin loan. In a futures contract, the margin is simply a guarantee that the investor will be able to make good on any losses that may occur. Both buyer and seller in the futures market put up margins, but those margins need not be in cash. Often, Treasury bills are used.
The futures exchanges say they have adjusted margins in line with volatility, a move that Mr. Breeden, among others, said threatened to bring down financial markets in 1987 and 1989. Although margins were low before the falls, they were raised sharply directly afterward, forcing traders to come up with an additional $500 million almost immediately in 1989.
''In the midst of a crisis, the futures markets were raising margins, draining credit from a market that was already under enormous stress,'' Mr. Breeden said. ''So you can have a small fall in the market turned into a gigantic crisis because of the excessive leverage that people were allowed to incur,'' he said.
Mr. Breeden said it would make more sense to have higher margins in calm times - perhaps 12 percent to 15 percent - with the ability to lower them if needed in a crisis. It is clearly not necessary to raise them as high as stocks, he said.
There are actually two margin levels for stock index futures traders. The higher one is for self-described speculators, and the lower is for professional traders on the exchange floors and for traders hedging positions in other markets. For example, an institution that owned stocks and wanted to reduce its market risk by selling an index future would be considered a hedger.
In practice, critics say, many traders who qualify for the lower margins are speculators. ''Have you ever looked at who gets a hedging margin?'' Mr. Breeden asked. ''It's who asks for it. Effectively, you self-certify your eligibility.''
Just how much speculation takes place via stock index futures is a subject of much discussion. The futures industry generally plays down the amount, and some critics suggest it may be substantial. For an investor who wants to bet on rising, or falling, stock prices, futures clearly offer the chance for much quicker profits than stocks, albeit at a higher risk.
Were margins for professionals to be raised sharply, futures officials say, there would be less trading because some traders would be priced out of the market. That, they say, would reduce liquidity and increase volatility. Some stock traders argue the reverse, contending that futures traders' ability to trade on low margins now increases current volatility.
''The main point is that people with very little cash are having a disproportionate affect on the equity market,'' said Richard Cantor, president of Neuberger & Berman, a New York money management firm that has campaigned for higher futures margins. ''We think it is established, as a matter of national policy, that people without cash ought not to be able to speculate in the equity markets. That is what has gone amiss.''
Futures industry officials contend there is no need to change the system. ''The margin policies that the futures exchanges have pursued have really worked,'' said Steven Manaster, the chief economist of the C.F.T.C. ''There have not been any defaults.'' Many strategies who use stock index futures can also use stock index options, which are similar in many ways. Options margins are regulated by the S.E.C., and some in the futures industry have seized on that fact to argue that the S.E.C.'s failure to raise them shows that it knows no increase is needed, and is using the issue to gain authority over stock index futures.
Mr. Breeden said he believed option margins should be raised, but that it would be pointless without a similar rise in the futures markets. ''It wouldn't reduce leverage in the markets; it would just transfer that leverage to the futures markets,'' he said.
A possible problem in the system now is that each futures exchange sets its own margins, and they have sometimes seemed to compete by lowering margins to attract business. More Government oversight could end that competition.
At the moment, futures margins are relatively high. To buy or sell a single S.&P. 500 futures contract, representing about $178,000 in stock values, a speculator must put up $21,000, an amount that was raised by $1,000 late last month. Last summer, the figure was as low as $5,400. The requirements for hedgers and professional traders have risen over that period to $7,500, from $4,000.
Just why the margins have risen so far is a matter of dispute. Mr. Breeden has noted that they also rose in 1988, when the Reagan Administration was considering whether to take action, and began falling after it decided not to do so. He questioned whether a new fall would soon begin, if the current bill is defeated.
Todd Petzel, the chief economist of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, said much of this year's increase was brought on by concern over volatility in Japan, where share prices fell sharply early this year, and not by politics.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Deregulation: The Good News

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHEN most people think about deregulation these days they are apt to focus on the dubious pleasures of selecting a long-distance phone company or pleading for service from the local cable television monopolist - or worse, on the sheer gall of the savings and loan bandits who made off with the keys to the United States Mint.
But when Clifford Winston ponders deregulation, he is more likely to savor the unambiguous victories of market over bureaucrat in the transportation industry.
In earlier research, Mr. Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution, measured savings from the deregulation of the airline industry. A combination of more efficient ''hub and spoke'' route structures and more flexible pricing, he argued, saved the public some $8 billion annually. Now, in collaboration with Thomas Corsi, Carol Evans and Curtis Grimm, he has estimated the even greater gain from unleashing the long-haul trucking and rail industries in 1980. 
''The Economic Effects of Surface Freight Deregulation,'' published by Brookings, may not make the best-seller list. But the economists' conclusion, that a freer market in transportation is saving the nation a remarkable $18 billion a year, should tame nostalgia for the good old days when Washington tried to fine-tune the needs of regulated businesses and their customers.
Trains and trucks, sometime rivals in the freight business, suffered from very different regulatory maladies. Railroads were ponderous enterprises, hauling too little freight over too many miles of track because the Interstate Commerce Commission refused to let them abandon service to declining mill towns in the Rust Belt. Worse, from the railroads' perspective, the commission denied carriers the right to pass along the costs of inefficient operations to their customers.
The regulators kept a tight lid on rates for coal, chemicals and grain, where railroads had little effective competition and might have made money by playing hardball with shippers. That left the railroads in the hopeless position of trying to cover their overhead on low-bulk commodities - machinery, processed foods and the like - where trucks could offer swift door-to-door service over the heavily subsidized interstate highway system. By the late 1970's, decades of anemic profits had brought the industry to the edge of collapse.
Truckers, by contrast, were mostly fat and happy - but only at the expense of captive customers, who paid rates high enough to cover both the industry's hefty profits and the waste generated by Soviet-style regulation. Under the archaic system invented in the 1930's Washington granted licenses for every route and every commodity, blocking the entry of competitors whenever the established carriers objected.
Partial deregulation of the railroads in 1980 permitted the carriers to abandon one-fifth of their track mileage and to negotiate long-term contracts on any terms shippers would accept. Posted rates to the general shipping public can no longer be challenged unless they are at least 80 percent above operating costs, giving the railroads substantial room to cover their overhead on shipments of bulk commodities.
But the extra revenue has not been wasted. Improvements in the speed and reliability of rail service have generated a net benefit for customers of around $6 billion a year.
Separate legislation that same year broke the back of the truck cartel, eliminating monopoly power and forcing trucking companies to trim the fat from their route systems. Wide-open entry eliminated the most egregious source of waste in trucking - the empty backhaul, in which trucks returned home without cargo because they lacked licenses to carry available freight.
Not surprisingly, some of the shippers' benefit has come at the expense of trucking company stockholders and teamsters' union drivers. What may be surprising, though, is that this $5 billion redistribution of income represents just one-third of the shippers' total savings. The other two-thirds is pure efficiency gain - a potent implication of the price Americans have paid for Government meddling with transportation markets.
Could a good thing be made better? Mr. Winston and his co-authors have a wish list: deregulation of intrastate trucking, a tougher merger policy for railroads, the elimination of Government rules that make it more profitable for railroads to lease out boxcars than use them on their own tracks. But the economists are not about to lose sight of the proverbial forest. America's grandest experiment with economic deregulation has also been its most successful.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Down

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again and interest rates rose further yesterday despite a highly successful auction of $5 billion worth of new 30-year bonds offered by the Resolution Funding Corporation, the Federal agency charged with financing the savings and loan bailout.
Traders said bidders were inticed by the price declines over the last three sessions - a drop that has pushed up long-term bond yields by about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a point, from late Thursday.
Indeed, bids at the auction produced an average yield of 8.93 percent, 38.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds at the time of the auction.
''With a spread of about 38 basis points over the long bond, there was very, very good demand'' for the new securities, one government bond trader said. ''And the reason demand was so good is that it is priced so well.'' 
The issue traded well after the auction results were announced.
By late in the day, the bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.91 percent.
 
Sale Was Mixed Blessing
For Refcorp, which struggled through the two 40-year bond auctions earlier in the year, yesterday's sale was a mixed blessing.
On the positive side, demand for the securities was unusually large.
Nearly $15.5 billion worth of bids were received for the $5 billion of securities that were sold, a ratio that is much wider than normal for 30-year Government bonds.
''Over the last four years the bid-to-cover ratio for 30-year Treasury bond auctions was about 2.36 to 1,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides research and commentary on activity in the foreign exchange and credit markets. ''The ratio here was greater than 3 to 1, a much deeper bid than what you have normally had for a 30-year security.''
However, given the protracted problems confronting Refcorp and its parent, the Resolution Trust Corporation, it took higher yields to attract demand this time than nearly nine months ago, the last time Refcorp sold 30-year bonds.
In October 1989, the 30-year Refcorp securities were priced at a spread, or difference, of 27 basis points over the prevailing yield on 30-year Treasury bonds.
''The market for our securities has changed significantly from when we issued our first bonds,'' said Diane Casey, a Refcorp spokeswoman. ''But we are comfortable with the fact that the bonds were well received.''
 
Treasury Prices Rally
Treasury prices, which dipped before the Refcorp sale, rallied after the results of the auction were announced, only to fade again as the session wound down.
Still, analysts and traders said they were hopeful that conditions would improve once today's sale of seven-year Treasury notes is completed.
''Compared to last week, when everybody was afraid not to own securities, right now everyone is afraid to own anything,'' the bond trader said. ''Hopefully, the Refcorp auction, and the seven-year, which should go well, will take that fear out of the market.''
Late yesterday the seven-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.58 percent, up from 8.56 percent late Monday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 31/32, down 9/32, to yield 8.56 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 102, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.56 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 31/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 8.39 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.78 percent, down one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by a like amount, to an offered rate of 7.72 percent. But one-year bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.61 percent.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by the sale of $869.7 million worth of revenue and special obligation bonds by the New York State Dormitory Authority.
More than $530 million worth of revenue bonds were sold.
Coupons on the serial bonds that were included in this part of the issue are from 6.5 percent on bonds maturing in 1992, to 7 percent on bonds maturing in 1995, and 7.50 percent on securities maturing in 2004.
The maximum yield on term bonds that were sold was 7.552 percent on securities that mature in 2017.
The remainer of the issue - some $339 million worth of securities -consisted of special obligation bonds.
Serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2000 made up this part of the offering. Coupons on these bonds range from 5.80 percent in 1991 to 6.70 percent in 2000.
Paine Webber acted as lead manager for the negotiated underwriting. The revenue bond portion of the sale is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The special obligation bonds are rated AAA by both agencies.
Activity in the secondary markets for municipal and investment-grade securities was very light, dealers said.
Prices of actively traded issues in both markets were basically unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
World Bank Is Beginning To Tap Smaller Markets

 BODY:
The World Bank began borrowing money in the smaller financial markets of the world yesterday when it became the first nonresident borrower in New Zealand.
The international agency offered $250 million (New Zealand), or about $200 million in United States currency, worth of seven-year notes in the New Zealand domestic market. 
The 12.50 percent notes, payable semiannually, were priced at $100.90 (New Zealand), or $80.92 in United States currency, to yield 12.30 percent.
''For us this deal is something of a prototype for use in other, smaller financial markets as they liberalize,'' financial regulations, said Kenneth G. Lay, senior managing financial officer at the World Bank.
Mr. Lay said that while two-thirds of the issue had been purchased by domestic investors, the balance had been bought by investors in the United States and Japan.
''We didn't call this a global bond,'' he said. ''But we have tried to facilitate global participation.''
Proceeds of the issue will be swapped for marks, which will be used in the general operations of the World Bank.
Fay Richwhite & Company, a leading New Zealand underwriter, acted as lead manager for the transaction. Ratings of AAA are expected from both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Pound; Forecast on Rates Lifts Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The pound took center stage in foreign exchange trading yesterday, sending the dollar to an 18-month low against the British currency. The dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen.
''The British pound is the whole story,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with the Bank of New York, summing up the day. 
Sterling's rise came amid continuing speculation that Britain will soon join Western Europe's currency-steadying exchange rate mechanism.
Built into the European Monetary System, the exchange rate mechanism limits the fluctuations of nine of the 12 European Community countries. Britain, Greece and Portugal are the three countries still outside the system.
 
Buying Extremely Heavy
In London, the pound rose by a cent from Monday, to $1.8155, its highest rate against the dollar since Jan. 3, 1989, when it reached $1.8270. At its peak yesterday, the pound reached $1.8270 and buying was extremely heavy, dealers said. In New York trading, sterling also advanced sharply, rising to $1.8220, from $1.8080 late Monday.
The yen rose after Smick Medley International, a Washington-based advisory firm, predicted that the Bank of Japan would raise interest rates during the next few months.
In New York the dollar plunged to 148.23 yen, from 151.15 on Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar dropped to 149.60 yen, from 150.70 yen late Monday, and it was quoted lower in London at 148.85 yen.
The dollar slumped to 1.15695 Canadian dollars, from 1.15855 late Monday. In Europe earlier, it fell to 1.1570 Canadian dollars from 1.1590.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late prices, included: 1.64185 West German marks, down from 1.6528; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3965; 5.51225 French francs, down from 5.5460, and 1,203.00 Italian lire, down from 1.21125.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, were: 1.6465 West German marks, down from 1.6495; 1.3945 Swiss francs, down from 1.3950; 5.5270 French francs, down from 5.5353; 1.8555 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8573, and 1,207 Italian lire, down from 1,208.50.

HEADLINE: Textron Settles U.S. Charges

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Textron Inc. has agreed to pay a record $17.9 million to settle a whistle-blower's charges that one of its subsidiaries supplied the Coast Guard with faulty helicopter engines, the Justice Department said today.
Robert Ballew, the 42-year-old whistle-blower who first brought the suit, was awarded $2.7 million under the settlement. 
The subsidiary, Textron Lycoming, neither admitted nor denied the charges. It also agreed to repair and maintain for six years the 96 helicopter engines it supplied, saving the Coast Guard about $60 million, the Justice Department said.
Engines made by Lycoming, under a 1984 contract worth a total of $310 million, required significant repairs after less than 600 hours of flying time, not the 2,400 hours promised, the Coast Guard said.
Mr. Ballew was a purchasing manager for the Aerospatiale Helicopter Corporation, a Grand Prairie, Tex., unit of the French-owned Aerospatiale Aircraft Company. Aerospatiale subcontracted the manufacture of engines to Lycoming.
Mr. Ballew said he filed his suit on behalf of the United States Government after his supervisors failed to address the problem. The Justice Department said there was no evidence of misconduct by Aerospatiale. But Mr. Ballew, of Fort Worth, is suing his former employer for dismissing him after he brought the suit. He said he was unemployed for a year.
The Coast Guard uses the HH-65A Dauphin helicopters to intercept drug smugglers' airplanes and ships and for air-and-sea rescue.

HEADLINE: A True Test of Diplomacy: Feeding the Summit Leaders

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 10

 BODY:
The economic world focused on the business of the seven leading industrial powers here, but Houston's food community has been obsessed since April with the politics of culinary summitry. The chefs and caterers wanted to do their part to make Houston look good after so many years at the bottom of the oil barrel. They wanted everything to be perfect. So why was a chef from Dallas, Houston's archrival, chosen to be the chief cook for the two major summit dinners?
How did it happen that that chef, Dean Fearing of the Mansion on Turtle Creek, chose two Houston chefs - Robert Del Grande, the chef and owner of the city's most acclaimed restaurant, Cafe Annie, and Robert McGrath, the executive chef of the highly regarded DeVille restaurant in the Four Seasons Hotel - to help him, but not the city's foremost society caterer?
And why did Washington bureaucrats tell Houston that though they wanted food and services donated, or at cost, any premature release of details would result in cancellation of contracts?'' What's the good of the honor if no one knows about it? 
''They are putting the squeeze on everyone,'' said Joe Bacon, a publicist for some of the events. ''They want it dirt cheap and then they swear everyone to secrecy.''
And why would President Bush insist on starting the festivities with a rodeo and country music from Tennessee when Houston was eager to show off its own full-time opera, ballet and symphony orchestra?
Houstonians had hoped the heads of state would remember something about the city besides bucking bulls, bronco riding and a chain restaurant's rendition of barbecued brisket, potato salad and baked beans. That meal was provided free to 5,000 guests at the rodeo by Luther's Bar-B-Q, a 19-restaurant chain based in Houston.
''I get the distinct feeling,'' said Hal Foster, president of the Houston public relations firm Callas & Foster, who has clients working on summit events, that the President ''is actually showcasing the Houston that existed when he lived here a while back. Since those years, Houston has gained a certain level of sophistication.''
The summit festivities were coordinated by a committee in Houston headed by Kenneth L. Lay, chief executive of Enron Energy of Houston, and George W. Strake Jr., president of the Strake Trading Group here, and by a committee in Washington, as well as by Barbara Bush's staff at the White House.
The people of the White House social office had their own ideas about what was appropriate for the formal functions.
Mr. Fearing was chosen by Washington because of mutual acquaintances to prepare the intimate dinner for heads of state Monday night at Bayou Bend, the magnificent former home of Ima Hogg, the daughter of a former Texas Governor. Mr. Fearing also prepared the summit dinner tonight for 110 people at the Museum of Fine Arts. The meal was served in the grand hall of the museum's Upper Brown Pavilion, a gallery where John Trumbull's portrait of Alexander Hamilton was hung especially for the dinner; it was brought from the Treasury Department in Washington.
An aide had left Mr. Bush's notes for his toast back at his hotel, so Mr. Bush simply welcomed the guests, saying: ''There is no work here tonight, no communiques, no amendments, no language to be corrected. We simply want you to have a very good time at this museum we are very proudful of. Make yourselves at home.''
The White House planners had wanted a regional touch to the dinner, but not what Mr. Fearing described as ''cutting-edge Southwest cuisine that just came off our line last week.'' The chefs do not always do as they are told, and these chefs do not do the continental-style food associated with White House dinners.
One of Mr. Fearing's offerings, Texas wild greens, became Texas greens because the word from Washington was, no dandelions. Tomatillos, those little Mexican green tomatoes, were out because someone in Washington could not pronounce the word (toe-mah-TEE-oh). ''The White House used the word 'traditional' a lot,'' Mr. Del Grande said.
In the end, the White House got menus that seemed innocuous enough, but the chefs cooked the food their way. Behind the basil lime sauce for the red snapper lurked mildly hot poblano chilies. Even the innocent-sounding morel sauce for the veal loin had been spiked, oh so gently, with chilies. The plain yellow tomato soup listed on the menu came with smoked poblano, a streak of cilantro cream and avocado relish.
''We had to keep our personal integrity,'' Mr. Fearing said. ''What are they going to do, fire us?'' The White House did not wish to discuss details of the preparations, but after his guests left Bayou Bend Monday evening, the President called the chefs into the living room. He told Mr. Fearing that he had made sure everyone cleaned their plates ''just like at Mom's.'' He said he particularly enjoyed the tortilla soup. When Mr. Fearing asked him if the food was too spicy, the President replied, ''Not spicy enough.''
Because the chefs donated their services and everything else was at cost, the Bayou Bend dinner cost $150 a person, half the retail price. The summit dinner tonight cost $120 a person, $60 less than retail. The State Department picks up the tab.
While the heads of state and their policy makers were dining Monday night at Bayou Bend, a 28-room mansion given to the city by its owner, the visiting spouses were dining at the gracious Georgian-style home of J. Hugh and Betty Liedtke, old friends of the Bushes. Mr. Liedtke, Mr. Bush and two other partners founded Zapata Petroleum in 1953.
Two of the Bushes' and Liedtkes' oldest friends, Baine and Mildred Kerr, were among the guests. Mrs. Kerr, for whom the Bushes' dog, Millie, is named, said she was amazed at how relaxed the evening was. ''It did not seem stuffyor strained,'' she said. ''Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Liedtke are so good at putting everyone at ease.''
Mrs. Bush had phoned Mrs. Liedtke about two months ago. After they chatted awhile, Mrs. Liedtke recalled, ''I said to her, 'What are you getting ready to ask me to do?' '' The answer surprised her.
''When I picked myself up off the floor, I said I'd be delighted,'' said Mrs. Liedtke, whose husband is chairman of Pennzoil. She said she rented the silver plate and plain white china for the dinner ''because I don't have 40 of anything.''
Jackson Hicks, Houston's society caterer, was recommended to Mrs. Liedtke. ''I had not used Jackson before,'' she said. ''I know his name and his reputation very well.''
Mr. Hicks is more famous for his extravaganzas than for his food. He catered the Media Fest for 5,000 people on Saturday night and the working lunches for the heads of state today, but some Houstonians were shocked that he was not tapped to feed the heads of state. ''The lunches are where the real action is at the summit,'' he said earlier in the week.
Others who chafed at the dealings with the Washington summit committee were not so circumspect.
Sharon Seline, a vice president of Tiffany's, which supplied the place settings of silver, china and stemware for the summit dinner at the museum, did not feel too kindly toward a representative from Washington who worked on the two heads-of-state dinners. Ms. Seline said the representative picked out one china pattern, Blair House by Tiffany, for the dinner.
After Ms. Seline had corraled 150 place settings from around the country, the White House social office said the china pattern was not suitable. Manhattan Blue by Tiffany was substituted. ''When you are donating $500,000 worth of time and services, you want good communications,'' Ms. Seline said. She said relations had improved in recent weeks.
Some caterers were bent out of shape over the Bushes' party for 7,000 to 10,000 people, ranging from volunteers who picked up trash to middle managers of companies that donated services, to be held Wednesday afternoon, when the weather in Houston is at its most sweltering. ''Who in their right minds would go outdoors at 3:30?'' said Mr. Foster, the publicist.
When Marthann Masterson of Masterson Catering was invited to bid for the event, she said, she was told the committee was looking for donations. She recalled: ''At that point, I said: 'I can't donate this. This is a thank-you-to-Houston party. It's not much of a thank-you.' ''
It was agreed that Ms. Masterson would be paid $8,000 to cater one of the thank-you pavilions. She also prepared a dinner Monday night for the Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, and others; they were among the better-fed guests, dining on crawfish quesadillas, crab cakes with cayenne mayonnaise and grilled quail.
Renee Ferrell of Bennie Ferrell Catering said she had been told the planning committee wanted her company to cater a private Presidential reception Wednesday afternoon, but ''something greater'' than the committee ''made the decision.'' (She will cater two pavilions at the thank-you party.) ''Something greater'' was James Huang's connection with Mr. Bush. Mr. Huang owns the Hunan restaurant in Houston. He and his daughter, Gigi, were overnight guests at the White House after a recent state dinner at which Mr. Huang sat at the President's table. Mr. Huang donated the food for the reception and created several new recipes for its banquet.
The Cadillac Bar, with its graffiti-covered walls, its grime-covered floors, loud music, loud customers and good Tex-Mex food, was the setting for a party given by the Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, and his wife, Georgette, on Saturday night for his foreign counterparts and a few friends. Mr. Mosbacher was not part of the official delegation but Houston is his home. Guests, including Kabun Moto, the Japanese Minister of International Trade and Industry, dined on barbecued goat, nachos, fajitas, frogs' legs, mesquite-grilled shrimp and quail.
While officials dined on quail and sipped vintage wines, the police supped on sandwiches, chips and fruit. Reporters were able to eat round the clock at the George Brown Convention Center, the press's headquarters for the summit session. The host committee spent $1 million, mainly to impress foreign journalists, on fare that included lumps of white crabmeat and jumbo shrimp.

Grilled Gulf Red Snapper With Basil-Lime Sauce
(Adapted from the Bayou Bend dinner menu)
 
Preparation time: 30 minutes
Cooking time: 6 to 8 minutes
 
2 small poblano chilies, charred, seeded and peeled
 1/4 cup pumpkin seeds or pine nuts, lightly toasted in a dry skillet
1 clove garlic, finely chopped
3 tablespoons finely chopped shallots
 1/2 cup chicken stock
4 fillets (6 to 7 ounces each) red snapper
1 tablespoon olive oil
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 1/4 cup heavy cream
 1/4 cup finely chopped basil leaves
1 teaspoon finely chopped lime zest
2 tablespoons lime juice.
1.Preheat a grill or broiler.
2.Combine the chilies, pumpkin seeds, garlic, shallots and chicken stock in a blender. Puree for about 30 seconds.
3.Transfer the puree to a saucepan, bring to a boil, and set aside.
4.Lightly brush the snapper fillets with the olive oil. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Grill or broil the fillets 3 to 4 minutes on each side, or until fish flakes easily.
5.Just before serving, add the cream, basil, lime zest, juice and salt and pepper to the sauce. Simmer 3 to 4 minutes. Spoon the sauce onto the dinner plates, and top with the fish.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Texas Peach and Blackberry Cobbler With Sweetened Cream
 
(Adapted from the summit dinner menu)
 
Preparation time: 32 minutes
Cooking time: 45 to 50 minutes
 
For the topping:
 
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
 3/4 cup sugar
4 tablespoons butter
1 teaspoon vanilla.
 
For the filling:
 
Z cup all-purpose flour
1 3/4 cups sugar
 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
5 eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla
2 cups milk
 1/2 cup heavy cream
Butter for greasing dish
4 cups peaches, peeled and cut into 1/4-inch wedges
2 cups blackberries, rinsed
2 cups heavy cream, optional
2 tablespoons confectioners' sugar, optional.
1.To make the topping, combine the flour and sugar. Cut in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse cornmeal. Add the vanilla, mix thoroughly, and set aside.
2.Preheat the oven to 375 degrees.
3.To make the filling, combine the flour, sugar, cinnamon, eggs, vanilla, milk and 1/2 cup of cream in a blender or food processor. Blend until smooth, 15 to 20 seconds.
4.Lightly butter a 13-by-9-by-2-inch baking dish.
5.Line the dish with the peaches and berries. Carefully pour the custard filling over the fruit, and bake for 30 minutes. Sprinkle the topping over the cobbler, and bake 15 to 20 minutes longer, until the topping is brown and a knife inserted into the center comes out clean. Serve warm. If desired, sweeten 2 cups cream with the confectioners' sugar, and serve on the side.
Yield: 8 servings.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 12, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1292 words

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEFENDS HIS SON'S INTEGRITY IN SAVINGS INQUIRY

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
President Bush today gave a ringing emotional defense of his son Neil, who has been accused of violating conflict of interest rules in a Denver savings and loan case, but he promised to stay out of the proceedings and ''let the system work.''
Federal regulators say Neil Bush did not disclose adequately his past business relationship with major borrowers of the defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. He and other directors and officials of Silverado may well face a $200 million Federal negligence suit over the failure of the institution. Bailing out Silverado is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion.
''I have confidence in the honor and integrity of my son,'' President Bush said, adding that ''if the system finds he's done something wrong, he will be the first to step up and do what's right.'' 
''This is not easy for me, as a father,'' he said. ''It's easy for me as the President, because the system is going to work, and I will not intervene. I've not discussed this with any officials and suggested any outcome.''
The remarks, in response to a question at a news conference in Houston at the end of the economic summit meeting of leading industrialized nations, came as the Senate approved measures to toughen penalties for those found guilty of savings and loan fraud.
The bill includes provisions for life prison sentences for offenders who conspired to steal more than $5 million. It would also increase the maximum prison term for lending fraud to 30 years, from 20 years at present.
The Administration's handling of the savings crisis has in the last few weeks become an explosive political issue, and lawmakers from both parties are worried about a rising voter sentiment that the Government has mishandled the bailout process.
The Senate package, approved 99 to 1 as an amendment to the Omnibus Crime Bill, would provide $162.5 million a year for the next three years for the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service to prosecute savings and loan fraud. That is more than triple the present amount.
Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican of Colorado, cast the no vote, contending that the bill was an attempt to create ''a smoke screen to shift the culpability for the S.& L. mess from the Congress and onto a few unscrupulous businessmen.''
The measure would permit the Government to bring civil racketeering cases and to confiscate property purchased with illegal profits and would require regulators to open enforcement hearings to the public. Last week, the Office of Thrift Supervision said it would hold open hearings. The Senate's provision would have the force of law and would apply to all banking, savings and credit union regulatory actions.
''There is no question that fraud and other crimes played a significant role in the S.&L. crisis,'' said Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat from Colorado.
 
Criticism of Cartoons
At the Houston news conference, the President was the most expansive he has been in public in discussing his son's case, saying the publicity surrounding Neil Bush's role had caused him considerable pain as a father.
''I've got three other sons, and they all want to go to the barricades when they see some cartoon they don't like, particularly those that are factually incorrect in total, demeaning the honor of their brother,'' he said. ''And I say: 'You calm down now, we're in a different role now; you can't react like you would if your brother was picked on in a street fight.'
''But we have great emotions that I share with Barbara, I share with my sons and my daughter that I won't share with you except to say: One, as President I am determined to stay out of this and let it work and let it work fairly. And secondly, I have confidence in the honor and integrity of my son.''
The Senate's overwhelming vote for the enforcement measure was a barometer of the extent to which Republicans and Democrats are now vying with each other to appear tough on savings and loan crime.
Both parties have problems to overcome. Four of the five senators who intervened with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix developer who controlled the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan, were Democrats, as was former House Speaker Jim Wright, who intervened on behalf of failing Texas savings institutions. The Republican image has been tarnished by the Administration's admission that it underestimated the cost of the crisis and by the Neil Bush matter.
The Democrats seem to smell blood. Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat from Colorado, has called for an independent prosecutor to investigate the Neil Bush case.
At this point, White House officials say their approach is simply to say nothing about the case unless asked, and then to respond essentially as the President responded today. But Republican strategists have been casting about for ways to counter Democratic attempts to blame the Administration for the crisis.
On Thursday, Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, is scheduled to give a speech at a meeting of the Republican National Committee in Chicago. He will say that specific Democratic lawmakers had a role in the savings and loan debacle and will assert that President Bush was the first chief executive to step forward and deal with the issue.
 
Qualifications Are an Issue
Documents released by the Office of Thrift Supervision on the conflict of interest charges against Neil Bush show that regulators viewed him as ''unqualified and untrained'' to be a director of a financial institution.
''Certainly he had no experience in managing a large corporation, especially a financial institution with almost $2 billion in assets,'' the documents said.
One troublesomee issue for President Bush is his handling of L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to manage the bailout. Mr. Seidman must ultimately decide whether to proceed with the $200 million negligence suit in the Silverado case.
The President said today that he supported Mr. Seidman in his current position, although Mr. Seidman has been under pressure from other White House officials to step aside.
''He wouldn't be there if I didn't have confidence in him,'' the President said. ''I have confidence in his integrity and his honor.''
Mr. Seidman would not discuss the possible negligence suit. ''We do not discuss these matters until they are officially filed, if they are officially filed,'' he said.
He added that his agency had not singled out Silverado, saying the F.D.I.C. investigated every failed savings and loan to determine whether misconduct had occurred. ''There is no difference because he's the President's son,'' he said.
 
More Legislation Considered
Mr. Seidman's comments were made as he emerged from a House Judiciary subcommittee hearing held to discuss legislative proposals to accelerate prosecutions of wrongdoing in the savings industry.
The House subcommittee is considering a wide variety of measures, including proposals that are part of the bill the Senate passed today, as well as the possibility of appointing a special prosecutor and giving new authority for the Secret Service to investigate savings and loan fraud. Lawmakers said they hoped to present a bill to the President by mid-August.
In the Senate, the Ethics Committee is deciding how to proceed with the so-called Keating Five, and whether to handle them as one case or five individual cases.
The four Democratic Senators under inquiry are Alan Cranston of California, Dennis Deconcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan; the Republican is John McCain of Arizona.

LENGTH: 919 words

HEADLINE: Amid Discord, Talks on Boat People Are Put Off

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 11

 BODY:
A 28-nation conference on Vietnamese boat people was postponed today when it became apparent that differences between the United States and Vietnam on one side and the Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong on the other have not been bridged.
At the headquarters here of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, under whose auspices the meeting was to be held, the indefinite postponement was considered a setback to the principle of first asylum.
Hong Kong, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia have reluctantly allowed the Vietnamese to land on their shores since the refugees began leaving in 1975. There they are maintained, in camps that are Spartan or worse, at international expense until they can find permanent refuge. The United States is the principal final refuge; others include France, Canada and Australia. 
 
No Longer Willing Hosts
Increasingly, however, as the flow of refugees shows no signs of ceasing and the readiness of final-refuge countries to accept the refugees has slowed, the countries that bear the initial brunt of the exodus have balked at continuing to play that role.
The Vietnamese refugees, who at the outset were automatically and widely accepted as political refugees, are now divided into those to whom this status is conceded and a majority, who are classified as economic migrants, suspected of leaving simply to achieve richer material lives and therefore subject to forcible repatriation.
Britain, the colonial power in Hong Kong, followed by the Southeast Asian countries, established cutoff dates, saying that all Vietnamese arriving afterward would be screened to determine which category they fall into. The economic migrants would be subject to deportation back to Vietnam.
The United States, however, opposes any involuntary return of Vietnamese who are classified as illegal economic migrants. Paradoxically, the American position coincides with that of Vietnam, which has so far refused to accept the return of those who fled unless they volunteer to do so.
 
Deterrent Wanted
Hong Kong and the Southeast Asian nations have been pushing for a policy that will clear out their camps and dissuade more Vietnamese from coming.
Today, Malaysia and Vietnam asked the High Commissioner to postpone the meeting, which was scheduled for Monday and Tuesday. No reasons were announced, but senior officials assumed that the two countries, which are on opposite sides of the dispute, were motivated by a desire to prevent a meeting that appeared to have no chance of achieving consensus and might formalize a split that all seek to avoid.
A recent visit to Washington by the High Commissioner, Thorvald Stoltenberg, which included a meeting with President Bush, has apparently failed to bring about a significant softening of the American position, believed to originate in the White House rather than at the State Department.
Officials and refugee relief workers of many nations, including the United States, are skeptical about the rationale for the American stand as to who is entitled to refugee status. They point out that the United States does not hesitate to intercept those fleeing Haiti by boat and return them to their country or deport them if they reach American shores.
 
Still Fighting Vietnam
These specialists attribute the American stand to a continuing harsh attitude toward Vietnam, more than 15 years after the Communist victory in the Indochina war. The United States regards Vietnam as an oppressive country to which no one should be forced to go against his will.
Whatever the motivation, American opposition to forcible return has led Britain and the Southeast Asian nations, all traditionally friendly to the United States, to threaten to end their commitments to allow the boat people to land. In effect, Malaysia stopped doing so last year and since March 1989, has pushed off 8,700 boat people. Most have reached Indonesia with the help of supplies and equipment provided by the Malaysian Navy.
But Indonesia has told the United Nations refugee commissioner's office that it will not indefinitely continue to allow them to land. Even the Philippines, which has been the the most tolerant of the Southeast Asian nations, has begun to adopt a more severe stand, particularly toward freighters that seek to put ashore refugees whom they have rescued at sea.
The United States has rejected a compromise proposal, which would permit sending the ''screened-out'' Vietnamese to a holding center on a Pacific island, such as the American territory of Guam, while a solution less severe than forcible repatriation is sought.
 
Those Who Remain
About 125,000 boat people remain in camps in Southeast Asia and Hong Kong. About 25,000 arrived before the dates on which their unwilling host countries instituted screening and are assured of permanent resettlement before the end of this year. Of those remaining, only 25,000 are considered likely to be granted refugee status.
Refugee officials now fear that the Southeast Asian countries may formalize their refusal to continue granting first asylum when their Foreign Ministers meet later this month in Jakarta in the annual conference of the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
According to the High Commissioner, as of April 30, there are 107,802 Vietnamese boat people in camps in Asia. More than half, or 54,718, are in Hong Kong, with 18,404 in Malaysia, 12,370 in Thailand, 12,205 in Indonesia and 8,459 in the Philippines.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1301 words

HEADLINE: THE HOUSTON SUMMIT;
Three Key Economic Issues Undecided as Meeting Ends

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 11

 BODY:
The leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies wrapped up their three-day meeting here today by proclaiming their united goal of fostering worldwide prosperity, but they hardly resolved the three main economic issues that had divided them at the outset.
On trade policy, the leaders at the 16th annual economic summit meeting endorsed an ambiguous statement about agriculture subsidies that was finally drafted at 2:30 this morning. It promised to put trade talks back on track, but it allowed all competing sides to assert victory.
On aid to the Soviet Union, they took the time-honored step of politicians unable to reach consensus: they formed a committee to study the situation.
 
Little Movement on Environment
And on the environment, they agreed that climate change was ''of key importance,'' but they acceded to President Bush and announced no timetable for limiting the emission of gases that might cause global warming. 
In many instances, the final communique presented by President Bush, the host of the meeting, was a masterpiece of euphemism and understatement, as such documents often are. But its language about the changes in Eastern Europe since last year's economic summit meeting was exultant.
''When people are free to choose,'' it declared in the first paragraph, ''they choose freedom.''
In his news conference afterward, Mr. Bush said, ''We are united in a common goal to extend to those who seek political and economic freedom a helping hand with our resources, talents and experience.''
 
Similar Points Made
The other leaders made similar points about the group's harmony. Summit meetings, said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, are looked to by people of the world for leadership on the great issues of the times. ''Once again,'' she continued, ''we have provided that leadership.''
But the comity on the overriding issues of war and peace, democracy and communism, was overshadowed this week by the tensions over the more mundane economic topics that are likely to dominate the alliance in the years ahead.
The most contentious issue, by far, was the question of farm subsidies, and the final communique gave something to everyone.
For the United States, it pledged that export subsidies and import protection would be reduced. And it specifically mentioned a proposal by Aart De Zeuuw, the Dutch chairman of the agriculture committee at the international trade talks, that the United States sees as a favorable basis for negotiations.
Under Mr. De Zeuuw's proposal, separate limits would be negotiated for each specific form of farm subsidy, including export supports.
 
Influential Political Force
For the European countries, where farmers are an especially influential political force, it recognized that ''social and economic conditions'' must be reflected in farm policy and that Government subsidies could be considered as a whole, rather than individually, when the level of protection is measured. The Europeans have been unwilling to make a commitment to reduce their export supports.
For Japan, the document said farm policy should take into account ''concerns about food security,'' a reference to Japan's prohibition on rice imports.
Whatever the ambiguity, Mr. Bush succeeded in putting the issue at the top of the international economic agenda, and that could give a political impetus to the current round of international trade talks that are scheduled to end in December.
The priority Mr. Bush gave to limiting farm supports seemed to surprise most of his counterparts, who tend to view agriculture policy as a matter to be handled by underlings.
 
Stifling of Growth Seen
The President maintained that unless the industrial countries began to limit their support for farmers, which distorts the world market for foods and feed grain, the current round of trade talks would break down. If that happened, Mr. Bush argued, worldwide economic growth would be stifled.
All seven of the countries here - the United States, Canada, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan - subsidize farmers in one way or another. The subsidies in Europe and Japan are much more extensive than they are in North America. The United States and Canada find the Europeans' export subsidies the most onerous form of protection because they believe they distort the market the most.
The Americans maintained that the summit agreement could get deadlocked trade talks restarted when negotiators meet next in Geneva on July 23. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said she was encouraged by the summit agreement, but she would not go so far as to call it a breakthrough.
''We gave a tremendous political impetus to the final negotiations of the round,'' Mrs. Hills told reporters. ''We did not come here to negotiate specific words. But we will get on with that on the 23d and put some meat on the bones.''
 
Delight Voiced by Europeans
The Europeans also expressed delight with the outcome. ''It's much better than I had hoped for,'' said Henning Christophersen, the European Community's vice president for economic and financial affairs.
On aid to the Soviet Union, Mr. Bush got a statement encouraging the steps toward a free market economy being taken by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Bush maintains that the United States can provide technical assistance to the Soviets but no money so long as the Soviets continue to spend vast sums on their military and on support of Cuba.
The Allies accepted his proposal for a study of Soviet economic needs under the auspices of the International Monetary Fund and other international economic organization.
 
To Reassure Gorbachev
At his news conference, Mr. Bush said the formation of the study committee was ''not an effort to delay anything,'' and he said he would ''make clear to President Gorbachev that he ought to view this outcome of this summit very positively.''
Later, the President added, ''I think Mr. Gorbachev understands that at this juncture, sending money from the United States is not in the cards.''
The summit meeting left other countries free to give aid to the Soviets. That pleased Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who has promised more than $3 billion in credits to the Soviet Union and who favors an international commitment of $15 billion. Mr. Kohl is going to Moscow this weekend to meet with Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Joint Program Predicted
''The necessary steps are being initiated in the Soviet Union now,'' Mr. Kohl said at a news conference. ''If this continues by the end of the year, we should be able to achieve a joint Western economic assistance program.''
Did Mr. Bush agree with that assessment? ''It doesn't work that you have to march in lockstep on all these questions,'' he said.
Mr. Bush seemed to have won a victory on environmental policy. The leaders rejected a West German proposal, which Mr. Bush opposed but the other leaders supported, that would have set a timetable for limiting the emission of gases that could contribute to global warming. They did approve, with Mr. Bush's support, development of a pilot program to help Brazil preserve its tropical rain forest.
The leaders also dealt with such areas as third world debt, aid to underdeveloped countries, narcotics control and international money laundering. These were central topics at previous summit meetings, and little new ground was broken this year.
Bettino Craxi, the former Prime Minister of Italy who heads a United Nations study on underdeveloped countries, was influential in the preparation of the section of the communique dealing with that area.
It asserted that the industrial countries' commitment to helping Eastern Europe would diminish their support for developing countries elsewhere in the world.

(Agence France-Presse)

LENGTH: 2549 words

HEADLINE: THE HOUSTON SUMMIT;
Excerpts From Economic Declaration by Chiefs of Seven Industrial Nations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 11

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Economic Declaration issued today by the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada at the conclusion of their summit meeting:
1. We, the heads of state and government of the seven major industrial democracies and the president of the commission of the European Communities, meeting in Houston for our annual economic summit, celebrate the renaissance of democracy throughout much of the world. We welcome unreservedly the spread of multiparty democracy, the practice of free elections, the freedom of expression and assembly, the increased respect for human rights, the rule of law, and the increasing recognition of the principles of the open and competitive economy. These events proclaim loudly man's inalienable rights: When people are free to choose, they choose freedom.
2. The profound changes taking place in Europe, and progress toward democracy elsewhere, give us great hope for a world in which individuals have increasing opportunities to achieve their economic and political aspirations, free of tyranny and oppression.
3. We are mindful that freedom and economic prosperity are closely linked and mutually reinforcing. Sustainable economic prosperity depends upon the stimulus of competition and the encouragement of enterprise - on incentives for individual initiative and innovation, on a skilled and motivated labor force whose fundamental rights are protected, on sound monetary systems, on an open system of international trade and payments, and on an environment safeguarded for future generations. 
5. In recent years, substantial progress has been achieved in promoting a stronger world economy through sound macroeconomic policies and greater economic efficiency. The economic expansion in our countries, now in its eighth year, has supported notable income growth and job creation in the context of rapid growth of international trade. However, unemployment remains high in a number of countries. Inflation, although considerably lower than in the early 1980's, is a matter of serious concern in some countries and requires continued vigilance. External imbalances have been reduced in the United States and Japan, whereas in other cases they have increased. Continuing adjustment remains a priority in order to counter protectionist pressures, alleviate uncertainties in financial and exchange markets, and contribute to avoiding pressures on interest rates. Sound domestic macroeconomic policies, which may differ according to conditions in each country, will make a major contribution to further external adjustment.
 
International Monetary Developments and Policy Coordination
9. Countries with sizable current account deficits should contribute to the adjustment process by the reduction of fiscal deficits, and undertake structural reforms to encourage private savings and increase competitiveness.
10. Countries with large external surpluses should contribute to the adjustment process by sustained non-inflationary growth of domestic demand with structural reform in order to improve the underlying conditions for growth and adjustment and to promote increased investment relative to saving.
14. We welcome the prospect of a unified, democratic Germany which enjoys full sovereignty without discriminatory constraints. German economic, monetary, and social union will contribute to improved non-inflationary global growth and to a reduction of external imbalances. This process will promote positive economic developments in Central and Eastern Europe.
 
International Trading System
18. The open world trading system is vital to economic prosperity. A strengthened General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) is essential to provide a stable framework for the expansion of trade and the fuller integration of Central and Eastern Europe and developing countries into the global economy. We reject protectionism in all its forms.
19. The successful outcome of the Uruguay Round has the highest priority on the international economic agenda. Consequently, we stress our determination to take the difficult political decisions necessary to achieve far-reaching, substantial results in all areas of the Uruguay Round by the end of this year. We instruct our negotiators to make progress and in particular to agree on the complete profile of the final package by the July meeting of the trade negotiations committee.
21. As regards agriculture, achieving the long-term objective of the reform of agricultural policies is critical to permit the greater liberalization of trade in agricultural products. Experience has shown the high cost of agricultural policies which tend to create surpluses. The outcome of the GATT negotiations on agriculture should lead to a better balance between supply and demand and ensure that agricultural policies do not impede the effective functioning of international markets. We therefore reaffirm our commitment to the long-term objective of the reform, i.e., to allow market signals to influence agriculture production and to establish a fair and market-oriented agricultural trading system.
22. The achievement of this objective requires each of us to make substantial, progressive reductions in support and protection of agriculture - covering internal regimes, market access and export subsidies - and develop rules governing sanitary and phytosanitary measures. Variations among countries in the mechanisms of agricultural support reflect differences in the social and economic conditions of farming. The negotiations on agriculture should therefore be conducted in a framework that includes a common instrument of measurement, provides for commitments to be made in an equitable way among all countries, and takes into account concerns about food security. The framework should contain specific assurances that, by appropriate use of the common measure as well as other ways, participants would reduce not only internal support but also export subsidies and import protection in a related way.
23. Agreement on such a framework by the time of the July meeting of the trade negotiations committee is critical to the successful completion of the Uruguay Round as a whole. Accordingly, we commend to our negotiators the text submitted by the chairman of the agricultural negotiating group as a means to intensify the negotiations. We intend to maintain a high level of personal involvement and to exercise the political leadership necessary to ensure the successful outcome of these negotiations.
24. Negotiations on market access should achieve agreement on a substantial and balanced package of measures. As regards textiles, the objective is to liberalize the textile and clothing sector through progressive dismantling of trade barriers and its integration, under a precise timetable, into GATT on the basis of strengthened GATT rules and disciplines.
28. For their part, developing countries should substantially reduce their tariffs and increase the percentage of tariffs that are bound; subscribe to balanced and effective restraints on all forms of exceptions, including measures imposed for balance-of-payments difficulties; and participate meaningfully in agreements covering the new areas. The end result should be a single set of multilateral rules applicable to all GATT contracting parties, although some developing countries, especially the last developed, may need longer transition periods or other transitional arrangements on a case-by-case basis.
29. The wide range of substantive results which we seek in all these areas will call for a commitment to strengthen further the institutional framework of the multilateral trading system. In that context, the concept of an international trade organization should be addressed at the conclusion of the Uruguay Round. We also need to improve the dispute settlement process in order to implement the results of the negotiations effectively. This should lead to a commitment to operate only under the multilateral rules.
 
Direct Investment
30. Free flows of investment increase global prosperity by complementing the open international trading system. In particular, foreign direct investment can help restructure the economies of developing and Central and Eastern European countries, create new jobs, and raise living standards.
 
Reform in Central and Eastern Europe
34. We and other countries should assist Central and Eastern European nations that are firmly committed to economic and political reform. Those providing help should favor countries that implement such reforms.
35. Foreign private investment will be vital in the development of Central and Eastern Europe. Capital will flow to countries with open markets and hospitable investment climates. Improved access for their exports will also be important for those Central and Eastern European countries that are opening up their economies. Western governments can support this process by various means, including trade and investment agreements.
37. We recognize that these countries face major problems in cleaning their environment. It will be important to assist the countries of Central and Eastern Europe to develop the necessary policies and infrastructure to confront those environmental problems.
 
Soviet Union
42. We discussed the situation in the Soviet Union, and exchanged views regarding the message that Soviet President Gorbachev sent us several days ago on his economic plans. We welcome the efforts under way in the Soviet Union to liberalize and to create a more open, democratic and pluralistic Soviet society, and to move toward a market-oriented economy. These measures deserve our support. The success of perestroika depends upon the determined pursuit and development of these reform efforts. In particular, we welcome President Gorbachev's suggestion for a sustained economic dialogue.
43. We have all begun, individually and collectively, to assist these reform efforts. We all believe that technical assistance should be provided now to help the Soviet Union move to a market-oriented economy and to mobilize its own resources. Some countries are already in a position to extend large-scale financial credits.
44. We also agreed that further Soviet decisions to introduce more radical steps toward a market-oriented economy, to shift resources substantially away from the military sector and to cut support to nations promoting regional conflict will all improve the prospect for meaningful and sustained economic assistance.
45. We have taken note of the decision of the European Council in Dublin on June 26. We have agreed to ask the I.M.F., the World Bank, the O.E.C.D... to undertake, in close consultation with the commission of the European Communities, a detailed study of the Soviet economy, to make recommendations for its reform and to establish the criteria under which Western economic assistance could effectively support these reforms. This work should be completed by year's end and be convened by the I.M.F.
46. We took note of the importance to the Government of Japan of the peaceful resolution of its dispute with the Soviet Union over the northern territories.
 
Developing Nations
48. We reiterate that our commitment to the developing world will not be weakened by the support for reforming countries in Central and Eastern Europe. The poorest of the developing nations must remain the focus of special attention.
51. Important contributions to a hospitable investment climate can be made by the protection of intellectual property, and by liberalization of investment regimes, including transparent and equitable investment rules and equality of treatment for foreign and domestic investors.
 
Third World Debt
55. Significant progress has been made during the past year under the strengthened debt strategy, which has renewed the resolve in a number of debtor countries to continue economic reforms essential to future growth. In particular, the recent commercial bank agreements with Chile, Costa Rica, Mexico, Morocco, the Philippines and Venezuela involve significant debt and debt-service reduction. Important financial support for debt and debt-service reduction is being provided by the I.M.F. and the World Bank, as well as by Japan.
58. For countries implementing courageous reforms, commercial banks should take realistic and constructive approaches in their negotiations to conclude promptly agreements on financial packages including debt reduction, debt-service reduction and new money.
60. Creditor governments have also provided special support for the poorest countries through the implementation of Toronto terms in Paris Club reschedulings. All of us have canceled official development assistance (ODA) debt for the poorest countries. We encourage the Paris Club to review the implementation of the existing options that apply to the poorest countries.
 
Environment
62. One of our most important responsibilities is to pass on to future generations an environment whose health, beauty, and economic potential are not threatened. Environmental challenges such as climate change, ozone depletion, deforestation, marine pollution, and loss of biological diversity require closer and more effective international cooperation and concrete action. We, as industrialized countries, have an obligation to be leaders in meeting these challenges. We agree that, in the face of threats of irreversible environmental damage, lack of full scientific certainty is no excuse to postpone actions which are justified in their own right. We recognize that strong, growing, market-oriented economies provide the best means for successful environmental protection.
63. Climate change is of key importance. We are committed to undertake common efforts to limit emissions of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide. We strongly support the work of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and look forward to the release of its full report in August. The Second World Climate Conference provides the opportunity for all countries to consider the adoption of strategies and measures for limiting or stabilizing greenhouse gas emissions, and to discuss an effective international response. We reiterate our support for the negotiation of a framework convention on climate change, under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) and the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The convention should be completed by 1992. Work on appropriate implementing protocols should be undertaken as expeditiously as possible and should consider all sources.
 
Narcotics
75. We urge all nations to accede to and complete ratification of the U.N. Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (the Vienna Convention), and to apply provisionally terms of the convention.
77. We support the declaration adopted at the ministerial meeting on drugs convened by the United Kingdom that drug demand reduction should be accorded the same importance in policy and action as the reduction of illicit supply. Developed countries should adopt stronger prevention efforts and assist demand reduction initiatives in other countries.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush was joined by other leaders at the presentation of the group's final communique. From left were Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan; Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy; Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada; Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany; Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Francois Mitterrand of France. (Reuters)

PUB-DATE: July 12, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 870 words

HEADLINE: South Florida Journal;
New Zeal Takes Aim at Official Vice

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 10

 BODY:
If a surge of investigations and indictments of public officials and financiers is any guide, Miami and its sister municipalities have been enjoying their vices even more than usual lately.
According to the United States Attorney's office, more than 30 investigations of corruption by local, state and Federal officials in South Florida are under way so far this year.
''We've indicted more public officials in the last 18 months than were indicted in the last 10 years,'' said Dexter Lehtinen, the acting United States Attorney in Miami.
In the small Dade County town of Sweetwater, for example, the Mayor and members of the City Council have been convicted of wrongdoing in office. In neighboring Hialeah, the Mayor and a member of the City Council have been indicted, and in Miami Beach the Mayor is under investigation. 
The burst of charges against community leaders has prompted soul-searching even in a city like Miami that is accustomed to easy money, fast deals and close relationships between developers and local politicians who control land use and building permits.
City officials whose probity has not been called into question, like Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami, say the current spate of investigations is far from the norm.
But other observers say that corruption among officials is inevitable in this state of seemingly endless real-estate booms and that the crimes being alleged are in fact ''business as usual'' here. What is unusual these days, many believe, is a new prosecutorial zeal.
Mr. Lehtinen has appeared to give some support for that view by repeatedly declaring in recent months that he is making a special effort to increase investigations and prosecutions of public corruption.
He said in an interview that he had assigned some of his best prosecutors to a public corruption unit and has been pressing the issue hard for the last year because ''corruption is a serious problem here in South Florida.''
Allegations of misdeeds have touched leading figures in the private as well as the public sector.
David L. Paul, the former chairman of Centrust Savings Bank of Miami who was once Miami's leading business magnate, is under Federal investigation after the $2 billion collapse of Centrust. The Federal Government seized the company in February and sold it off two weeks ago.
Mayor Alex Daoud of Miami Beach came under the scrutiny of Federal investigators earlier this year when, they found out while investigating Centrust that he had received a total of $35,000 in 1988 and 1989 in supposed legal fees from an insurance subsidiary of Centrust. During that time the Mayor had voted in favor of a zoning waiver to let Mr. Paul extend a disputed teak dock at his island home to better accommodate his new 95-foot $7 million yacht.
Mr. Daoud refused to comment on his vote and the payments. But his lawyer, Alan E. Weinstein, said the Mayor had not broken any laws and had not allowed his vote to be influenced.
''You can be on retainer to a corporate client and vote on an issue involving a member of the firm,'' Mr. Weinstein said. ''That is not illegal.''
He also said the Council vote had been 6 to 1 in favor of the zoning waiver so Mr. Daoud had not cast the deciding vote.
Mr. Paul has consistently refused to comment on the issue, and his lawyer, Sandy Bowrer, said he would not comment either beyond saying Mr. Paul had not broken any laws.
Other business arrangements by local officials have also come under scrutiny. Judge John Gale, a veteran of Dade County Circuit Court, for example, was provided with new Jaguars for 18 years at well below cost by a local dealer.
Judge Gale has denied wrongdoing, but last month the state's Judicial Qualifications Commission formally charged him with ''receiving gifts and favors'' while on the bench. The judge continues to serve and will be allowed to defend his actions before the commission.
In Hialeah earlier this year, Mayor Raul Martinez and Councilman Andres Mejides were removed from office by the Governor under Florida law after being indicted for extortion and racketeering in real estate deals.
In its indictment the United States Attorney's office contended Mayor Martinez received at least $275,000 from alleged racketeering. The indictment charged the Mayor and Councilman Mejides with ''explicitly and implicitly threatening to use their official powers and authority to the economic detriment of the real estate developers, builders and investors.''
Mr. Martinez, who continued to work as a developer while Mayor, has denied all charges of wrongdoing, as has Mr. Mejides.
In Sweetwater, six of the City Council's eight members, including the Mayor, were named in a corruption indictment in January and then removed from office by the Governor. Last week, former Mayor Irain Gonzalez and former Councilmen Antonio Duran and Carmen Menendez were found guilty of conspiracy to commit extortion.
As for the three other Council members removed from office, Hugo Alvarez and Lucio Cobian have pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit extortion and Manuel Avila was an unindicted co-conspirator.
''It's certainly not business as usual,'' said Mayor Suarez of Miami. ''This definitely is embarrassing.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: FLORIDA, USA (96%); 

CITY: MIAMI, FL, USA (96%);
