HEADLINE: Two Worlds of Washington: Turmoil and Growth

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Every day, Ruth Ernst goes downtown from her northwest Washington neighborhood, from a subway stop that did not exist six years ago, to a law firm that had not been formed seven years ago, in a booming commercial center where four years ago metal grates covered decrepit storefronts and fear emptied the streets at dusk.
If what Ms. Ernst calls a ''livable city'' seems part of a civic booster's rosy dream, it coexists with the Chamber of Commerce's worst nightmare: the bloody drug-bred turmoil on the city's streets, the roster of city officials indicted and convicted, the shambles of public housing and the tawdry testimony in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. Caught between the dream and the nightmare is a city reinventing itself, politically, demographically and economically. For most of Mr. Barry's 12 years as Mayor, Washington has been the beneficiary of an economic boom that has transformed the metropolitan area into an archipelago of shining high-rises and mini-urban centers stretching from Tyson's Corner, Va., to Rockville, Md.
 
Facing the Grimmer Side
But while Ms. Ernst and others like her thrive in Washington's boom, people like Robert Taylor, a retired police sergeant, are too often faced with the city's grimmer side: the epidemics of crack, AIDS, teen-age pregnancy, single motherhood and homelessness. 
How much of this change was influenced by the city's Mayor and how much by Congress, which keeps the city on an ever-tightening leash, are a matter of sharp dispute. But there is little dispute that during Mr. Barry's tenure the city became a better place to work and visit and, in many blue-collar and poor neighborhoods, a worse place to live. It has also continued to be a hard place to understand.
''Washington has always been a place the rest of the country looks down on and distrusts,'' said Atlee Schidler, president of the Greater Washington Research Center, a private group. ''In most minds across the country, Washington is divided between Federal bureaucrats and poor blacks. But this is a predominantly middle-class town.''
Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, put it this way: ''The American people see it as an ungovernable or ungoverned city where you can't go into the streets. I'm constantly amazed at people who come in and say, 'This is really a lovely city.' They are surprised it's not Sodom and Gomorrah.''
After all, the afflictions of Washington - the crimes, the drugs, the homelessness - are those of any large city. When the capital's statistics for crimes like rape, assault and robbery are compared with cities like Boston and Baltimore, they are about the same.
When Mr. Barry leaves office in January 1991 - or perhaps earlier, depending on the jury's verdict - he will leave a Washington decked out in the angular stone and glass motifs of high-rent downtown offices: 17 million square feet of new office space since 1985, bringing the city's total to 69 million square feet.
He will also leave a city grimly trying to keep its black middle class, who fled the city in such numbers in the 1970's that the Washington area is now the only major metropolitan region with more blacks in its suburbs (52 percent) than in the city (48 percent). After seven years of population stability in the range of 630,000 people, a sharp downturn in the past three years has left the population at about 604,000, according to the Census Bureau.
But young people continue to move in. Ms. Ernst, 27 years old and three years out of law school, is one of the newest wave of young professional migrants. The perennial crops of young Congressional aides and Government lawyers have been joined by more and more professionals in private business and public-interest groups.
Ms. Ernst's law firm, Ross, Dixon & Masback, which specializes in corporate insurance law, boasts ''competitive'' salaries, meaning $55,000 to $75,000 a year for someone like Ms. Ernst. Nationally, Washington ranks first in the percentage of residents 18 to 34 years old who earn more than $50,000.
''I just like this city,'' said Ms. Ernst, a native of Iowa. ''I like the theater; I like the free things like the Smithsonian museums. Living in the East as a transplanted Midwesterner, I'd choose it over Boston or New York. I like the pace.''
Even so, she said, she still roots for the Cubs and the Bears. ''I don't feel this is my town yet. I don't feel the sense of community here.''
She is not alone in her sense of rootlessness. For years the city of Washington has been a place that people in their early 20's flock to and people in their early 30's flee, said Eunice S. Grier, a demographic researcher.
By the time Ms. Ernst has been here long enough to feel the city's sense of community, she may be gone. ''I miss not having a congressman or senator,'' said Ms. Ernst, who rents a home at the city's northwestern edge. ''If you move a few blocks to the north you get congressmen and senators.''
In Washington, there are plenty of congressmen and senators. But except for Delegate Walter E. Fauntroy, who represents the city but has no vote in Congress, they represent other people. With Mr. Barry's worsening troubles, among them the conviction of top city officials on corruption charges and growing rumors about drug use by the Mayor, these representatives exercised ever tighter control over the city's affairs.
In the late 1970's and early 1980's, the Barry administration devised a workable rent-control program and attempted a face lift on some blighted areas by building municipal centers in outlying neighborhoods. Some of the most pressing issues, including subways and sewage disposal, were regional, and they were solved by collaboration among the potentially fractious mix of Federal, local and state officials.
 
Scandals and Problems Mounted
In the mid-1980's, scandals in the Barry administration multiplied. Simultaneously, the management of the city's prisons faltered and the delivery of health and housing services to the poor repeatedly failed. People were kept waiting for years for a place in often-crumbling public housing and the city's infant mortality rate rose to become the highest in the nation.
For Robert Taylor, the woes are no longer endurable. By the year's end, the 50-year-old retired police sergeant will leave his blue-collar, predominantly black neighborhood east of Union Station and move to a new home outside the city line.
''My youngest son moved to Maryland,'' said Mr. Taylor, a Washington native. ''My oldest son is following me to Maryland. I'm getting there just as soon as my house is built. I'm sick of this city.''
Crime is what makes Mr. Taylor particularly mad. For the last two years the city has had the highest murder rate in the nation.
Crime is not a big worry for Dr. Celia J. Maxwell, although her work as a Howard University Hospital physician and co-director of the university's AIDS clinic takes her up and down the crime corridor on Georgia Avenue. ''When I lived in Manhattan, I was in Upper Harlem,'' said the 39-year-old Panamanian native. ''I'm not cavalier about violence. But compared to Harlem, this was Mickey Mouse.''
Dr. Maxwell moved to Washington in 1980 after graduating from Columbia Medical School because the city was a mecca for black professionals. ''I wanted to be with people who looked like me,'' she said. ''At Howard I could evaluate my performance based entirely on my performance. It has nothing to do with my color.'' Although she feels comfortably rooted, ''taxes are too damn high,'' she said.
The city's per capita local tax burden, at $3,339 in 1988, including property taxes, compares with a national average of $1,772 per capita for combined state and local taxes; only Alaska residents pay more. City officials argue that they have few options. About 42 percent of city land, most of it belonging to the Federal Government, is off the tax rolls. And because two-thirds of the city's workers commute into the city, their taxes go elsewhere.
The most binding element of the complicated relationship between the Federal and District governments is the lump-sum payment the United States makes to the city each year. For the past three years, Congress has frozen the payment at $430 million, less than 14 percent of the district's $3.1 billion budget for the 1990 fiscal year. In the early 1980's the payment was about 20 percent of the budget.
 
Spending Efficiency Questioned
Watchdog groups increasingly question how efficiently the city government is spending that money. Compared with other city, county and state governments, the district's financial efficiency is low. ''The District spends 86 percent above the national average in meeting nearly average needs,'' according to a new study by the federally sponsored Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
The city has one of the nation's highest ratios of public employees to residents, about one worker for every 12 residents. Of the 47,300 city jobs, 10,000 have been added since Mr. Barry took office. In the same time the population fell by more than 30,000 people.
But the city's basic problems, said Harry Hatry, an analyst with the National League of Cities. all come down to the equation that has plagued urban centers for decades: a shrinking middle-class tax base and an intractable core of poverty.
And while the young professionals come and go, the people below the poverty line, about 150,000 of them, remain locked in the city by high housing prices elsewhere. Moreover, 45 percent of the families with children are headed by a single parent.
''Those demographics are what the next mayor is really going to have to fight,'' Mr. Hatry said.

HEADLINE: Ecuador's Debt Is Used To Create Scholarships

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 11

 BODY:
Harvard University and an educational foundation in Ecuador have agreed to begin a program of converting Ecuador's foreign debt into Harvard scholarships for Ecuadorean students, university officials announced Tuesday.
While other debt-conversion plans have been used to finance conservation and health projects in Latin America, Africa and Asia, Harvard's ''debt-for-scholarship'' trade is believed to be the first agreement to exchange foreign debt for educational purposes.
Under terms of the Harvard plan, the university will buy $5 million in Ecuadorean debt - now selling for 15 percent of its face value - for $750,000 from United States banks eager to get the devalued loans off their books. Harvard will then donate the debt to Ecuador's Fundacion Capacitar, an educational foundation that can exchange the debt for Ecuadorean Government bonds worth 50 percent of the debt's face value, or $2.5 million. 
The Ecuadorean Government bonds, issued in local currency, will be sold in Ecuador by the foundation. Income from those sales will be used to buy dollar-denominated securities to support the scholarship fund.
 
Enthusiasm at Harvard
Financial analysts agree that the bonds are unlikely to sell well on the international market. But Teresa Petras, vice president in charge of Ecuadorean debt trading at J. P. Morgan in New York, noted, ''There is a limited secondary market for the local-currency bonds within Ecuador.''
Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok, who was approached by the Ecuadorean foundation about the deal last November, has pressed the university to increase foreign student enrollment and courses in foreign studies.
The fund, expected to produce $100,000 to $200,000 a year for scholarships, will support more than 70 full and partial scholarships over the next 10 years, roughly doubling the number of Ecuadorean scholarship students at Harvard. Money from the fund will also be used to support research grants and internships for Harvard students and professors in Ecuador.
Harvard now spends $70 million a year on student financial aid, said Robert Scott, Harvard's vice president for finance. ''This is going to increase substantially the financial aid we have for these students,'' he said. ''It is a win for everyone.'' He added that the university was interested in pursuing similar agreements with other countries.
 
Other Schools Interested
Several other American universities, including the University of California at Los Angeles, are also pursuing debt-for-scholarship agreements with Ecuador, and the University of Pittsburgh is waiting for approval of a debt-for-education trade that would finance research in Brazil, said Jack Ross, executive director of Debt for Development Coalition Inc., an international development group based in Washington.
For Ecuador, which has an external debt of more than $11 billion, the program will help reduce the debt burden while allowing Ecuadorean students to study at Harvard.
Other developing countries have pursued similar agreements to finance development projects in exchange for debt reduction. As of May, more than $132 million debt-for-development trades had been completed by American banks, according to the Debt for Development Coalition.
In 1987, Bolivia and several environmental groups completed a debt-for-nature trade that promoted land conservation. Another program, in which environmental groups purchased $5.6 million in Costa Rican debt for $700,000 from an American bank, was converted to local currency bonds, and the interest on them financed conservation projects in that country.

HEADLINE: Summit Promise - and Shame;
A Chance, at Least, for Fair Farm Policy

 BODY:
The Houston summit meeting resolved no important dispute. The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations did more agreeing to disagree than agreeing. But to judge their annual economic conference a failure is hasty. The leaders differed about how to aid the Soviet Union. Dismayingly, they condoned help for China. But on the primary issue of agriculture policies, the leaders agreed to phase down protectionist subsidies. 
Their language on farm subsidies is promising; perhaps they are willing finally to use the prestige of their united stance to help face up to domestic political resistance. But the words, however promising, are vague. The world won't know till December if they have bite.
With or without a cold war, economic issues divide the Western alliance. The European Community protects millions of inefficient family farmers by blocking low-cost food imports from big, efficient farms in the U.S. and farms in the third world. The system costs European taxpayers and consumers as much as $100 billion a year, but the European leaders have little stomach for threatening the jobs of politically potent farmers.
The U.S. is in a peculiar position. On the one hand, it too protects domestic agriculture, blocking imports of sugar, peanuts and dairy products. Yet the overwhelming economic interest of the U.S. lies in opening European markets to American grain and other products. And there's even more at stake: the Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks, scheduled to end in December.
Food-exporting countries, especially in the third world, are demanding that the industrialized countries open up their markets to more food imports. In exchange, they will consider new trade rules proposed by the industrialized countries governing services, intellectual property and foreign investment.
If the U.S. and Europe cannot agree to lower protectionist farm subsidies, the third world will likely pull out of the trade talks. That would be a grievous blow to world trade and growth. The impasse can be lifted only by national leaders, and the Houston meeting offered an ideal forum.
Did the Houston summiteers get that job done? The answer is unclear. Their words seem evasive. Yet for the first time, the Europeans specifically agreed to lower export subsidies, internal price supports and tariffs. And each of the European leaders is now armed with an international commitment that can be used against politically entrenched farmers at home.
Still, no European leader faced up to the fact that real reform would cost millions of European farmers their jobs. By December, they will have to offer the food-exporting countries tangible evidence that their products will be allowed in. The Houston summit agreement may fortify the European leaders and enable them to face down their farmers. Or maybe the summit agreements merely allow the leaders to evade brutal politics.
Fortify or evade? The world won't know until the trade negotiators get back to work and hammer out a document for the world's trading partners to consider in December. In the meantime, there's at least the promise of good news.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Toe in the Water: Cuomo Scouts '92 Convention

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Welcoming Democratic National Convention delegates to his home state, the Governor eloquently quotes St. Francis. Five days later he accepts the Presidential nomination, allowing as how he had not aspired to the office and that he would have preferred a better candidate, but noting that ''from such dread responsibility one does not shrink in fear, in self-interest or in false humility.''
The governor was Adlai E. Stevenson. In 1952 he was the last major-party Presidential candidate nominated at a convention in his home state. 
That 40 years later the convention will be held in New York, home state of another eloquent governor who, in his keynote address to the 1984 convention, also cited St. Francis, seems unlikely to influence the choice of a nominee. Nowadays, party conventions largely ratify results of primaries. Stevenson was the last nominee not selected on the first ballot.
Arguably, a candidate nominated in New York can leave lugging the baggage of fear, racial tension, poverty and permissiveness that many out-of-towners reflexively associate with the city. Worse yet if the candidate is a New Yorker. Even in 1924, the Presidential ambitions of Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York were probably not enhanced by the delegates' prolonged exposure to the city over 14 days as they struggled through 103 ballots before nominating John W. Davis.
To the degree that the city puts on its best face for the convention, as it is likely to do again in 1992 in conjunction with the Columbus quinquecentennial, that may redound to its nominee. To the extent that New York's woes are perceived as emblematic of misplaced national Republican priorities, as they were in 1976 when the Ford Administration's urban policy was capsulized in The Daily News's ''Drop Dead'' headline, a candidate could transform adversity into campaign capital. It is the kind of political alchemy that Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo of New York is very good at.
''He's making that case already,'' said John Sasso, who was vice chairman of Michael S. Dukakis's 1988 Presidential campaign.
Last time, Mr. Cuomo flatly declared that he would not be a candidate for President. He said it would be politically impractical to campaign outside the state because, unlike Mr. Dukakis, he was at the mercy of a politically divided Legislature. He was haunted by his defeat in the 1977 New York City mayoral race by a better-prepared rival.
Speculation about a Presidential candidacy enhances Mr. Cuomo's stature in a gubernatorial election year, when he may be spared the scrutiny any incumbent deserves after two terms. He decries the ''semantic carousel'' set spinning by his every disclaimer.
Yet Mr. Cuomo has refrained from stating flatly, as he did before winning a second term in 1986, that running again for governor would preclude a Presidential campaign. His vaguer disclaimers seem less convincing.
''I believe he's going to run,'' Mr. Sasso said yesterday.
For every season there is a candidate. In 1976, Jimmy Carter's integrity was promoted; in 1988, Mr. Dukakis's competence was. ''What they are looking for in '92, I suspect,'' said Robert A. Farmer, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee and Mr. Dukakis's top fund raiser, ''is charisma and vision. That seems to be tailor-made for Governor Cuomo.''
Defying conventional wisdom, the Governor suggested yesterday that hailing from New York might be less of a liability because so many of the city's negative qualities were no longer unique to New York, if they ever were. ''I saw homeless sleeping across the street from the White House,'' he said.
He again dismissed speculation about 1992, suggesting to reporters at a City Hall celebration of New York's snaring of the convention that it was something they save for rainy days. It was raining when Mr. Cuomo was asked why, if he wanted to close the door on a Presidential candidacy, he did not simply rule that out and do the same about a draft, as he did in 1988, 14 months after declaring that he would not be a candidate.
His statement would not be believed, Mr. Cuomo replied. Also, he said, some people would consider it an affirmation that he had something to hide. There is an unstated third reason: Why should he?
It would be shortsighted to rule out a race that because of President Bush's perceived invincibility and the potential importunings of fellow Democrats, Mr. Cuomo might indeed be persuaded to make and to justify in the loftiest terms.
''There has always been that possibility,'' he said. ''I have never foreclosed it.''
How long will he leave the door ajar? ''Until someobdy comes along who's better,'' Mr. Cuomo said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Vows Glorious Show For Democrats

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins accepted the Democratic Party's gift of its 1992 National Convention to New York City yesterday, pledging to make it a ''glorious pageant of progress'' that would ''renew America's progressive values.''
Surrounded by political, business, labor and civic leaders in a packed City Council chamber, Mr. Dinkins signed the city's contract with the national Democratic chairman, Ronald H. Brown. They used a desk that belonged to George Washington when New York was the nation's capital, to make official what was supposed to be secret but had been known for days.
The Mayor promised to spend $20 million in city money to rent and prepare Madison Square Garden and other sites for the 20,000 delegates, alternates and guests and the 15,000 news people expected to arrive in the city two years from this week. He said the crowds would generate $100 million for the local economy. 
 
Private Contributions
The $100 million figure is based on estimates that the delegates and reporters attending the convention, some for four days and some for seven, will each spend an average of $353 a day, or a total of $51 million. The Democratic National Committee itself is expected to spend another $8 million.
All that direct spending would mean new income to local residents and businesses, who would presumably re-use some of it, generating even more activity that - according to the city's economic models -would multiply the direct spending by a factor of 1.7, for a total impact of about $100 million.
Besides the $20 million the city plans to spend - including $6.6 million for police overtime - a host committee of business and labor officials led by Robert E. Rubin, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, has pledged to raise $2.7 million in private contributions of cash and services to entertain and support the conventioneers and their staff.
In addition to Madison Square Garden, the city plans to use the Penta Hotel, the Fashion Institute of Technology and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for press offices and party caucuses, while the Sheraton Centre on Seventh Avenue is to be the official headquarters hotel.
An army of cars, buses and golf carts will shuttle delegates, dignitaries and security guards from place to place.
Mr. Brown, who announced his decision in Washington and then flew to New York to announce it again, called the city ''the center of an international communications universe that will allow our candidate and our party to send a message of hope, empowerment, change and responsibility to millions across America and around the world.''
But even before the celebration had ended, and before they could answer questions about what the convention would mean for New York's myriad problems, from homelessness to crime, Mr. Brown and the others got a taste of what they may be in for.
As Gov. Mario M. Cuomo rose to speak, he was drowned out by an anti-abortion heckler who stood up amid the invited crowd and shouted that the Governor should be excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church.
''This convention has been highjacked by Mario Cuomo's New York City Democrats using the blood of aborted babies!'' the protester yelled.
After the man had left the chamber, Mr. Cuomo paused for a moment, chuckled at the heckling and said, referring to the city's reputation for brashness: ''Let's be honest. It never would have happened in New Orleans,'' the city Mr. Brown turned down in favor of New York. The audience roared.
 
Personal Ties to New York
Mr. Brown said the Louisiana legislature's recent adoption of the strictest anti-abortion law in the country had played a part in New Orleans's loss, but he praised that city's efforts.
In the end, several Democrats said yesterday, Mr. Brown's personal ties to New York had as much to do with his decision as anything else Mr. Brown grew up here, is a longtime friend of Mr. Dinkins and former law student of Mr. Cuomo.
As they celebrated the choice of the convention site and its possible effects, local and state politicians hovered at City Hall yesterday. Mr. Cuomo, who has been regarded as a serious Presidential contender, repeated that he had no plans to run for the Presidency.
Reporters not content with the old game of jousting with Mr. Cuomo forced even Mr. Dinkins, whose assiduous pursuit of the convention has raised some lighthearted speculation about his own national ambitions, to say several times that he wanted only to be a good Mayor.
 
'Dinkins for President'
But the Mayor gave a coy answer in a letter he sent yesterday to the actor Michael Moriarty, who recently sent him a $1,000 check payable to ''Dinkins for President.''
''After we cure all the problems we face in New York, I will have plenty of energy left to lend a hand in Washington,'' Mr. Dinkins wrote. ''But I have to concentrate on New York first, so I'm happy you did not specify the Presidential campaign year for which your check would be valid. Will it hold till the turn of the century?''
In any case, yesterday's announcement was a big victory and a belated birthday present for Mr. Dinkins, who turned 63 on Tuesday. With the brand of majesterial populism that he has mastered, the former Marine marched into the flag-decked chamber as a brass band in the balcony played the Marine Hymn.
Later, Mr. Cuomo gave Mr. Dinkins a birthday present of a tile mosaic panel picturing a red apple, in token of Mr. Dinkins's repeated references to New York as a ''gorgeous mosaic'' of diversity, an image Mr. Cuomo first used years ago. Praising Mr. Dinkins lavishly, the Governor seemed eager to dispel the suggestion of some mayoral aides that he should have left the spotlight yesterday to the Mayor alone.

HEADLINE: Dirty Schools: Will a New Contract Help Clean Them?

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
A little more than two years ago, before the signing of a contract hailed as the start of a new era in school maintenance, New York City school custodians cleaned classrooms every other day, cafeterias once a week and mopped floors three times a year. Head custodians were paid almost $20,000 more than the average teacher and about $7,000 less than the average principal.
Now, as school officials negotiate with the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 891 for a new contract to replace the one that expired June 30, school custodians clean classrooms every other day, cafeterias once a week and mop floors three times a year. A backlog of repairs, from clogged toilets to broken windows, has not abated, nor have complaints from community groups about how difficult it is to reserve the use of school buildings in the evenings. 
Despite assurances that the 1988 contract would improve school maintenance and give principals more control of the buildings they supervise, 60 percent of principals surveyed by the City Comptroller's office last year said custodial service had not improved, while 58 percent said that their custodian does little or no ''hands on'' work.
According to reports both anecdotal and documented, in some schools teachers mop their own classrooms and hallways are swept by students instead of one of the system's 956 custodians or their thousands of staff members.
Principals are still not even sure what duties the custodians are required to perform - and a report by City Council President Andrew J. Stein found that only about half of all principals have copies of the custodians' contract.
Disappointed parents groups and education advocates have renewed their calls for changes in the way the system works. In particular, they want the new contract to spell out the responsibilities of the custodians and of the board.
The president of Local 891, John W. Holahan, agreed yesterday that the cleaning schedule was inadequate, but he said the problem lies beyond the control of his union.
 
'The Board Designed the Schedule'
''I think it's horrendous you're cleaning classrooms every other day and that windows are washed once a year,'' Mr. Holahan said. ''Prior to the 1970's financial crisis we cleaned the building every day. The board designed the schedule; they made the cuts and never restored them.''
Mr. Holahan said the 1988 contract called for a substantial expansion in the types of repairs done by custodians. But he said the board failed to provide materials to make those repairs, resulting in a backlog of 55,000 work orders.
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has said that while there are schools where custodial care is not as it should be, many custodians and their staffs work against the odds to create a clean environment. The limited resources to do the job right make the job difficult, he said.
The contract negotiations, which are not expected to be resolved before the end of the month, represent another test of Mr. Fernandez's political muscle. Among the Chancellor's crusades since taking over in January have been efforts to encourage schools to open their doors to public use, to improve the appearance of school buildings and to restore the balance of power between the board and the custodians union.
''This is a very important negotiation for us,'' said James Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez. ''It's one that has a large impact on the way we run our schools.''
 
Increasing Accountability
At informal meetings over the last three months, Mr. Fernandez and Mr. Holahan agreed that the key areas of discussion will include increased custodial responsibility for maintenance and repair; the use of the schools after 3 P.M. and fees for those activities; removal of asbestos from school buildings, and the relationship between principals and custodians.
Making the custodians more accountable to principals is high on Mr. Fernandez's agenda. While custodians report to the principals, they have complete discretion under existing contracts on how they perform routine cleaning and repairs as long as they meet minimum obligations.
The custodians function both as city employees and independent contractors. Each administers his own staff and an annual allowance for supplies, equipment and salaries. The 1988 contract clarified vague language that in the past led to custodians' refusing to perform routine tasks like repairing a broken window.
But many say the changes did not go far enough. ''My perspective is nothing has changed since 1988,'' said John Fager, vice-president of the citywide Parent Coalition and a former education adviser to Mr. Stein. The father of two children in city schools, he is Director of Education for the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.
 
'The Same Old System'
''Here's an example of a system that has a tremendously adverse impact on the schools and we were supposed to have reform, but we're back to the same old system,'' Mr. Fager said. ''Can you imagine cafeterias that are mopped only once a week? If any of these schools were treated like restaurants they'd be shut down by the Health Department.''
And despite what in 1988 was described as a breakthrough in reducing large fees paid to custodians for after-hours use of school buildings, a report scheduled for release today by a coalition of family service groups said that confusion and perhaps even more red tape remain as barriers to public use of school buildings.
Mr. Holahan said yesterday that principals are responsible for after-school activities and that the rates are set by the Board of Education. But there appears to be widespread confusion among both principals and custodians about who does what.
 
'A Whole Anarchy'
''The contract and the system are so terrible,'' said Barbara Miller, staff director of the Neighborhood Family Services Coalition. ''The custodians do only what they are required to do.''
Ms. Miller said as part of their research, the coalition sent questionnaires to all elementary and intermediate school principals. They also called 11 school district offices seeking information on how a community group could rent school space.
They received six different answers on how space could be rented, only four of which were correct, Ms. Miller said. Eight different fees were quoted, of which three were correct. One district quoted a price that amounted to a 20.5 percent overcharge.
''It's difficult because among the principals and custodians, no one can decide what the fee is or who pays the fee,'' she said. ''It's just a whole anarchy of no one knows what's going on.''

HEADLINE: Hoboken Warns Of Tax Increase After Plan Dies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A vote on Tuesday in which residents rejected a $30 million plan to redevelop Hoboken's waterfront is expected to result in tax increases and layoffs, officials said yesterday.
''We anticipate sizable layoffs,'' said Peg Thomas, director of planning and community development for Hoboken. ''Everyone in the community will have to bear the burden.'' 
The $30 million waterfront development deal with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was defeated by 12 votes - 4,418 to 4,406 - in a special election. The project would have been the first major development on the Hudson River waterfront since cargo ships began taking their business to the ports of Newark and Elizabeth 30 years ago.
As part of the deal, the Port Authority would have also financed $41 million in municipal improvements.
 
Far-Reaching Implications
City officials argued that the plan would bring in much needed revenue and be an attractive replacement for the crumbling warehouses and docks along the waterfront.
But a coalition of environmental, anti-development and community advocates successfully lobbied against the plan, saying it would tarnish the city's image and overwhelm the one-square-mile community.
Hoboken's 42,000 residents will now face increased taxes and cuts in city services as a result of that success, city officials said. They said it was too early to give any exact figures.
''The city will have to reassess its fiscal situation and will have to reorganize,'' said Ms. Thomas, adding that any worker layoffs would be felt across the board. ''There'll be a lot of far-reaching implications and ramifications.''
 
Work Suspended
The city must also repay $7 million it received from the Port Authority, which was already incorporated into the city budget. It will also lose an additional $8 million that was expected from the agency this year.
Under the agreement with the Port Authority, Hoboken would have leased about 32 acres of waterfront to the agency, which would have built 3.2 million square feet of commercial and residential space, including offices and retail stores.
The Port Authority would have also paid the city $30 million during the next five years.
Until an alternate plan is agreed on, the city and the Port Authority have suspended all work on the project.

HEADLINE: H.U.D. Project On Ninth Street Halted by Judge

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
A judge ruled yesterday that the Department of Housing and Urban Development had violated its rules in approving funds for a low-income housing project on the Lower East Side. The judge issued a preliminary order blocking H.U.D. from proceeding on the project.
The project, 80 units of housing for the elderly with low incomes, is planned for Ninth Street and Avenue C, a high-crime area where many houses are boarded up. 
A neighborhood group, La Plaza Defense League, sued to block the project, arguing that in accordance with Federal guidelines the housing should not be approved because of the area's ''undue concentration'' of poor people.
In his decision, Judge William C. Conner of Federal District Court said the housing agency had violated its regulation against allowing projects to add to poor neighborhoods. The reasons for approving the project, the judge added, were subjective and not well considered, saying, ''H.U.D. has paid only lip service to the requirements of its regulation and the purpose of the statute.''
 
Park for the Neighborhood
La Plaza sued after The New York Times reported in October that the regional economist in the housing agency, David Burns, had said that he had originally opposed the project because he felt it violated policy. But Mr. Burns added that his superiors pressured him to approve the housing.
La Plaza says it is seeking to stop the project because it would force the closing of La Plaza park, which is at the site of the proposed housing. The park, built and maintained by neighborhood residents, would be razed. Judge Conner's decision means that the suit can go to trial. In issuing the restraining order, the judge found that La Plaza would most likely win the case at trial.
The lawyer for the league, Harry Kresky, called the ruling ''a very signficant victory for the community.''
The ruling does not mean that the park will remain. Anticipating the project, the city started eviction proceedings against La Plaza. A suit by the group to block the eviction is pending, and Mr. Kresky said the Federal decision would bolster the group's case in Civil Court.
Officials in the regional office of the housing agency said they had not seen the ruling. ''The best we can say is that we will certainly study it closely and consult with the U.S. Attorney's office and the Department of Justice on whether or not we would appeal it,'' said the deputy regional administrator, Burton Bloomburg.

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
If you are one of the 50 million adult Americans who still smoke cigarettes, now is the best time to quit. The incentives to end your affair with nicotine have never been greater.
Nationally, less than three adults in 10 smoke. In many social circles, less than 10 percent of people still smoke, and even fewer dare to smoke in public. And the places where smokers are permitted to light up are growing ever smaller and farther between.
Restrictive legislation and public pressures are increasingly turning smokers into social pariahs who must sneak off by themselves or ask others for permission to smoke. The time is ripe to expedite the goal of the former Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop: to create a smoke-free society by the year 2000. 
The economy can no longer afford the 1,000 deaths a day and the even greater number of serious illnesses directly attributable to cigarette smoking. The majority of Americans who are nonsmokers are no longer willing to have their own health jeopardized by the noxious habit of the minority. The evidence that passive smoking is harmful is so convincing that the Environmental Protection Agency now lists it as a serious environmental hazard.
But how can so many people be weaned from cigarettes? Almost every smoker questioned in surveys believes the habit is personally harmful, and more than four smokers in five expresses a desire to quit. Most have tried one or more times to break their addiction to nicotine; alas, they relapse, usually within a few days or weeks, but sometimes years later. Typically it takes four to 10 attempts before a potential quitter finally makes it stick.
It is certainly not easy - many heavily addicted smokers say quitting was the hardest thing they have ever done, but all who really want to quit can find a way to become former smokers forever. As one exasperated would-be quitter put it: ''There are as many ways to quit smoking as there are people who have quit, and I've tried them all! Now, I've got to find the one that was tailor-made for me.''
 
Tales That Inspire
In a fascinating and inspiring book, ''The Last Puff'' (W. W. Norton, $18.95), Dr. John W. Farquhar and Dr. Gene A. Spiller give 30 former smokers a chance to share the secrets of their success. The stories can be a source of inspiration, hope and helpful hints for smokers who have, like the storytellers, made repeated failed attempts to quit.
Each found a particular trigger that prompted yet another effort, this time for keeps.
One man, a three-pack-a-day smoker for 30 years, finally quit after his wife agreed to the purchase of a fancy new car if he agreed never to smoke in it. Then, as soon as the car arrived, the couple left on a three-week, crosscountry trip in it.
One woman, a college teacher and writer for whom words and cigarettes were intricately entwined, finally decided to quit for good after seeing a smoker who appeared much older than her years and was beginning to ''look like an ashtray'' with wrinkled, gray skin, yellow teeth and fingers, and thin, limp hair.
A man who wrote advertising copy for a tobacco company said he quit ''because it began to nauseate me that I was a slave to tobacco,'' adding, ''My whole life revolved around being able to smoke.'' He had to leave concerts, the theater, movies, every 20 to 25 minutes to smoke and even resented sleeping because it meant he couldn't smoke.
What nearly all had in common was a long ''incubation period'' - usually years of thinking they wanted to get the tobacco monkey off their backs, plus innumerable failed attempts. They also all learned from their earlier failures. They learned what didn't work and, on the final attempt, many tried a new tack.
For Elton W., a public relations specialist, it was a new attitude that spelled success. ''In all the previous attempts,'' he said, ''I acted out of a spirit of self-sacrifice. I was giving up something that I liked and quitting was unpleasant. I felt like a martyr.''
On his final attempt 20 years ago, he changed his perspective. He practiced a new identity: that of a nonsmoker. He imagined himself in all kinds of situations in which someone might offer a cigarette and then said out loud, ''No, thanks, I don't smoke.'' Not ''I'm trying to quit'' but ''No, I don't smoke.'' And he imagined himself to be a super-wholesome person, a squeaky clean Goody Two-Shoes, the kind of person no one would dare to offer a cigarette to.
Several successful quitters found it easiest to do on vacation. Being away from familiar surroundings and the usual triggers and stresses that prompt them to reach for a cigarette helped them break the habit. By the time they returned home, they were over the worst of the addiction, had evolved some alternative actions and were well on the road to being permanent former smokers.
As for the means to this coveted end, more than 90 percent of the 43 million Americans who have stopped smoking did so on their own. Most of the successful quitters quit cold turkey, some after cutting down or switching to a less potent brand of cigarette but most just by throwing away all their cigarettes and their smoking accouterments.
 
Challenge for Women
Women have an especially hard time giving up cigarettes. If current trends continue, in five years there will be more American women than men who are smokers. And smoking-related diseases, like lung cancer, are rising among women at astronomical rates. Yet, most research on quitting techniques has focused on men.
To deal with the special problems of women who smoke, like a fear of weight gain if they quit and a strong dependence on cigarettes to cope with stress, Sue Delaney, herself a former smoker who puffed away two packs a day for 40 years, has written a small but very valuable guide, ''Women Smokers Can Quit: A Different Approach'' (Women's Healthcare Press, $6.95). The book can be purchased directly by calling 800-543-3854 or by writing to Women's Healthcare Press, 500 Davis Street, Suite 700, Evanston, Ill. 60201.
A surprising number of Americans who have stopped smoking say their physician's advice to quit was the most important motivating factor. Yet only 46 percent of all smokers surveyed last year by the United States Public Health Service said they had been advised by a physician to quit smoking. Even fewer people have been actively counseled as to how to go about quitting.
Doctors can now prescribe a nicotine-containing gum to ease withdrawal. For some smokers, this temporary aid enables them to make a concerted effort to stop smoking and wean themselves from a behavioral dependence on cigarettes without suffering through the extreme irritability of nicotine withdrawal that can prompt family, friends and co-workers to beg them to resume smoking. Smokers who depend heavily on the relaxant and stimulant effects of nicotine can become hooked on the gum, but the gum is easier to give up than cigarettes.
Other aids that help some people include hypnosis (especially when the smoker learns self-hypnosis); acupuncture, which can reduce the craving for addictive drugs, and a variety of relaxation techniques, which can calm the raw nerves of a would-be quitter and provide them with an alternative way to relax.
But this does not mean that organized stop-smoking programs are of little or no use. While it is true that less than 10 percent of former smokers quit through such programs, those who do best in a group setting are nearly always smokers who have repeatedly tried to quit on their own and failed. Success is fostered by group support, the feeling that they are not the only ones going through this, the helpful hints offered by the counselor and other participants and in many cases the fact that they paid for the program.
And even when a relapse occurs after completing an organized program, the learning experience can often abet success of a future effort to quit on one's own.
The bottom line of stop-smoking efforts, then, is the old Boy Scout motto: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again, because each failure can be a steppingstone to future success. And by the year 2000 the air both outside and inside the lungs of Americans can be a lot cleaner.

HEADLINE: Summer, Children And 'War of the Exes'

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
FOR legions of divorced fathers, a ritual is under way. A time of love and reunion, it can also be an agony of dashed hopes and recrimination. It is the extended summer visit with the children, an arrangement included in most divorce settlements, which in 9 of 10 cases give custody to the mother.
During most of the year, these ''noncustodial'' parents are weekend fathers. They can be spotted with their children on Saturday-morning shopping trips to suburban malls, when fathers from intact families might be mowing a lawn or playing golf. They order two scoops of ice cream for the youngsters instead of one, and extra chocolate sprinkles.
For many of these men, the summer visit, with its heightened expectations, is also the yearly culmination of a struggle to maintain a parental role, despite what they perceive as formidable obstacles put in their path by the courts and their former spouses. 
From the mother's point of view, giving up a child for part of the summer can also be highly stressful, especially in the first years after a divorce, when emotions can still be raw and animosity between the former spouses at a peak. One mother feeling those worries this week was Dina McClellan, a freelance editor in Manhattan, who was awaiting the return of her two young children from a two-week visit with their father in Jersey City.
''They were all excited, packing their bags, and my daughter didn't even look back at me when she went prancing off with her father,'' she said. ''I was actually shaking and depressed. They see him as a good-time father, where with me, we just kind of hang around together. I feared they liked being with him more.''
The forces that helped break up a marriage, like a struggle for control or an inability to communicate, can quickly resurface during a summer visit. The children can become players, willing or not, in their parents' continuing battle.
A New York business executive was at La Guardia Airport recently to pick up two pre-adolescent sons who live with his former wife in the Midwest. He had mailed them first-class tickets, and they emerge from the plane wearing torn jeans and dirty sneakers. ''I give your mother all this support money, and this is how she dresses you?'' were the first words out of his mouth. The boys looked at each other and smirked. The battle lines were drawn.
''I asked this man if he would start one of his business meetings like that,'' said Jeannette Lofas, a Manhattan therapist who works with divorced fathers, including the one whose airport encounter she described. Ms. Lofas, who heads the Stepfamily Foundation, said summer visits with children can be one of the toughest tests of fatherhood.
''I call it the war of the exes,'' she said. ''If there continues to be bad blood between the ex-spouses, the summer visit can be as painful as the divorce itself. The kids may arrive filled with anger at their father. At home, they've been given too much permission to bad-mouth him. Some arrive as Mom's little spies, to sneak a look at his bank balance or check out his new girlfriend.''
The situation is even thornier if the man has remarried and has other children. There are an estimated 11 million married couples in the United States in which at least one partner has been divorced.
Joe Nasar, a Manhattan accountant, is one remarried father who sought counseling. ''One kid pulls you one way, and the other pulls you another, and your ex-wife and your current wife each want something else,'' Mr. Nasar said. ''A visit can drive you nuts unless you plan it down to the letter.''
Summer visits take two basic forms, said James C. Melamed, the executive director of the Academy of Family Mediators in Eugene, Ore., a national group representing divorce mediators. ''There is the one-to-three-week visit, and the visit covering more than half the summer,'' he said.
The length of the visit usually depends on more than a father's personal commitment. It often hinges on how far the child has to travel, how much vacation the father has, and whether or not a new wife, friends or grandparents can help look after the youngsters, Mr. Melamed said.
Logistics can be an issue. Michael Krouch, a 42-year-old social worker in Westchester County, has a rough road to keep a commitment to his children, one that winds through three states week after week.
One Saturday morning saw Mr. Krouch, who is now single, behind the wheel of his Ford Escort by 8 o'clock. He was headed for the Connecticut home of one of his two former wives to pick up their 6-year-old daughter.
It was the first stop in a complicated weekend routine for Mr. Krouch, who takes graduate courses at Columbia University and tends bar some nights to help make support payments. With his daughter scrunched happily in the front seat beside him, he pointed the Escort westward; 75 minutes later they arrived at a park in Teaneck, N.J., where Mr. Krouch's son from his first marriage, Canaan, 13, was playing in a Little League baseball game.
''Two children from two broken marriages who live in two different states doesn't leave much free time for myself,'' Mr. Krouch said with soft-spoken acceptance, his former wife Debby seated next to him at the game. ''You're always on the go.''
Debby Krouch, a United Airlines supervisor, considered transferring to Denver last summer. But, she said, ''Canaan needs both his parents, and Mike is a good father.''
When children live with their mother in a different city from their father and see him only infrequently, the summer reunion can cause extraordinary stress on all sides, family experts said. For men deprecated by their former wives in front of their children, the visit can turn into a crusade for vindication.
''I had a client who was a businessman who lost his job and had to drive a cab for a while,'' said Ellen Weber, a New York psychotherapist. ''His esteem hit bottom. If he couldn't see his son, that meant his wife had triumphed over him once again, so his attitude with his son was, 'You're going to come see me even if it kills you!' ''
Feelings of powerlessness and humiliation can become so painful during visits that some men cut back on time with their children or drop out of the relationship completely.
Studies of divorced fathers show alarming numbers retreating from emotional and financial commitments after a divorce. By some estimates, nearly half of all children in the custody of their mothers have little or no contact with their fathers.
The numbers have fostered theories that the bonds between men and their children are weaker than those between mothers and children, or that men are more irresponsible. Those assumptions, while they may apply in some cases, hurt those men who agonize over the legal, financial and psychological impediments to close, loving contact with a child.
''A lot of people say fathers don't care about their children and are deserting them,'' said Dr. Marion Lindblad-Goldberg, the director of the family-therapy training center of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic. ''I don't share that view. Many fathers care so much, they try to protect themselves by pulling away. Sometimes their ex-wives make visitation so difficult that just coming by to pick up the kids can be emotionally traumatic.''
Stephen Erickson, a Minneapolis divorce mediator, said that ''even the label of 'noncustodial visiting parent' put on fathers by the divorce courts tells you something.''
''The only other place 'custody' is used is in prisons,'' he said. ''The only other place 'visitation' is used is in funeral parlors.'' Fathers' rights groups say that some embittered former wives will go to great lengths to deny men their legal claim to visit their children. Across the country such groups have sought legislation to establish joint legal custody in uncontested divorces, to give men equal authority in major decisions about their children.
New York does not provide for shared legal custody, and is unlikely to in the foreseeable future, said James Taylor, a fathers' rights campaigner in Clinton, N.Y.
''It's a dead issue for the time being,'' Mr. Taylor said in a telephone interview. He called the state ''a bastion of powerful women's organizations'' that urge women to gain sole custody as a means of control and as a way to insure that fathers keep up with support payments. ''They feel women end up economically on the shorter end of the stick because of a man's greater earning power,'' he said.
Lawrence Morgan, an accountant who is the president of the Fathers' Rights Association of Metro New York-Long Island, said, ''Our family court systems look at fathers only to the extent that they supply money, never that fathers have a right to be involved in a child's educational life, medical life or other components that go into his well-being.''
But not all family experts are convinced that joint custody guarantees that the father will be an involved father. ''I'm still in favor of joint custody because it sends the right signal to fathers, but I don't have any illusions about it,'' said Andrew Cherlin, a Johns Hopkins sociologist who cited studies showing that large numbers of fathers stopped seeing their children, even with joint custody.
''There's a relatively small group of well-educated and sensitive fathers who are prevented by custody arrangements from acting as responsible parents,'' he said. ''But their numbers are dwarfed by those who don't give a darn.''

HEADLINE: Congress Unit Assails U.S. Information Policy

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The Federal Government is ignoring scientific and technical information that could potentially be one of its most valuable weapons in the battle for high-technology international competitiveness, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment reports.
While the Bush Administration has been concerned about the consequences of an industrial policy that favors one industry over another, the report says the White House has overlooked the role that the Federal Government could play by improving access to computerized technical and scientific data bases.
The report, scheduled for release Thursday, sees access to a wide range of information as an essential part of the innovation process. It also describes such information as a central product of the $65 billion that the United States Government spends on research and development. 
 
Controversial Issue
Improving access to Government information by modernizing storage and retrieval systems has become a controversial issue in recent years as information companies and public-interest groups have clashed over how new computerized data bases should be made available to the public. But these groups now appear to be close to a compromise.
The report criticizes the President's Office of Science and Technology Policy for failing to show leadership on the issue.
''During several years of debates on Government-wide information policy, there is no evidence that Office of Science and Technology Policy has been a player in that debate,'' said Fred B. Wood, project director for the Office of Technology Assessment study. ''There has been no one on the executive branch side looking out for the agencies or trying to reflect the broader national interest.''
The Reagan Administration hampered Federal scientific and technical information programs, the report said, because it favored getting the Federal Government out of the business of distributing information and did not pursue policies to modernize distribution systems.
 
Price for Information
In 1985, the Office of Management and Budget issued a document that emphasized the role of private companies in disseminating Federal information and supported the idea of charging people to get it.
Legislation now before Congress would alter the Government's policy to emphasize that Federal agencies have the primary responsibility for providing information.
The report by the Office of Technology Assessment sees computerized data bases as the only way to manage Federal data libraries. It notes that for a Federal initiative to succeed, it must take several steps:
* Create standards for data bases so that information can be freely moved between agencies and users.
* Index data bases and documents so that information is easy to find.
* Increase financing for basic scientific and technical information in Government research and development budgets.
While creating a single centralized Federal information data base is still not technically feasible, the report argues, ''low-cost, user-friendly electronic scientific and technical information'' would stimulate computer-based science, mathematics and engineering education.
Copies of the report, titled ''Helping America Compete: The Role of Scientific and Technical Information,'' can be ordered from the Superintendent of Documents, at the United States Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20402, for $3.75.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.
''The fixed-income market was jolted last Friday by an unexpected upward revision in the May employment figures, and unemployment has still not responded to Fed pressures,'' said Walter S. Frank, the chief economist at Donoghue's. ''So the market, which has been anticipating lower rates for the near future, retreated and rates went up.'' 
This week, interest rates have moderated somewhat.
''Still, the important factor behind any interest-rate adjustment will come from Government budget negotiations and from the weak economy,'' Mr. Frank added. ''Right now, it's an eager market pitted against slow-moving events, accounting for the seesaw effect in rates.''
Tax-exempt money managers increased the number of days securities are held in their portfolios to 49, from 48.
The assets increased by $3 billion, to total $78.9 billion, with the average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield down by 16 basis points, to 5.30 percent, and the 30-day average yield down by 2 basis points, to 5.40 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield would be 7.36 percent, and it would be 7.91 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
 
Calvert Ranks High
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million survyed by IBC/Donoghue's, Calvert Tax Free Reserves, distributed by the Calvert Group in Washington, outperformed the other funds this week by yielding 6.01 percent.
The assets of taxable funds increased by $4.7 billion, to a total of $379.2 billion. Those of institutional funds increased by $800 billion, to $79.6 billion, while the assets of consumer funds rose by $3.9 billion, to a total of $299.6 billion. The gains were attributed to a a narrowing of yield spreads between certificates of deposit and money market funds.
The average days to maturity of taxable securities held in managers' portfolios fell to 43 from 45.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund fell by a basis point, to 7.95 percent, while the 30-day average yield was unchanged at 7.97 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company in Jersey City, showed the best return for the second straight week, with a yield of 8.82 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 41.83 in Heavy Program Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, with oil, high-technology and drug stocks leading the way.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 41.83, to 2,932.67 - just a few points away from the all-time high of 2,935.89 set on June 4. Computerized program trading accounted for more than half the run-up.
Birinyi Associates said it had tracked five buying programs that lifted the Dow 24 points and one selling program that cut the Dow 2 points, for a net gain of 22. A 10-minute buying spree near the end of the day alone accounted for 12 points of the gain, it said. 
Continuing to pick up significantly, trading volume spurted to 162.22 million shares, from 147.63 million the day before. And in a sign that traders must have welcomed, 971 stocks rose, only 506 declined and 74 reached new highs.
Among other stock indexes, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 4.74, to 361.23; the Nasdaq composite, buoyed by technology stocks, rose 2.93, to 463.90, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.68, to 359.41.
 
'Big Position' in Technology
Peter DaPuzzo, co-head of worldwide equities trading in the Lehman Brothers division of Shearson Lehman Hutton, said, ''Technology stocks led the rally Tuesday and again Wednesday despite Oracle's disappointing profits; that shows there's real strength in the tech stocks.''
Mentioning I.B.M., Digital Equipment and Compaq, among others, he said that several big financial institutions were ''taking really big positions'' in such stocks.
''History shows that leadership in the tech stocks creates follow-through in the overall market,'' he said.
One trader said the market was also responding to Alan Greenspan's ''moral suasion.''
Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a House Judiciary subcommittee yesterday that ''short of a constitutional restraint on expenditures, it's very difficult to see what one can do'' about the Federal budget deficit.
''The market likes that kind of talk,'' the trader said.
On a cautionary note, Robert H. Stovall, the president of Stovall/ Twenty-First Advisers, said ''the stock market's heading into a near-term correction - a drop in prices.''
The reason, he said, is that ''the Japanese have made it clear they wish to see the yen go higher versus the dollar; that means higher Japanese interest rates to pull money into the yen.
''Historically, a weak U.S. dollar does not bode well for U.S. stocks or bonds because they become unattractive for non-U.S. investors,'' Mr. Stovall said.
 
Wal-Mart Leads Volume
A minute-by-minute chart of the Dow industrials showed that except for a brief rise after the opening bell and a short decline in the wake of Tuesday's strong selloff, the blue-chip index moved steadily into higher ground for most of the day.
Although Wal-Mart led the New York Stock Exchange's list of 10 most active stocks, rising 3/8, to 33 3/4, on expectations that sales figures out today will be strong, the Dow industrials were prominent on the list.
Recovering from a negative report on tobacco in Barron's, Philip Morris, No. 2 on the list, rose 1 1/8, to 49 1/4, on 2.4 million shares. No. 3, A.T.& T., the most widely held stock, fell 1/8, to 37 3/8, on 2.3 million shares, hitting a new low of 37. It said last month that second-quarter profits would decline.
Fighting off an unwanted takeover bid, DeSoto, a paint and detergents producer, surged 5 1/2, to 45, in heavy trading after saying it would pay stockholders special dividends totaling as much as $28.
In a strong oil group, reacting partly to predictions of sharply higher oil prices coming in a few years, ARCO rose 2 1/8, to 117 5/8; Oryx 1 3/4, to 43; Chevron 1 5/8, to 71; Unocal 1 1/2, to 27 3/4; Royal Dutch 1 1/2, to 76 1/2; Texaco 1 3/8, to 58; Mobil 1 3/8, to 61 5/8, and Amoco 1 1/4, to 51 3/4.
And in a strong drug group, Eli Lilly rose 2 1/8, to 86 7/8; Rorer 2, to 75 3/4; Abbott 1, to 43 3/4; American Home Products 1, to 53; American Cyanamid 1, to 60 7/8; Johnson & Johnson 1 5/8, to 69 5/8, and Merck 1 7/8, to 88 1/4 - all in heavy trading. Health-care stocks are regarded as ''defensive'' in uncertain times.
Among the technology stocks, Oracle Systems fell 2 1/2, to 19 7/8, with 9.36 million shares changing hands - No. 1 on the Nasdaq active list. Despite a 58 percent rise in quarterly profits, analysts said Oracle's earnings were less than expected. But I.B.M. rose 1 3/8, to 119 1/8; Honeywell 1 3/8, to 104 1/2; Digital Equipment 1 1/8, to 86 5/8, and Compaq 7/8, to 64 1/2. On Nasdaq, Conner rose 1, to 27 3/4, and Intel 1 3/4, to 48.Royal Dutch/Shell

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds Modestly; Gold Prices Off in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded modestly yesterday, but foreign-exchange dealers predicted that the United States currency would resume its downward course shortly.
Gold prices were mixed, moving higher overseas but falling in later New York trading.
The dollar picked up more than 2 cents against the British pound and more than a pfennig against the West German mark in New York trading. Dealers attributed yesterday's gains to profit taking as traders sold other currencies that had soared in recent weeks against the dollar. 
Dealers cautioned that despite the dollar's better showing it was still fundamentally weak against the yen, while high interest rates were still shoring up European currencies, including the pound.
 
Yen Prices Mixed
In New York the dollar rose to 148.40 yen from late Tuesday's 148.225. The United States currency reached a four-and-a-half-month low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo, slipping to 148.10 from late Tuesday's 149.60 and was quoted at 148.64 yen in late London trading.
Dealers said the pound should remain firm because of the Government-imposed 15 percent base interest rate on bank lending to curb inflation. The high interest rate continues to attract investor money to London.
The pound slipped to $1.7995 in New York yesterday from late Tuesday's $1.8220. Earlier in London, the pound closed at $1.7980, down 1.75 cents, from $1.8155 late Tuesday.
The dollar rose to 1.6540 marks in New York, compared with 1.64185 late Tuesday. In earlier European trading, it closed at 1.6507 marks, up from 1.6465.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.4020 Swiss francs, up from 1.3930; 5.5515 French francs, up from 5.51225; 1,211.25 Italian lire, up from 1,203.00, and 1.15885 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15695.
Other late rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4030 Swiss francs, up from 1.3945; 5.5285 French francs, up from 5.5270; 1.8582 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8555; 1,207.04 Italian lire, up from 1,207.00, and 1.1586 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1570.
 
Gold Prices Up Overseas
Gold bullion prices rose overseas after falling $4 an ounce Tuesday on reports that between 10 and 15 tons of the metal had been unloaded by Middle East sellers. But gold was lower in domestic trading.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Jack Kemp's Favorite Public Housing Tenant

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Her voice does not invite dissent. Kimi Gray spots a child littering the lawn and responds with a machine gun locution that fuses her words into one unambiguous command: ''Come here, baby -Getthistrashouttamyyard.''
As it happens, the yard in question is not yet Ms. Gray's, although she would very much like it to be. So would Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the two have joined in an unusual Washington collaboration. It has made Ms. Gray, who runs an experiment in tenant management that is aimed at tenant ownership, a symbol of the self-help politics the Secretary promotes as ''bleeding heart conservatism.''
Is she a Republican tool? She curses and says the people with the luxury to think so are not forced to live in public housing. ''If I'm being used, then I like it,'' she said. ''I'm using them too. We're using each other.'' The Best Connections Variously sophisticated, blunt, bellicose, shrewd, articulate and sometimes coarse, Ms. Gray has become perhaps the nation's best known resident of public housing, personifying inner-city hope in frequent network television appearances. She is almost certainly the one with the best Republican connections. 
''Kimi Gray is my hero,'' said Mr. Kemp. He envisions inner cities full of Ms. Grays, people who run their own projects, increasing revenues and services while decreasing vacancies, vandalism and welfare, people who start their own businesses and move to buy their own homes. He is promoting Government policies that he says will help make this happen.
Ms. Gray sat with Mr. Kemp's family during his Senate confirmation hearings, where he called her ''a model for the rest of the country.'' But he is far from her only contact among conservatives. President Reagan was her host at the White House several times. William J. Bennett, the director of drug policy, has sought her advice.
Ms. Gray's place in Republican iconography has upset some who support the concept of tenant management - an idea that arose on the political left. They worry it is being used as a ploy to justify ending Government support for new low-income housing. ''A fraud, a snare, a delusion'' is what Florence Roisman, a staff attorney with the National Housing Law Project, calls Mr. Kemp's plans.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is an admirer of Ms. Gray, cautions that conservatives within the Reagan and Bush Administrations have used ''the exemplary model like Kimi to give the impression they're committed to housing for the poor.'' He added, ''The P.R. may be projecting the person, but the policy's the opposite of the projection.'' Can She Be Copied? Beyond the question of intentions, there are questions about whether Ms. Gray is, in fact, a replicable model. Willful as a freight train, she may be capable of making any neighborhood work. But what will happen under tenant management in places without a Kimi Gray?
And although Ms. Gray is often touted for her self-sufficiency, critics raise the delicate issue of government subsidies. Her apartment complex, Kenilworth-Parkside in Northeast Washington, has benefited from a full deck of government-backed programs to provide health care, day care, substance-abuse counseling, recreation and transportation, as well as government subsidies to operate the apartments themselves. Ms. Gray portrays herself as simply a good grant applicant, not the beneficiary of political favoritism. Either way, a snapshot of Kenilworth would fit as easily into Lyndon Johnson's scrapbook as it does into Mr. Kemp's. She sees the criticisms coming and swats them as though they were flies.
 
'No Such Puppet'
Is she unique? ''There's a Kimi Gray in every housing public housing development in America,'' said Ms. Gray. ''Let's just hope she's not as obese as I am.''
Is she a beneficiary of special treatment? ''People assume that I was a favorite child,'' she said. ''No such puppet.''
Where do her political loyalties reside? She has a stock way of explaining that she is loyal to whoever will further her cause.
''I'm a dollar bill,'' Ms. Gray said. ''And on each bill there's a different President. My family was poor when we had Roosevelt for the White House. We had Kennedy, Nixon, Ford and Carter and we're not richer now.''
The ideological mix surrounding Ms. Gray's public work is reflected in her personal politics. For all the company she keeps on the right, Ms. Gray is a registered Democrat who has twice voted for Mr. Jackson for President and views him as a important role model for black children.
But when speaking of Mr. Kemp, her sharp tongue floats rhapsodic sounds. ''Anybody that loving, understanding and committed to a mission of this type has to be led by God,'' she said. ''It's not just a job for him at H.U.D. It's a mission.''
 
Path to Prominence
Ms. Gray's improbable path to prominence began with a number of backward steps. She had her first child at the age of 14, and had borne five by the time she was 19. When her marriage fell apart, Ms. Gray and her children turned to welfare. In 1966, at the age of 21, she secured an apartment at Kenilworth, the low-rise complex of 37 buildings that became her life's work.
Her reputation as a neighborhood force began to swell in the mid-70's, when some Kenilworth students told her they wanted to attend college. After calling schools, raising money and stoking spirits, she delivered 17 students to campus doorsteps in the first year of a program that continues today. ''Knock on everybody's door,'' she said. ''Get 'em all.''
She took her own advice, finishing a degree at Federal City College, now the University of the District of Columbia, in 1979. Ms. Gray now works as a counseler for the city Recreation Department for $22,000 a year.
 
Rent Collections Rise
She brought the same insistence to her work as a resident manager. The Kenilworth-Parkside Resident Management Corporation began running the complex in 1982, with her as its unpaid chairwoman. Three years later, Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, found that rent collections had increased by 77 percent while vacancy rates dropped to 5 percent from 18 percent. The accountants estimated the city saved $785,000 over four years.
Among the hats Ms. Gray came to wear was that of a one-woman employment agency. The resident corporation hired Kenilworth residents as office and maintenance workers. And it offered prodding - and loans - to residents for an array of small business efforts: a laundromat, a screen-door repair shop, a beauty salon and a catering company. The accountants' study found that 132 Kenilworth residents left welfare during the first three years of resident management.
The secret to her success, Ms. Gray said, is ''residents' being in control of their own destiny.''
But others note that the Kenilworth destiny still involves a good deal of government support.
Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting firm, recently estimated that government subsidies provide about $1.6 million of the $2.3 million the apartment spends each year on utilities and operating expenses. Add to that a $23 million renovation program to modernize the 31-year-old apartments - about $50,000 a piece. And add to that Kenilworth's array of city and federally financed social services.
 
'A Great Deal More Money'
''It does take a great deal more money than what's available in other housing projects,'' said Robert E. McKay, executive director of the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities.
Still, Ms. Gray's talk of owning her destiny very much appealed to Mr. Kemp and his political allies, who have been preaching a theology of inner-city enterprise for more than a decade. While a handful of other tenant leaders had done similar work elsewhere, Ms. Gray's work was happening just across the river (the Anacostia, that is) from Congress and the think tanks, and it gathered the most attention.
Robert Woodson, a conservative who founded the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, introduced her to Mr. Kemp. Stuart Butler, the director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, praised her work in a book on anti-poverty strategies. She, in turn, was the host of a party for him at Kenilworth. ''Ask people from the Brookings Institution how many times they've had book receptions in a housing project,'' he said.
The characteristically complicated politics that surround her were on display several years ago, on the day Kenilworth residents signed an agreement to buy their apartments. The 1987 legislation permitting the sale had been co-sponsored by Mr. Kemp, then a Republican Representative, and Walter Fauntroy, a Democrat who is the District of Columbia's Delegate to the House.
 
'Rained on Our Parade'
But when the White House scheduled a ceremony marking the event just before the 1988 Presidential election, Mr. Fauntroy joined Jesse Jackson at a counterdemonstration to denounce the Reagan Administration's housing policies. Ms. Gray said the two of them ''rained on our parade'' and that Mr. Fauntroy ''staged a protest against his own legislation - that's what it ended up with, no?''
Ms. Gray is now making plans to turn her purchase agreement into a final sale. While the details are still being worked out, H.U.D. guidelines provide for five years of continued Government subsidies to build a reserve fund that residents would then use until tenant contributions meet actual expenses.
And why does Ms. Gray want to own her own home? The question catches her in a rare moment of surprise, as though the answer should be self-evident, and she said:
''I want help on my taxes. I want to leave something to my children. I want to own some brick. That's the American dream, isn't it?''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kimi Gray, right, at the housing project in Washington she runs as an experiment in tenant management. With her is her daughter Tonya. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)
