HEADLINE: FED CONSIDERS CUT IN INTEREST RATES TO BOOST ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Expressing concern that banks have become overly cautious in lending money, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the central bank might need to cut interest rates to keep the economy moving ahead.
Shifting from a long-held position that tight credit conditions were confined to real estate, Mr. Greenspan pointed to slow growth of the money supply and rising rates for commercial loans as evidence of a restriction of credit that poses a threat to continued economic expansion.
''We don't think tightening at this stage would be desirable, and as a consequence may have to act to offset it,'' Mr. Greenspan said in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee.
 
Change Would Be 'Modest'
He said a policy shift would involve ''a very modest change'' in the interest rate on overnight loans among financial institutions, a benchmark rate over which the central bank exercises considerable control by varying the amount of money it provides to the banking system. 
That rate, the Federal funds rate, has stood at 8 1/4 percent since December, and analysts said after Mr. Greenspan's remarks that they expected it to fall in coming weeks to 8 percent.
Such a decline would put downward pressure on interest rates in general, although consumer borrowers might not immediately derive much benefit. A quarter-point reduction in the Federal funds rate might not be immediately reflected in the banks' prime lending rate, which has tended to move in half-point increments lately.
 
Financial Markets Rally
The market for bonds and shorter-term fixed-income securities rallied on the news, as did the stock market, which rose to a record close of 2,969.80 in the Dow Jones industrial average. [Pages D1 and D6.] But the dollar plummeted, as the prospect of lower rates reduced the attractiveness of holding dollars. [Page D13.] Mr. Greenspan and his Federal Reserve colleagues, remaining vigilant against inflation, have been restraining the economy by means of relatively high interest rates. But growth has slowed to an annual rate of less than 2 percent, and the Bush Administration has repeatedly urged in recent weeks that the central bank relax its grip.
Until today, the central bank had given no indication that faltering growth or a pullback in lending had pushed it to the brink of a policy shift.
Mr. Greenspan's statement before the committee today, made in response to a question, said:
''We have been closely watching various interest rate spreads and other indicators to determine if the pulling back of commercial banks to less lax lending standards is moving over the line and, in effect, creating a tightening in credit markets, independent of actions by the Federal Reserve. The cumulating evidence indicates commercial bank loan rates and collateral requirements are firming in the context of an unchanged Federal funds rate. This suggests a market tightening of modest dimensions may be occurring.
''If so, that could have undesirable effects on the economy that the Federal Reserve would have to consider offsetting with an ease in monetary policy.''
Private analysts said this seemed to confirm the widespread belief that Fed strategists decided at a policy-making session last week to tilt to lower rates pending a moment that now appears to be arriving.
''It is very unlikely that Greenspan would have voluntarily raised the possibility of ease without a serious intention of following through,'' declared Robert T. McGee, a senior vice president of Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York. He said the Federal Reserve would look for some excuse to lower interest rates within the next month.
Mr. Greenspan, whose appearance today was formally on the subjects of deposit insurance and wider powers for banks, is to return to the committee next Wednesday to make his required semiannual presentation on the outlook for the economy and monetary policy.
As recently as three weeks ago, Mr. Greenspan said there was little evidence of any broad-based lack of credit, and a Fed survey published at that time stated that ''lenders are reported to have tightened standards especially for real estate loans, but there is still little information that suggests credit restraint is spreading into other markets.''
On Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan met privately over lunch with Senate Republicans and heard various members express fears that reduced lending and high rates could tip an already fragile economy into recession.
Mr. Greenspan, according to some of those present, gave no indication of any intention to move to lower interest rates. Although he apparently was not asked specifically about cutting rates, he did suggest that it would not take much to induce such a move.
One participant, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, told a group of reporters this morning that Mr. Greenspan's thinking is dominated by a fear of recession.
 
Talk of an Obsession
''He's been accused of being obsessed with inflation,'' Mr. Lugar said. ''What he's obsessed with is that growth must continue; we must not have a recession. The growth may be only 1 1/2 percent, as it is now, but it's got to stay positive. Everything we are doing, whether we're talking about the budget, resolution of the savings and loans and so forth, is dependent upon this stream of growth. Absent that, we really do have a lot of problems.''
Mr. Lugar, apparently still reflecting the chairman's comments, pointed out that recession would not only widen the budget deficit because of revenue shortfalls and additional spending but would also prevent a needed rise in the market value of real estate and other savings and loan assets that the Government has taken over and wants to sell.
''Greenspan would say, sure, he's interested in inflation, because he perceives that if we have a binge of inflation we will for sure have a recession,'' Senator Lugar said. ''And that will end the growth, for a while, and we cannot afford to have that.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, talked with the Senate Banking Committee chairman, Donald W. Riegle, left, yesterday before telling the commmittee that the central bank might need to cut interest rates to keep the economy moving. (Associated Press) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Sudan Forces Refugees Back to Barren Lands

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AKON, the Sudan, July 6

 BODY:
In a new tactic in the seven-year Sudanese civil war, the Khartoum Government is forcing tens of thousands of refugees who fled to Khartoum from the south to return home, further straining food supplies in the famine-struck region, relief workers and village chiefs here say.
After two years of preventing more than a million southerners from going back, the Government is now organizing their return from Khartoum to northern Bahr el Ghazal Province around Akon. At the center of the disastrous 1988 famine, Akon can scarcely support its diminished population.
Until now the Government feared that the refugees would provide new recruits for the rebel army in the civil war, which pits the Arab and Islamic north against the African and mostly animist south, if they returned to their homes in rebel-held territory. 
In all, about 60,000 people, mostly of the Dinka ethnic group, have returned to northern Bahr el Ghazal since the beginning of the year, according to a report last month by the United Nations Children's Fund. Because of poor communications and the expulsion of many relief workers from the area by the Khartoum Government, the extent of the influx only became known to the United Nations in late May. The Unicef report called the influx alarming.
 
Food Grown in '89 Running Low
After virtually no harvest in 1988, last year's yield was better but uneven, according to Unicef. And now, the food that was grown in 1989 is running out and the harvest to be reaped about October looks unpromising.
The combination of the returning refugees and the low food reserves means about 125,000 people are in need of food relief in northern Bahr el Ghazal, according to the Unicef report. That part of the Sudan has been a focus of the $130 million international relief effort underway in Government and rebel-held areas of the Sudan for the last 18 months. About half of that amount has been paid for by the United States Agency for International Development, according to American officials.
These days the relief effort, mostly operating under the auspices of the United Nations and the International Committee of the Red Cross, is concentrating on attempting to make the southern Sudan self-sufficient. Where possible, seeds, tools and fishing nets are delivered rather than handout foodstuffs.
But as the lack of expected food for the returning refugees around Akon shows, obstacles to the donors' best intentions abound. Red Cross workers, for example, were stationed in Akon to vaccinate the Dinkas' cattle. In November, the Khartoum Government withdrew permission for the Red Cross to work in Akon, which is under the control of the rebel Sudan Peoples Liberation Army. A Sudanese veterinarian hired by the Red Cross now remains idle in Akon because of a lack of vaccines. Under Red Cross rules intended to reduce corruption, only a full-time Red Cross delegate can receive relief items.
 
Return of Extended Family
And relief food from the United Nations has not materialized because a train that was loaded with 1,500 tons of grain in September in the northern town of Muglad for delivery to the south has been blocked by the Government, according to relief officials of the United Nations and the United States. The Government of Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashir is apparently fearful that the train, destined for the garrison at Aweil, will deliver disproportionate amounts of food along the way to areas under rebel control.
Some relief workers said they believed that by sending the refugees back, the military Government is trying to disrupt the area around Akon, a region mostly populated by members of the Dinka ethnic group, who make up the backbone of the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army. The expulsion of the refugees from Khartoum also relieves the Government of an unpopular presence in the crumbling city, the relief workers said.
For the last five months, relatives of Chief Deng Goc Tong have been streaming back to their villages in this bleached, flat terrain that forms a bridge between Equatorial Africa and the continent's northern deserts, relying on promises that the war and famine they fled is over and a better life awaits them.
For Chief Deng, the return of his extended family is a melancholy experience. He likes to see his people back, yet loathes to see them suffer again.
''But the people prefer to come and die in their homeland,'' said the Chief, who decided to remain at home when many of his relatives struggled north to Khartoum two years ago. ''People are collected by the police in the camps in Khartoum and searched. If you have money, you pay for the train. If you don't they put you in the car free.''
According to the United Nations, the refugees are taken by train to Muglad or Babanusa and then by truck to Abyei, about a four-day walk from Akon.
 
'We Don't Have Enough Seeds'
''When they leave Abyei to begin the walk southward to their homes, they are prevented from carrying food and trade items by army and the local militia,'' the Unicef document says.
A scrawny man with deep creases in his face, Chief Deng has been doing what he can to share the cattle of his clan with the those who are returning. Many, he said, were reduced to eating boiled leaves, wild fruits and the bitter kernels of desert dates.
The crop prospects look poor. ''We don't have enough seeds to plant, not enough food to give energy for those who are lucky to have seeds to cultivate, and now no rain,'' he said. Since February, 43 children and 7 adults who came home to his village have died of malaria, Chief Deng said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Sudanese Government is forcing tens of thousands of refugees back to their homes in the famine-stricken south. ''The people prefer to come and die in their homeland,'' said Chief Deng Goc Tong of his relatives who returned to the area around Akon. (Jane Perlez/The New York Times); Map: Akon, Sudan

SECTION: Section A; Page 7, Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Impasse Ends on U.S. Bill to Aid Europe

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have reached agreement on the structure of an economic aid package for Eastern Europe that would allow the President to provide technical help to Moscow for the first time, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The officials said that tentative agreement on the bill for fiscal 1991 was reached Wednesday night after four months of wrangling. The understanding suggests an emerging consensus between Congress and the Administration on the politically sensitive question of aid to the Soviet Union.
After much initial resistance, the Adminstration appears to have accepted the view of many in Congress that technical aid programs intended to promote free-market economic reforms should also apply to the Soviet Union. The President would be able to offer those programs to Moscow at his own discretion in fiscal 1991. 
Administration officials said they had no idea to what degree Mr. Bush would use such authority. But his acceptance of the language reflects, at least symbolically, a steady shift by the Administration toward a more active role in helping President Mikhail S. Gorbachev succeed.
 
Agreeing on the Conditions
Congress, for its part, seems to be endorsing the President's position that until Moscow undertakes more serious, irreversible steps toward a free-market economy and reduces its military spending, Washington should confine any assistance to technical advisory programs, not cash grants or loans. Mr. Bush affirmed that stance at the economic summit meeting of seven industrial nations this week.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said the President had reiterated in a briefing after the Houston meeting ''that additional economic reforms are necessary.''
''I can only say that I don't dispute the President's statement at this time,'' Mr. Foley said.
Since the meeting of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev in Malta last December, the Administration has been providing limited technical aid to the Soviet Union out of various departmental budgets. Most of the programs have involved exchange visits, like a trip to Moscow by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, or an effort by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to teach Soviet officials how gather accurate economic figures.
 
Money for Ventures and Farms
The cost of most of these programs amounted only to the air fare and daily expenses of the officials involved. What the new legislation would give the President is the power to unlock money and exercise a variety of other options for much broader technical aid to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
The Senate's draft bill, for example, suggests giving the President the authority to extend to East European countries and the Soviet Union programs for developing small private businesses, creating extension services to support family farms, building Western-style legal systems, banks and credit unions, and providing English-language instruction.
The draft would also enable the Administration to establish American business centers in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union. Charging a user's fee, the centers would provide office space, translation services, secretarial help and legal assistance to American businesses seeking to start up enterprises in the formerly Communist countries.
The bill also includes financial aid packages along the lines of those approved for Poland and Hungary last year. But it restricts the use of such direct aid to specified Eastern European countries and prohibits it from going to the Soviet Union.
The Administration and Congress are still at odds over how much money should be allocated for the bill and which technical assistance programs should be included. The Administration is seeking as much freedom as possible in choosing programs, and the Senate bill is designed to provide such leeway in exchange for assurances that certain programs will be put into force.
The Senate bill calls for $536 million for fiscal 1991, including $70 million for the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The Administration only wants to spend $300 million, including outlays on the European development bank. A House version calls for $489 million.
 
Insisting on Clause for Soviets
Agreement on the basic structure of the bill was reached in talks between Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who is coordinating Eastern European aid for the Administration, and Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Europe. Mr. Biden is drafting the Senate version of the aid package with Sen. Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who chairs the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Since the negotiations began in February, Mr. Biden has insisted that the bill for fiscal 1991 include some language that would authorize the President to use the programs not only for former Communist countries in Eastern Europe but for technical aid to promote changes in the Soviet Union.
The Administration initially resisted the inclusion of even technical assistance to Moscow in the bill, saying that the question of aid to the Soviet Union should be dealt with separately. Administration officials argued that writing such authority into the legislation might reduce incentives for the Soviets to enact difficult free-market reforms.
They contended that the language could increase pressure on the Administration to follow the example of West Germany and other European countries that are eager to give financial aid to Moscow before the changes there are in place. The White House was also worried that it would be criticized by the right wing of the Republican Party.
 
Signal From Eagleburger
But on Wednesday night, Mr. Eagleburger signaled to Senator Biden that the Administration was prepared to accept his broad language on the issue. The phrasing would allow the President to use any program authority in the bill when he determines ''that the use of such authority would assist the emergence or transition of that country from Communist rule through the development or strengthening of Democratic institutions and the practices of a free market economy.''
''The challenge and opportunity in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union today demands that the President assume more active leadership,'' Mr. Biden said, ''not by giving money to President Gorbachev, but by supporting the reform process in the Soviet Union. This bill will enable him to do that.''
A senior Administration official said: ''It is hard to argue against it now. There has been a change in attitude at the level of the President, albeit slight. It has moved from an attitude in which it was unimaginable that public or private funds be used to help the Soviets do their restructuring, to at least entertaining the possibility. We are not there yet, though.''

HEADLINE: Republicans on the Attack In Savings and Loan Crisis

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 12

 BODY:
Unnerved by the rising public outrage over the nation's savings and loan scandal, the Republican Party opened an orchestrated effort today to blame the Democrats before the Democrats succeed in their effort to blame the Republicans.
''We're fighting back, plain and simple,'' said Charles Black, a leading Republican strategist. ''They've got more guys involved in this than we do.''
In speeches and hallway remarks at the Republican National Committee's summer meeting, which is being attended as well by other prominent Republicans, there were efforts to cite the soaring interest rates during the Carter Administration and savings and loan operators' big campaign contributions to Democrats to explain why the scandal was not the fault of President Bush and his party. 
''For a few million dollars in campaign contributions, the Democrats sold out the taxpayers,'' Edward J. Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said in a speech here this afternoon.
 
A Central Political Issue
The attention being devoted to the matter here effectively demonstrated that the Democrats, with considerable help from news organizations' focus this week on the troubles of the President's son Neil, a former director of the now-defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, had succeeded in making the issue a central one in the politics of 1990.
Several Republicans here expressed concern that the issue posed great perils for them, and there was also a general feeling that the party's national chairman, Lee Atwater, was being sorely missed in their efforts to combat it. Mr. Atwater, who for months has been suffering from a brain tumor, was readmitted to a Washington hospital Wednesday night for treatment and observation.
Mayor Susan Myrick of Charlotte, N.C., warned her Republican colleagues that voters were furious that many billions of dollars would have to be spent to clean up the savings and loan industry. ''Because there is a Republican in the White House, you know who gets the blame,'' she said. ''We do.''
That is just what Democrats have been hoping, and the attention on Neil Bush, who has been accused of conflict of interest, has only increased their glee. ''What's scaring the Republicans is Neil Bush - that's too close to home,'' Richard Bates, executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said in a telephone interview today.
 
Brown's Opening Salvo
Neil Bush's problems mushroomed just as the Democrats decided to go on the offensive. The Democratic national chairman, Ronald H. Brown, announced at his party's summer meeting in Portland, Ore., two weeks ago that they would make the savings and loan scandal a central theme in their attacks on Republicans this year.
Mr. Brown, in a speech and an interview at the time, made it clear that he was willing to pay the price of hurting some office holders of his own party if by sharpening the focus on the issue he could portray Republicans as protectors of the wealthy.
In responding today to Mr. Brown's remarks in Portland, Mr. Rollins said in his own speech: ''Brown says we Republicans will only raise taxes to bail out wealthy savings and loan speculators. He says the Reagan-Bush Administration created this crisis. I say Ron Brown is proof that America's education system needs reform. If Ron Brown thinks the Republican Party wants to bail out the Democratic campaign contributors, who caused the savings and loan mess, he must be dreaming and prayimg.''
Mr. Rollins ran through a list of former and present Democratic members of Congress - including Speaker Thomas S. Foley; former Speaker Jim Wright; Tony Coelho, former House Democratic whip, and Ferdinand St. Germain, former chairman of the House Banking Committee - and said they had all received substantial campaign contributions from the savings and loan industry.
He said that this was the reason why the industry was given greater Federal insurance and less supervision during the 1980's and that, contrary to the Democrats' assertion, the reason had nothing to do with the Reagan Administration's drive toward deregulation.
 
A Late Deletion
The text of Mr. Rollins's speech included a line that said House Republican leaders had not received any money from savings and loan institutions. But he did not read that when he delivered his speech.
In the telephone interview, Mr. Bates, the Democratic strategist, noted that most House Republican leaders -including Robert H. Michel, the minority leader, and Newt Gingrich, the minority whip - had received contributions from savings and loan operators, as had the Republican National Commitee and Mr. Rollins's own National Republican Congressional Commitee.
Mr. Bates called Mr. Rollins's speech ''the rantings and ravings of a desperate man with selective amnesia.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 844 words

HEADLINE: Pauperized Workers Are Price of 'Free' Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The foreign-trade deal the Bush Administration has negotiated with Japan (front page, June 29) follows the thinking of the Reagan Administration and will continue the giveaway of essential interests of the United States. Because it assumes that unregulated foreign trade - always called ''free trade'' - automatically benefits both nations involved, this viewpoint makes light of the one-sidedness of United States trade. The net takeover of our markets by excess imports, and the shrinkage of our industries and jobs, is attributed to some outside factor, and token policies are devised to deal with these imaginary causes.
Thus, the real causes of the self-destructive pattern of United States foreign trade were not touched by the Reagan Administration's initiating unfair trade practices investigations or getting commitments from other countries to increase their ''economic growth.'' Neither will they be touched by the Bush Administration's getting Japan to increase its public-works spending, to speed up the issuing of patents, to reduce protection of small shops and to increase prosecution of bid rigging. These actions may be desirable, but their effect on the huge United States trade deficit with Japan will be long delayed and trivial. Saving the economic future of the United States requires the regulation of United States imports to bring about balanced, two-way-benefit trade with countries that differ from us in economic policies and institutions, market sizes and qualities, wage levels and other ways. 
The widening spread in American incomes and the worsening plight of our ordinary workers is shown by data and has been viewed with concern by many commentators. Americans were once proud of being the only country where the factory parking lot was filled with the workers' cars - cars of one-income families. Two incomes may not permit workers to raise a family in today's United States, and the situation is continuing to worsen.
History provides an illuminating parallel. The ancient Roman Republic became politically unworkable largely because the jobs of ordinary Roman workers and small farmers were taken over by cheaper outside labor, in this case by burgeoning use of imported slave labor. Slave labor was cheaper than the labor of free Romans. Thus, ''the free market'' said, ''Use the slave labor.'' Doing so enriched Roman landowners and the affluent. But the shift to slave labor took away the jobs of ordinary Romans, who had been the backbone of Rome's armies and state. They became an unemployed proletariat in the city of Rome, degraded by politicians' free bread and circuses - and Rome as a republic stopped working.
The United States turned the jobs of its ordinary workers over to outside labor - because it was cheaper than American labor - by accepting imports vastly in excess of our exports, imports that are cheaper than American-made goods because of foreign wage levels a tenth or less as high (as was initially true of Japan, which now relies on other advantages over United States production). One-sided immigration of low-wage labor has the same effect. The Americans whose jobs are given away to outside labor, like the pauperized Roman workers and farmers, will not go away. They have no place to go. They are finding that the available temporary jobs, the part-time jobs, the minimum-wage jobs without job security, medical insurance and retirement benefits do not permit them to live and raise a family like other Americans - not even when both spouses work. What is to become of these people? What will become of a United States in which groups not subject to such foreign competition live extravagantly, while the ordinary workers thrown by one-sided foreign trade into wage competition with the poorest of the world's burgeoning millions of poor become outcasts in their own country?
The economic theory on which United States policy is based evades this problem by assuming an imaginary world in which unemployment is cured by lowering wage levels, where foreign trade and job shifts automatically balance out and where cheaper implies more efficient. Laissez-faire economics and the Bush foreign trade policy perhaps would work in this imaginary world - just as Communist economics perhaps would work in its imaginary world.
But in the world of reality, the United States is self-destructing in permitting one-sided ''free trade'' to throw ordinary American workers into competition with hundreds of millions of foreign workers who can live on much less than they. This kind of ''free trade'' may be a time bomb of laissez-faire ideology more deadly even than ''free'' savings and loan association pillaging, ''free'' airline mergers, ''free'' liquidate-American-industry takeover deals, the ''free'' selling of America to foreigners and ''free'' government spending without taxes.
 
JOHN M. CULBERTSON
 Madison, Wis., July 3, 1990
The writer, emeritus professor of commerce at the University of Wisconsin, is author of ''The Trade Threat, and U. S. Trade Policy.''

HEADLINE: Space Program Builds America's Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Big Science, Little Gain'' (editorial, June 24), you make a cogent parallel between the United States space program and the Pharaonic penchant for pyramid building in ancient Egypt. Nevertheless, I must disagree with your conclusions.
The ancient Egyptian public-works project was sold to the public in those days, under the umbrella of religion, as the supreme national undertaking: to build the portals through which the deceased Pharaohs could span the crossing from the world of mortals to that of the gods. Be that as it may, pyramid building did provide employment to countless artisans and other surplus labor, and indeed produced momentous gains for civilization in mathematics and measurement, architecture, medicine and other spinoffs. Some of this later passed on to the Greeks, although much of it was lost with the destruction of the great library of Alexandria. I cannot discern any convincing evidence that the erection of the pyramids had much, if anything, to do with hastening the decline of Egyptian civilization many centuries later. 
The United States space program has begun building the infrastructure of our grandchildren's economy and is enabling scientists and engineers laid off (permanently, we hope) from military industries to channel their energies into a direction private industry will not enter for lack of short-term profit. While huge government programs are wasteful and inefficient, and that the space program may never bridge the light-years gap between our planet and distant galaxies, the future of our wounded biosphere demands that we shift many pollution-ridden process industries into space in the next century and begin robot-mining the mineral wealth of asteroids and nearby planets to save our suffocating Mother Earth. Nothing short of a total commitment can accomplish this task.
The Japanese and others may reap interim advantages by selling us more of their microchip-based gadgets for a while and buying some of our real estate in exchange, but we'll get it all back when camera-toting Japanese tourists and others line up to board commercial space-bound American-built shuttles of the future.
As for ''small science,'' perhaps that should be left mainly for small countries to do.
 
JACK BARRY
 Rehovoth, Israel, June 26, 1990

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
After The Cold War (2)

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
Through most of its history this has been an unmilitarized country. The Framers of the Constitution wanted it that way. To prevent a large standing army becoming a habit, they provided that Congress could not appropriate money for the military ''for a longer term than two years.''
In the time of the cold war the unmilitarized tradition has been abandoned. For four decades the United States has had millions of men under arms. Much of our resources and our scientific intellect has gone to build expensive new weapons. The country has been transformed into a national security state. 
Right now we have the greatest opportunity in two generations to shed the burdens of militarism and return to the older American tradition. The crumbling of the Warsaw Pact and the changes in the Soviet Union dramatically lessen the threat that was the premise of our militarization. But will we seize the day? Last week in London the leaders of the Western alliance declared the cold war over. That declaration surely indicates that the time has come to rethink American national security policy, to focus on how to reduce the military burden. But in the last week newspapers have told us of these developments:
* The armed forces are pressing ahead with plans to buy 4.5 million more acres of land in this country, to add to the 25 million they already have for bombing ranges, bases and the like.
* An all-out enthusiast for the Strategic Defense Initiative, Henry Cooper, was named to head the star wars program, whose planners want between $55 billion and $69 billion to put a first phase in space in the next 10 years.
* The Pentagon is insisting on buying a $4 billion radar-jamming device, the Airborne Self-Protection Jammer, that has failed its flight tests.
All of those, and much else, tell us that it is business as usual in the national security state. NATO may announce the end of the cold war, political pressures may force cutbacks here and there, but the minds of Washington are not thinking about fundamental change in the direction of policy. The aim is to preserve as much of the status quo as possible.
To go on that way, unthinkingly, would be profound folly. For the militarization of the cold war years has done terrible damage to the real sources of American security, our constitutional system of government and our economic strength.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan spelled it out, movingly, in a piece last month in The New York Review of Books. He wrote about the costs to this country of becoming ''a national security state, geared for war at all times.''
''As everything became secret,'' Senator Moynihan said, ''it became ever more difficult to correct mistakes. Why? Because most of the people who might spot the mistakes were kept from knowing about them because the mistakes were classified. . . .
''The national security state began to threaten the Constitution itself. From the time of the Vietnam War . . . the executive branch has been more and more tempted to use secrecy to avoid responsibility, even legality. The Iran-contra affair was only the latest such episode. . . .
''The national security state consumes the Presidency. It grows more and more insulated from the people. . . .''
That the United States has paid a heavy economic price for cold war militarization is hardly necessary to argue - not when we see the boom in the two countries that avoided most of that burden, Japan and Germany. We have a military-industrial-scientific complex that limits our ability to compete in the civilian goods the world wants.
The interests that fed on the cold war will fight change. That is only natural. No one gives up money and power easily. The question is whether the national interest can prevail over the parochial, and that is a question of political leadership.
It is not a conservative-liberal issue, or should not be. Conservatives do not like big government and concentrated power, which have been by-products of militarization. It is not suggested that we rush into massive demobilization; there are still uncertainties. But we have to change direction, and there should be no pain in thinking about that. Senator Moynihan put it:
''How do we now demobilize? How do we move from a national security state to a government that merely asks what are our interests abroad and our needs at home, and calmly and openly pursues them? What a wonderful challenge!''

HEADLINE: The Talk of Sullivan County;
Victory Leaves a Prosecutor With an Orphaned Court

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

 BODY:
More than two years after the Sullivan County District Attorney's office asked, in an anonymous complaint, that a state judicial commission investigate the county court judge here, prosecutors have emerged triumphant in theory, if a little traumatized in practice.
Last fall the panel, the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct, censured the judge, 68-year-old Eugene M. Hanofee, for improprieties ranging from banishing a Legal Aid lawyer from his courtroom to seeking favored treatment from another judge.
In April a second panel, the Advisory Committee on Judicial Ethics, recommended, as the District Attorney had earlier requested, that the judge remove himself from any case involving the District Attorney's office, the Legal Aid Society or any other lawyer who had testified for or against him before the commission.
That has left prosecutors without a judge of their own, like students perpetually assigned subsitute teachers: Judge Hanofee, the only County Court judge, had handled all of the criminal cases in semirural Sullivan County, where crack houses co-exist with Catskill resorts. 
For the next two years, until Judge Hanofee reaches the mandatory retirement age of 70, he will be reassigned to other counties; judges from other counties, meanwhile, will rotate through here every four weeks.
 
Judge of the Month
''We're thinking of handing out judge-of-the-month T-shirts,'' the District Attorney, Stephen F. Lungen said. ''We may be upstate, but we're close enough to New York City that we have a significant criminal caseload, and having to deal with a new judge every month has inherent problems.'' John Ferrara, a staff lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of Sullivan County, said, ''It has the potential of being a disaster.
''The cases in the pretrial stage are stagnating, and we're going to have a bottleneck soon,'' he said.
But the bureaucratic morass aside, Mr. Lungen said Mr. Hanofee's reassignement was ''the right thing.''
''You can't have a legal system that operates on distrust,'' he said. The District Attorney's office and Judge Hanofee had shared a well-known strained relationship for some time.
It was Mr. Ferrara who was barred from Mr. Hanofee's courtroom for 88 days in early 1988 after he raised objections to remarks made by the judge. During sentencing of a Cuban-born defendant charged with selling drugs, Judge Hanofee said that if the defendant, a United States resident of 18 years but not a citizen, is ''unhappy with our justice system'' then ''perhaps he should go back where he came from.''
One of the charges against the judge was that he made ethnically derogatory comments to five Hispanic defendants. While that charge sparked the most anger in the county, where hotel jobs draw many Hispanic workers, it was ultimately dismissed by the Commission on Judicial Conduct.
 
A Taxing Night's Rest
 Not too many decades ago, Sullivan County was home to hundreds of hotels, there for New Yorkers who needed a breather from New York City. Then came easy air travel, Club Med and Atlantic City, and today, only a handful of resort hotels remain. ''We're an endangered species,'' said Milton Kutsher, president of Kutsher's Hotel and Country Club, one of the survivors here.
Sensitive to their precarious future, hotel owners rose up last year in a failed effort to defeat a proposed county tax of 2 percent on hotel room charges. Still reeling from that loss, the hotels were hit just last month with a new state hotel tax of 5 percent on rooms over $100 a night.
The resort hotels received a ''food credit'' of 50 percent toward the new county and state taxes since three meals are included in room rates. But guests are starting to grumble. Between the state and county sales tax of 7 percent, the county hotel tax and the new state hotel tax, a couple staying in a choice double room for one week at Kutsher's now pays $157.50 in taxes, on top of the $1,500 room charge.
''Of course, I object,'' said Harvey Klein, a 70-year-old Bronx resident, stopping in the lobby recently. ''They're getting enough already.'' Others are taking the taxes in stride. ''I'm taxed to the hilt anyway, so what's the difference?'' said Roberta Scotti, a 51-year-old Manhattan resident staying at the Concord Resort Hotel here. ''I have wonderful memories of coming to Sullivan County as a girl. I know it's a depressed area, and I'm willing to pay my share.''
What made last year's debate over the relatively small county hotel tax so emotional was that a historically symbiotic relationship had soured. Afraid that the new tax would hurt business, hotel owners accused the county, which for years benefited from tourists, of kicking the industry while it was down. County officials countered that they had simply run out of options in their search for new sources of revenue.
 
Bye-Bye, Bungalows
 Clusters of summer cottages, known as bungalow colonies, were enormously popular in Sullivan County in the 1940's and 50's. Tourist interest has since withered, however, and scores of empty, crumbling bungalows blight the countryside.
Now, a movement is afoot to tear them down. ''I'd rather see trees and grass than dilapidated buildings,'' said Darryl J. Kaplan, the Town Supervisor in Fallsburg, whose idea to order the demolition of unsound bungalows has caught on in other towns. ''When people see buildings falling apart, they feel down and out.''
In the last few years, 220 structures, mostly bungalows, were razed in Fallsburg after property owners were found in violation of safety ordinances that were on the books but unenforced. In all but two cases, the owners hired wrecking crews themselves. ''There's a realization that we need to clean up our act,'' said the county's Director of Economic Development, Paula Osenni.
 
No Bashful Billboards
 A profusion of roadside signs advertising motels and meals greets motorists all along Route 17, the main drag through the Catskills, as well as on quieter roads. In a great billboard debate raging in the county, some residents say the signs are alluring and attract tourists, while others say they are lurid and turn people off.
Two years ago, the Sullivan County Visual Quality Task Force, a 10-member panel appointed by the county, drafted a model ordinance for towns to adopt that greatly restricts the size, color, lighting, typography and placement of new signs. It mandated that available billboards be painted dark green instead of bright yellow.
But to date, only one of the 15 towns in Sullivan, Highland, is seriously considering its enactment.
''The business owners say the county can't develop without signs,'' said Nicholas A. Michaels, an architect and task force chairman. ''But I say look at Vermont, Nantucket and other classy resort areas. They have the strictest sign ordinances in the nation, and they're booming.''

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Goals Similar, but Florio and Cuomo Split on Strategy

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Not long into their respective tenures as Governors of New York and New Jersey, Mario M. Cuomo and Jim Florio each audaciously expressed political philosophies of unapologetic liberalism.
For Mr. Cuomo, that expression came most boldly in his riveting keynote address to the 1984 Democratic National Convention.
For Mr. Florio, a gubernatorial rookie, it came last month when he sponsored a stunning series of against-the-conservative-grain tax increases and measures aimed at redistributing income and school aid. Those initiatives - which strive toward a traditional, but these days rarely realized, liberal goal of narrowing the gap between the wealthy and the less so - he willfully pushed through a dazed and at times fearful Legislature.
 
Challenge to Assumptions
Whether that turns out to be good politics, much less good government, remains to be seen. But what is clear is that Mr. Florio is challenging many assumptions about what is possible or politically wise for a governor to do. 
And in the process, Jim Florio, son of an Italian-American dockworker in Brooklyn, and Mario Cuomo, son of an Italian immigrant grocer in Queens, have offered a striking example of how two similarly strong-willed men of similar political persuasion can wind up with vastly different governing strategies and images, shaped by political, governmental and economic circumstance, political strategy and, more murkily, character.
''They share a critical vision of what government should be now in terms of income redistribution and public aid to schools,'' said Richard Wade, a professor of history at the City University of New York and a longtime Cuomo adviser. ''But what Mario has done incrementally, this guy has done in one fell swoop. Mario was the liberal in the age of conservatism. He had to go against the tide all the time. That's what made him so distinctive. But the tide is changing, and Florio is a little ahead of it. He's on the whitecap.
''It's also a difference in personality. Mario is a liberal, there's no doubt about it. But politically he's by nature more prudent, more cautious. Mario doesn't get many people mad, while this fellow doesn't care.''
Indeed, said George Sternlieb, a professor emeritus at Rutgers University and founder of its Center for Urban Policy Research, ''I think Florio is taking one of the great political gambles of the century.''
If it works, Professor Sternlieb said, Mr. Florio ''is going to be the hero of the 90's, as the guy who first caught sight of the fact that class warfare is back and you can run against the rich and tax them.'' If that strategy does not work, Professor Sternlieb added, ''he'll go from rooster to capon overnight.''
The differences in style have as much to do with differences in states as in men, many observers pointed out. Mr. Florio won his first term in a landslide in November, garnering 62 percent of the vote and sweeping Democratic majorities into both houses of the Legislature.
When Mr. Cuomo, now in the midst of a re-election campaign, won his first term in 1982, he squeaked to victory and has had to live with a contentious Republican majority in the State Senate ever since, to say nothing of a contentious Democratic majority in the Assembly.
In New Jersey, the Governor's supremacy runs further. Aside from United States Senators, of whom Bill Bradley, a fellow Democrat who looms almost as large as Mr. Cuomo as a Presidential prospect, Mr. Florio is the only official elected statewide. There are three others in New York. Different Terrain, Distinct Approach Mr. Florio has broad patronage powers. And with few television stations in the state, it is particularly difficult for opposition figures to emerge as prominently.
The governmental terrain is also far different. When Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983, New York was home to what by many measures was the heaviest tax structure in the nation and one of the most progressive. Competitiveness was the issue, Mr. Cuomo says, as much as redistribution is for Mr. Florio now.
Even after Mr. Florio had prodded the Legislature to double the income-tax rate for the wealthiest citizens, households with incomes of less than $250,000 will still pay less than their counterparts in New York.
Finally, by most measures, the different levels of government are far more dependent on local property taxes in New Jersey than in virtually any other state. That has led to a wide disparity in school spending between rich and poor areas that the State Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional even as Mr. Florio was pushing his school-financing plan through the Legislature.
In New York, although the disparities are great, they usually do not approach those in New Jersey. The State Court of Appeals has several times declined to throw out New York's school-aid formula.
But even in light of all the differences, their approaches are in many ways remarkably distinct.
Mr. Florio's multibillion-dollar school and tax plan had clearly identifiable goals, not only to pay the bills, but also to do so by shifting wealth from the rich to poor and struggling middle-class families. To balance a budget that was hundreds of millions of dollars in the hole, a situation that he attributed to his Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, he and the Legislature raised the sales tax, from 6 to 7 percent, and extended its reach - generating an estimated $1.3 billion.
Incidental taxes and fees were raised as well, to the tune of $200 million a year. In addition, by doubling the highest income-tax rate, to 7 percent, Mr. Florio and the Legislature expect to raise an additional $1.25 billion next year for school aid to less-affluent districts, property-tax rebates for the poor and middle class and a state takeover of many welfare and social-service payments from the counties.
His administration maintains that 83 percent of the state's taxpayers would not pay more in income tax as a result of the measure, which applies only to income beyond $150,000 for couples and $75,000 for individuals.
 
How They React Under Pressure
 If Mr. Florio faces critics who contend that his program is reckless, needlessly divisive and perhaps suicidal, Mr. Cuomo has frequently had to deal with criticism of another sort, that he is too tentative and ''Hamlet-like'' in the face of contentious issues.
In his first year in office he gave a ringing inaugural address, presided over the successful resolution of a prison uprising, negotiated the early balancing of a budget in a year of large deficits and personally championed the passage of the state's first large bond issue in years.
Yet Warren M. Anderson, at the time the Senate majority leader, noted that the State of the State Message included 33 study commissions and other panels, devices that he contended were allowing Mr. Cuomo to avoid making hard decisions. Mr. Cuomo strongly dissented from that conclusion.
Mr. Cuomo, in a telephone interview last week, expressed frustration that what he considers the accomplishments of his administration had not been properly recognized. He cited three fundamental reasons.
First, he said, he has expressly refrained from concentrating his emphasis on a few major themes and areas, instead moving on many fronts at once.
Second, because of Senate opposition some initiatives have been thwarted or taken years to pass. Third, as someone who has won high marks for oratory, Mr. Cuomo said, he has been a victim of the ''dumb blond theory,'' which in this version holds that because he speaks well he must not be able to do anything else, like govern.
''We swamp people with lists of the accomplishments,'' he said. ''We have a very long list of accomplishments that I think have not been properly noted, at least until recently, because I have never focused on just one issue.
''I have never focused on just education. If I had, with nearly a 100 percent increase in school aid, with money for 170,000 computers in the schools, with our Liberty Scholarship program, I could very easily say we are the education state.
''If you wanted to take infrastructure, nobody is even close over the last eight years. We did three bond issues, every one of which people said could not get done. We have the first acid-rain law, the first seat-belt law.
''You see what happened is because I never stood up and said this is our claim to fame. Because we didn't make it simple and focused, it never got the attention that it deserved.''
 
'Playing Catch-Up With New York'
 Indeed, Mr, Cuomo's chief of staff, Gerald Crotty, can add amply to the list.
One million jobs have been added to the state economy, and the administration points to its efforts to cut taxes as a reason.
Norman Adler, an adviser who helped Mr. Cuomo win election and then had a falling out with him, concluded, ''A lot of the stuff in New Jersey that people look at as visionary is really playing catch-up with New York. It's hard to compare a veteran of seven and a half years with a divided Legislature with a guy just coming in with total control over the Legislature.''
Maybe so, but there are those who see comparisons. ''The Governor won by an incredible landslide four years ago, and you didn't get this radical approach,'' Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said. ''I've always viewed the Governor as a moderate'' whose changes ''have been incremental.''
Mr. Cuomo's liberal reputation, Mr. Miller said, owes more to his opposition to the death penalty, which Mr. Florio favors, than to anything else.
The issue of school aid, and how it has played out in the two states, shows how difficult it is to separate out factors like personality, tactics and the realities of the political landscape.
In 1988, Mr. Cuomo appointed a commission to study school aid that recommended a drastic increase in New York City's share. The Governor used the recommendations as the basis of his school-aid proposal this year. But many legislators said they never took the proposal as do-or-die, and it went by the board amid other budget problems.
 
Cordial Praise For Each Other
 Mr. Miller said that although the Governor had the proposal in his budget he ''never fought for it with the Legislature.'' But even if he did, Mr. Miller said, because of the Republican-controlled Senate, ''it's probably a dream that you can't do.''
''Even if he dug in, I don't think you can win the fight,'' Mr. Miller said.
In regard to each other, the Governors extend cordial, if not effusive, praise.
''A very impressive, articulate person with a great future on the national level,'' Mr. Florio said of Mr. Cuomo.
''Superb,'' Mr. Cuomo said of Mr. Florio's handling of his fiscal situation, which he said required bold action. Still, Mr. Cuomo said, raising taxes does not define a liberal agenda.
It falls to their proponents to sing more abundant praise. Ann F. Lewis, former executive director of Americans for Democratic Action, a major liberal lobbying group, said: ''There are a handful of Democratic leaders who have spoken to the best the party has to offer, who have had the courage to say, 'We are better than this.' I think Mario Cuomo has been one.''
Ms. Lewis described Mr. Florio's recent legislative session as breathtaking. His actions, she said, ''represent the future of American politics.''
Not surprisingly, Roger Stone, a Republican consultant who has run campaigns for candidates who opposed Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio, said:
''They do share the same grand vision of redistribution of wealth. Florio is more open in his public-be-damned attitude. Cuomo knows how to obfuscate. I think he's a liberal, but somewhat less ideological. Only time will tell us which one of them is a better politician.''

Cuomo, moving against the conservative tide, has achieved his results incrementally. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Florio Signs and Explains Tax Rise

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 12

 BODY:
The battle over how to explain the largest tax increase in New Jersey history was joined by Gov. Jim Florio today, as he signed the bill to raise $1.25 billion in new income taxes. He described the action as property-tax relief for the middle class.
The law, which will raise the top tax bracket, to 7 percent from 3.5, for top wage earners, will provide money for increased school aid to less-affluent districts and for property-tax rebates to families that earn less than $100,000 a year.
''What we are doing today is for the people in the middle who've just been squeezed and squeezed and squeezed,'' Mr. Florio said as he stood in front of a chart that showed 17 percent of taxpayers will pay higher income taxes. ''Look at the numbers on this chart that clearly show who is going to pay higher taxes and who is not. The vast majority of people are not. It's that simple and it's that fair.'' 
In recent weeks thousands of New Jerseyans have expressed rage at the Democratic Governor, describing him as an autocrat who is raising taxes at a time when average residents can ill-afford to pay them. To the chagrin of Democrats, many of the 6,000 people attending an anti-tax rally here on July 1 were just the middle- and lower-income voters whom Mr. Florio says he is trying to help.
 
Moves by County Boards
An ad hoc group of anti-tax protesters, Hands Across New Jersey, is gathering signatures around the state protesting the tax increases and asking for the right to recall Mr. Florio, a provision that does not exist under state law.
In addition, the Boards of County Freeholders in Bergen, Morris and Hunterdon voted this week to place non-binding referendums on the ballot in the fall to urge the repeal of the tax increases. The income-tax rise is scheduled to start on Jan. 1; the sales tax was raised, to 7 percent from 6, on July 1.
Although Mr. Florio has said a majority of taxpayers would benefit under the complex set of bills that the Legislature passed last month, he acknowledged that many New Jerseyans did not understand what was in it for them. His next goal, he said shortly after the bills had been approved, was to do a better job of explaining how his fiscal policies will work.
At the signing of the income-tax bill in his office in the State House, Mr. Florio stood beside Rich Mauro, a warehouse worker from Carteret, who, Mr. Florio said, was struggling with wife and three children against the rising cost of property taxes for middle-income families. The income-tax package, Mr. Florio said, is intended to help families like the Mauros.
 
Describing Who Will Pay
In a handout the administration described the people who will pay higher income taxes as 17 percent of the taxpayers. Single people will begin to pay higher taxes on taxable incomes of more than $35,000. Families and single heads of households will begin to pay added taxes on taxable incomes of more than $70,000.
The administration said 89 percent of the new taxes would be paid by people making more than $100,000 a year. The top rate, doubling from 3.5 to 7 percent, will be levied on incomes of more than $75,000 for single people and incomes of more than $150,000 for families or heads of households.
Without detailed statewide polling, it is hard to determine exactly how most New Jerseyans perceive the increases. Most politicians agreed that it was easier for voters to understand that sales and income taxes were going up than new and complex formulas.
Republicans have been generally delighted with what they say are a public repugnance with Mr. Florio's policies.
''It has been horrible for Florio and the Democrats, at least the reaction among my constituents,'' said Garabed Haytaian, Republican of Hackettstown and the Assembly minority leader. ''People are truly upset.''

Mr. Florio said middle-income families like the Mauros would benefit from the income-tax increase. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Presents Anti-Drug Curriculum for Schools

BYLINE: By LESLIE MAITLAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
The Department of Education today issued a detailed program for drug prevention lessons that it will send to more than 120,000 school administrators across the country, in an effort to teach children skills for resisting drug use.
This is the first time the department has offered a curriculum model to all the nation's schools.
In a press conference, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos emphasized that his department was not trying to mandate what schools must teach, but was proposing a curriculum they might voluntarily add to their current drug prevention efforts.
The curriculum, which covers kindergarten through 12th grade, is based on research into child development and is intended to teach children self-esteem, decision-making skills and a sense of personal and civic responsibility. 
''This emphasis on civic responsibility helps students understand that drug use is not just a personal choice with only personal consequences,'' Mr. Cavazos said. ''Students learn that drug use is part of a culture of pain and potential violence that harms both individuals and society as a whole. And they learn that they can help change this culture through their own behaviors.''
 
Guidance for Parents
The curriculum, ''Learning to Live Drug Free,'' is intended to give children with the psychological tools and the information on the social, economic and health effects of drug use to help them resist peer pressure and make healthy choices for their lives, Mr. Cavazos said.
The program offers guidance for parents, teachers and communities and offers methods for infusing drug prevention into a range of subject areas: health, physical education, language arts, mathematics, science, social studies, art and music.
But to underscore that it is not dictating a comprehensive lesson plan, the department is issuing the curriculum in a looseleaf binder, so that schools may take from it what they want or add their own materials.
''We want it to be a living document,'' said one of the principal authors, Charles H. Flatter, a professor of human development at the University of Maryland who has been on the board of advisers to the children's television program ''Sesame Street.''
 
'Prevention Messages'
In an introduction, the plan's authors explain that while the curriculum model includes information on drugs and drug use, ''it focuses primarily on positive prevention messages: being drug free is something to be proud of; building children's academic and life skills is an important drug prevention strategy; and providing appropriate adult guidance is necessary so that youths will choose to participate in wholesome, healthy activities.''
The time when children make ''big decisions about who they're going to be in life'' is moving down to age 10 or 12, Dr. Flatter said, adding, ''Good decision-making and peer refusal skills have to start before that age.''
At the earliest level, kindergarten through third grade, the curriculum suggests encouraging children in activities like drawing ''Good Person Shields'' depicting things they like about themselves. It advises teaching children how to solve problems by having them play roles in dramas about stressful social situations. Seventh and eighth graders, for example, are presented with situations such as the following:
''You share a locker with a very popular student at school. Before school one morning, you open the locker and discover a small plastic bag with something in it that you think looks like marijuana. You must decide how to speak to your locker partner about your discovery. You do not want to jump to conclusions about the contents of the bag and why the bag is in your locker, but this locker also belongs to you, and you are responsible for its contents.''
 
Concern on Implementation
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, today commended Mr. Cavazos on the curriculum, but questioned whether it would be broadly implemented.
''I hope the Secretary plans to follow up the distribution of this document with incentives for these schools to make this a reality,'' Mr. Rangel said. ''Otherwise, this is just another pile of Washington white paper.''
Lee Dogoloff, executive director of the American Council on Drug Education, and Elizabeth Karnes of the National Commission on Drug-Free Schools, said the curriculum model is likely to be welcomed enthusiastically by administrators. They were among a group of experts who were consulted on the model before its publication.
Mr. Dogoloff, a member of the President's Drug Advisory Council and a drug adviser to former President Carter, said the model represented a ''terrific contribution.''
''Most drug prevention curricula are quite expensive, running into the thousands of dollars and also require special training, which is expensive,'' Mr. Dogoloff said. ''This is free and it is good. Now, there's no reason why every school in this country shouldn't have an adequate drug curriculum.''
Dr. Karnes, who is a curriculum expert and a school board member in Omaha, said: ''There has been a demand for this from teachers, administrators and parents all over the country.'' She noted that many curriculums fail because they simply impart information about drugs, which may actually spark students' curiosity.
'' 'Just say no' is not enough,'' she said, echoing the theme that Nancy Reagan had made the motto of her drug war. ''Children need alternatives.''
In his comments today, Mr. Cavazos said ''the format of the model is designed for easy and continual expansion, revision and adaptation,'' and he urged teachers nationwide to provide the department with examples of how they introduce the prevention theme into their school lesson plans. The department expects to send out the curriculum within the next two weeks. It put the total cost of the project at $1 million.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
Whatever else the participants at the economic summit meeting accomplished, President FRANCOIS MITTERRAND of France came away with a new title: distinguished professor of architecture at the University of Houston. The title and an honorary doctorate of humanities was awarded in a hastily arranged presentation yesterday at the university's College of Architecture, the four-year-old building created by Philip Johnson after a design by the 19th century French architect Claude-Nicolas Ledoux. 
Of possibly greater interest to Mr. Mitterrand was the college's current exhibition, Architecture Capitales a Paris. The exhibition features the 11 buildings and design projects known as his Grands Travaux, works that involved Mr. Mitterrand. His participation in the projects, which included the glass pyramidal addition to the Louvre and the Musee D'Orsay, won him praise and condemnation.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
Dr. ARNOLD RELMAN , editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine, is to retire next June after 14 years at the helm of the prestigious chronicle of medical research. Dr. Relman, who is 67 years old, said he plans to write, teach and lecture. The weekly magazine is owned and published by the Massachusetts Medical Society, which is to form a committee to select a successor to Dr. Relman. 
During his tenure, the journal became a forum for examining social and economic issues in medicine as well as reporting research findings. Dr. Relman was frequently criticized for using the journal to question, among other things, the growing role of business in medical care.
Many colleagues agree that Dr. Relman's chief accomplishment has been taking the journal into the contentious area of medical finance and ethics. The journal has reported on and commented editorially upon such matters as the growth of profit-making medicine and conflicts of interests that affect physicians.
''I want to spend the next few years as a more active participant in what I think will be a growing national discussion of health care,'' Dr. Relman said. ''I think the medical profession can make a major contribution toward solving the health care problems of this country if it will rouse itself.''

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased Slightly Last Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lower prices and special promotions increased business at stores last month but sluggish economic conditions continued to restrain overall sales growth, the nation's largest retailers said yesterday.
Despite the small rebounds, analysts say retailing has been facing a difficult period because consumers have been losing confidence in their financial security and have grown more cautious about spending.
''People no longer whip out their plastic cards for anything that catches their fancy,'' said Kurt Barnard, a retailing consultant and publisher of an industry newsletter in New York. 
Jeffrey Edelman of Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. said, ''I think we are witnessing a gradual slowing in the consumer sector.''
 
Reluctant Shoppers
 Weaknesses in employment and income growth, combined with heavy debt loads, have made shoppers reluctant to spend freely, especially when considering purchases of expensive, long-lasting merchandise.
In an indication that the Federal Reserve Board is worried about the economy's prospects, Alan Greenspan, the chairman, suggested yesterday the central bank might nudge interest rates lower.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee in Washington that slow growth in the nation's money supply and increasing commercial interest rates indicated that credit conditions might be tightening without central bank action.
 
3.5% Gain at Sears
 Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, posted a June gain of 3.5 percent, after a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase in same-store sales in May. The June figure was still unimpressive, the analysts said.
Gains at same stores, those open at least a year, give a more accurate reading of a retailer's performance. New stores typically attract extra shoppers who do not return regularly.
The promotional activity and markdowns, which reduce the amount of money that retailers receive for goods, are expected to impede the industry's profitability.
''Second-quarter profits are going to be under pressure,'' Mr. Edelman said.
 
Low Summer Inventories
 Most retailers have not had to cut prices drastically or resort to unplanned clearances because they were carrying lean inventories of summer goods. But the markdowns have been more prevalent than the industry had anticipated when the season began, the analysts said.
Several discounters did much better than the industry average.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., a nationwide chain in Bentonville, Ark., that is the country's third-largest retailer, said its June sales soared by 28 percent. Its sales at stores open a year or longer grew by 14 percent.
Target, the discount-store division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis, posted a 14 percent gain in total sales and an 8 percent gain in its same-store sales. But Dayton Hudson's department stores had a same-store sales increase of only 1 percent.
Following is a list of the sales of the other largest retailers:
 
Sears said its sales in the five weeks ended on July 7 rose 3.7 percent. Its same-store sales increased 3.5 percent.
K Mart Corporation, based in Troy, Mich., said its sales in the five weeks ended on July 4 rose 13.7 percent, while same-store sales grew 4.3 percent.
J. C. Penney Company, based in Dallas, said its June sales rose 5.3 percent. On a comparable-store basis, sales grew 4.1 percent.
May Department Stores Company, based in St. Louis, reported a total June sales gain of 8 percent. Its comparable-store sales rose 3.2 percent.
The Limited Inc., based in Columbus, Ohio, posted a 15 percent increase in total June sales. Its same-store sales rose 5 percent.
The Gap Inc., based in San Francisco, said its total June sales surged 31 percent, while its same-store sales increased 24 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 37.13 to Set a Record

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
The prospect of lower interest rates and higher corporate profits pushed stock prices to record levels yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average surged by 37.13, to a new high for the blue-chip average of 2,969.80.
Volume was heavy and program trading again accounted for almost half the gain. The day was choppy, marked by three computerized selling programs before 11 A.M. and five buying ones starting at noon. 
Referring to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Peter G. Grennan, the senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., remarked, ''Greenspan finally mentioned the word 'ease.' ''
 
Fed May Lower Rates
 Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, Mr. Greenspan cautiously raised the possibility that if, as it appears, bankers were tightening credit, the Fed ''would have to consider offsetting with an ease in monetary policy.''
The previous record for the Dow had been 2,935.89, set on June 15. The gauge also broke the previous intraday record of 2,956.93, set on June 13.
But the record set in June for the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks still stands at 367.40, although the index rose by 4.21 yesterday, to 365.44.
Although traders still remained cautious before today's figures on the Producer Price Index are released, volume rose sharply to 211.5 million shares, the highest level since the middle of May, when it stood at 225.4 million. On Wednesday, volume amounted to 162.2 million shares.
And in yet another good sign for investors, 987 issues advanced while only 545 were down.
 
Factors in Gain
 Two big factors in yesterday's strong gain, Mr. Grennan said, were ''the conclusion from what Mr. Greenspan said that he will protect the economy from going into a recession'' and, after a flood of weak earnings in recent weeks, several ''positive earnings'' reports. Mr. Grennan mentioned Motorola, Safeway, Walgreen and Fannie Mae.
After reporting poor earnings, Computer Associates, a software producer, tumbled by 6 1/4, to 10 1/4, with 7.9 million shares changing hands. It led the New York Stock Exchange's list of the 10 most active stocks. And although it reported a rise in its profits, the stock also reached a new low of 10 1/8 after the analysts said they were disappointed with the gain.
Timothy McCollum of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. eliminated his recommendation, while John Maxwell of Dillon, Read & Company cut his earnings estimate.
 
Contel Soars $7.125
 The Contel Corporation, the telecommunications giant based in Atlanta, soared by 7 1/8, to 35 1/8, on 4.8 million shares after GTE, the telephone company, offered to buy it for about $6 billion in stock. GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., offered 1.27 shares of its stock, or $37.78 1/4 a share at yesterday's price, for each Contel share. GTE fell by 1 1/4, to 29 3/4, with 6.6 million shares trading.
Although telecommunications issues have been lagging lately, the Contel move put new life in the telephone sector - except for the regional Bell telephone companies.
Contel Cellular, which is 90 percent owned by Contel, jumped by 3 3/8, to 21, in over-the-counter trading, while Lincoln Telecommunications increased by 3 1/4, to 28. On the Big Board, Rochester Telephone rose 3, to 34 3/4; Southern New England Telecommunications rose by 2 1/2, to 35 5/8, and Century Telephone gained 2 3/4, to 30. ; On the American Stock Exchange, Telephone and Data Systems rose 1 7/8, to 38 1/4.
But Nynex fell yesterday after The Wall Street Journal disclosed on its front page that it had uncovered evidence of what it called ''a series of bawdy gatherings at Florida resorts.''
Nynex, which traded as low as 77, fell by 1 1/8, to 78 5/8, in heavy volume. Although the traders expected some fallout from the Nynex problem, all of the Bell regionals bounced back from their lows of the day, but Ameritech fell by 3/8, to 59 1/4.
 
Oil Issues Continue Rise
 With oil prices strengthening, petroleum stocks continued to rise sharply. ARCO increased by 4 1/4, to 121 7/8; British Petroleum by 2 1/4, to 71 5/8; Texaco by 2 1/8, to 60 1/8; Chevron by 2 7/8, to 73 7/8; Mobil by 1 7/8, to 63 1/2; Pennzoil by 2 3/8, to 78 3/4, and Amerada Hess by 2, to 47 1/2.
Motel 6, the Dallas economy chain, rose by 2 5/8, to 19 1/4, after is agreed to be acquired by Accor S.A., a French company, for about $1.3 billion.
Among other gauges, the Nasdaq composite index rose by 3.27, to 467.26, while the Amex's market-value index gained 2.82, to 362.23.

HEADLINE: Brady Gives Views on Bill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady acknowledged today that the Bush Administration would probably fail to persuade the Senate to pass all of its proposals to revise the regulation of the financial markets.
But Mr. Brady refused to say whether he would accept a compromise to insure the passage of some of the changes. 
''I understand that we won't get everything in the legislation,'' Mr. Brady said in response to a question from Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. ''But I would not want to comment at this time on what a second-best solution was.''
The possibility of a compromise was first raised on Wednesday when the Senate Banking Committee began its hearings on the Treasury Department's proposal to shift jurisdiction over stock index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. It would also transfer the authority to set margins from the Chicago exchanges to the S.E.C.
The Senate is divided over the proposal, which is opposed by the commodity futures board and agriculture interests on Capitol Hill. A vote is not expected until the end of the hearings, which is scheduled for July 24.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 12

 BODY:
A surge in exports widened Japan's trade surplus by 27.5 percent in June, causing some analysts to believe that an 18-month shrinking of the trade imbalance may be over.
Japan's unadjusted customs-cleared trade surplus expanded to $6.72 billion in June, compared with $5.27 billion a year ago, the Finance Ministry said today. 
Behind the larger surplus was the first year-to-year rise in exports in nine months, Government officials and analysts said.
The surplus grew from levels a year ago for the first time since March and registered its largest year-to-year increase since February 1989, when it rose 38 percent from the previous year.
Economists said the yen's recent weakness accounted for much of the surplus's growth. A cheaper yen makes Japan's exports more competitively priced abroad.
June exports climbed 4.7 percent from the previous year, to $23.76 billion, bolstered by an 8 percent increase in exports by Japanese auto makers, with much of that going to Europe.
Imports fell 2.2 percent in June, to $17.04 billion. Although import growth was not expected to be strong, the decline surprised some economists who had expected surging domestic demand to offset expansion in exports.
The June trade data disclosed a narrower trade surplus with the United States.
