HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Tumbles in Selloff After Greenspan's Remarks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday in a selloff set off by comments by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who suggested that the central bank might consider lowering interest rates.
The Fed chief's comments in Congressional testimony caught many foreign exchange dealers holding portfolios weighted heavily toward the dollar.
Renewed technical buying in later afternoon New York trading carried the dollar above its session lows against other key currencies but it still ended below Wednesday's closing levels. 
In overseas and early United States trading, the dollar was driven higher amid buying inspired by the lack of any currency-related announcements when the seven major industrialized nations concluded the Houston summit conference on Wednesday.
It had been expected that the leaders would indicate support for a stronger Japanese yen. But the dollar abruptly reversed course around midday in New York after reports of Mr. Greenspan's comments to the Senate Banking Committee reached the market.
Hugh Walsh, a currency dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York, said as the session progressed traders began to view Mr. Greenspan's comments more skeptically, which may have aided the recovery in the dollar. He said Mr. Greenspan only stated the possibility that the Fed might ease monetary policy and did not declare that it would do so, or when.
In New York the dollar closed at 147.40 yen, down from 148.40 yen late Wednesday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.90 Japanese yen from 148.10. In London late Thursday the dollar was quoted lower at 148.45 yen.
A pound was quoted at $1.8130 late in New York, stronger than Wednesday's late level of $1.7995. In European trading, it closed at $1.7995, more expensive for buyers than late Wednesday's $1.7980.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.6355 German marks, down from 1.6540; 1.3895 Swiss francs, down from 1.4020; 5.4910 French francs, down from 5.5515; 1,198.75 Italian lire, down from 1,211.25, and 1.15675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15885.
Selected late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday's levels, were: 1.6525 German marks, up from 1.6507; 1.4020 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030; 5.5460 French francs, up from 5.5285; 1.8625 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8582; 1,211.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.04, and 1.1580 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1586.
The British pound closed higher despite a day of speculation about criticism of West Germany, France and the European Community by Britain's Trade and Industry Secretary, Nicholas Ridley.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery added $4 a troy ounce to settle at $358.10. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357.70 an ounce, up $4.30 from Wednesday.
The late gold bid in London, the major metals market, was $351.75 a troy ounce, down from $354.45.

HEADLINE: Days of Fruit Tramp's Painful Harvest Fade

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
Luther Henry Tindal, who is 45 years old and looks 60, and his wife, Linda, 34, rest on a dust-caked couch outside their $125-a-month cinderblock shack here, smoking discount cigarettes and drinking discount beer.
Their four children, ages 2 to 15, play in the sandy soil under a walnut tree with Buck, the pet goat, and Tramp Two, the pet mongrel. (An alligator in Florida ate Tramp One.) ''L. H.,'' as people know Mr. Tindal, had all his teeth pulled years ago, and Mrs. Tindal has lost most of hers. He is 5 feet 6 inches tall and once weighed 125 pounds. He says he is now down to about 95; he speculates that this is because of - a bout with tuberculosis four years ago and working among pesticides in fruit orchards.
 
Poverty and Hard Work
Mr. Tindal's poverty, his hard living and the toll of both on his health are emblems of a disappearing strain of migrant farm workers. He is a one of a huge clan, current and former migrant workers all, that includes his four other children from a previous marriage, his 10 brothers and sisters, Mrs. Tindal's 15 brothers and sisters, along with scores of cousins, other relatives and unrelated hangers-on. 
These are ''Grapes of Wrath'' people, native-born Americans, who follow the fruit and vegetable harvests in jalopies from Florida through Georgia and the Carolinas to Michigan and upstate New York. Unlike most migrant workers who are bound to a crew chief, these are independent operators who take pride in their skills, covet their freedom and exist in the shadows of public scrutiny. They call themselves ''fruit tramps'' to distinguish themselves from other migrant workers. Some others call them ''freewheelers.''
Fruit tramps are hard to spot because they try to live outside the law and contemporary conventions. Few have gone beyond junior high school. Mr. Tindal said he stopped at the 5th grade and his wife in the 10th. They say they have never voted, had a bank account, saved any money or owned a home and had a telephone only once, for a few months. Like some of the other men in his family, Mr. Tindal has never had a driver's license, although until recently he did drive.
They put up with Social Security tax deductions when they work for big farmers, who have too much to lose in evading the law. But they seek payment in cash, without deductions, from small farmers and people who give them part-time jobs. On rare occasions and when produce prices were higher, a family could earn $500 to $600 a week, but often with the help of their children in violation of the child labor laws. Now they say it would be hard to earn $400.
 
A Dying Breed
Clans like the Tindals and his wife's family, the Moteses, did most of the nation's migrant labor until 30 or 40 years ago, when teams made up only of men began moving in. More recently Hispanic, Haitian and Jamaican workers began taking the jobs once claimed by American families. Like Mr. Tindal's health, the American migrant clans are fading, victims of the way they live and the brutal economics of farm work.
Officials at the Census Bureau and the Department of Agriculture say they have stopped trying to count migrant workers because they are too elusive. Unofficial estimates range from hundreds of thousands to several million, but families hardly show up. Certainly there are a few hundred fruit tramps, possibly a few thousand; most of them are white. That fruit tramps persist is in part the discovery of a photojournalist, Herman Emmet, who came upon the Tindals in the late 1970's. He lived and worked with the Tindals off and on for more than a decade and wrote about them in a book of photographs called ''Fruit Tramps,'' published last year by the University of New Mexico Press.
Mrs. Tindal's 58-year-old mother, Betty Motes, who like her husband, Leroy, and her parents was an itinerant fruit picker, said a dozen families around her neighborhood in Fort Pierce, Fla., are fruit pickers. Everette W. Noel, one of the many peach growers 50 miles from here in Johnston, S.C., which calls itself ''The Peach Capital of the World,'' has employed the families for years. He turned them away this season, however, because storms and a March freeze mutilated his crop.
Mr. Noel prefers to hire migrant families because, he said, they are relatively stable and seem not to use hard drugs. ''They're not bad,'' Mr. Noel said. ''Just kind of defeated. Their problem is alcohol.''
 
Picture of Southern Poverty
Mr. Tindal's arms and emaciated torso are covered with primitive tattoos. He said he got most of them while on a prison chain gang when he was 18. On his left shoulder is a tattoo that says ''Live hard'' and on the right one that says ''Die young.'' He got his latest tattoos some weeks ago, little crosses on his neck to align a radiation machine for treating his throat cancer.
The Tindals have lived here for almost a year, longer than any place else, so that Mr. Tindal can be treated 20 minutes away in Columbia. At Lot 100C, beyond the Silver Lake trailer park, the house presents a stereotypical picture of Southern rural poverty, with light bulbs hanging from wires, a decrepit washing machine resting in a puddle outside the kitchen door, the hulk of an abandoned car on one side of the house and the hulk of another beyond the clothesline in front.
The Tindals bought their current car, a 1982 compact Pontiac station wagon, some three months ago for about $1,500, and they still owe $1,300 on it. It has a license plate on the front that says ''Jesus,'' and a bumper sticker in back that says, ''Good girls go to Heaven, bad girls go everywhere.'' The children leave the doors open, and the goat gets in and eats the seats.
The Tindal home is a scene of coping and pulling together. Most days, relatives and friends come to check on Mr. Tindal and to chat, smoke, drink beer and help out.
The Tindals say their sole income is Mr. Tindal's $371 monthly Social Security disability check. They were cut off from food stamps in March because Mrs. Tindal earned too much last year, at $35 a day at a produce stand. She says she cannot work now because she is caring for Mr. Tindal. She reapplied for the stamps but says she has heard nothing.
L. H.'s brother Lewis Tindal, 49, found the house for them and stops by frequently. He is the trailer park's full-time maintenance man, having stopped picking fruit three or four years ago, and he seems the most prosperous of the lot. The father of eight children, he owns his own home, a four-bedroom trailer about 20 minutes away, that he bought for $15,000 in cash.
The Tindals' most essential prop, however, is a lifelong friend: David Langston, a gangling, gregarious, heavy-drinking 43-year-old Vietnam War veteran who sleeps on the couch in the living room. Mr. Langston spends much of the $40 that he earns each day at an open air market on beer and cigarettes for himself and the Tindals, and he brings them the market's excess produce. Mrs. Tindal drives him to work and does his laundry and cooking. He stopped picking fruit regularly a year ago, he said, to care for the Tindals. Is It Freedom or a Trap? Most migrant workers sign up with sometimes unscrupulous crew leaders, and are herded by vans and old buses from farm to farm. The crew leaders provide meals and keep track of each person's production, and the farmers provide barracks-like housing. Fruit tramps, by contrast, drive straight to the farm and make their own arrangements. When conflicts arise with a farmer or a crew leader, they head for another farm.
The Tindals say their way of life is liberating, but they don't often calculate its cost. ''They have their gypsy life,'' said Mr. Emmet, the photographer. ''But that's all they have. Is it freedom, or is it a trap? It's a trap.'' Fruit tramps are constantly alert to the presence of the law. Mr. Noel said that when the police appear at his farm, whatever the reason, the workers scatter.
L. H. Tindal said he went to jail for ''not minding my own business,'' but declined to elaborate. Lewis Tindal said he had gone to jail ''a hundred times'' but never for more than 30 days. Mrs. Tindal's 38-year-old brother, Leon Motes, said he had served 12 years: 5 for trying to kill a policeman, 7 for auto theft.
Another brother, 29-year-old Terry Motes, cited a time when he went in for nine months. ''Illegal tags, no license, eluding a police officer,'' he said. He said he did not have a license because he couldn't read well enough to take an examination. ''I knew I was going to jail anyway, so I tried to get away,'' he said.
 
Prisoner of the Elements
Evading conventional payment arrangements can also cause problems. Mr. Langston recalled a Miss Hurd in upstate New York, who invited the Tindals, Mr. Langston and three other men to work for a day picking raspberries. ''She gave us $5.50 for the whole day - a dollar for the men and 50 cents for Linda,'' he said. They had no recourse.
But if these people are in a trap, it is not entirely their own design. Consumers benefit from abundant, cheap fruit and vegetables. Peach pickers typically get 35 cents for each sack they pick; orange pickers about 55 cents. They are assured the minimum wage of $3.85 an hour if they pick too little to earn more. But the minimum wage no longer provides a standard of living above the poverty level, and migrant workers earn less than other minimum-wage workers because they can't work in the rain or when there's nothing to pick.
Other economic forces work against them. St. Clair Guess, publisher of The Citizen-News in Edgefield, S.C., near Johnston, said that in the low-interest-rate era of the 1970's, fruit growers, like many other farmers, planted more land and overexpanded, leading to today's often abundant harvests. Large supplies of fruit help keep prices down, he said, leaving growers little room to pay their workers more and still earn enough to pay off their loans.
The influx of foreign workers makes matters worse, Mr. Guess said. Mexicans will pick the fruit at rock-bottom wages, holding down the pay the fruit tramps might otherwise get. ''Without inexpensive labor,'' Mr. Guess said, ''the farmers can't survive.''
 
'It's in the Past'
The children of fruit tramps, unlike their parents when they were children, have set their sights on other careers. James Tindal, a cousin of L. H.'s, is 52 and said he had had three heart attacks in five years after a life of picking fruit. ''I raised four children and got all mine out of it,'' he said.
Tina Tindal, at 15 the oldest of Mr. and Mrs. Tindal's children, told Mr. Emmet that half of her wanted to carry on as a fruit tramp. But she has ruled that out. She says she wants to be a model or a teacher. ''See, Daddy's sick,'' she said. ''I liked it at first, but it's in the past. I don't see no life in fruit picking no more.''
Shannon, 9, the next oldest, said: ''It gives me the chills. All them bugs that got on me. No way I'll pick fruit.'' Mr. Tindal said, ''I'm glad of it.'' ''Fruit picking is a freedom job: Nobody's hollering at you, cussing at you, telling you what to do.'' But he added:
''You got to be a damn nut to pick fruit now. You got have a weak mind, a strong back and alcohol to put up with it.''
As long as the children are under her roof, Mrs. Tindal added, ''they're staying in school.''

HEADLINE: Starrett City Keeps Apartments Vacant Despite Waiting List

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In the 20 months since the United States Supreme Court outlawed racial quotas that favored white applicants to the huge Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn, the black and Hispanic families who had sought apartments for years have remained stuck on a long waiting list.
Instead of offering apartments to those on the list - who the Federal courts determined were the victims of a quota system that Starrett's owner said had been created not to enforce segregation but to preserve integration - the owner has left as many as 400 apartments vacant.
Most of the apartments that have been rented since the High Court decision have gone to more affluent families paying higher rents, Federal and state housing officials say. Without seeking the permission of the Government regulators who oversee the complex, Starrett has for the first time advertised for families not on its waiting list who are willing to pay market-rate rents and it has offered as an inducement four months rent free.
It is not clear why Starrett decided to limit the use of its waiting list or whether that violated a consent decree Starrett had signed with the Justice Department. Starrett officials said they were forced to seek market-rate tenants because government subsidies no longer covered all their operating costs. 
Starrett, overlooking the Shore Parkway at Pennsylvania Avenue in the East New York section, has traditionally been home almost exclusively to subsidized moderate- and middle-income tenants.
Some open-housing advocates questioned whether Starrett was trying to circumvent the Supreme Court decision by denying apartments to people on the waiting list.
Other housing officials said they thought that the management was motivated more by economic than racial concerns, to increase rental income and to prepare for a possible conversion from rental housing to a private cooperative.
Some officials said that whatever the motivation, a result was that the less-affluent families on the waiting list, most of whom are black and Hispanic, continued to be denied subsidized housing.
Officials at the complex, which has been renamed Starrett at Spring Creek, contend that they have acted properly. They said they were allowed under a Federal contract to rent at market rates up to 10 percent of the nearly 6,000 apartments in the 42-building complex. Three-bedroom apartments have been offered for as much as $1,200 a month, and two-bedroom units for $1,000.
Starrett officials said they were not trying to get around the Supreme Court ruling; most of the 100 families who have recently rented apartments at market rates are black, they said.
State and Federal officials, who have a different interpretation of the contract and Federal rules, said Starrett was not permitted to charge market rates and had to rent vacant apartments to people on the waiting list who qualify for subsidies.
 
Reviews Planned by the State
The state housing agency that oversees the complex has ordered Starrett to stop renting apartments at market rates. Saying Starrett had resisted requests for its records, the state has demanded copies of the waiting list and many other documents and has said it would begin reviewing every applicant selected by Starrett to rent an apartment. Families eligible for subsidies generally pay 30 percent of their incomes for rent, with the Federal Government paying the rest. Subsidized apartments also rent for $300 to $400 a month less than market rates.
The bias suit, filed by the Reagan Administration, received national attention because the owner, the Starrett Housing Corporation, had taken an unusual line of defense. The company asserted that racial quotas were needed to keep the complex integrated.
 
Fear of 'Segregated Wasteland'
About 55 percent of the 20,000 residents are white, and 45 percent are black, Asian or Hispanic. Management argued that preference had to be shown to white applicants to maintain the racial balance. Otherwise, they said, whites would flee and Starrett would become, in the words of a lawyer representing the complex, ''a segregated wasteland.''
Two Federal courts decided that the quotas violated the Fair Housing Act because they discriminated against minority families on the waiting list. In November 1988 the Supreme Court turned down an appeal by Starrett.
A spokeswoman for Starrett, Devora Fong, said it had deliberately kept apartments vacant between the Supreme Court decision and the signing of the consent decree with the Justice Department six months later. Starrett was awaiting instructions on how it should go about renting apartments, Ms. Fong said.
In the last year, Ms. Fong said, vacant apartments have been rented to market-rate tenants and to less-affluent families on the waiting list. But residents and state officials, who are awaiting proof that waiting-list applicants had received apartments, said they believed that hundreds of apartments remained empty.
 
Dispute on Subsidy Numbers
State and Federal housing officials said Starrett had to use all of the Federal rent subsidies at its disposal. Only then, they said, would they consider allowing it to rent at market rates.
Under one Federal program, the officials said, Starrett is required to rent 2,500 subsidized apartments to moderate-income households. Federal and state officials said Starrett had failed to rent 200 apartments under the program to meet the requirement.
Ms. Fong said 120 families on the waiting list for the program were ''being processed right now.'' Starrett was built with state and city subsidies, and it has contracts for three different Federal subsidies.
A spokeswoman for the Justice Department, Amy Casner, would not comment on whether Starrett's actions violated the consent decree. Ms. Casner said the department was aware of the Federal and state concerns.
 
Order From State Official
In a stern letter, the state agency that oversees Starrett, the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, ordered the management in April to stop renting at market rates and to rent empty apartments to those on the waiting list.
''Since the signing of the Justice Department consent order, Starrett City has been holding hundreds of apartments off the market, limiting rentals to applicants on the existing list who are in need of subsidy, while concentrating their marketing efforts on market-rate tenants,'' wrote Myron Holtz, a deputy housing commissioner.
The state had met with ''marked resistance to our requests for access to office records,'' Mr. Holtz wrote. He ordered Starrett to send the waiting list, all applications for apartments and all credit reports on applicants to the state ''for review and approval prior to move in.''
The rental practices and the state's response were disclosed in an article in City Limits, a monthly publication on New York housing.
 
Pleased With Amenities
State housing officials said in interviews that Starrett had long been one of the best-managed and maintained middle-income housing complexes in New York. Many residents said that their apartments were spacious and inexpensive and that they enjoyed amenities like an indoor swimming pool, a recreation center and excellent public schools. State officials said they were puzzled and disturbed by management's recent actions.
Starrett had not previously tried to market apartments to more affluent people, state officials said. Although a small number of tenants have paid market-rate rents over the years, nearly all of them had received rent subsidies when they entered the complex. As their incomes grew over the years, some families no longer qualified for the Federal subsidies, and their rents were increased.
Phyllis Spiro, assistant director of the Open Housing Center, a fair-housing group, said she had received complaints from people on the waiting list who said Starrett had told them that apartments were not being rented to those on the list.
 
Skepticism on Motivations
Ms. Spiro speculated that more white families would be likely to afford higher rents than minority families. She also said Starrett might be preparing to convert to a cooperative, which it is entitled to do after 1994. Management has indicated an interest in doing so. Affluent tenants might be more likely to buy their apartments, Ms. Spiro said.
The director of fair housing at the City Human Rights Commission, Harvey Fisher, said he was skeptical about management's motivations.
''For them to be able to market co-op apartments, I think they are going to have to take into account white anxiety about a very integrated development,'' Mr. Fisher said, adding that he thought that Starrett might have been recruiting more affluent tenants, whether white or minority middle-class families, who would be less threatening to potential white buyers.
Starrett officials insisted that they were doing basically what they had always done, renting apartments both to market-rate tenants and to less-affluent subsidized families. State and Federal officials said, however, that virtually all tenants had been subsidized for the last 10 years.
''We have had meetings with them,'' Ms. Fong said of the government officials, ''and we are all working on this together. I don't think we are in an adversarial position.''

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about vacant apartments in the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn misidentified the owner. The development, recently renamed Starrett at Spring Creek, is owned by Starrett City Associates, not the Starrett Housing Corporation.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
The People Threat

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Lucien Paye, head of the O.E.C.D., which groups 24 industrialized countries, was asked what worried him most on the horizon. U.S. budget and trade deficits? Protectionism? Recession?
''It depends if you talk short-term or long-term,'' he answered. The serious concern, out about a decade, ''is demography.'' Third-world countries are building up population at a rate no imaginable economic development effort could accommodate. 
As things are going, pressures will become explosive, launching invasion tides of desperate people trying to throw themselves on labor markets. They won't be armed, but will set forth in overwhelming multitudes.
Mr. Paye is a Frenchman, and he was thinking mainly of burgeoning African populations. Already immigration from the south is the most abrasive political issue in France, strengthening the nationalist ultra-right. The issue is sharpening in Italy, a country with no tradition of absorbing the poor from abroad.
For the U.S., the push will mount primarily from Latin America. But the stakes are global because development, environment, peace will be put at risk if the number of people and capacity to sustain them is thrown into such imbalance.
That is why deliberate restraint of science in providing reproductive choice is beyond comprehension. The U.S. is hobbling a humane approach by its obsession with abortion. In the name of ''right to life,'' American militants are disregarding conditions of life for children around the world: nutrition, health care, education at home, famine, disease, war abroad.
During the Reagan Administration, funds for United Nations population control programs were cut because they might be used for abortions. In the last couple of years, threats from American groups have blocked distribution of a pill that prevents development of a fertilized egg.
It is RU486, called the ''French pill'' because it was developed by a French biochemist, Etienne-Emile Baulieu, who won a 1989 Lasker Award for his discovery. The citation said it provided a ''safe, effective'' means for preventing pregnancy and avoiding surgical abortion. Made by the French company Roussel Uclaf, RU486 has been widely tested in France and other European countries. In April, reports on 40,000 cases of use listed only two ''incidents,'' without damaging consequences.
The anti-abortion lobby in the U.S. succeeded in preventing legal importation of the drug under Federal law. Worse, by threatening a general boycott of pharmaceuticals from the German company Hoechst, which controls Roussel Uclaf, the lobby persuaded Hoechst to shut down production. The order was reversed in France by the Government, which had a minority share, so the pill is available here under medical supervision, but not much elsewhere.
Now, a group of San Francisco doctors has decided to test a California law that permits import of banned drugs for experimental purposes, passed to enable investigation of as-yet uncertified treatments for AIDS. The French newspaper Liberation quotes Dr. Bernard Gore as saying, ''Like your Minister of Health, we think this revolutionary discovery is the moral property of women.''
He pointed out that some 300,000 women die yearly of botched abortions, mostly in the third world, and that law or no law, some 300,000 women in California undergo abortions every year.
The difference between a contraceptive pill and RU486 is that it can be taken after insemination. It works in the early stage of pregnancy by countering the hormone progesterone, which serves to attach the fertilized egg to the uterus.
The World Development Forum called RU486 a ''breakthrough for developing countries.'' Dr. Baulieu said, ''It is a far safer method of abortion than any operation in countries where medical facilities are limited.''
But, the Forum said, Hoechst has refused to license production in China, and the World Health Organization is ducking the issue. ''We have no position,'' a spokesman said. A Hoechst spokesman said his company had yet to make a final decision, which would be based on medical reports, chemical trials ''and other issues, such as opinions in society. We will take note of their wishes.''
That is a way of saying that the threat from American militants of commercial loss on its other products has intimidated Hoechst to the point of depriving the world of an urgently needed safeguard. The San Francisco doctors have a chance to prove the pill should be legalized in the U.S., and open the possibility of worldwide distribution. They deserve support.

HEADLINE: Nunn Panel Cuts Pentagon $18 Billion

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
In the first Congressional action on the 1991 military budget, a Senate committee today approved a plan to cut $18 billion from the Bush Administration's proposal, and called for sharp troop reductions in Europe and cuts in the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.
The action, by the Senate Armed Services Committee, made it plain that Congress was seeking far deeper reductions in military spending than those sought by the Administration.
The Senate panel is the first of four Congressional committees that will address the military budget this year, and it is the most supportive of the Pentagon's budget plans. Its chairman is Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who exerts considerable leverage in military issues. In a number of speeches earlier this year, he emphasized the need to restructure the United States military in the face of a diminishing threat. His outline essentially became a blueprint for the committee. 
 
Others Might Cut Deeper
The other committees, which are not likely to act before September, are the House counterpart of Mr. Nunn's panel, and the two chambers' military subcommittees on appropriations, where the actual money for the military will be provided. They are expected to make even deeper cuts in the Administration's $307 billion budget request, which is 2.5 percent below current military spending when adjusted for inflation.
In a news conference at the Capitol today, Senator Nunn called the committee's proposal a ''responsible'' and ''manageable'' plan toward ''a major restructuring of our military establishment and the way it does business.''
Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, said that while the proposal ''may be just Round 1,'' it also represents a ''foundation and a guidepost for how those cuts could be made and the very severe consequences of further reductions.''
The committee's plan includes these major elements:
* Reduction of United States troop strength worldwide by 100,000 from 2.1 million, including a reduction of 50,000 troops in Europe. The Administration proposed cutting worldwide troop strength by 38,000.
* Cancellation of the $1.3 billion proposed rail system for shuttling MX missiles around the country, leaving only $548 million for continued research. The committee approved $202 million in research on the single-warhead Midgetman.
* Cuts of nearly $1 billion, to $3.7 billion, in the Administration's budget on the ''Star Wars'' program.
* Approval of the Administration's request to build two of the Stealth, or B-2, radar-evading bombers.
* Creation of a Strategic Environmental Research Program to address environmental threats by enlisting the research talent available to the military, as well as its computers, planes, ships, satellites and other resources. The plan, sought by Mr. Nunn, proposes $200 million to finance the program.
* Elimination of an Energy Department request for a $65 million new plutonium plant at Rocky Flats, Colo., shifting the money to clean-up efforts.
Major battles are expected on the Senate floor and with the House over the anti-missile program, the Stealth bomber and perhaps troop levels. Senate leaders clashed this week over whether cuts should be taken more heavily in personnel or weapons systems.
The reductions in the panel's $289 billion spending plan reflect its philosophy that adjustments should be made to reflect the reduction in the Soviet threat overseas and economic demands at home. This philosophy embraces nuclear deterrence, but at lower force levels, delaying production of more advanced weapons systems until they pass performance tests and improving existing weapons before committing to expensive new systems.
The plan would, for example, slow production of major weapons, including the A-12 aircraft carrier plane, C-17 transport and Seawolf attack submarine, by rejecting all or nearly all of the Administration's production request for them for next year.
The Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, cautioned that the proposed cuts, if forced on the services too quickly, could jeopardize the military. ''If I have to take big cuts the first year, and it's in fast-spend accounts, then it has to come out of personnel, and that does begin to do serious damage to the quality of the force,'' he said in an interview with the Cable News Network.
In addition to the cuts in troop strength in fiscal 1991 the panel also approved a fiscal 1995 level of 1.6 million military personnel, a reduction of nearly 475,000 from the current level.

HEADLINE: QUAYLE DEFENDS BUSH'S TAX STAND

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 13

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle sought to reassure a nervous group of Republican leaders today that President Bush did not simply kick away one of their best campaign issues when he acknowledged last month that tax increases would be needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
Mr. Quayle, raising the issue that clearly most worries those gathered here for the summer meeting of the Republican National Committee, said clear differences on taxes remained between Democrats and Republicans even after Mr. Bush's reversal.
''The reaction of some Democrats to the President's June 26 announcement was a useful reminder of this fundamental difference between our two parties,'' Mr. Quayle said in a luncheon speech on the second day of the committee's three-day meeting. ''The President reluctantly announced that he would consider tax revenue increases to get the negotiations going -as one of six elements of a budget deal. But many Democrats made it clear that their first and only priority was to raise taxes.'' 
 
A Defensive Position
Mr. Quayle's speech here was part of an effort by the White House and the Republican National Committee to dig out of the uncomfortable, and somewhat unaccustomed, defensive position the party finds itself in as the fall campaigns draw near.
''This meeting is about one thing: offense,'' Ed Rogers, a top White House political operative, said of the Republican gathering.
The Republicans have felt on the defensive on issues as diverse as the savings and loan scandal and abortion. But perhaps most threatening of all is the issue of taxes, their stated resistance to which has been a central element of their success in the last three Presidential races.
 
Assailing the President
Even as the committee was meeting here today, a number of conservatives were holding a news conference in Washington to attack Mr. Bush on several fronts, including his softened stand against taxes.
The critics, led by L. Brent Bozell 3d of the Conservative Victory Committee, released a letter they had sent to Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, in which they said, ''If the Republican Party compromises the basic tenets of the 1988 platform, it will spell disaster for its candidates in the upcoming Congressional elections.''
In Chicago, Peggy Noonan, the former Reagan speechwriter who coined Mr. Bush's ''read my lips'' 1988 campaign promise to resist new taxes, seemed to sum up the delegates' feelings when she told them, ''I truly believe we must not lose the tax issue.''
Finding a way to hang on to that issue, while the White House continues negotiating with Congressional Democrats to reduce the deficit, was uppermost on everybody's mind here.
 
Strong Economy Emphasized
Several different, and perhaps contradictory, approaches were in evidence. One was to emphasize the importance of a strong economy, as Jeannie Austin, party co-chairwoman, did this morning, and to praise Mr. Bush for his ''leadership and his courage'' in making hard decisions to assure that economic strength.
But another approach, which drew considerably more applause whenever it was brought up, was to suggest that the deficit talks might fail and that Mr. Bush could walk away, blaming the Democrats for the collapse and not raising taxes after all.
Many Democrats on Capitol Hill believe that public concern about the deficit has risen to such a level, and that the economy has slowed to such a point, that Mr. Bush cannot afford to let the budget talks collapse.
But both Mr. Quayle and Ms. Noonan, who is a good friend of the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, rejected that.
''A good deal, or no deal at all,'' Mr. Quayle said.
Ms. Noonan said, ''I hope this party will, if it must, take the tax-and-spend issue to the people.''
Seeking to shift the political focus from taxes to spending, Mr. Quayle demanded that the Democrats respond to Mr. Bush's willingness to discuss tax increases by detailing spending cuts they would be willing to accept in a budget deal.
''Their silence on this issue, as usual, has been deafening,'' the Vice President said.

HEADLINE: Drunken Flying Persists Despite Treatment Effort

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Bruce K. is a pilot who flies Boeing 727 jetliners for a major airline. He is also a recovering alcoholic.
Until about three years ago, he routinely showed up to work only three or four hours after a night of heavy drinking. (Federal rules prohibit a pilot from drinking within eight hours of flying.) ''As long as I got some sleep and ate some mints, I figured I was O.K.,'' he said. To hide the fact that he was too drunk to fly, he devised other ways to hide it, like assigning his co-pilot to fly the first flight of the day.
Finally, with his family life in tatters and his job in jeopardy, he reached what he called his ''personal bottom.'' At the urging of his wife, he entered an in-patient treatment program at a hospital in the Middle West. Seven months later he was back at work, earning the same pay and retaining his seniority. Today he is a counselor in a support group for alcoholic pilots. And his group is one of many. #1,200 Pilots Rehabilitated About 1,200 airline pilots have been treated for alcoholism and have returned to the cockpit since the Government began a rehabilitation program for such pilots 15 years ago, said Dr. Burton Pakull, chief psychiatrist at the Federal Aviation Administration. 
The rehabilitation programs are the most visible sign of an industry still wrestling with the problem of alcoholism. Statistics on pilots with drinking problems are virtually impossible to come by, but industry and government officials said they believed that treatment programs are not reaching all pilots who drink too much. And although most pilots in treatment programs say they never mixed drinking and flying, Bruce K. is not alone among pilots who said that they have flown while drunk.
''There are probably a number of early-stage alcoholics flying,'' said Gary Kohn, corporate medical director for United Airlines. ''We don't pretend we screen out all substance abusers, but we do screen out some.''
 
'Great Potential for Tragedy'
The arrest of three Northwest pilots in May, charged with flying while under the influence of alcohol, has brought new attention to the issue. The pilots, who have since been dismissed by Northwest, have denied the charges. Their trial is scheduled to start July 25 in Federal District Court in Minneapolis. If convicted, they could face up to 15 years in prison.
''The Northwest incident establishes very clearly that there is a great potential for tragedy,'' said Stephen Hilton, spokesman for Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is sponsoring a bill that would require random alcohol testing of pilots. Only testing for drugs like marijuana or cocaine is now required.
But some experts fear that alcohol testing will simply force pilots who drink to seek treatment without the airline's knowledge, as was the case before the rehabilitation program began in 1975. Since the arrest of the three Northwest pilots, counselors have reported an increase in the number of pilots seeking help for alcoholism.
''All of us in the industry are glad that the incident was publicized,'' said Chuck G., a retired pilot from Seattle who was one of the first to be treated in the rehabilitation program. ''It was a good warning to people.'' #16 Accidents Since 1983 Since 1983 there have been only 16 airline accidents in which drug or alcohol use by pilots was found to be a factor, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.
The 16 accidents involved commuter airlines and charter flights. But about 6 percent of all accidents in private aviation are traced to drug or alcohol use.
Since 1984, 61 professional pilots have had their licenses suspended or revoked for flying while drunk.
''For every pilot I treat, there are five more who just sneak into early retirement,'' said Dr. Joseph A. Pursch, director of the Addiction Institute in Costa Mesa, Calif. Dr. Pursch, a psychiatrist, helped start the rehabilitation program.
Today, every major airline has a confidential rehabilitation program. A pilot who passed psychiatric tests after the rehabilitation can return to work with no loss of benefits or seniority. The pilot is monitored monthly for at least two years by an airline doctor, a fellow pilot, a counselor and an airline executive.
 
Unusual Cooperation Seen
These rehabilitation programs represent unusual cooperation among a Government agency, a major industry and a union. Indeed, with a success rate of more than 90 percent, they are regarded by counselors as models for other recovery programs.
Experts attribute the high success rate to close monitoring and a strong motivation to fly again. ''It put the job on the line in the most clear and unequivocable way,'' Dr. Pursch said.
Nobby Hall, a union representative at Trans World Airlines who helps detect pilots with drinking problems, said, ''You get them where they live: pride, ego and a $100,000-a-year salary.''
Northwest Airlines had long been an industry holdout; it began its program less than a year ago. ''They were adamant about not having a program,'' said Dr. Pakull, the F.A.A. psychiatrist. ''They were a conspicuous exception.'' Company Policy Recalled Robert Gibbons, a spokesman for Northwest, said the airline decided last year to bring its policy in line with the rest of the industry. Previously, its pilots were not permitted to drink 24 hours before flying; those who violated the policy did not receive rehabilitation but were grounded for two years. ''As we became more enlightened,'' Mr. Gibbons added, ''we understood that we were not encouraging pilots to come forward.''
The rehabilitation costs about $17,000 a person, with the airlines paying for the treatment. In this the airlines are motivated by economic as well as humanitarian reasons.
''An airline has spent millions of dollars training these people to take the pilot's seat,'' said Richard Bickerton, a spokesman for the Employee Assistance Professionals Association, a trade group that represents counselors. ''These people are human assets.'' About 85 percent of the pilots who have problems with alcohol are flagged by fellow pilots who have been trained to look for signs of the disease. And evidence of a drinking problem must be verified by at least two colleagues.
 
'A Conspiracy of Silence'
Still, there is reluctance to turn in a fellow pilot. ''There is a conspiracy of silence among macho men: 'Don't rat on your buddy,' '' said Don F., a recently retired pilot who is a recovering alcoholic and now counsels pilots in northern New Jersey.
''The attitude is, 'I'll cover for you because next time you might have to cover for me,' '' said Bruce K., the 727 pilot. Both spoke on the condition that they not be identified.
Denial, always a formidable obstacle when treating alcoholism, is especially daunting among pilots, who are trained to keep their emotions in check.
''Every pilot I treat, it's clear that he should have been treated 10 or 15 years ago,'' said Dr. Pursch. ''They say he's not that bad, he has only three years to go before he retires. They look the other way.''
 
No Match for the Disease
Bruce K.'s drinking bouts slowly caused his family life to unravel. The discipline instilled in him early in his career proved no match for the disease. ''I had been trained for over 20 years to be in control,'' he said. ''Finding something I wasn't in control of was a hard pill to swallow.''
Today he counsels other pilots at a group called Birds of a Feather. The group, which is affiliated with Alcoholics Anonymous, has 25 chapters worldwide. Meetings are part confession, part therapy and part aviation patter.
''My hero was an airline pilot: the steely-eyed, womanizing drinker,'' one member said.
Bruce K. is no longer monitored by the airline and, as far as his employer is concerned, he is no different from the airline's thousands of other pilots. When he is asked by his colleagues why he will not join them for a beer, he has a few stock replies: ''I had to give it up,'' or ''I don't drink casually.'' Usually, he said, the subject is dropped.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Joseph A. Pursch, a psychiatrist who helped start a nationwide alcohol rehabilitation program for airline pilots, at the airport in Monterey, Calif. ''For every pilot I treat, there are five more who just sneak into early retirement,'' he said. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rights Bill for Disabled Is Sent to Bush

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The Senate today completed Congressional action on a far-reaching bill to bar discrimination against people with physical and mental disabilities.
After a brief but highly emotional discussion in which several senators described relatives with handicaps, the lawmakers voted 91 to 6 to accept the House-Senate conference report on the Americans with Disabilities Act.
The measure now goes to the White House. President Bush said today he was ''delighted'' that the bill had been approved and would sign it when it reached his desk. 
The bill, the most sweeping anti-discrimination measure to be approved since the Civil Rights Act of 1964, will bar bias in employment, transportation, public accommodations and telecommunications against what it estimates as 43 million Americans with a physical or mental disability.
More than 100 supporters of the measure, some in wheelchairs, gathered in a reception room off the Senate chamber and cheered wildly when a security guard announced the final vote.
''No longer will people with disabilities be second-class citizens,'' said Pat Wright, executive director of the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund, a lobbying and advocacy group.
 
Emotional Tributes
Earlier on the Senate floor, one of the bill's prime sponsors, Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, said he was addressing his comments to his deaf brother, Frank. ''Today, Congress opens the doors to all Americans with disabilities,'' Mr. Harkin said, using sign language as well as words. ''Today we say no to ignorance, no to fear, no to prejudice.''
Some lawmakers expressed concern about the effects on business, among them Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican who supported the bill and in fact dedicated it to his brother-in-law, Raymond Hansen, who died in May 1970 after a long bout with polio.
''If our bureaucrats in Washington, our regulators - maybe that's a better word - write the regulations too stringently and too tough, there are aspects of this bill that could make it very difficult for the free enterprise system,'' Mr. Hatch said. The six Senators who voted against the bill were Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, Jake Garn of Utah, Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Gordon J. Humphrey of New Hampshire, Steve Symms of Idaho and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, all Republicans. Their objections ranged from a concern over increased suits against business to the extension of protection against bias to people with AIDS. Some also felt that the law would place an economic burden on businesses.
 
Fear on Expenditures
''Rather than merely prohibiting discrimination against the disabled, the bill compels employers to make significant expenditures and extensive physical alterations to their facilities to accommodate an unlimited variety of job applicants,'' Mr. Humphrey said.
How much the bill will cost will depend on two factors: the regulations that will codify how the legislation will be carried out, and the legal penalties that businesses will face for violations. The regulations are to be drafted within 18 months.
The scale of legal costs will depend greatly on the fate of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which the Senate is now considering. The disabilities bill links the monetary damages that victims of discrimination may receive from the courts to those embodied in the Civil Rights Act of 1964 - currently back pay for those who have been dismissed or denied a promotion. The new civil rights bill seeks to amend the 1964 legislation to allow those who prove willful bias to receive an unlimited amount of compensatory and punitive damages.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that local governments would spend $20 million to $30 million a year to buy lift-equipped buses for people in wheelchairs, and $15 million more to maintain these vehicles. The C.B.O. makes no estimate on the additional costs for subway, railroad and trolley cars. But the agency projects it would cost $1 billion to alter ''key'' railroad, subway and trolley stations to make them accessible to people with disabilities, as will be required by the law.
There are no reliable estimates on the economic burden on private busineses, but Cecelia Fepp, a research analyst for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said it would be ''millions of dollars annually.''
A 1987 study by the Job Accommodation Network, a consulting concern that helps business deal with disabled workers, concluded that in less than 1 percent of cases did a business have to spend more than $5,000 to make a reasonable accommodation for a disabled worker.
''This thing is not going to be as costly as you think it is,'' said Ray Robertson, the organization's executive director.
 
Definitions and Coverage
The legislation approved today defines a disability as a condition that ''substantially limits'' a ''major life activity,'' like walking or seeing. It covers recovering drug abusers and alcoholics, but not a host of other emotional disorders like kleptomania, compulsive gambling or pyromania.
For the first time people who have acquired immune deficiency syndrome or are infected with the AIDS virus will be granted Federal protection against discrimination in housing or employment.
''It's wonderful,'' said Dr. June Osborn, dean of the University of Michigan School of Public Health and chairman of the President's Commission on AIDS. ''It's a necessary first step to allow people to satisfy their own personal concerns and seek to know where they stand without fear of discrimination.''
The disabilities bill would require that within two years, businesses would be forbidden to refuse to hire a disabled applicant. And companies would have to make a ''reasonable accommodation'' to permit the worker to do the job. Employers would be exempted from this requirement if they can show that meeting it would place an ''undue hardship'' on the business.
Thirty days after enactment of the law, operators of railroads, intercity and intracity bus lines, mass transit or light rail system and public school bus companies would have to insure that all new vehicles they buy are accessible to people with physical disabilities, including those in wheelchairs. Within five years of enactment, all trains and subways would have to have at least one car that is accessible.
Public mass transit systems would have to provide alternative transportion for people unable to board buses or subways. In addition, within three years ''key'' subway and light rail stations must be made accessible to the disabled. In New York City, that will affect 54 of the 469 subway stations.
The legislation also says people with disabilities cannot be denied service at commercial establishments like office buildings, hotels, theaters, supermarkets, dry cleaners, doctors' offices, zoos, amusement parks and bowling alleys. Existing businesses would have to be made accessible, unless that would create ''an undue burden.'' All new public and commercial buildings would have to be accessible.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Senate yesterday approved a bill, which President Bush is expected to sign, that will bar any bias against Americans with physical or mental disabilities. Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, left, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah were among those celebrating the approval in Washington. (Associated Press); Table listing rights of the disabled.

HEADLINE: Chinese Dissident to Study in U.S. (and to Speak Out)

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, England, July 13

 BODY:
Fang Lizhi, China's most prominent dissident, said today that he planned to study in the United States for at least six months beginning in January. He also said that while he was there he would meet with exiled Chinese dissidents and speak out against his country's Government.
In an interview, Mr. Fang, an astrophysicist, said he might make the United States his permanent place of exile. He was allowed to leave China last month with his wife, Li Shuxian, more than a year after taking refuge in the United States Embassy in Beijing during the violent crackdown on dissent.
Mr. Fang's intentions seem likely to cause concern among the hard-liners in Beijing and could prove an irritant in relations between Beijing and Washington, but they do not appear directly to break any known elements of the agreement between the countries that allowed him and Miss Li to go free. 
 
Face-Saving Measure
Although they were initially released to Britain, apparently as a face-saving response to Chinese concerns that Mr. Fang not go to the United States, there is no known agreement that prevents them from moving later on.
And while Beijing might regard Mr. Fang's speaking out against the Government as a breach of his pledge not to conduct ''anti-China'' activities while in exile, Mr. Fang was careful not to rule out criticism of the Chinese Government, as opposed to criticism of the nation itself.
In the wide-ranging interview, Mr. Fang, whose full name is pronounced fahng lee-jur (rhyming with burr), gave details of negotiations involving the United States Embassy in Beijing and the Chinese authorities that led to exile for him and his wife, who is also a physicist and a prominent dissident.
He said the authorities had asked him to agree not to participate in activities against the Government and to admit that he was a criminal. He said he had refused on both counts but agreed to other terms, including a demand that he say he was going abroad for medical treatment. Mr. Fang, who spoke in English throughout the interview, called that professed reason ''diplomat's language'' and said nothing was wrong with his health.
 
Urges Sanctions Against Beijing
Appearing relaxed and cheerful at his office at Cambridge University's Institute of Astronomy, Mr. Fang also touched on the state of the democracy movement in China, the need he saw for continued economic sanctions against the country and the role the Bush Administration could play in bringing about change.
Mr. Fang, who is here doing research into the structure of the universe, said that the Chinese authorities had allowed one of his sons, who had remained behind when the couple left, to travel to Britain a week ago and that the family, including a second son, had now been reunited.
Mr. Fang, 54 years old, said he had accepted an invitation from the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. - an independent institute that grants fellowships for research in various fields - and would conduct research there for at least six months.
Mr. Fang was asked whether he would meet Chinese dissident leaders while in the United States, where he would have a broader platform for his views. He said, ''I think so.'' Asked whether he would speak out, he replied, ''Yes, I think so.'' But he said that whether he would be willing to serve as the leader of exiled dissidents would ''depend on the situation.''
Mr. Fang said he might make his home in exile in the United States because it ''is very large and very easy to spend a longer time'' there than in Britain. He said he would visit various parts of the United States and had already received invitations from universities and institutes in California, Chicago, Colorado and New York.
 
Chose to Go to Britain
He said the Chinese authorities, for reasons that were unclear to him, had not wanted the United States to be his first stop after leaving Beijing. He said he had told the authorities he was willing to go to any developed country, and ultimately chose Britain, where he conducted research in 1979.
Mr. Fang and Miss Li flew to exile in Britain on June 25 after having been in the United States Embassy in Beijing since June 5, 1989. They took refuge in the embassy the day after the Communist leaders sent troops into Tianamen Square and after pro-Government demonstrators burned Mr. Fang in effigy.
Mr. Fang said he believed that the Government had allowed him to leave largely because it was feeling the pressure of economic sanctions. But the authorities also wanted to improve their image, he said, because ''intellectuals don't believe them and students don't like them.''
He said Western governments should relax sanctions against China only when it freed imprisoned dissidents and returned human rights to its citizens. He called on President Bush, whom he said he hoped to meet in the United States, to demand that pro-democracy demonstrators be released, adding that only about two student leaders had been freed.
He said Mr. Bush could not have acted to prevent the killings near Tiananmen Square because by that time, ''the Chinese Government had already become illogical.'' But he said a stronger response from the Bush Administration in the aftermath could have lessened the number of people who were detained or killed. He said at least 1,000 people were still in jail and gave 700 as the ''lower limit'' of the number of people who died when the Government sent troops and tanks into the square to crush the student-led demonstrations.
 
Long-Term Optimism
Mr. Fang said that world trends made him optimistic that democracy would be achieved in China but that ''we'll be waiting until the old generation'' of leadership is gone. He said it was difficult to determine which of the country's current leaders would become ''China's Gorbachev,'' because the autocratic system made it difficult for them to reveal ''what is really in their minds.''
For the first couple of weeks of their stay in the embassy, Mr. Fang said, he and his wife feared that the authorities would come and take them away, ''because there were still shots'' being fired.
''After the first two weeks were gone,'' he said, ''I know we are safe. They can't get in there. Even in that time, many sons and daughters of Chinese leaders applied for visas for the States. I know if they apply for visas for the States, I'm very safe.''
 
Life in the Embassy
Mr. Fang said he had spent most of his time in the embassy doing research and writing five scientific papers. Life was ''very confined'' for him and Miss Li, he said, because for security reasons, only Ambassador James R. Lilley and a few staff members were allowed to approach them. He said his wife taught two nurses how to cook Chinese food.
Mr. Fang said he would go back to China if the Government guaranteed ''all my rights as a citizen.''
He said he still kept his Chinese passport and would never apply for political asylum. ''In our Constitution, citizens have many rights, including freedom of speech,'' he said. ''If they will guarantee that, I will go back.''
 
WOULD BE WELCOME IN U.S.
WASHINGTON, July 13 - A senior State Department official said today that Mr. Fang would be welcome in the United States. Any plans he might have for a prolonged stay, the official said, would not contradict the terms of the agreement reached with Beijing.

(Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Viola Is Erratic and Reds Prove Exploitive

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, July 13

 BODY:
From the season's start, Frank Viola has insisted that he doesn't focus on his statistics, being, among other things, suspicious that he might get dizzy from any high opinion of himself that might result. Tonight, his numbers weren't anything to get dizzy about.
''The wheels kind of fell off,'' Bud Harrelson, the Mets' manager, said of his ace left-hander after the Mets lost here to the Cincinnati Reds, 4-2. The defeat put the Mets two games out of first in the National League East behind the Pittsburgh Pirates, who beat the San Diego Padres. 
Viola left the clubhouse without comment. His teammates were left to digest and decipher the numbers: five innings pitched, nine hits, three walks and a wildly expensive wild pitch.
 
A Slump of Sorts
''He was a little different out there tonight,'' Howard Johnson said of Viola. ''He let things bother him more than usual.''
One result was the Mets' first real discomfort in more than a month. The team, which had won 18 of its last 20 games by late Thursday, has lost two in a row for the first time since June 3.
''In that, we've done something I thought we wouldn't do the rest of the year,'' Harrelson said. ''I'd call it a mini-slump.''
If it is a mini-slump, it is one born of maximum frustration at the left hands of Tom Browning and Randy Myers. Browning, his efficient effort blemished only by Darryl Strawberry's home run in the seventh, Strawberry's 23d homer of the season, and Dave Magadan's run-scoring single in the eighth, had a perfect game through four innings, working fast and fearlessly.
 
Teufel Blames Anxiety
''We were all just too anxious, too aggressive,'' said Tim Teufel, who spoiled one threat by being thrown out trying to stretch a single into a double in the sixth. ''Especially against a guy who keeps things in rapid motion.''
Myers, who entered in the eighth, gained his 19th save, setting down five of the six Mets he faced with intimidating economy.
''They know what's coming,'' Myers said of his former teammates. ''I just try and keep them honest.''
Viola, en route to his briefest night's work since May 24, had thrown only half a dozen pitches before it was clear that he had left most of his magic in the dugout. He did manage a couple of tricks to escape self-created trouble in the opening innings, but was given the hook after the fifth.
Through three innings, Viola permitted six base runners, five of whom reached scoring position. But matters became unsightly in the fifth. Glenn Braggs singled to start the inning. One out later, Todd Benzinger singled, then Mariano Duncan doubled off the wall in right to score one run. Joe Oliver's groundout scored another, then Viola's ground-ball wild pitch to home plate scored a third.
 
DARLING'S UNHAPPINESS CONTINUES
 Ron Darling, upset over what he considered his premature exit in the nightcap of Thursday night's doubleheader here, expressed yet again his unhappiness and confusion over his current situation. Darling, the current Mets starter-in-residence in the bullpen, said he no longer had faith in what he was told by the club about his status.
''I don't put a whole lot of merit in what I hear,'' said Darling, who was taken out for a pinch-hitter after four innings in a game the Mets lost, 3-2. ''The Mets are a conservative outfit. They'll do with me what they want, when they want. But I don't think they know yet what they want to do with me. It's pretty obvious there are guys on this team they'd like to trade, and they can't pull the trigger. How are they going to pull the trigger on me?''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chris Sabo of the Reds sliding into third base under the Mets' Howard Johnson in the first inning last night in Cincinnati. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Still Excluded After All These Years

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran

DATELINE: TEANECK, N.J.

 BODY:
Twenty summers after his book ''Ball Four'' was supposed to have destroyed the game of baseball as we know it, the leading pitcher of the Little Ferry Giants of the New Jersey Metropolitan League sat in his office and thought about his distinction in the history of the New York Yankees.
The Yankees are having another Old-Timers Day today, and Jim Bouton is not invited. This is neither a bulletin nor a surprise. It is his tradition. Bouton, the Bulldog back in the early 1960's when his cap kept flying off, when flattop crew cuts were in and the concept of a dynasty still applied in the Bronx, may well be the most accomplished pitcher in Yankee history to become a nonperson on a day that glorifies what little sense of majesty the organization has left. 
Which makes him smile. ''I think it's terrific,'' Bouton said. ''It almost confirms 'Ball Four.' Talk about small thinking. This is it, folks. It tells more about baseball than anything. Twenty years? What kind of crime did I commit?'' What he did was violate the order that appeared on some clubhouse walls, but was imposed throughout the major leagues: ''What you say here, what you see here, what you do here and what you hear here, let it stay here.''
When Bouton took note of the laughs inside the game, plus the joys, the hypocrisy, the back-of-the-bus silliness, the pettiness and togetherness, the alternating feelings of achievement and worthlessness, and the unfairness near the end of baseball's economic dark ages, the paying customers were finally able to learn the truth.
But as the years have passed, we have discovered that Bouton accomplished more than that. Nearly five years ago, on that emotional early September night when the Mets met the Cardinals at the beginning of a stretch run, Keith Hernandez stood just outside a batter's box and listened to 30 noisy seconds of emotional support. He had just testified at the drug trials in Pittsburgh, placing the torture of his cocaine use on the public record.
And as Hernandez spoke that night in Flushing, the extent of the book's influence became clear.
''If this had happened 15 years ago, it would have been different,'' he said of the crowd's response to his situation. ''Now people know that athletes make mistakes, athletes are human, too.
If that book accomplished anything, it broke down the facade of athletes as idols.''
It was not merely the words Hernandez chose late that night, but the matter-of-fact tone, the acceptance of an intelligent veteran, that suggested that ''Ball Four'' had become part of the fabric of the game.
Decades of mythology, too often perpetuated by the press, had at last been replaced by some understanding of the people that millions pay to see.
Years after Bouton was criticized for wondering how good Mickey Mantle might have been if he didn't drink so much and so often, Mantle often publicly wondered the same thing.
Seventeen years after the book, co-written with Leonard Shecter, addressed the racial inequities in the business of baseball, the ''Nightline'' blunder of Al Campanis on live network television finally forced the sport to acknowledge a problem. In the era of the million-dollar utility infielder, the 20th anniversary edition of the book reminds us of the days, not that long ago, when management would do its best to strongarm some kid out of an extra $500.
And if ''Ball Four'' has been confirmed in terms of management's tactics, it has also shown the consistency in one slim 51-year-old right-hander's outlook toward the game.
Bouton was away for nearly five years, dealing with the fallout from a divorce, when he was driving by a field with his wife, Paula Kurman, five years ago. ''I said, 'Would you mind if I just stop here and watch a couple of pitches?''' he remembered. ''I wanted to see this kid's motion. So we both sat in the car watching a couple of pitches.
''And she said, 'Do you miss it?' I said, 'I don't know.' She said, 'Why don't you ask if you could work out with them?' ''
Five years later, when not delivering motivational speeches or heading a company that invents and markets sports-related items, he has a record of 5-2 for a team that has won 10 of 18 games in a league of former major and minor leaguers plus undrafted college players. He was approached last year by a team in the Senior Professional League in Florida, but quickly rejected that idea as far too serious.
But Bouton has confirmed the thought he recorded 20 years ago, after the end of his 1969 season with the Seattle Pilots, the minor league Vancouver Mounties, and the Houston Astros: ''You see, you spend a good piece of your life gripping a baseball and in the end it turns out that it was the other way around all the time.''
He smiles and says he would rather have the distinction of being uninvited to Old-Timers Day than be announced as the reason Mickey Mantle decided to stay away. But now that flattops are back, in the summer that Nelson Mandela made it to Yankee Stadium, it would be nice to see the Bulldog lose his cap just one more time.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Bouton in 1964. (United Press International)

HEADLINE: Strong Increase of 0.5% Shown in Retail Sales

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Helped by strong department store sales, overall retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. It was the first increase since January.
Retail sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $147.82 billion in June, up $784 million from the May level, the Commerce Department said. 
''It's a welcome sign for a beleaguered sector of the economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. ''It offers a good deal of hope that the economy will keep on expanding.''
 
Three Months of Declines
But analysts also cautioned against reading too much into the sales turnaround. They noted that the June increase followed three months of declines - the first such period of sustained weakness since 1981. ''The question is whether it's a one-time reversal of a string of weakness or the start of something new,'' Mr. Sinai said.
Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, prolonged weakness in retail sales raises fears that the economy could be headed for a downturn.
Analysts said the upturn in June retail sales was probably due, in part, to consumers who had delayed making purchases in April and May. They noted that cool May temperatures probably resulted in a delay of purchases of summer clothing, air-conditioners and other seasonal items. Those purchases were likely made in June, when the weather warmed up, the analysts said.
David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill called the June increase ''just a rebound from the softness we saw in May.''
''We're up only 2.4 percent from a year ago,'' he said. ''That's not even keeping up with inflation.''
Americans continue to show signs that they are cautious about their spending, said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
''The consumer did not turn tail in the spring, but nonetheless is behaving in a rather restrained way,'' Mr. Dederick said.
The June increase of five-tenths of 1 percent was the first rise in retail sales since January, when sales rose 2.8 percent. Retail sales showed no change in February, fell four-tenths of 1 percent in March, 1 percent in April and six-tenths in May.
The overall gain stemmed partly from spending at department stores, which rose 2.8 percent, reflecting a rebound after a drop of 2.2 percent in May. Department store sales had fallen for three months, and analysts said the June increase resulted from price cuts intended to encourage purchases of summer clothes.
Auto sales edged up a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in June after being down two-tenths in May. Weak auto sales have contributed to the overall sluggishness of consumer spending this year.
Sales at building material and hardware stores rose 1.3 percent after falling two-tenths of 1 percent in April.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises in U.S. Trading After Declining in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose in the United States yesterday in volatile, heavy trading after falling in Europe.
The American currency - after declining on Thursday on comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the Fed might ease interest rates - changed direction yesterday. It rose in domestic trading in a seesaw session. 
The dollar tumbled after Mr. Greenspan's remarks because lower rates reduce the returns on dollar-denominated investments, thus sending investors to other currencies.
Traders said the dollar rose yesterday after the Government reported that wholesale prices climbed by two-tenths of a percent in June, indicating low inflation.
But the currency then slipped after the Fed added money to the banking system. That has the effect of lowering interest rates, and some of the traders interpreted it as a follow-up to the Fed chairman's comments.
The Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, moved lower, which has a negative influence on the dollar.
But the dollar soon climbed again, partly because European traders were buying dollars to shore up their positions as the markets there closed, said Francoise Soares-Kemp, a vice president in the foreign exchange department of Credit Suisse in New York.
The currency was also strengthened by the traders, who believed the dollar had reached its bottom and were buying them to cover short trading positions, the traders said.
Against the Japanese currency, one dollar bought 148.15 yen in New York trading, up from 147.40 yen late on Thursday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to its lowest level since Feb. 22, closing at 147.42 yen, down 1.48 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar firmed to 147.50 yen.
The dollar jumped against the West German currency, to 1.6510 marks, up from 1.6355.
In London, the British pound traded at $1.8020, up from $1.7995 late on Thursday. But in New York, a pound cost $1.8005, cheaper than $1.8130 late on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Climb Sharply; Grain and Soybeans Also Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures rallied strongly yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, but some analysts wondered whether the market would sustain the gains, which were prompted in part by a decline in interest rates.
On other commodity markets, silver also rose; petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans advanced, and livestock and meat futures rose.
Gold futures settled $6.20 to $6.70 higher in New York. The contract for delivery in August was at $365.70 an ounce, its highest settlement price since May 31. The expiring July contract was up $6.30, to $364.40. 
Silver futures ended 1.7 cents to 1.8 cents higher, with the July contract at $4.908 an ounce.
The rally in gold extended the $3.90 gain posted on Thursday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, indicated that the Fed was ready to ease credit, if necessary. Interest rates fell sharply on the news, and gold, which is considered a hedge against inflation, rose.
Analysts agreed that lower interest rates could create a friendlier atmosphere for gold. Craig Sloane, a metals analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the upward swing of gold on Thursday could be seen as a sign that the market had ended its recent decline.
But Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said other conditions did not appear right for gold to sustain the rally. Gains in the stock market, like those of Thursday and Friday, are typically bearish signals for gold, he said.
 
Bargain Hunting Seen
Mr. Savaiko said the two-day run-up in gold prices might simply have represented the squaring of books before the expiration of the August gold options contract on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and bottom-picking by investors when gold fell to near $350 an ounce on Thursday.
Crude oil futures ended mixed in a volatile session dominated by bullish news of unity by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on measures to restrict production and raise prices.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 10 cents lower to 17 cents higher, with August at $18.36 a barrel; heating oil was 0.78 cent to 1.85 cents higher, with August at 54.21 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.43 cent to 1.38 cents higher, with August at 61.95 cents a pound.
Prices of crop futures ended higher on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department reported that the agency had lowered its projections for winter wheat production and corn and soybean stockpiles.
But gains were limited by expectations that beneficial weather would continue as the corn crop enters its critical pollination phase.
Cattle futures rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash markets.
