HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rose 2.5% in Early July

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 13

 BODY:
Helped by strong demand for light trucks from General Motors and Ford, sales of American-built vehicles rose 2.5 percent in early July, the industry's second consecutive 10-day period of healthy sales gains.
Over all, sales of domestically produced cars rose six-tenths of a percent in early July. G.M., Honda, Mazda, Mitsubishi and Toyota all reported higher sales, while Chrysler and Nissan showed sharp declines, and Ford's sales were marginally lower.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.3 million, lagging behind the 7.4 million rate for the comparable period a year earlier. The number of selling days was the same in both years. The selling rate for the last 30 days was 7.3 million; for the last 60 days, cars sold at a rate of 6.9 million. 
 
Trucks and Vans Up
Sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles, which account for roughly a third of all vehicles sold, rose 5.6 percent in early July, compared with a year ago.
''This was a surprise,'' said Scott Merlis, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, ''because rebates have been coming down, prices just went up, and sales were higher than we had anticipated in June: three reasons for lower sales in early July.''
Mr. Merlis noted that inventories of unsold cars and trucks had fallen to the lowest level in five years.
''People could be waiting in line to buy a car this summer,'' he said, ''which would be ironic compared to the fire sales that were held a year ago to move unsold vehicles near the end of the model year.''
Sales by the ''transplant'' auto makers - the Japanese companies that build cars in the United States -increased 35.2 percent. The Big Three domestic makers reported a collective decline of 2.3 percent, most of it from Chrysler.
 
Problem Area for Chrysler
Indeed, the gains posted by G.M. and Ford in light-truck sales appeared to be at the expense of Chrysler, which reported a 13.9 percent drop in sales of light trucks. That category includes Chrysler's mini-vans, which have new rivals in G.M.'s plastic-bodied mini-vans. Those appear to have caught on with buyers after slow initial sales in the spring.
In addition, Ford's new four-door Explorer sport-utility vehicle is challenging Chrysler's Jeep Cherokee, which has dominated the market for the hybrid between pickup trucks and station wagons, but must now contend with new four-door rivals from several auto makers.
''Chrysler faces substantially increased competition from here on, in both mini-vans and Jeeps,'' said Philip Fricke, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities.
G.M.'s car sales rose eight-tenths of a percent, led by gains for the Geo line of compact cars, which are manufactured by Isuzu and the G.M.-Toyota joint venture in Fremont, Calif.
 
Aided by a Movie
Sales of the Chevrolet Lumina also surged. The car is featured in the movie ''Days of Thunder,'' and many Chevrolet dealers have held special promotions to take advantage of the film's release.
''There's no question that the movie is helping sales,'' a Chevrolet spokesman said.
Other G.M. models that sold well in early July included the redesigned Chevrolet Caprice, Pontiac Grand Prix, Oldsmobile 98, and Cadillac Seville. Sales of the Seville rose more than fourfold.
G.M.'s light-truck sales increased 18.2 percent, led by two mini-vans, the Chevrolet Lumina APV and the Oldsmobile Silhouette APV.
Ford's 6.1 percent gain in light-truck sales came almost entirely from the new Explorer and the Bronco II sport-utility vehicle.
Sales of cars made by Ford fell four-tenths of a percent. Sales of the Escort remained sluggish, lagging behind last year's by 28 percent, despite an extensive marketing campaign for the redesigned small car. Sales of Escorts and Ford's subcompact, the Festiva, are essential in helping the company meet Federal fuel economy standards for its total product line.
Chrysler's car sales fell 18.8 percent, as customers failed to respond to an aggressive advertising campaign featuring Lee A. Iacocca, the company chairman. Sales of Chrysler's light trucks and mini-vans were also down, by 13.9 percent. Some analysts suggested that buyers might be waiting for Chrysler's new mini-vans, due out this fall.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up Modest 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
In a mixed reading on inflation, the Labor Department reported today that prices at the producer level rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in June but would have climbed much more without continued declines for energy and food.
Excluding those two volatile components, the Producer Price Index jumped six-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest increase since June 1989, with passenger cars and tobacco products showing substantial increases.
Although the rise in the so-called core figure was higher than most analysts had expected, the widespread view was it was unlikely to be sustained and that inflation remained essentially under control.
 
Expectations Fulfilled
But they also said that the inflation data today seemed to underscore the concern expressed to Congress on Thursday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that overcaution by bankers in making loans was putting the economic expansion at risk. Today, the Fed took steps that pushed down a key money-market interest rate, thereby quickly fulfilling expectations that Mr. Greenspan had raised. 
Since the Fed's chairman is believed to have known the June producer price figures before going to Capitol Hill on Thursday - and acted as he did to signal lower interest rates in spite of the six-tenths of 1 percent jump in the core rate - this supported the view that the Fed's policy had been readjusted.
''The Fed has definitely shifted direction and priorities,'' said John O. Wilson, chief economist for the Bank of America, adding that he thought Mr. Greenspan was interested in doing more than just offsetting the tightened credit terms being imposed by bankers. ''I think he's really worried about the economy,'' Mr. Wilson said.
But analysts at Salomon Brothers, who were less worried about the pace of the economy, expressed some anxiety at the Fed's decision to shift from its ''standing priority of paring inflation'' to address the different risk of shoring up the financial system and avoiding a credit squeeze. Easing policy ''may be benign in a sluggish economy but it does little to lower inflation expectations,'' these analysts wrote in their weekly ''Comments on Credit'' publication, which was published today.
 
Comment by White House
At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called the modest rise in the overall price index ''excellent news,'' saying that ''declining inflation should continue to relieve pressure on interest rates.''
In a separate report, the Commerce Department disclosed that retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June following three straight declines. This rise provided some reassurance about the prospects for continued economic growth.
The rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in prices received by domestic producers for goods ready for sale to the final business or individual user followed an increase of three-tenths in May and declines of three-tenths in March and April.
Food prices declined moderately for the third time in four months, the Labor Department said, while energy prices dropped for the fifth straight month after soaring by nearly 14 percent in January.
Among items reversing direction were fish, pork, processed chickens and pasta, which fell in price, and eggs and fresh fruits and vegetables, which rose. Home heating oil fell 10.5 percent, even faster than May's 6.2 percent, but gasoline prices turned slightly higher. 3.1 Percent Rise in Year Over the last year, the index for finished goods has now climbed 3.1 percent, with the increase without food and energy a slightly higher 3.4 percent.
For the first half of 1990, the finished goods index rose at a 3.7 percent rate, down from 7.4 percent in the first half of 1989 but higher than the 2.6 percent inflation rate posted during the second half of 1989.
Two companion indexes, for prices of goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production, both posted declines last month, today's report showed.
 
Intermediate Goods Down
Intermediate goods, which are one step further removed from the ultimate user, such as a bag of flour or a bolt of cloth, edged down two-tenths of 1 percent with most categories showing little change. Excluding food and energy, the decline was one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
Over the last year, the inflation in intermediate goods was a negligible two-tenths of 1 percent. ''A lot of us in goods-producing industries find it hard to believe there's any inflation at all,'' said John D. Walter Jr., an economist at the Dow Corning Corporation, which makes silicones and related chemicals.
Prices of crude goods, such as wheat or raw cotton, fell 2.4 percent last month after virtually no change in May and declines averaging more than 2 percent in March and April. Disregarding food and energy, crude goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent last month.

HEADLINE: Sears Expects Steep Drop In Second-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 13

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it expects a sharp decline in second-quarter earnings because its Allstate Insurance group's catastrophe-related losses exceeded expectations and sales by the merchandise group were disappointing.
In a brief statement, Sears said second-quarter earnings from continuing operations were expected to be about 65 cents a share, down from 95 cents a share in the comparable period last year. Discontinued operations added 16 cents a share to earnings in the period last year, bringing actual net income for the quarter to $1.11 a share. 
Analysts had expected Sears to earn about 80 cents a share in this year's second quarter. They have for some time been revising their estimates downward, based on Sears's weak retail sales in recent months.
''We knew they would be lower, but the magnitude of decline was much greater than I had anticipated,'' said Richard Nelson, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Mr. Nelson reduced his full year's estimate of earnings per share to $4.25, from $4.40. Last year Sears earned $4.30 a share.
Edward A. Weller, an analyst at Montgomery Securities, dropped his 1990 estimate to $3.90 from $4.05.
The price of a Sears share fell 37.5 cents today, to $34.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
On Thursday, Sears said its retail operations had a 3.7 percent gain in sales for the five weeks ended July 7. Sales at stores open more than a year were up 3.5 percent.
A Sears spokesman declined to elaborate on today's announcement on the earnings outlook. Sears expects to announce its second-quarter results early in the week of July 23.
The recent fires in California account for Allstate's unexpectedly high losses. Ira H. Malis, an insurance analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore, said Allstate was particularly susceptible to losses from fires and other disasters because a high percentage of its business is insuring houses and cars. Mr. Malis said that most analysts had not lowered their estimates for the insurance industry over all because of the recent fires, floods and other natural disasters.
Analysts said that today's announcement was further evidence of how daunting a task Sears faced in its highly publicized effort to revive its retail business by cutting prices and emphasizing national appliance and electronic brands.
''The job they have is immensely complicated,'' Mr. Weller said. ''I don't think people worry about Allstate's ability to thrive in the same way that many of us worry about the merchandise group.''
Still, management has said for some time that profits from Sears stores will improve in the second half of the year, and the company stood by that claim today. ''We continue to expect a solid performance for the second half of the year based on our outlook for continued moderate growth in the economy,'' the chairman and chief executive, Edward A. Brennan, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Costly Proposals to Curb Asbestos Ignite New York City Debate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Proposals aimed at reducing the threat of airborne asbestos in buildings have set off a furious debate in New York City, which already has some of the toughest asbestos regulations in the country.
Prominent in the debate are religious groups, along with many other property owners and businesses, all of them alarmed over the prospect of a law that would require them to pay millions of dollars for inspections, maintenance and possible removal of asbestos in their buildings.
The proposals, one of them submitted by Mayor David N. Dinkins, have also reignited a controversy over the medical dangers of chrysotile, the type of asbestos most commonly used in insulation and fireproofing.
On Thursday, a senior aide to John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, sparred with New York City Council members over the proposed legislation, saying it would impose ''a staggering economic burden'' that would force religious and nonprofit groups to slash social spending. 
But the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, and a spokesman for the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, told the Council that the dangers of so-called in-place asbestos are real and that the proposed law was a prudent response to a public health problem of immense proportions.
Asbestos, a naturally occurring mineral, can cause cancer and scarring of the lungs if its microscopic fibers are inhaled, although the symptoms of asbestos-related diseases usually take a decade or more to appear. Scientists believe that the risk is tied to quantity of asbestos inhaled and the length of exposure.
The City Council exchanges this week came during a daylong hearing on two asbestos bills, the second of which was submitted by Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, a Queens Democrat.
The measures, whose mainly technical differences are being ironed out by the Council's Environmental Protection Committee, would require inspections of asbestos insulation and fireproofing in all public and private buildings in the city and the repair or removal of any that is damaged and apt to become airborne.
In a sense, the New York City proposals would extend the kind of inspections and abatement policies that the Federal Government already requires for public schools nationwide to all 800,000 of the city's public and private buildings.
The procedures, which would be performed by city-certified contractors, would be at owners' expense. Owners would also be responsible for regular maintenance and periodic reinspections. Specific guidelines for building inspections would be established by the Environmental Protection Commissioner. These could address such questions as whether air sampling would be used to augment visual inspections or whether an owner would be required to tear down a wall to examine asbestos.
But the Commissioner, Mr. Appleton, stressed in his testimony that the legislation ''does not mandate, and in fact actively discourages, the unnecessary removal of asbestos.''
Besides the Roman Catholic Church, which owns 2,000 buildings in New York City, the most vociferous critics of the legislation include many other property owners, including other religious and nonprofit groups, many large businesses, people with co-operative apartments, hospitals and former manufacturers of asbestos products.
A gradual ban on all new asbestos products was announced last year by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. But except in schools, there has been no Federal action on asbestos already in place. But beginning in 1985, New York City adopted strict procedures for minimizing exposure to asbestos at construction sites.
Under its new proposals, property holders like churches, owners of walkup apartments, stores and service stations would have 12 1/2 years to comply fully, while owners of apartment buildings with elevators, tall office buildings, hospitals and hotels would have 6 1/2 years.
Mr. Appleton estimated that 544,000 of the 800,000 public and private buildings in the city contain significant amounts of asbestos and that 87 percent of the asbestos is damaged.
The hearing this week at City Hall included a slide presentation by an asbestos-abatement consultant, Laurence B. Malloy of the Malloy Corporation, showing how the flaking of asbestos from insulation or fireproofing can spread the cancer-causing fibers into the air, even into food.
The proposed law ''is meant to help prevent a new cycle of illness and death,'' said Councilman Enoch H. Williams, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee, which heard from 15 witnesses on Thursday. They ranged from critics like Janet Fox, a spokeswoman for the Consolidated Edison Company, to supporters like Carol Steinsapir, an official of a worker advocacy group, the New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health.
 
Shifting of Funds
Cardinal O'Connor's aide, Msgr. Henry Mansell, estimated that compliance would cost the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn $60 million to $120 million, plus $7 million annually for inspection and maintenance.
''If we have to put this kind of money into asbestos procedures, we will have to take it away from things like schools,'' AIDS programs and other forms of vital social assistance, Monsignor Mansell said.
Mr. Williams replied, ''Some of the problems that come about as a result of asbestos are just as bad as many of those problems, too, so we're going to have to achieve some balance here.''
The Monsignor, who is Chancellor of the Archdiocese, added that no insurance is available to property owners for asbestos abatement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Religious groups and other property owners said they were alarmed over the prospect of spending millions of dollars to conform to the city's proposed new asbestos regulations. HEADLINE: About New York;
Not Just Mortar Holds Together Church's Stones

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Eddie Pizzaro grew up poor in Spanish Harlem. His father abused drugs, went to jail every so often and beat his precious mother in front of him. Out on the ragged streets, friend after friend seemed to fall inexorably into similar dismal traps.
Amazingly, Eddie did not. ''While everybody was in trouble, I was trying to build things,'' he explained. 
Build things. The other morning, Mr. Pizzaro, now 29 years old, strolled through the world's second-largest church, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and pointed out things he had built. The round-cheeked high-school dropout paused at Poets' Corner to gaze at black slate stones he had cut in honor of Henry James and Emily Dickinson. (Each took two days' work.) He then indicated a time capsule in which he had scampishly ensconced his own name. In the adjacent stone yard, which he manages, Mr. Pizzaro pointed to a continuing project, a bust of Nelson Mandela.
This direct-speaking Puerto Rican with the giant smile regards all those as lesser works. His most important creations are human -the neighborhood needy to whom he teaches the ancient stonecutting skills that can add up to a ticket to a better life. His is an exquisite lesson: ''We're not all perfect, but we can do something perfect.''
Nothing is more transcendent than a cathedral, those awesome holy books writ of stone and glass sprinkled magically about this sorry planet like answered prayers. Generations are born and generations die before many cathedrals are finished.
People look so small in cathedrals.
 
The Cathedral of
St. John the Divine began to rise more than a century ago.
But construction ground to a halt for World War II because the armed forces needed iron and steel.
 
Then the Episcopal
Church was reluctant to resume work on a grand structure in such a poor neighborhood for fear they might appear insensitive to the needy.
The church found a novel way out of the conundrum by deciding to hire unemployed young residents of Morningside Heights, Harlem and Newark and teach them the dying trade of stonework. Master artisans were summoned from England. The venture has become so successful that it employs more than 60 people and has recently begun taking on outside work - some as far afield as a restoration of the Iowa State Capitol - and plowing profits back into the cathedral.
Not surprisingly, many recruits to the demanding craft fell by the wayside. But others are doing work that has won praise even from European experts. ''We're trying to build people as well as revive the craft,'' said Alan Bird, a third-generation carver from England. ''The stone is the binding.''
Mr. Pizzaro is a huge success story. He worked four years as an apprentice before winning the title of journeyman. A few years later he became a supervisor and was recently appointed stone-yard manager. In this role, how important is Mr. Pizzaro to the cathedral's construction?
''Eddie is this whole enterprise,'' Mr. Bird said.
Eddie Pizzaro grew up building things. Often working in abandoned buildings, he built scooters, go-carts and, he figures, as many as 30 bicycles from scratch. What intrigued him were numbers and dimensions. He said he was called ''master of the ruler'' by schoolmates.
Despite excelling at mathematics, Mr. Pizzaro dropped out of school in the 11th grade. He says it was the only way his sister and two brothers could remain in school. His mother was already stretched to the limit, working in a hat factory downtown and cooking nights in an uptown restaurant.
Mr. Pizzaro found a job restoring abandoned buildings. About that time, he went to the cathedral for his brother's graduation from junior high school. The gargoyles captivated him, and he could not help scratching one to see whether it was made of plaster. (Hardly.) He began applying for a job, ultimately being hired to operate a 52-inch saw.
Mr. Pizzaro threw himself into the 10-hour days he still works. And he learned things. For example, when you look at a massive hunk of Indiana sandstone you must visualize the completed form before making the smallest cut. And the artisan's attitude is everything. ''If you feel bad, your stone looks bad,'' he said.
The difficulty of the task is increased by problems some employees arrive with, like drugs. And the job can seem downright eternal. After a decade, one tower comprises 4,000 stones of a planned 11,000. The other has not begun.
In the background, a chiseler chipped methodically. Mr. Pizzaro acknowledged that he would never see the finished cathedral. ''My goal is to see the towers,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Clemson to Establish M.B.A. Program in Moscow

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CLEMSON, S.C., July 14

 BODY:
Students in the Soviet Union will be able to earn a degree that epitomizes capitalism, a master's in business administration, under a program that Clemson University is setting up in Moscow, the university announced today.
Officials from the university and the Soviet Education Ministry plan to sign an agreement on Sunday calling for the school to develop the M.B.A. program.
''With the rapid changes both in the Soviet Union and Europe, they feel they need M.B.A.'s who understand U.S.-style management,'' said Ryan Amacher, dean of Clemson's College of Commerce and Industry. 
''We're excited to be the initial degree-making institution,'' he said. ''In 10 years we'd like to have 500 Clemson M.B.A.'s in the Soviet Union.''
 
Classes in English
The program could begin as early as next year, Mr. Amacher said. The degree requirements would be the same as those of the M.B.A. program at Clemson, and all classes would be taught in English.
The agreement calls for a new group, the Consortium of Universities for International Business Studies, to develop, finance and operate the Institute for International Business Studies-Soviet Union. Clemson heads the group.
The consortium would provide faculty members for an M.B.A. program in Moscow and also offer non-degree managerial training through the institute in the Soviet Union.
In addition, it would encourage United States-Soviet trade and ease cultural and academic exchanges between the two countries.
 
International Financing
''This is just the opening of a door which could eventually lead to a number of educational and research partnerships with the Soviets,'' Mr. Amacher said.
An international business group based in Paris, Investment Services, will finance the program with money derived from business ventures in the Soviet Union.
The group wants U.S.-trained Soviet business leaders who can help with the expansion of trade between the Soviet Union and other countries, Mr. Amacher said.
Plans call for the M.B.A. program to begin no later than 1992, with some prerequisite courses offered in the fall of 1991. Faculty members would be selected by the consortium and would spend at least one semester in Moscow.
Most students would be able to complete the degree requirements in two years, Mr. Amacher said.
 
Rationale for Program
Clemson would benefit by having some of its professors and students travel to Moscow for classes, he said, but American students would make up no more than 20 percent of the program's enrollment.
Clemson organized the consortium after it became apparent that the university did not have enough faculty members to run the Moscow program alone without hurting the school at home, Mr. Amacher said.
The others in the consortium are Florida State University, the University of Georgia and Mississippi State University. They would also have a chance to send students and faculty members to Moscow and could also eventually offer degree programs, he said.

HEADLINE: With Time and Influence Evaporating, Aquino Finds Rivals All Around Her

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
As her shaky six-year term winds down and her rivals maneuver for 1992 presidential elections, President Corazon C. Aquino is trying almost desperately to preserve some political leverage.
After the long, dictatorial rule of Ferdinand E. Marcos, Mrs. Aquino's humility and her pledge to serve only a single term were welcomed. But she has always presented herself as a reluctant leader, proud of her lack of political know-how, and this has set the stage for six coup attempts, a faltering economy and rampant corruption.
Increasingly, Filipinos express a desire for strong and decisive leadership of a kind that they clearly do not feel they have, and which they remember from the best years of the Marcos era. The main beneficiary of that desire has been Mrs. Aquino's estranged cousin, Eduardo Cojuangco Jr., a close ally of the late Mr. Marcos. 
As Mrs. Aquino and her advisers continue to try to pump some life into the last two years of her term, their chosen instrument is a new political organization called Kabisig, roughly translated as ''arm in arm.'' It is intended to be a citizens' lobby to press for legislation and change as well as an effort to reignite the waning popular support she once enjoyed. It is also intended to raise the possibility, still denied by Mrs. Aquino, that she may yet decide to run again.
 
A Land of Ambitious Politicians
The targets of Kabisig are the stagnant bureaucracy and the ambitious politicians, mostly in Congress, who are looking ahead to 1992. But these politicians say they are not terribly happy about being made scapegoats for Mrs. Aquino's own failures of leadership.
Both she and they feel betrayed, and yet for the sake of an even modestly functioning Philippines, they need one another.
Mrs. Aquino's main problem, some of her top aides admit, stems from her own limited sense of her job. Having installed democratic institutions, she does not seem to want to use them.
After the authoritarianism of Mr. Marcos, her style of democracy, in particular her respect for the separation of powers, is so rigid as to be unworkable even in the United States, they say, let alone in the feudalistic, crony-style politics of the Philippines. She is not a glad-hander; she does not flatter politicians' egos or make calls. Convinced of her own righteousness, aides, congressmen and diplomats say, she neglects the need to take advice or explain her decisions. She seems contemptuous of political horse-trading.
Ordinary Filipinos, who regard the maneuvering in Manila as childish or arcane, do notice the stagnation, however. They speak of corruption continuing on a broader, ''more democratic'' scale, of power outages and uncollected garbage, of bureaucratic and military abuses, of poverty undiminished and decisions unmade.
 
Everything Seems Worse
''I think Cory is O.K.,'' said Wilson Fernandez, a 35-year-old fisherman in the little village of Padre Burgos, on the remote Bondoc peninsula on Luzon island. ''But since Marcos, nothing has changed except for the worse.''
Mr. Fernandez notes that Filipinos like to complain, and reputable polls show they are increasingly disaffected with Mrs. Aquino. Since August, her approval rating has dropped 11 percentage points, to 48 percent.
More and more Filipinos seem to think they may find strong leadership in Mr. Cojuangco. He is known universally as Danding, and by his allies as ''Boss'' or the ''Americano,'' for his reputation for decisiveness, rapid action and loyalty.
Mr. Cojuangco profited considerably from the business opportunities Mr. Marcos provided him, for which he now faces numerous criminal and civil charges. Mrs. Aquino has accused Mr. Cojuangco of having had a role in the most recent coup attempt, in December, just after he re-entered the country clandestinely after four years of exile in the United States. Mr. Cojuangco has not been formally charged.
He is considered a more natural heir of the Marcos political legacy than the former President's widow, Imelda, still banned from the country and blamed by many for her husband's failings, or Vice President Salvador H. Laurel, whom Filipinos regard, however affectionately, as inept, or Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, considered cynical and devious.
In various newspaper straw polls, Defense Minister Fidel V. Ramos and former Immigration Commissioner Miriam Defensor Santiago are popular. Mr. Ramos has no party and is not an inspiring speaker, but may yet get Mrs. Aquino's backing. Ms. Santiago is a brash and noisy former judge who has created the image of a graft-buster, but is thought to have offended too many people to be a credible candidate.
 
Call for Action
Mr. Cojuangco has not publicly announced that he will run for President in 1992, but his friends are setting up a political party for him. The celebration of his 55th birthday on June 10, two days before Mrs. Aquino announced the formation of Kabisig, drew 10,000 followers, paid and unpaid, from all over the country.
''Let us bury the past and move on to a new beginning,'' Mr. Cojuangco said in a strongly political birthday address. ''With you by my side, how can we fail? Together, there is no goal we cannot reach.''
A senior Western diplomat said he took Mr. Cojuangco very seriously. ''He has a lot of money and a lot of contacts in the traditional 'patron' style, and he seems to symbolize the vigorous, decisive management Filipinos want,'' he said.
''It seems almost unbelievable that Danding should be gaining this way,'' he continued. ''But it's a mark of the frustration people feel that they would consider making someone President who played such a part in a discredited administration only a few years ago.''
This potential clash of cousins continues a long rivalry within the Cojuangco family. Mrs. Aquino and Mr. Cojuangco share the same great-grandfather, who emigrated from Fujian Province in China in the 1890's, became a Roman Catholic, hispanicized his name from Ko Hwan-ko to Cojuangco and called himself Jose. He rode the train from Manila to the end of the line in Tarlac Province, about 100 miles north of the capital, where he set about getting rich, first from trade and then land, and married into the elite.
 
Family Grudge
His oldest grandson and namesake was the father of Mrs. Aquino; another grandson fathered Mr. Cojuangco. Mrs. Aquino's father prospered; Mr. Cojuangco's father, it is said, resented that success and felt ill treated.
While Mrs. Aquino's late husband, Benigno, was governor of Tarlac in the 1960's, Mrs. Aquino's younger brother, Jose (Peping) Cojuangco Jr., ran for Congress against Danding, a member of Mr. Marcos's Nationalist Party. Peping won. When Mr. Marcos fled to the United States, Danding went with him, settling in Los Angeles.
Diplomats point out, however, that the Philippine political universe -which includes the military, the newly wealthy and populist politicians - has become too large to describe it merely as ''Cojuangco vs. Cojuangco.''
Even if Mrs. Aquino does not run again for the presidency, it is considered unlikely that her brother will. Peping Cojuangco is an influential congressman, but he is considered a backroom operator, unable to articulate a national agenda.
After December's failed coup, Mrs. Aquino asked Congress for emergency powers. But she used them so ''pedestrianly,'' and on issues of so little sweep or moment, that they made little difference, a Western diplomat said.
 
Politics Is Too Degrading
He said she proposes legislation and appointments to Congress but does not lobby for them, considering it degrading. Similarly, the effectiveness of Kabisig has been undercut by the fact that Mrs. Aquino announced the organization without first consulting the politicians who support her. This infuriated them.
''I don't think she understands the process very well,'' a Cabinet member said. ''People tell her that successful American Presidents, like Ronald Reagan, worked and flattered Congress, while the aloof ones, like Jimmy Carter, failed. But she finds it hard.''
Her administration is divided when she cannot afford it, he continued, when she still has an active threat from both the left and the right. She remains sandwiched between an active insurgency and a frustrated military, which is both her protector and her most immediate threat.
While the recent withdrawal of American Peace Corps volunteers and the kidnapping of one of them has brought new attention to the Communist insurgency, the rebels have in fact grown weaker, not stronger, diplomats say.
As for the military, the coup plotters continue to plot, with more attention paid to a group called the Young Officers Union.
Still, there is one major advantage to the more heated politics as the elections come closer: the prospect of political change is widely believed to make a coup attempt less likely. A Cabinet member, after making a similar comment, laughed and said, ''Actually, the only time we know we're not going to have a coup is when everyone expects one.''

HEADLINE: The French Seek Their Own 'Peace Dividend'

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 12

 BODY:
Having long pursued an independent military policy, the French Government is for the first time facing domestic pressure to reduce its arms spending in response to the changes sweeping the Warsaw Pact and NATO.
The immediate focus is on proposals to cut the 1991 military budget. But the debate is already touching on broader political issues, including France's status as one of Western Europe's strongest military powers and its complex relationship with Germany.
Reacting to the first signs of public interest in a possible ''peace dividend'' that would trim the Government deficit, the Economy Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, has proposed a cut of $1.1 billion to $1.25 billion in the military budget for next year. The budget is about $40 billion. 
After the NATO summit meeting in London early this month sought to reassure Moscow of the alliance's friendly intentions, President Francois Mitterrand sent a message to Bonn noting that ''logic will require'' the withdrawal of 51,000 French troops stationed on German soil.
 
Resistance to Defense Cuts
Yet it is already apparent that even if only minor spending cuts are involved at this stage, any change in military strategy will be strongly resisted by much of France's political and military establishment, including sectors of Mr. Mitterrand's Socialist Party.
Unhappy that the military budget through 1993 was trimmed earlier this year, the Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, now wants a 4 percent increase in military spending next year. And any French troop withdrawal from Germany, he says, will not come before 1994 or 1995.
In defending a strong military, he has the support of the armed forces, the arms industry and the two main conservative parties. ''If France is a nation that counts in Europe and the world, it is due largely to its defense,'' said Pierre-Andre Wiltzer of the center-right Union for French Democracy.
Today, the very existence of a debate on the military is a novelty for France. Until now, successive governments enjoyed solid political and public backing for the independent policy established by de Gaulle when he withdrew French troops from NATO's integrated military command in 1966.
 
A Counterweight to Bonn
Over the last quarter-century, France has formally remained a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But no American or other foreign troops are on its soil and it controls its land, air and naval nuclear striking force.
With Britain, Western Europe's other nuclear power, France has also refused to join the United States and the Soviet Union in nuclear disarmament negotiations. More than Britain, though, it has viewed its military strength as an important political counterweight to West Germany's economic might.
But now, with the Warsaw Pact in ruins and NATO rethinking its strategic options, an independent military policy that for many years proved politically beneficial to France is suddenly threatening to isolate the country and even irritate relations with its neighbors.
At the 16-nation NATO summit meeting last week, Mr. Mitterrand was alone is opposing the alliance's new definition of nuclear arms as weapons of ''last resort,'' arguing that they should essentially be seen as deterrents to be used to prevent rather than to win wars.
 
Crumbling Domestic Consensus
And as part of the modernization of its nuclear forces, France is still formally committed to developing its new short-range nuclear missile, which cannot reach the Soviet Union, as well as a new generation of a air-launched nuclear missiles.
Nonetheless, as NATO commits itself to change, France is under increasing Western pressure to move closer to the alliance. There are also clear signs, even in recent public-opinion polls, that the traditional domestic consensus on military issues is beginning to break up.
''The Socialist Party is urging the Government to spend more on social welfare,'' a Western diplomat said. ''So the obvious place to take from is defense. France can't afford an independent defense policy for much longer. One way of saving money is to cooperate more with others.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: S.M.U.;
3 Sets of Proposals To Reduce Costs Win Cash Awards

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Southern Methodist University has begun giving money to students and faculty and staff members whose proposals can help the school save money.
This year the winners of the 1990 Cary Maguire Productivity Award are Gregg Mader, the university's manager of copy centers, first place, for suggesting that several satellite photocopy centers around the campus be consolidated, saving the university an estimated $152,000; Dennis C. Kendall, a staff member in the physical plant, second place, for proposing the consolidation of air-conditioning and temperature-control shops, for a projected savings of $35,000, and, Robert Skinner, the central university librarian, and Dennis Bowers, a staff member in the dean's office of the Meadows School of the Arts, third place, for a plan to use microcomputers, instead of people, to conduct library instruction tours. Projected savings would come through eliminating one or two positions. 
 
Project Is Under Way
The university president, A. Kenneth Pye, said the administration would do everything it could to use the winning proposals.
The university has already begun the copy center consolidation, which is to be completed by July 1.
''With all the satellite centers, we had some people who were real busy, and some twiddling their thumbs,'' said Mr. Mader, explaining the inspiration for his copy center plan.
The productivity award, established in January by a trustee, Cary M. Maguire, provides $3,000, $2,000 and $1,000 for the best ideas for helping the university reduce costs. The three winners are picked by a seven-member committee composed of faculty and staff members.
Mr. Maguire said the judges look in particular at the cost-effectiveness of the proposal and the ease with which it can be put into practice. Thirty-one proposals were submitted to the awards contest this year.
 
Making Management Think
Mr. Maguire, president and chief executive officer of Maguire Oil Company in Dallas, said he created the award, which is similar to one he instituted at Maguire Oil several years ago, because S.M.U. cannot keep raising its tuition at a rate exceeding that of inflation. The university's fee for tuition, room and board for the 1990-91 academic year will be $13,752, up 9.5 percent from the year just ended, a typical increase over the last few years.
The university does not release information about its budget, though administrators acknowledge that there has been a deficit for several years.
Although Mr. Maguire donates the money to be used for the award, he has no say in which proposals win. But he noted that experience has shown that even rejected ideas can be instructive. ''It makes management think,'' he said. ''You have to give a reason why you would turn an idea down.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Mississippi;
New Graduates Prepare To Teach in Rural Areas

DATELINE: OXFORD, Miss.

 BODY:
Armed with honors, degrees and noble ambitions, 25 of the nation's brightest scholars are going to battle for better education in some of the neediest schools in this state's rural areas.
The first Mississippi Teacher Corps, comprising top students from 19 United States colleges and universities, will finish nine weeks of intensive teacher training at the University of Mississippi next month and go to work in the state's impoverished public schools. The program is for graduates in subjects other than education and is intended to relieve the critical shortage of teachers in Mississippi. Corps recruits study classroom management, advanced psychology, teaching techniques and curriculum planning and get hands-on training twice weekly in three northern Mississippi summer schools. 
This fall, in exchange for the summer of free courses and room and board, worth about $3,000, most of the recruits will move to rural Mississippi to work in junior and senior high schools desperate for teachers in subjects like science, mathematics and foreign languages. Others will fill vacancies in urban schools.
They will receive full certification as Mississippi teachers and will be obligated to teach for one year, each earning about $18,000.
 
'Help Other People'
''We don't have a lot of experience. But I think we'll make up for it in enthusiasm,'' said Karen Cajka, 24 years old, of Somers Point, N.J. Ms. Cajka, a 1988 graduate in English from the University of Pennsylvania, left her home near Atlantic City to live amid the cotton fields and poverty of Yazoo City, a town of 12,400 near the Mississippi Delta.
''I decided I wanted to see a different part of the country and help other people. Teaching was something I had always considered, but I wanted to teach kids where it was truly needed,'' Ms. Cajka said. Her goal in teaching is ''to break through the social, economic and political stratification'' she sees in Mississippi.
''It probably sounds like I'm this idealistic kid from the North who wants to solve all of Mississippi's problems. I know I can't do that. But even if one child is happy he had my class and it makes him want to learn more and get ahead, I'll feel like I've been successful,'' Ms. Cajka said.
The poorest state in the nation, Mississippi ranked lowest nationally in per-pupil expenditures for 1988-89. The state's average teacher pay, $22,579 in 1989-90, was about $7,000 less than the national average. In April, the Mississippi Legislature passed a $182 million comprehensive education bill but has yet to provide funds for it.
 
'Like the Peace Corps'
''We tell the recruits that Mississippi has the highest number of poor kids to educate in the nation and a history of poor performance,'' said Andrew Mullins, director of corps placement and special assistant to the state education superintendent. ''They see that as a challenge,'' he said. ''To the ones from outside the state, it's kind of like the Peace Corps,'' he said.
Michael Cox, 23, of La Conner, Wash., and a 1989 social studies graduate of Harvard, believes racial segregation of Mississippi schools -sanctioned until the mid-1960's - is partly to blame for the state's current education crisis. ''For the South to progress, its racial tensions have to ease. I hope I can be a part of that,'' Mr. Cox said. ''I came because of the blues, because of red beans and rice and Southern culture,'' said Jeffrey Seinfield, 22, a 1990 classics and anthropology graduate of Stanford University from Tacoma, Wash.
The Teacher Corps program evolved from an alternative certification policy that Mississippi adopted in 1982 to qualify more people to teach in its public schools.
 
Avenue of Public Service
The State Board of Education, institutions of higher learning and community and junior colleges are sponsoring the program using $78,400 in grants from four private foundations. Recruiting on college campuses by representatives of the trustees of the institutions for higher learning in Mississippi began his spring. More than 125 honor graduates, who had to write essays on why they wanted the positions, applied.
''We expect to see a lot of success stories - a lot of junior and high school students turned around because of this program,'' Mr. Mullins said.
For Celia Savitz, 23, of Boston, the Teacher Corps is an avenue of public service. Her 1990 degree, ''magna cum laude'' from Harvard, could have led her into international business. But instead she is pursuing ''a chance to make a difference in Mississippi,'' she said.
''I try not to be idealistic,'' said Ms. Savitz, a social studies major. ''The reality is I'll be working with kids with discipline problems, kids on different learning levels, kids who don't want to learn. I'll be a first-year teacher. They're going to know it. I'll be an outsider in every way possible.
''But I'm ready for the challenge,'' she added, breaking into a laugh. ''I hope. I'm scared.''

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Is Tonality Pie in the Sky Or Pie in the Face?

BYLINE: By DONAL HENAHAN

 BODY:
Nothing is harder to kill than a good myth. Beat on it with hard facts, and it will hardly notice. Chop off its head, and it will grow another one by nightfall. Nothing, it seems, can put an end to a myth but its replacement by another myth.
One of the accepted ideas of the 20th century has been that traditional tonality was dealt a mortal blow around World War I, probably in 1913 at the premiere of Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps.'' Subsequently, Schoenberg laid the poor bones to rest by developing the 12-tone method, which made all the notes of the chromatic scale democratically equal and therefore, as it turned out, inherently static. Several generations of avant-gardists have kept busy throwing dirt on tonality's coffin to make sure the ghost did not walk, but they neglected to drive a stake through the corpse's diatonic heart. 
In the dying years of our century, the revival of tonality, with its apparatus of cadences, modulations and tonal centers, has become, if not the dominant new myth, at least a remarkably vivid illusion. Even at concerts of new music, you are as likely to hear works that are recognizably tonal, if not necessarily consonant, as pieces constructed according to yesterday's atonal esthetics.
It is a commonplace of music criticism nowadays that the mathematical formalism and severity of post-Webern Serialism finally led younger composers to react violently in favor of more accessible music. Repetition, formerly anathema, is elevated to a place of honor. The angst of the New Viennese School is replaced by a creed of quietism derived from Oriental philosophies. The rigor and dissonance long associated with contemporary academic music is replaced by calculated blandness and nonlinear logic.
About two decades ago, upon first encountering what came to be called Minimalism in the works of composers like Philip Glass and Steve Reich, I developed a ''cream-pie theory'' to explain it. For many years, that is, listeners tired of the nouvelle-cuisine leanness favored by the most highly regarded academic composers had yearned for an occasional taste of dessert to balance the diet. The early Minimalists responded by hitting us in the face with the whole pie: unrelenting repetition of a few consonant chords at interminable lengths. The reaction produced the strange hybrids that merge childishly simple tonal formulas with monotonous pop rhythms and, in extreme form, the cotton candy known as New Age music.
So we have a new ruling myth, which encourages us to believe that the function of music is either to serve as a background for meditation or as an incitement at mass puberty rites. I have heard it argued, in effect, that this musical leveling-down adds up to a cultural earthquake whose impact on world culture will make the American, French and Russian revolutions seem mere twitches on the Richter scale. At very least, we are in the presence of a ''new Wagnerism,'' whatever that means.
All this remains to be demonstrated, but no one who has read much cultural history would rule out the possibility that the next turn or two of the wheel could bring a renascence comparable in impact to the Nuove Musiche reforms around 1600 that resulted in the accessible style of monody and the birth of opera. It is always necessary to believe that such a renewal is possible. What else would encourage anyone to sit through one more meandering post-Minimalist work but the hope of discovering how this myth of innocence and rebirth may be more artistically fruitful than the sterner one it replaced.
Speaking of musical myths, I was interested to see several old ones laid out for autopsy by Kirke Mechem, who participated in a symposium last fall at the national conference of the Central Opera Service. Mr. Mechem, a San Francisco composer whose first opera, ''Tartuffe,'' has been performed 100 times, therefore speaks out of some practical knowledge. In my digested version, here are his candidates for the trash bin and his comments.
 l. ''New music has never been understood in its own day.'' That notion was never true in the past and even in our own century does not stand up to inspection.
 2. ''It's the audience's fault if it doesn't like a new work that has been declared a masterpiece.'' Efforts to ''educate'' audiences about new works and their ''responsibility to the art of their times'' are wasted and counter-productive. It does no good to market new music as bad-tasting medicine that is good for you.
 3. ''Only ugly art can reflect the reality of our times.'' A conceit perpetrated by bad historians. Art can shine a light on the horrors of our times, but it must be more than a mirror. It is a puny art that cannot rise above its environment.
 4. ''Musical theater (in the Broadway sense) is the opera of our time.'' Even the best musicals rely so heavily on musical cliches and production formulas and aim at such a low level of musicality that most opera lovers consider musicals a different category, even when they enjoy them as light entertainment. Some concerned people in opera management want to believe that opera and musical theater are the same thing. Not true. Don't be deceived, you administrators, by the fact that there is a big audience for musicals and that you'd love to get those people into your opera house. There is an even bigger audience for rock music. The solution to the contemporary opera problem is not writing down to any audience; it is writing up to the audience you already have, an audience that is used to great music.
I especially like Mr. Mechem's approach to the music-theater issue and commend this challenge to the attention of our better opera houses: ''If I ever see a Broadway show that gets to me like 'Die Meistersinger,' 'Gotterdammerung,' 'Falstaff,' 'Otello,' 'Figaro,' 'Jenufa' or 'Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk' - that has . . . music of that beauty, power, scope and grace - then we'll talk about opera and musical theater being synonymous terms.''
Mr. Mechem's argument, of course, is defensible only on the grounds of musical discrimination and taste, not theory or economics. It goes against the cultural Zeitgeist, but that is the Zeitgeist's problem.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
How a Real-Life Drama Came to an Unhappy End

BYLINE: By HILARY DE VRIES; Hilary de Vries has written about culture for The Wall Street Journal and other publications.

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
When the avant-garde theater director Anne Bogart and the Trinity Repertory Company came to the last act of their drama in May and parted company, it was more than a dispute over budget cuts. The fact that after less than a year the 38-year-old director and one of the nation's leading regional companies did not live happily ever after is an example of the challenge now confronting a number of the nation's not-for-profit theaters: how to secure the next generation of artistic directors while maintaining a faithful subscriber audience (the key to a sound operating budget) and at the same time allow for a new artistic vision.
Even before Ms. Bogart's appointment last fall, Trinity had been a troubled place, beset by controversies and a leadership vacuum that formed during the last two seasons when Adrian Hall, Trinity's founder and longtime artistic head, had also assumed the directorship of the Dallas Theater Center. Among the ranks of a new generation of young regional artistic directors assuming control of the nation's regional theaters, including Des McAnuff at the La Jolla Playhouse in California, Robert Falls at Chicago's Goodman Theater and Garland Wright at Minneapolis's Guthrie Theater, none was regarded as more of a harbinger of the future than the avant-garde Ms. Bogart. ''During the changeover of artistic leadership at a theater there are tough questions to be answered,'' said Robert Brustein, the artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, in Cambridge, Mass., the only other regional theater where Ms. Bogart had directed. ''It is very hard to say who the theater belongs to then - the artistic director, the board, the subscribers, the audience? And when the choice of successor is adventuresome, as in the case of Anne Bogart, the board must hang tough. Such a transition is always accompanied by anger on the part of the audience and a falling off in subscriptions.''
Indeed, the transition period is increasingly important to regional theaters, as several of them, including the Guthrie, the Dallas Theater Center and the Cleveland Playhouse, have experienced subscription declines and even financial difficulties during the changeover of artistic directors. A recent conference of regional theater heads included several panel discussions addressing just such challenges. However, the situation at Trinity Rep is regarded as one of the most extreme because of its financial problems and the abrupt departure of its artistic director after less than a year.
By the end of Ms. Bogart's first season as artistic director, the company faced one of the worst financial crises in its history - an escalating $1.5 million deficit, half of which predated Ms. Bogart's arrival. The theater's board opted for a 25 percent cut in the budget from $4.2 million to $3 million. Insisting that such retrenchment would mean broad cutbacks in personnel and production budgets, Ms. Bogart refused. It was a move the board took as her resignation. Richard Jenkins, a longtime company actor, director and protege of Adrian Hall, was appointed as artistic director for the 1990-91 season.
''Anne's season was artistically acclaimed, but not a box-office bonanza,'' said John Howland, chairman of the Trinity board since October. ''It seemed prudent that we take a fiscally responsible position. We all hoped Anne would work with us on that.''
Ms. Bogart, however, said she had planned the second season of her two-year contract (in which her first year's salary was set at about $75,000) with the original $4.2 million budget figure. ''If they had come to me at the beginning of the year and said, 'Look, this is the way it is,' I would have done things differently,'' she said. ''Instead, they wanted me to be the hatchet woman and I wouldn't. At the time I didn't know I was resigning.''
Ms. Bogart's departure - coming in the wake of a controversial and critically mixed season with marked declines in attendance - raises significant questions about the future of the prestigious but financially troubled 26-year-old company. So unsettled is the current situation that many actors and board members spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
Squeezed by falling revenues and escalating costs in a weakened New England economy, the theater had been forced recently to meet weekly operating expenses by borrowing against its $500,000 endowment fund, its $500,000 capital reserve fund and a $210,000 Mellon grant that had been earmarked for new play development over three years.
The theater has also restricted use of long-distance telephone service and obtained a 60-day extension from creditors. Mr. Jenkins, who two years ago refused the offer of the Trinity artistic directorship, says he accepted the one-year appointment now ''because I didn't want to see the theater where I had spent 20 years of my career go south.''
Mr. Jenkins and the board have already dismissed 31 artistic and administrative staff members, roughly one-quarter of the company - including the acting managing director and the marketing director. He has moved to restructure the theater's administration, replacing many of Ms. Bogart's assistants with former staff members and consultants employed during Mr. Hall's tenure. Mr. Jenkins has also invited Mr. Hall to return as a director, dropped Trinity's $255,000 two-year student training program from the budget, canceled the rest of the theater's summer season and announced a reworked 1990-91 season that will draw from a selection of plays, including such popular fare as ''Mr. Roberts'' and such small-cast dramas as Terrence McNally's ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune.''
In contrast, Ms. Bogart had been best known for her work in New York's avant-garde circles. Her inaugural season at Trinity Rep - an ambitious mix of classical and new work including plays by Gorky, Brecht, Shakespeare and Maria Irene Fornes, a contemporary American playwright - reflected European avant-garde influences and was an esthetic stretch for a theater and an audience used to Mr. Hall's socialist-populist theater. ''This is a very people- and actor-oriented theater,'' said Peter Gerety, a longtime Trinity company member. ''Anne is from a dance and movement orientation. There was a philosophic difference right from the beginning.'' (Two of Mr. Hall's acclaimed productions were his adaptation of Robert Penn Warren's political novel of the South, ''All the King's Men,'' and Franz Xaver Kroetz's domestic drama ''Mensch Meier.'') Audiences balked at such Bogart productions as a highly stylized ''Summer Folk'' by Maxim Gorky, a nontraditional ''Christmas Carol'' and a Brecht ''Baal'' that featured simulated homosexual activity. Subscriptions, already down by 30 percent from a peak of 18,000 two years ago, remained flat. Single-ticket sales were nearly 20 percent below the company's audience projections of 82 percent capacity - an ambitious figure for a theater that had not been three-quarters full for many years.
In addition, some of Ms. Bogart's administrative moves proved controversial. She dropped 10 actors from Trinity's 30-member troupe, including several longtime and well-liked company members, causing Mr. Hall to speak out publicly against her decisions. ''That was a wound that didn't heal,'' said one company actor who asked not to be identified.
Ms. Bogart prefers to work with a small handful of close associates and brought on board several administrative and artistic colleagues with little professional experience at regional theaters. When Timothy Langan, Trinity's longtime managing director, resigned this spring, ''there was a period of about four months when the theater was being run by people with literally no experience,'' said the actor William Damkhoeler, a company veteran.
Ms. Bogart, who will return to the American Repertory Theater in the fall to direct George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart's ''Once in a Lifetime,'' acknowledged that several of her decisions had been challenging to both the company and the community. ''And when we lost Tim we were all neophytes making it up as we went along. But I don't think that's bad. I believe this institution needs radical restructuring, and I don't think one year is enough time to figure it out.''
Just before her resignation, Ms. Bogart had indicated a willingness to accommodate her critics. She had announced next year's season - a more user-friendly program peppered with such familiar classics as ''Hedda Gabler'' and such popular new plays as ''Driving Miss Daisy'' -with a pledge to ''do anything to put people in those seats.'' Yet when the final production of this season, the musical ''On the Town,'' opened in May to mixed reviews and poor ticket sales, Ms. Bogart's efforts were perceived as too little too late.
Several staff and board members said that the director had inherited a company with an acclaimed artistic tradition but a history of fiscal mismanagement and lack of direction from an inexperienced board. In 1979, the National Endowment for the Arts had to bail out the company with a special grant after the Internal Revenue Service sought $100,000 in back taxes from it. The early 1980's saw a rejuvenated Trinity. But by the mid-80's, when Mr. Hall was dividing his time between Providence and Dallas, the perception was that Trinity was a rudderless ship.
''This theater is a $3 million-a-year business that requires professional management,'' said one board member. ''For too long this company was a seat-of-the-pants operation.'' Today, Trinity remains one of the few regional theaters whose 30-member board has no minimum donation requirement and the average annual gift made by board members is less than $1,800 per person.
But several people familiar with the situation who asked not to be identified say that Trinity's problems remain far from resolved. They add that despite Mr. Jenkins's standing within the community and the company, the theater is again being run by a small group of people with little administrative experience.
As for the future, there is widespread agreement among company actors and board members that even with subscription renewals running slightly ahead of last year's - ticket prices have been significantly reduced - next season remains crucial. ''Right now, the theater has no artistic mission except to woo back its audience,'' says another board member. ''And the board has gone back to being just a rubber stamp for another artistic director who has no experience.''
Mr. Jenkins disagrees. ''I didn't know Anne's people and I didn't have time to find out if I could work with them, so I brought back a lot of the people I worked with before,'' he said.
Mr. Howland says he is sanguine about the theater's future. ''During Anne's tenure the board was relatively uninvolved. Now we have our eyes open and we are trying to achieve a working partnership between the board and the artistic director to balance our artistic objective with fiscal stewardship.''

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Museums Hear a Knock on the Door: Politics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
Those who need further evidence that nowadays no manner of alchemy can separate the art world from the world of politics might consider the following incident, which illuminates what is becoming a quagmire for American museums.
On June 6, as organizers for Nelson Mandela's tour of the United States were still ironing out plans, Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco presented what sounded very much like an ultimatum to the president of the board of trustees of that city's Fine Arts Museums. Mr. Mandela will not visit San Francisco, Mr. Agnos wrote in a letter, unless the museums get a different sponsor for an exhibition of Dutch 17th-century paintings scheduled to open next February.
''I would like to strongly encourage that the Fine Arts Museums find another sponsor or cancel the show,'' the Mayor wrote.
The Mayor had been told by Claude Everhart, a deputy mayor, that the show might cause Mr. Mandela to skip San Francisco. According to the Mayor's office, Mr. Everhart served on the executive committee of the Northern California Mandela Tour Coalition, which had urged the national Mandela tour committee to avoid San Francisco if a new sponsor for the show were not found. 
The decision by the tour organizers was to add Oakland but not San Francisco to the African leader's trip. The show was ''not the determining factor, but it definitely didn't help San Francisco,'' Madoda Hlatshwayo, assistant to the chief representative of the African National Congress in Washington, said last week. On June 14, at a public meeting that included many anti-apartheid protesters, the museum board was persuaded to pass a resolution seeking an alternative sponsor. The board did not say what it would do if no other sponsor were found.
Why would Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, be concerned with the financial backing of an exhibition of 17th-century Dutch paintings that would not take place until months after his visit? Because the sponsor was Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, the Dutch parent company of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Royal Dutch has a subsidiary in South Africa. Shell has been a target of protests by anti-apartheid groups in this country and elsewhere.
Museums may be among the last American public institutions to feel the impact of social changes that years ago swept through the offices of government officials and university presidents. As the Shell incident shows, accountability at museums now extends beyond the quality of exhibitions to encompass issues of divestiture and equal representation. In trying to deal with these new realities, museums come face to face with an even larger question, one they have not had to confront in such a public way: To whom, ultimately, do they feel responsible, not only artistically but also politically and morally? Finally, and perhaps most disturbingly, there looms in the Shell episode once again the matter of free speech and government involvement in cultural affairs.
Last year, employees of the Fine Arts Museums raised the first questions about the show with museum officials, and this spring they were joined by members of the United Mine Workers of America, the Northern California Chapter of the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists and other protesters. Word of their concerns eventually reached representatives of the African National Congress in the United States, and in April Tebogo Mafole, a high-ranking A.N.C. official, accompanied members of anti-apartheid groups when they presented the case against Shell before the museum's board.
 
Conceiving Art In Political Terms
 That politics has become the order of the day in the art world, there can be no doubt. The controversy involving the National Endowment for the Arts has, of course, captured the most widespread public attention.
But within the art community an increasing number of politically charged debates have monopolized discussion - debates about the inclusion of women and members of minority groups in exhibitions and museum collections, for example, and debates about the interpretation of art among feminists, post-structuralists and Marxists, on the one hand, and more traditional art historians on the other. Perhaps not since the 1930's have so many American artists conceived of their work in such explicitly political terms, or at least received so much notice for that sort of work.
As for museums, they find themselves confronted with political and economic challenges that appear to demand contradictory solutions. In the 80's, art and money seemed to become inseparable. Astronomical auction prices only fueled the public's impression that art is a domain principally for the rich and powerful, and this image has certainly done no harm to the endowment's critics who argue that the art world is elitist to the point of decadence.
Worse, changes in the tax laws during the mid-80's, which discouraged donations to museums, have led these institutions to go to sometimes questionable lengths in courting private collectors by building elaborate annexes and emphasizing vanity exhibitions of these collectors' holdings. Recent, and sometimes disturbing, sales of valuable works from permanent collections further demonstrate how much pressure there now is on museums to raise money.
It is not simply the exorbitant price of acquiring certain art that has put museums at a disadvantage. Higher prices at auction lead to higher insurance costs for paintings, which in turn make it more expensive to organize the blockbuster exhibitions that have helped some museums avoid budget shortfalls. It may well be to everyone's benefit if the high price of blockbusters encourages museums to spend more energy on focused exhibitions drawn from their permanent collections instead of lavishing so much attention on traveling extravaganzas. But this is at best only a partial solution to an economic crunch that affects all facets of museum activity.
 
Relying on Corporate Help
 Especially because funds from the Federal Government have diminished over the last decade, museums have become even more dependent on the support of such corporations as Royal Dutch Petroleum, which can cover the estimated $500,000 tab for presenting the ''Great Dutch Paintings in America'' exhibition in San Francisco. The show, organized by the Royal Picture Gallery at The Hague, where it will be shown in the fall, includes some 70 works by such artists as Ruisdael, Vermeer, Hals and Rembrandt, and is accompanied by a 500-page catalogue.
It should go without saying that if the right wing succeeds in persuading Congress to cut the budget of the National Endowment, there may be even less government money available for elaborate exhibitions like ''Dutch Paintings,'' among other things, which would make museums even more reliant on corporate help.
In turn, and perhaps not surprisingly, corporations have been demanding greater prominence at museums by requesting, for instance, that their logos be displayed at the entrances to exhibitions and in advertisements for the shows. Shell's participation in the Dutch display was especially noticeable because the event was organized to celebrate that company's centenary.
 
Under Attack From Right and Left
 All of this comes at a time of heightened public scrutiny of corporate activity, and for museums, the resulting dilemma is obvious. Just when they are more than ever beholden to private collectors and what seems to be a diminishing pool of art-minded corporate sponsors, museums may now be facing the prospect of censure from groups like the anti-apartheid organizations in San Francisco. These organizations insist that the museums, as institutions serving the public and receiving public money, should be held as accountable for their actions as are public schools and government officials. In one sense, what these groups are doing is not all that different from what Shell and other corporations are doing: using museums as vehicles to advertise themselves.
The day may be over when museums and corporations can expect that philanthropic gestures will be accepted without question by a grateful public. And if so, it will be even harder for museums to entice private sponsorship at precisely the moment when their dependence on private support is greatest. After all, some of the most generous corporate sponsors of the arts in recent years have been targets of boycotts or protests, among them the cigarette maker Philip Morris.
Can Harry Parker, director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, now assure prospective corporate sponsors of the Dutch exhibition that they will not become targets of boycotts and protests? And should these companies take the risk? Museums, in other words, find themselves under attack from the political right and left, and not necessarily from people who attend art museums but from those who have come to see these institutions as symbols of what they consider undesirable activity. These people protest the sponsorship of an exhibition, but they may not be able to compensate for the financial loss when a museum rejects money from a corporation like Shell.
For Mr. Parker, the most encouraging aspect of the Shell incident is that a ''grass-roots, cross section of individuals,'' including anti-apartheid activists, has been trying to raise money for ''Dutch Paintings.''
''We have a responsibility to assist the museum to put the show on without Shell,'' said Geraldine Johnson, president of the Northern California Chapter of the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists and an outspoken opponent of Shell's participation in the Dutch display. ''We're not trying to cancel the show or to deprive art lovers in the Bay Area of the chance to enjoy this exhibit.'' Ms. Johnson has been writing to labor leaders and others, asking for money.
As of a few days ago Local 790 of the Service Employees International Unions - which represents 150 employees of the museums and was a strong opponent of Shell's involvement - had pledged $2,000 toward the exhibition. Its offer has been supplemented by $53,000 pledged from individuals. Still, $55,000 is a long way from the $500,000 goal.
 
Little Choice But to Give In
 In the mid-80's San Franciscans approved a policy to withdraw city pension funds from companies that did business in South Africa. They also passed an ordinance against investing city money in goods or services from businesses active in South Africa. Last year the museum, responding to protests by its employees, asked the city's attorney to determine whether the show violated the ordinance; in November it received written assurance that the ordinance was ''not applicable to this exhibition.''
But last month Mr. Agnos asserted in his letter that ''the sponsorship of this show is, however, in conflict with the spirit'' of the ordinance. Approached last fall by Mr. Parker, the Mayor's office said it supported the idea of the exhibition. During the winter, however, representatives for the Mayor began to express to the museum their concern with the mounting protests about Shell's involvement. By June Mr. Agnos, further distressed at the suggestion that Mr. Mandela might skip San Francisco on his tour, persuaded the city's Board of Supervisors to pass a resolution opposing Shell's involvement. He then made public his own letter to the museum.
Coming at a time when Mr. Mandela was making direct pleas to the American people to maintain economic sanctions against his country, the Mayor's letter effectively left the museum - whose collection and building are city owned, and which is given free rent and public subsidies - with little choice but to accede.
 
Anti-Apartheid Or Anti-Art?
 For Mr. Parker it has been a source of some pain that his institution faces this dilemma at the same time that it has taken a strong public stand in support of the National Endowment. (For example, as a protest against assaults on free expression, the museum wrapped a shroud around the copy of Rodin's ''Thinker'' that stands outside its entrance.) The director points out a connection in terms of free speech, because just as religious fundamentalists and other conservative groups seek to hinder financing for exhibitions they deem morally unacceptable, anti-apartheid groups are effecting something similar with the Dutch show. The result in both instances is to threaten the public's ability to see art.
In any case, there is a narrow line between, on the one hand, Senator Jesse Helms impinging on the activities of museums and the content of artists' work, and, on the other, Mr. Agnos pressuring the San Francisco museum to find an alternative sponsor or cancel the Dutch exhibition. Senator Helms is taking the additional step of trying to enact restrictive legislation. But the involvement of Mr. Agnos and the Board of Supervisors, even if at one point solicited by the museum, raises many of the same troubling questions about government interference in museum practices and programs.
 
Money With Strings Attached
 What, then, are museums to do? Clearly, no simple solutions exist. Their endowments could be invested in companies that don't operate in South Africa, but financially strapped museums, which compete for a limited number of supporters, do not usually have the luxury of deciding among sponsors for exhibitions.
Still, museums may view the Shell incident as a warning that if they do not regulate themselves the government and special-interest groups may, in effect, regulate for them. This means that museums must confront the fact that the money they accept and the art they display both come with strings attached, and that they should be prepared to explain their actions in clear and simple terms that the public - not just the art community - can understand. What has been a largely closed-door process among museums could become part of a more informed public discourse about art and politics. ''We must realize that as institutions we are in politics and public affairs,'' Mr. Parker says. ''To think of ourselves in an ivory tower is a dated attitude.''
