HEADLINE: FORUM;
Savings and Loan Bailout, Soviet Style

BYLINE: By JAY G. BARIS; Jay G. Baris, a financial services lawyer, is of counsel to Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling in New York.

 BODY:
Read my lips: No more savings and loan crisis.
With 1992 just around the corner, President Bush must quickly shed this albatross lest history remember him as the ''one-term savings and loan President.''
Fortunately, he need look only as far as the Soviet Union to solve this half-trillion-dollar problem. Beset by 75 years of Communism - with no private ownership of homes and few quality goods to purchase - the Soviet Union stands idly on the dock while Western ships of prosperity sail by. 
All the President has to do is invoke the law of supply and demand, and offer President Gorbachev the ultimate foreign aid package: America's savings and loan institutions.
Instantly, the Soviets would solve their most pressing economic need: they would inherit an infrastructure - including mortgages and credit cards - custom-designed to stimulate a sagging economy.
In return, the Soviets must agree to pay the tab. That is, they must take on the liability for the savings and loan cleanup. This could be accomplished by the creation of an R.T.C. - the Russian Trust Company.
The Soviets would be foolish to pass up this opportunity. Recall that America's savings and loans themselves were born out of necessity just a little more than 50 years ago. Savings and loans offered low-cost mortgages to encourage home ownership. Federally insured deposits guaranteed a steady low-cost source of funds and fostered savings too. And, by giving away toasters and credit cards they encouraged consumer spending.
The system worked superbly for many years, generating decades of economic prosperity. Only when a few greedy executives took advantage of deregulation and poor regulatory supervision, and stopped giving out the toasters, did it sour.
If they learn from America's mistakes, the Soviets need not worry about creating a savings and loan crisis of their own. For example, by discouraging Reaganesque deregulation, they would keep savings and loans from straying into the risky investments in ''junk bonds,'' art collections and ski lodges that brought down the American institutions. And strong police powers - traditionally a Soviet strength - would deter Russian savings and loans from criminal mischief.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Too Many Bosses, Too Few Workers

BYLINE: By RICHARD ROSENCRANCE; Richard Rosecrance, a professor of political science at the University of California at Los Angeles, is author of ''America's Economic Resurgence: A Bold New Strategy.''

 BODY:
Before Americans can celebrate the decline of Communism, we should ponder why a Japanese eighth grader typically knows more mathematics than an American with an M.B.A., and whether our own decline can be far behind the Soviet Union's. I believe we can avoid that fate, but we need to make a number of fundamental changes in business, government and education if we are to continue to prosper.
First, we must recognize that most of our organizations - public and private, military and economic - have too many chiefs and not enough Indians. We have embraced Max Weber's bureaucratic society with a vengeance, with overstaffed corporate headquarters in which specialization has been narrowed to a pinpoint. Committees proliferate, but the job does not get done. It is almost as if leading American businesses were run by a series of ganglia but not by a single brain. 
In all too many of our organizations, management specialties - not production and meeting the needs of the consumer - are the way to the top. More than half of the modern American corporation consists of workers uninvolved in operations or production work, an astounding fact. At the General Motors Corporation, 77.5 percent of the work force is white collar and salaried, while only 22.5 percent are hourly blue-collar workers. At Mobil Oil, 61.5 percent of the staff is white collar; at General Electric, 60 percent; at Dupont, 57.1 percent; at International Business Machines, 91.5 percent. (Because I.B.M. does much of its manufacturing overseas and most of its strategic planning at home, this is not surprising.) At Exxon, the figure is 43 percent; at Ford, 37 percent; at A.T.&T., 42 percent; at Chrysler, 44.4 percent. The ratio in typical corporations in Japan is about one-sixth of the American figure.
This tendency toward bureaucratization in modern American life is not confined to business; it also applies to our military and school districts. At the peak of our Vietnam effort only about 60,000 troops formed the maneuver battalions doing the actual fighting, but nearly 500,000 more military personnel supported this fighting. The number of America's most senior military officers - three-star officers, full generals and admirals - is now considerably greater than at the peak of World War II even though they have roughly one-sixth the number of combat forces to command.
In school districts the number of service and supervisory personnel has increased relative to the number of teachers. In Los Angeles, teachers make up only 50.6 percent of the total school district's employees; in New York, the figure is 46.3 percent; in Philadelphia, 47.6 percent, and in Denver, only 24 percent. In universities the number of administrative personnel has risen relative to the number of professors. In every area, there is a great surplus of captains over sergeants and lieutenants, and the result is a reduction in American productivity. America's manufacturing productivity now limps along at 1 percent per year, far less than historic figures of 2.5 or 3 percent.
Over time, corporate, government and educational bureaucracies must be ruthlessly pruned. The industry of the future needs fewer, but much more broadly trained executives. Workers should take on some management tasks. Many companies are already experimenting with self-managing work teams. Under one approach, 5 to 12 workers rotate jobs and take responsibility for an entire product or service with only limited supervision.
If the United States is to arrest its decline, two developments need to occur in the near future: first, American business will need to increase the ratio of operators to managerial staff, giving management a much wider purview; second, workers will increasingly come to fulfill a management function. In the more distant future, the distinction between white and blue collars may disappear.
But an increase in American white-collar productivity will not itself lead to economic resurgence. Corporate survival must become an objective beyond that of return to shareholders. Chief executive officers must manage for the long term and that means longer than the 6.1 years top officers stay on the job. The United States must invest more in its most important asset: human capital. American workers are undereducated. Schools need an infusion of talent, from universities, businesses and government. We need new tax incentives to encourage consumer saving. But if this country makes the necessary reforms and is willing to face difficult days, and perhaps difficult years, it will see a long-term economic resurgence.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Modem Makers Are Picking Up the Pace

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Computers are getting faster, more powerful and more reliable, and so too are modems, the devices that allow two or more computers to share information over regular telephone lines. Fairly bristling with advanced circuitry, the new modems achieve their performance by taking over a lot of processing done by computer-based software communications protocols. ''The modem is doing much more processing than the computer,'' said Dennis C. Hayes, president of Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. of Norcross, Ga., which for many years has set the industry's standards.
The change is important for the new computer systems that can perform several tasks at once, with a communications program running in the background while the main processor is working on other applications. For the last few years, the standard office modem has been able to transfer 1,200 or 2,400 bits of information a second, through modulation and demodulation (hence the name modem). Because of improvements that safeguard the accuracy of data, industry analysts are expecting the standard to make a leap to 9,600 bits a second. 
Using such techniques as data compression, which in effect squeezes out the ''white space'' between chunks of information, some makers of 9,600 b.p.s. modems boast that their devices have an actual ''throughput'' faster than 9,600 b.p.s. - several times faster, in some cases. A few brag of speeds that once were thought possible only on a digital phone network, like the Integrated Services Digital Network that is still several years from widespread use.
''Businesses are finally beginning to appreciate higher speed'' in data transmissions, said Greg Szumowski, a data communications analyst for the International Data Corporation, a market research company in Framingham, Mass. He added, ''They are aware that 9,600 is the next step up, and they've leapfrogged over 4,800.'' A 9,600 b.p.s. modem theoretically sends a file in one-fourth the time of a 2,400-b.p.s. modem, and the increased speed makes it economically feasible to exchange larger amounts of data. Because businesses increasingly need access to information stored in computers far away, long-distance telephone charges are a significant expense.
''We find that a lot of companies are changing the way they do business through these technologies,'' Mr. Hayes said. ''For example, a textile company in South Carolina is spearheading an industrial integration system where customers place orders electronically to improve service. Pharmacies and drugstore chains are using dial-in services to do drug-interaction checks, to make sure a prescription from one doctor does not cause ill effects when used with a prescription from another doctor. Companies are realizing that in providing those kinds of services there is a transmission cost involvedin sending data. High-speed modems can significantly reduce phone bills and make them more competitive.''
But telephone lines were designed to handle human voices, not computer data. The quality of the line is not critical for voice transmission, because the human brain has superb built-in error correction and data compression capabilities. Computers, on the other hand, are essentially dumb boxes that have to have everything crystal clear. The slightest pop, hiss, whistle, click or echo on a phone line can knock a computer senseless. A single bit that strays out of place can lead to all sorts of problems. Often, if the modem senses that the line quality is inadequate, it will simply drop the connection and force the caller to redial.
When modems try to pump more and more bits down the same standard telephone line, the importance of error checking and correction technology increases. As a result, the Consultative Committee on International Telephone and Telegraph, or C.C.I.T.T., an organization that sets worldwide standards for such things as modem and facsimile transmissions, developed a standard for 9,600 b.p.s.modulation, which is called V.32. If the V.32 modem makes a connection with another modem, it performs a ''handshake'' in which the two devices exchange information about themselves. If the V.32 modem detects that its partner is not V.32, it typically ''falls back'' to a lower standard. ''V.32 is a funny animal,'' said Casey Cowell, chairman and president of U.S. Robotics Inc. of Skokie, Ill., a leading maker of data communications equipment. ''It was originally conceived as a way to transmit data on leased lines over short distances, and it was not really optimized for long-distance connections. The technical trick was to get it to work well with regular telephone lines.''
U.S. Robotics, Hayes and other modem makers quickly adopted the V.32 standard for high-speed communications. Then, in the quest for further speed enhancements, the C.C.I.T.T. developed a standard called V.42, for error checking and correction, and a second standard, known as V.42bis, for data compression.
V.42 incorporates and surpasses earlier error correction standards called M.N.P., for Microcom Network Protocol. Many businesses already have modems that include MNP levels 2, 3 and 4, and they will be able to communicate with V.42 modems. V.42bis also supplants an earlier standard, called MNP level 5. In general, said Mr. Cowell of U.S. Robotics, V.42bis offers about a 35 percent increase in performance over MNP-5 modems on typical data files.
In short, businesses that need to exchange a large amount of data would do well to shop for V.32 modems with V.42 and V.42bis capability. Such modems typically cost $1,000 to $1,600. Because they cut phone bills so efficiently, they have the potential to pay for themselves in a relatively short time.
Modem makers often add proprietary schemes to the industry standards in their efforts to make modems go faster. U.S. Robotics's Courier modems, for example, employ a technology called HST that boosts the effective speed of the V.32 modem to 14,400 bits a second when it is connected to another HST modem. Otherwise, it falls back to the other modem's top speed. Mr. Cowell said HST also greatly improves the chances of a successful handshake on the first try and reduces the time it takes for modems to perform that handshake, to an average of 6 seconds from the typical V.32's 14 seconds.
''That means the HST modem can send 100,000 bits of information before a regular V.32 can send bit one,'' Mr. Cowell said. ''In many applications where people are calling to remote sites to extract data several times a day, every day, those differences add up.''
And last month, Hayes introduced a modem called the Hayes V-series Ultra Smartmodem 9600, for $1,199. The Ultra 96, as it is called, can reportedly achieve pure data throughput of as many as 38,400 bits a second when connected with another Ultra 96.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Giving Less Time to Good Causes

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Two years ago, internal dissension threatened to destroy the Shanti Project, the San Francisco nonprofit group that is one of the world's largest providers of care for people with AIDS. Its founder had stepped aside and Douglas P. Holloway, a member of Shanti's board, ran the group on a day-to-day basis for eight months while holding down a full-time job as an executive vice president of Wells Fargo & Company.
''I was coming to work at 5:30 A.M. and getting home at 10, 11 o'clock at night,'' Mr. Holloway recalled.
Mr. Holloway continues to put in many hours a week at Shanti, at Irwin Memorial Blood Centers and on similar nonprofit boards because he is ''personally committed'' to an adequate blood supply and to helping AIDS victims. But this kind of commitment has grown rare. 
''Nonprofit agencies are finding it harder to sign on board members,'' said Chrystl Kasler, a specialist in nonprofit organizations in the Washington office of Chicago accounting firm Grant Thornton.
It is a particularly thorny problem for smaller, little known - and underfunded - organizations, said John N. Odom, executive director of the New York State Society of Clinical Social Work Psychotherapists. He noted that, although United Way of New York and several other nonprofit groups run programs to recruit and train directors for smaller boards, their emphasis has been on finding minority members, not corporate executives. ''The small, struggling groups that need the fundraising clout of prestigious board members just can't find them,'' Mr. Odom said.
There are many reasons for the growing managerial aversion to serving on nonprofit boards. Private-sector downsizing has meant that jobs eat up a lot more hours in the day than they once did, leaving less time for philanthropic activities. Scandals, like the one revolving around Covenant House in New York, have made potential directors leery of accepting board memberships of groups they do not intimately know.
And horror stories about directors getting hit with lawsuits and fines abound. One executive in Washington was on a nonprofit board that, he said, was so strapped for cash that its executive director used the withholding taxes it had collected from employees to pay its monthly bills. The Internal Revenue Service tried to make him and other board members personally liable for some $90,000 in back taxes. The executive, who spoke on condition that his name not be used because he did not want to attract the I.R.S.'s notice yet again, says he spent more than $5,000 on legal fees before the I.R.S. backed off.
Since most nonprofit groups indemnify their directors, such stories are rare. Still, Ms. Kasler tells clients to check the last audited financial statement of any nonprofit before they join.
''Financial problems can mean a lot of hand-wringing and unpleasantry, even if the insurance company will pay,'' she said.
Not all nonprofit groups have the same degree of trouble attracting directors, of course. Accountants, doctors and other professionals are generally eager to serve on the boards of their own professional associations because it affords networking opportunities. Membership on the boards of major art museums or philharmonic orchestras are considered prize plums for high-society types. And chief executives can usually attract their peers - and certainly subordinates hoping to rise - to boards they favor.
Yet even these boards are on dangerous ground, in that they are asking their directors for a lot of time and money.
''Too many people think putting their name on the letterhead is enough,'' said Gordon C. Dixon, a fundraising consultant in New York. ''Non-profit boards have to make it clear to their private-sector directors that, with Federal funds drying up, it's become essential that they attend meetings, read the material, and, most important of all, raise funds.''
 
THE INCENTIVES TO SIGN ON
Why do executives join boards?
 Often, their corporations have made it professionally worth their while. Conoco, Colgate-Palmolive, the Aluminum Company of America and a fair number of other companies have made community participation part of the evaluations that decide bonuses and promotions. And many others, through articles in employee publications and generous time-off policies, have made it clear that community service is looked on with favor.
''An emphasis on community participation is part of our corporate culture,'' said George L. Knox 3d, vice president of public affairs at the Philip Morris Companies. ''But where lower-level people become volunteer ambulance drivers, senior vice presidents sit on boards.''
Boards that offer networking opportunities also have a good shot at attracting directors. Thomas M. James, a partner in Gorsuch, Kirgis, Campbell, Walker & Grover, a Denver law firm, spends an average of 25 hours a month on his five nonprofit boards. The majority of that time goes to a local chamber of commerce. ''Sure, I'm committed to volunteer service, but let's be honest - exposure to the business community certainly helps in developing clients,'' he said.
Similarly, when Lyn Corbett Fitzgerald was an advertising project manager for Kraft Inc. responsible for promoting Kraft products to the under-19 set, she joined the board of Future Homemakers of America, a nonprofit group that points teen-agers toward careers in home economics. Being on the board put her in touch with a whole slew of teen-agers, allowing her to see how they would respond to various promotion and product ideas.
Now, Ms. Fitzgerald is doing public relations at Quaker Oats, and is no longer immersed in the youth market. Her three-year stint on the Homemakers board was up this month, and she did not re-enlist. She's finished with nonprofit service, at least for a while. If she joins another board, it will be in the private sector, she said.
''Nonprofits have so many subgroups with their own agendas that it becomes exhausting just finding out where everyone is coming from, where the biases are,'' she said. ''At least on a for-profit board I'm dealing with financial ramifications, shareholder interests, other things I really understand.''

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Japan, Smaller Is Beautiful

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
What's going on in Tokyo? Why are some small stocks soaring and the lesser-known stock indexes at record highs? With the closely watched Nikkei 225 Index still floundering around 32,600, how can some forecasters still expect it to hit 40,000 - a new high - by the end of the year? And has Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, given a boost to market hopes with his surprising promise to lower American interest rates if credit for businesses and individuals remains too tight?
The Nikkei 225 index, which charts the market's leading companies, is still struggling to regain a modest amount of the ground it lost with its 28 percent slide to 28,002 earlier this year. But the Second Section in Tokyo, which includes many smaller companies with fewer shares in the market, has already surged 35 percent to a new record after reaching bottom in April. The Second Section was up 48.54 Friday to 4467.25, its fifth new high in the last six trading days. 
One reason for the surge of stocks with smaller capitalization is that high interest rates in Japan have driven many investors from the stock market to the better yields in money-market instruments, leaving them with very high cash positions.
What has been sold is the better name, bigger company stocks. But the smaller capitalizaton stocks offer specal opportunities. One is that some of them had low price/earnings ratios. But more important, with fewer shares outstanding, any large purchase has a large effect on price.
''It is easier to push up these prices,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''You cannot buy and push up Nippon Steel, but it is easy to push up small-cap shares.'' However, he cautions, even these stocks may peak soon because the rally has now pushed their price/earnings ratios too high.
The reason for a change in the outlook for the market overall is the new talk of higher interest rates, on top of high rates that are already undermining the market.
Yoshiro Katsuya, senior vice president of Nikko Securities in New York, says worries about inflation persist, although price levels now are low. The fears have been intensified partly because of the 430 trillion yen in public-works spending the Government has promised over 10 years, he said. Higher rates may also be needed to boost the anemic yen.
So he expects short-term interest rates, now around 7.5 percent, to rise and the Bank of Japan to raise its official discount rate. The Bank of Japan has already pushed up short-term market rates, by about 25 basis points at the end of June.
While this is a negative for the stock market, shares should get some boost from a stronger yen, which last week commanded a rate of less than 150 to the dollar. Between these trends, the market is caught in the middle, which is not good, especially if the stronger yen is just a result of higher Japanese interest rates. So while the official view of Nikko in Tokyo is still that the Nikkei 225 could reach 40,000 this year, Mr. Katsuya sees a top of 36,000 to 37,000.
But Salomon Brothers, one of the earliest to trumpet a major turnaround in the Tokyo market, is sticking to its year-end forecast of 37,000 to 40,000. Its analysts, lead by Christopher M. Mitchinson, feel that the Japanese economy is at a turning point, which could lead to lower interest rates, and that much of the worry about inflation (consumer prices are up only 2.2 percent in the last year) is overdone.
Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, may have given their prediction a boost, since the major stumbling block to a new Nikkei high is interest rates. After the chairman told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday that the Fed might ease off on rates because of tight credit, it apparently did so on Friday, adding reserves and pushing the Federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans between banks, down to eight and one-sixteenth percent from eight and one-quarter percent.
This ease, much earlier than expected, could help strengthen the yen against the dollar and reduce some of the pressure on the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 15, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1818 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 8-13

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

INTERNATIIONAL
 
The Best Little Summit in Texas
 
A summit conference meant to celebrate the triumph of free-market economics became a demonstration of laissez-faire diplomacy as well. For every country and cause, the final communique had a clause. As the conference in Houston ended, West Germany came away with the right to unilaterally aid the Soviet Union, Japan the right to aid China. The United States avoided taking a strong stance against global warming, while the European nations beat back American demands for a commitment to end agricultural subsidies. Instead of unanimity, the leaders of the West's seven major industrial powers settled for chumminess. President Bush tried to loosen up his guests with rodeo and barbecue, even as some Houstonians fumed that their art museum better reflected their worldly sophistication.
 
Promises, Promises
 
On one summit issue, President Bush got downright vehement. He demanded an end to agricultural subsidies. The United States showers its own farmers with aid and protection, but not nearly as much as Japan or Western Europe do. Administration officials said that subsidies keep food exports from America and the third world out of major markets. The President won no specific timetables or commitments from other leaders, just a general promise to roll back protectionist subsidies. 
 
Helping the East Go On-Line
 
First the computer conferences, then maybe the computer sales. Western sellers are rushing to meet the Eastern bloc's potential buyers at one computer show after another. From last Tuesday through today the International Data Group has held its first PC World Forum/Moscow. Last month, the International Computer Club held its first International Computer Forum in Moscow. Set for early fall are the Softool U.S.S.R. conference in Moscow and the Edventure East-West High-Tech Forum in Budapest. The conference come as the West eases its technology export rules. But computer vendors still face unconvertible currencies, clogged distribution channels, scant office space - and doubts about whether the person who signs a deal today will have authority to live up to it tomorrow. ''I'm trying to first tell everybody how tough it is,'' said Esther Dyson, publisher of the Release 1.0 newsletter and sponsor of the Budapest conference. ''Then, if you still want to do it anyway, more power to you.''
 
COMPANIES
 
Defending the Family Honor
 
It was a trying week for a President attempting to distance himself from the savings and loan debacle. He defended his son, Neil, against accusations that he violated conflict of interest rules as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver. ''I have confidence in the honor and integrity of my son,'' President Bush said, while pledging to stay out of the case. Federal regulators are considering whether to file a $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush and other directors to recover some of the Government's losses in Silverado's failure. The regulators released documents last week showing that loans Neil Bush voted to approve for a business partner cost the Government at least $45 million when they went bad. Democrats tried to force the Justice Department to appoint a special prosecutor, bringing protests from Republicans.
 
*
 
A Senate panel opened hearings into what Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, called ''the worst case we have found'' of abuses in the savings and loan bailout program. An Arizona insurance executive with a history of legal and regulatory problems garnered promises of $1.85 billion in Federal subsidies to buy 15 failed savings and loans. The executive, James M. Fail, consolidated them into Bluebonnet Savings, which, with the Government aid, became the most profitable large savings and loan in the nation last year. Mr. Fail received help in securing the funds from Robert J. Thompson, an aide to George Bush when he was vice president.
 
*
 
The Senate approved a bill to provide $162 million to clean up the savings and loan industry and increase maximum penalties to life imprisonment.
 
Taken for Granite
 
Fly the friendly floors: American Airlines plans to charge its La Guardia Airport passengers an extra dollar a ticket for the privilege of treading imported granite floor tiles. Passengers on flights from Newark, New Orleans, West Palm Beach, Fla., and Fort Myers, Fla., will pay as much as $4 more for each ticket as well, reflecting what American calls ''excessive charges'' at these airports. At La Guardia, American objects to the use of granite tiles in the main terminal areas. American says the tiles are at least four times as expensive as the porcelain tiles the airline installs in its own terminal areas. While some consumer groups griped about the charges, analysts politely applauded. Julius Malduits of Salomon Brothers said airlines should be able to recoup added costs, whether at the airport terminals or at the fuel pumps. ''How's this any different from the fuel surcharges?'' he asked.
 
The Brademas Touch
 
If they had the millions, John Brademas had the lintels, with space for their names. And so, under his nine-year tenure as president of New York University, he lined up donors for the Tisch Hospital, the (Leonard N.) Stern School of Business and the Alexander S. Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies, named after Aristotle's son. His board of trustees, with Laurence A. Tisch of CBS as chairman, was stocked with Alan C. Greenberg of Bear, Stearns; Lewis L. Glucksman of Smith Barney; Thomas S. Murphy of Capital Cities/ABC; Milton J. Petrie of Petrie Stores, Lewis Rudin, the builder; Mr. Stern, of the Hartz Group; Martin Lipton, the lawyer, and Ann G. Getty. After raising $800 million in all, Dr. Brademas said last week that he will step down in December 1991.
 
Chi-Chi Shopping
 
With other tony New York retailers closing down, is there room for a new French arrival to open up? Galeries Lafayette of Paris plans to put its first American store in the Trump Tower space vacated by Bonwit Teller. But New York's appetite for Euro-glitz is slumping along with its economy. And Au Printemps S.A., Galeries Lafayette's Paris rival, closed its only United States department store, in Denver, last year. New York City's morale did improve last week with the Democratic Party's decision to hold its 1992 national convention there. But Galeries Lafayette will need to attract plenty of shoppers long before the conventioneers hit town.
 
Adding Insult to Injury
 
It was bad enough for John A. Mulheren Jr. to be convicted last week on four felony counts of conspiracy and securities fraud. But worse, he was convicted even after the lead witness against him, Ivan F. Boesky, confessed to keeping millions of dollars in ill-gotten profits, bribing fellow prisoners to do his laundry and deducting half his $100 million fine from his taxes. Mr. Mulheren, a former trader, was accused of conspiring with Mr. Boesky to manipulate the price of Gulf and Western Industries stock. A Federal judge declared a mistrial on 26 other charges when the jury deadlocked.
 
In Brief
 
A Federal judge took steps on Monday to consolidate hundreds of thousands of asbestos cases in an attempt to control legal costs. He also froze spending by a trust that the Manville Corporation set up to handle the claims.
 
*
 
Sears, Roebuck and Company said it expected sharply lower second-quarter earnings because of unanticipated losses in in its Allstate Insurance unit and weak sales in its stores. Eastern Airlines said Friday that it had entered merger talks with Northwest Airlines. Eastern also predicted 1990 losses greater than the projected $330 million.
 
*
 
Robert W. Kearns was awarded more than $5 million in his suit against the Ford Motor Company for infringing on his patent for intermittent windshield wipers.
 
*
 
Who says the leveraged-buyout boom is over? Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company agreed last week to the sale of Motel 6 to Accor S.A. of France for $1.3 billion. Kohlberg, Kravis and its investors will earn five times their original $125 million investment.
 
*
 
The GTE Corporation intends to acquire the Contel Corporation in a stock swap worth $6 billion. GTE would become the nation's second-largest mobile telephone operator.
 
*
 
The United Parcel Service plans to convert its 2,700 delivery trucks in Los Angeles to run on cleaner natural gas.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Loosening the Credit Reins
 
It's as if Alan Greenspan got turned down for a loan himself. For months, business people have been complaining about tight bank credit, but the Federal Reserve chairman said he saw a problem in real estate only. Last Thursday, Mr. Greenspan announced that banks had indeed become too unwilling to lend, so the Fed was ready to compensate by easing interest rates. The very next day, market analysts saw signs that the Fed was pushing rates down. The markets rallied, with the Dow climbing above 3,000 for the first time, before closing at 2,980.20, up 75.25 for the week. Mr. Greenspan believes the economy is strong enough to resist a recession, analysts noted. ''The easing we got today seems to have been a special, once-and-for-all response to the banks' tightening,'' said Lawrence Krohn, an economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton.
 
In Brief Truth in performing: New York and New Jersey are considering laws to require notices on concert tickets and advertising when a performance will be less than live. Many rock stars gyrate and lip-synch their way through programs of canned music that have all the spontaneity of political conventions.
 
*
 
Regulators ordered the nation's largest banks last Wednesday to write off 20 percent of their loans to Brazil and raise their write-offs for Argentina's debt from 40 to 60 percent.
 
Inflation Takes a Hike
 
No sooner does the Fed begin lowering interest rates than the inflation report takes a jump. While the producer price index rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the core rate, excluding volatile food and energy prices, increased six-tenths of 1 percent. The jump in the core rate was twice what many economists expected. And evidence last week that oil producers were arranging to limit output might reverse recent declines in energy prices. Some economists said Friday's price report was nothing to worry about after several months of low inflation; for the first half year, wholesale prices still increased at an annual rate of only 3.7 percent. But other economists questioned whether higher prices will limit the Fed's flexibility. ''We do have an inflation risk,'' said Stephen S. Roach, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley. ''It will not go away, and most definitely not with the Fed adopting an easier policy.''

HEADLINE: Currency;
Surprises From the Fed

 BODY:
Last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took the foreign exchange market by surprise, announcing Thursday that the central bank might ease interest rates because of dwindling credit from commercial banks and then, on Friday, actually pushing rates down slightly. The dollar fell sharply after his remarks but recovered some on Friday, partly because the June increase in producer prices was disappointingly high. This week Mr. Greenspan will give his semiannual explanation of Fed policy to Congress. Analysts will be searching for clues to what happens next. If Mr. Greenspan says there will be no further easing, the dollar's fall may slow. But many analysts expect the Fed to ease rates again later this year.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Warning to Lamenters

BYLINE: By A.M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
I read that a former newspaper colleague of mine is so depressed by the way things are in the United States these days that he says it reminds him of Romania.
Then, a day later, I came across two pieces on the Op-Ed page of The Times singing laments about how the U.S. had wounded itself fighting the cold war.
One said the United States had already become a militarized national security state. But that was positively lighthearted compared with the other piece. 
That one said the ''North American colossus is now widely regarded as a colonial power whose verbal championship of freedom, democracy and social reform cannot be taken any more seriously than that of the Soviet Union.''
You hear that, Colussus? That is what the man said, word for word. Widely regarded. You could look it up, if you don't believe me.
No, this writer, Christopher Lasch, was not trying to be funny, although I don't blame anybody for thinking that.
His final pronouncement was that the choice between the Soviet and American ''empires,'' even the ''abstract choice between socialism and capitalism,'' no longer interests the rest of the world.
I am sending copies of that showstopper to some Czechoslovak politicians, Polish unionists and Hungarian economists I know. Somehow they and Soviet democrats believe the difference between capitalism and socialism is the difference between national survival and national death. They could use a few chuckles nowadays.
But the man is a history professor and must have meant what he wrote. So now comes a cautionary word to readers who believe the country has become a police state or is so lowdown mean and dirty, so weakened in soul and ethic, that you can't tell it from the Soviet Union.
WARNING: What follows is extremely sentimental about the U.S., very God Bless America. So don't read further. It will make you sick.
On Friday I went down to Battery Park in New York to watch a naturalization ceremony.
There were flags, a snappy small band, a police honor guard, the oath of allegiance with hands over heart, ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' belted out. It was held outdoors and, get this, you could see the Statue of Liberty. The new citizens wanted their pictures taken with her in the background.
Wait, it gets worse - some of them cried.
Thirty countries of birth were represented, 66 people in all - 34 from the Caribbean, 10 from Asia, 12 from Central and South America, 3 Africans and 7 Europeans.
Chief Judge Charles L. Brieant Jr. of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, whose grandfather was a bone-poor immigrant from England and who has the best handlebar mustache in the entire Federal judiciary, had all 66 swear to renounce foreign potentates and bear arms for this country if needed.
A young man in Army uniform nodded as he held up his hand and so did a Caribbean woman who was 70 if she was a day. The judge and Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks Commissioner -the Battery is part of her domain -made short, sensible speeches.
The judge said nobody had to tell the new Americans the meaning of America - they chose this country and then chose to work to take the ceremony of belonging. The Commissioner said if the new Americans ever needed information about the parks, just call her.
I don't know what was in the minds of the people at the Battery or the other 250,000 people who become Americans every year. I only know what was in my own mind decades ago when I swore that Canada's potentate would have to get along without me.
It was that in the United States you become a member of the national society the moment you take the oath and forever are so considered and name yourself: American.
I could live in almost any other country the rest of my life after taking its citizenship and never be thought of as an Englishman, an Italian, a Frenchman. That difference is important to me.
Before they left Battery Park, 66 men and women carefully put away their naturalization certificates and their small gift flags from the Daughters of the American Revolution to keep forever.
Then strangers from different parts of the world kissed; suddenly they had something dear in common.
I thought of mentioning that piece about the United States being widely regarded as no different than the Soviet Union when it came to championing democracy and asking some of the new Americans what they thought about that.
But I was afraid they would think I was some kind of a klutz.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Bush's Campaign Pledge of No New Taxes: Misleading or Naive?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Walter F. Mondale urges us to give President Bush credit for realizing the United States needs revenue increases and to applaud his courage in stating the obvious (Op-Ed, July 3). The former Vice President is off the mark. In the game of hardball politics this response is what the Administration sought. That it should come from a former standard bearer of the opposition is a coup for the Administration. More important, it is a disgrace to the Democratic Party and a disservice to the working men and women of this country. 
Who does not realize the seriousness of the budget deficit? One does not applaud as courageous an attempt, finally, to fix the deficit created in a decade of cavalier irresponsibility by Reagan-Bush Administrations. The President claimed in his speech that he now understands the seriousness of the deficit and the savings and loan crisis. That crisis was precipitated by a policy and fundamental philosophy marking the last 10 years of deregulation. It was perpetrated by wealthy members of our society, who have benefited in so many ways from the changes in the 1980's. What occurred should come as no surprise.
What should be surprising is the President's desire to rectify this financial scandal by taxing the middle class precisely to the exclusion of the well off.
Candidate George Bush promised America no new taxes. Was he (1) engaging in misleading the public, or (2) so fundamentally naive about national economic problems as not to see the tough decisions he would be required to make as President?
Whether misleading or ignorant, his mocking intransigence did a disservice to the discourse and issues of the 1988 campaign - rhetoric from which we have yet to recover. For this we should give him credit and applaud his courage? I think not, Mr. Mondale.
 
MICHAEL A. JOGERST
 Iowa City, July 3, 1990
 
The writer is a professor of political science at the University of Iowa.

LENGTH: 579 words

HEADLINE: College Students, at Least, Aren't Apathetic

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A June 28 front-page article characterizes young people 18 to 29 years old as ''indifferent toward public affairs'' and current events, and you quote a Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press study that states they are a group that ''knows less, cares less, votes less and is less critical of its leaders and institutions than young people in the past.''
Our research among college students nationwide since March 1988 leads to a different conclusion -there are among 18-to 29-year-olds a crucial core group of students that does care, does vote and is aware and critical of the world around them. College students have strong opinions about the major issues facing the country and are active consumers of major news media, from newspapers and news weeklies to television news. A summary of key findings:
* Three-quarters of undergraduates are registered to vote, and 83 percent of those voted in the 1988 Presidential election. Both rates are far higher than those for their non-college peers or adults as a whole. 
* College students are critical of our national leadership. More students approve of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's performance (81 percent) than President Bush's (63 percent) or Vice President Dan Quayle's (40 percent).
* Students are especially critical of the business community's environmental efforts. Asked to rate the business community on a 10-point scale for protecting the environment, students gave business a grade of less than 4. Only 7 percent of undergraduates gave it a rating of 7 or higher.
* By a 5-to-1 margin, students rank the overall quality of Japanese products over those of the United States; there was even a slight preference for the quality of products from West Germany. By better than 2-to-1 students rank the Japanese economy over the United States as the strongest in the world.
* In our news media studies, Newsweek and Time are consistently the leading publications read by students and news is among the top five television programs they report watching. Eighty percent read their local newspaper at least weekly and more than a quarter read it five or more times a week. More than 90 percent read their campus newspaper.
* Sixty percent indicate that they have become more politically aware since coming to college. A similar number indicated their political views had shifted since coming to college.
* Asked if they were likely to be involved in political organizations or activities after college, about half answered that they would.
* More than 90 percent of students favor a woman's right to choose abortion; 63 percent favor elimination of investments in South Africa; 89 percent favor stronger protection for the environment, even if prices or taxes rise as a result, 80 percent favor Government assistance to provide day care for working families; 80 percent favor prosecution of drug users, and 78 percent indicate that they do not believe that equal opportunity exists for all Americans.
We do not share the view that this is an ''indifferent generation.'' What's more, all people 18 to 29 cannot be lumped into one uniform group. While we cannot speak for the noncollege population, we can point to three years of studies on campuses across the country that this is a vibrant, opinionated, active group. They'll be heard from.
 
STUART HIMMELFARB
 New York, July 9, 1990
 
The writer is president of CollegeTrack, a market research and consulting company.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 629 words

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Mr. Bush and America's Greens

 BODY:
President Bush's next summit meeting might well be a cozy little chat in the Oval Office with a handful of environmental leaders. There's much common ground between them. But one would never know that from the poisonous and sometimes silly rhetoric that filled the air during last week's economic summit meeting in Houston.
Environmentalists from seven nations descended on Texas like boll weevils to monitor their governments' actions. The Americans, in particular, had reason to be supremely disappointed at Mr. Bush's reluctance to embrace even a modest strategy for limiting emissions of carbon dioxide that could cause a catastrophic warming of the earth's climate. 
But they had no reason to engage in the hyperbole attributed to Jay Hair, the moderate president of the National Wildlife Federation. ''Bush's efforts at balance, compromise and consensus building,'' he cried, ''are killing the world.'' Not to be outdone in the bombast sweepstakes, the ever-competitive Mr. Bush retorted that he wasn't out to win ''brownie points'' with environmentalists. Nor would he be swayed by ''extremists,'' or seduced by ''radical positions'' that would ''throw a lot of American men and women out of jobs.''
The childishness of all this is self-evident. It's hard to imagine President Bush waking up and saying, ''Barbara, let's go out and mess up the earth today''; equally hard to imagine Mr. Hair gleefully calculating the number of families he could impoverish by saving the spotted owl.
What makes this backbiting dangerous is that it blocks serious discussion of very complex questions. Environmental issues are never easy; their solution is rarely cost-free. They require hard choices between environmental protections the voters obviously want and the economic growth many Americans are loath to abandon. And that requires a maximum of care and a minimum of cant. Mr. Bush has shown himself capable of both. His clean air bill, though greatly improved by the environmentalists, was patiently conceived.
His recent decision to ban coastal drilling, taken after long study, was a sensible bow to the environmentalists who argued that the oil was not worth the risk. It was also a good example of the ''balance, compromise and consensus building'' that Mr. Hair finds so distasteful.
Conversely, given an opportunity to strike a balance between jobs and nature in the spotted owl controversy, Mr. Bush responded with pained indifference, threatening to change the endangered species law that had dumped the problem on his desk in the first place.
His vision on global warming seems even more cramped. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany asked the President to cut harmful emissions by 25 percent over the next 15 years. John Sununu, the White House chief of staff, screamed that any such plan would threaten America's sovereignty and plunge it into depression. This ignored the findings of tough-minded economists like Yale's William D. Nordhaus, who argues in the latest Economist that a 20 percent cut can be achieved at very little cost to annual economic growth.
Even so, with Mr. Bush in the White House, America's greens at least have somebody to work with. That's more than they had before. Between 1980 and 1988 the White House was occupied by a man who wanted to drill everywhere, thought that acid rain was a figment of some crazed Canadian's imagination and blamed ''killer trees'' for global warming.
The time ought to be ripe for sensible debate on the competing demands of the environment and energy. While perpetual dissatisfaction is the natural state of any self-respecting environmentalist, caterwauling doesn't help. Neither does a petulant President who keeps threatening to pick up his bat and ball and go home.
ROBERT B. SEMPLE Jr.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Houston Scorecard

 BODY:
When the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations met last week in Houston, the three main issues of contention were trade policy, aid to the Soviet Union and the environment. Here, by David E. Rosenbaum, a New York Times correspondent who covered the Houston event, is a look at the issues, what the summit meeting produced and the outlook.
 
Trade
 
The issue: International trade liberalization talks are deadlocked over farm subsidies. The summit partners all subsidize their farmers, resulting in severely distorted world prices. Government support in Europe and Japan, however, is much more extensive than it is in the United States. President Bush asserts that unless the supports are reduced, developing nations with little to sell but their farm products will walk out of the trade talks. But the Europeans are especially reluctant to act. 
 
The summit decision: The final communique included ambiguous language that allowed all sides to claim victory. For the United States, it pledged specific attention to reduction of export supports. For the Europeans, it recognized that ''social and economic conditions'' must be reflected in farm policy. For the Japanese, it implicitly recognized that their prohibition of rice imports is considered a matter of national security. But more important than the words, the summit may have provided the political impetus to get the trade negotiators talking again.
 
The next step: When trade negotiators resume, some agreement will probably be reached on lowering farm subsidies. But it is too early to tell whether it will satisfy the developing countries.
 
Soviet Aid
 
The issue: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has pledged more than $3 billion in credits to the Soviet Union and with the support of President Francois Mitterrand of France is pushing for a $15 billion aid package from the industrial countries. The United States and others oppose direct aid but are prepared to offer technical assistance. They maintain that the money will be wasted in the absence of a free-market economy. Furthermore, Mr. Bush argues that he cannot provide money to the Soviet Union so long as that country spends vast sums on its military and supports Cuba.
 
The summit decision: The leaders encouraged the steps being taken toward a free-market economy, and agreed that individual countries were free to support the Soviets directly. They agreed to a study of Soviet economic needs by international organizations.
 
The next step: After the meeting Mr. Bush said, ''I think Mr. Gorbachev understands that at this juncture, sending money from the United States is not in the cards.'' But Mr. Kohl, maintaining that the ''necessary steps'' are being taken, said, ''If this continues by the end of the year, we should be able to achieve a joint Western economic assistance program.''
 
The Environment
 
The issue: Chancellor Kohl, with the support of the other leaders except for Mr. Bush, proposed a specific timetable for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that some scientists believe contribute to global warming. Mr. Bush insisted that scientific data on climate change were inconclusive. He held that reduction of greenhouse gases could damage the economy in the United States and other countries and that action should not be taken without further evidence.
 
The summit decision: Mr. Bush prevailed in that no timetable was set. But the communique declared that the countries were ''committed to undertake common efforts to limit emissions of greenhouse gases'' and that ''lack of full scientific certainty is no excuse to postpone actions which are justified in their own right.'' The leaders also agreed, with Mr. Bush's support, to develop a pilot program to help Brazil preserve its tropical rain forest.
 
The next step: Mr. Bush is likely to face considerable pressure to relent on the global warming issue not only from his summit partners but also from environmental groups at home. International studies of the matter are under way, and more discussions will be held at a conference in Geneva in November.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
IN HAITI, THUGGERY IS EASIER ALL THE TIME

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
With the return from exile last week of two figures associated with political violence and torture, one pessimistic notion seemed to resound clearly through the thick atmosphere of Port-au-Prince. For many, the return of Roger Lafontant, the former head of the Tontons Macoute, and Williams Regala, a top army officer under Jean-Claude Duvalier and successor dictatorships, showed how little ground has been gained in the four years since Mr. Duvalier was routed in a street revolution.
Now, after only four months in office, Haiti's fifth interim Government since 1986 is listing badly, and infighting among civilian politicians is increasing. Again the country is flirting with violence and chaos nurtured by groups - often tied to drug trafficking or other forms of illegality - that are loyal to former barons of the Duvalier system and bent on derailing democratic change. 
Many criminal enterprises got started under Jean-Claude Duvalier, whose tolerance for independent illegal activities was notoriously high, as long as they didn't interfere with his family's own acquisitive habits; since his departure, the hold of these groups has only grown stronger in the absence of a stable central government.
After five years in which each government has seemed less in control than the last, many Haitians realize that popular movements and international sanctions have failed to curb the chilling determination of these groups to preserve their interests at all costs. ''With each crisis the situation has only gotten worse, with all of these groups, not just the Tontons Macoute, but the drug smugglers and the contraband traffickers, even traffickers in people, gaining ever more of a hold on the system,'' said Anthony P. Maingot, a Caribbean affairs expert at Florida International University in Miami. ''These are criminal enterprises that are threatened by change and they are not going to allow real elections.''
Mr. Maingot and others have said meaningful elections in Haiti are possible, but only if the democratic sector could somehow unite long enough to sweep the civil service clean of corrupt Duvalierists and reform or eliminate the armed forces - which now are in near-chaos themselves. But Haiti's opposition forces are anything but unified. They range from veterans of the dictatorship who now profess democracy to excitable nationalists, including members of the Haitian clergy, who call for a revolution. They give the impression of an assortment of often impressive but headstrong individuals, each pulling mightily in his own direction.
 
Disunity and Distrust
 ''What these people don't seem to realize is that if they really unify themselves, they could defeat what is left of the army and the Tontons Macoute and break the back of the kleptomaniac state,'' said Larman C. Wilson, a specialist in Caribbean affairs at American University in Washington. ''They are unwilling to set aside differences before an election and fight it out later. They fight things out beforehand and end up being torn apart.''
Others say Haiti must invite a multinational force to temporarily take over governance and insure security during elections. But few politicians are likely to publicly support such a step. Distrust of Washington, which was involved to varying degrees in all of the frustrated efforts to advance democracy here, is high, and Haitians have a historic suspicion of foreign intervention.
One angry Haitian businessman, who spoke on the condition he not be identified, declared, ''We have the impression the United States is against us; the Government, the press, the C.I.A., all are working together to keep Haiti cordoned off, to make the world as unsympathetic as possible to us, even to prevent any sense of solidarity with black Americans from developing.'' Such feelings are reinforced by memories of American aid to Jean-Claude Duvalier and by Washington's failure to heed signs that the first post-Duvalier dictator, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, harbored no democratic intentions. The latest American ambassador here, Alvin P. Adams, quickly earned high marks from many Haitians with his personal diplomacy, his knowledge of Creole, and, shortly after arriving last November, his role in easing Gen. Prosper Avril out of power. On his arrival, Mr. Adams used a Creole proverb - ''a heavily laden donkey must move forward'' - to suggest that the country must proceed to elections. This earned him a complimentary sobriquet, bourik chage, or loaded donkey. Recently, however, with Haiti's political future as clouded as ever, many references to him have been shortened to donkey.
Still, the ambassador's most potent weapon for change remains the assertion that without democracy, Haiti will remain cut off from the rest of the hemisphere and from the economic aid it has been denied since 1987. ''We're a cheap shot, everyone can have a go at us,'' Mr. Adams said during a recent interview. ''But the point that has to be made is that he who interferes with the electoral process will have a price to pay.''

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: Giant Steps;
Germany Makes the Most of Its Newfound Power

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
There is no doubt in anyone's mind in London, Paris or Bonn that the Western leader who dominates the international agenda these days is not Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain or President Bush of the United States, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.
Part of the reason is that German economic and political strength is beginning to overshadow Europe the way Soviet military strength did for 45 years. Now Soviet weakness has reduced the leverage the United States had during the years of Soviet menace. The result is a net flow of political power and self-confidence to Mr. Kohl, an enormous man who is positively bursting with pride these days and flew off confidently to Moscow yesterday for another heart-to-heart talk with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about German unification. 
An extraordinary series of summit meetings - the European Community, then the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and finally the Group of Seven industrial democracies in Houston last week - has seen his partners, including the United States, content to let Mr. Kohl set the agenda, and to provide the backing he demanded for German reunification on his terms. Now, with the Group of Seven acquiescing in West German plans to offer the Soviet Union hefty sums of real money (marks, not dollars) to ease the loss of Moscow's strategic position in East Germany, Mr. Kohl will be getting to know Mr. Gorbachev better in Moscow and Stavropol today and tomorrow. He is prepared to talk about everything from future German-Soviet trade to limits on the size of Germany's armed forces, in order to make its NATO membership more acceptable to Moscow.
Despite the heartfelt professions of good will and the camaraderie, there are bitter memories and not a little resentment about the new German strength, not only in the Soviet Union but in most of Western Europe.
In Germany as well, there is profound ambivalence about the new German role, and much criticism of Mr. Kohl for having gone too fast and too far. German flags waved after West Germany won the World Cup in soccer last Sunday, but there was no national wave of triumphalism. Instead, by the end of the week, many Germans were anguishing about why a British Government minister who is one of Prime Minister Thatcher's closest and oldest friends, Nicholas Ridley, had compared German domination of Europe today with Hitler's conquests earlier; the only comfort for the Germans lay in the fact that most British politicians felt obliged to apologize rather than agree with Mr. Ridley. Germany may be powerful, but it is still insecure.
 
Taking Charge
 Nevertheless, Mr. Kohl has taken charge of unification and the associated issues with dizzying speed, in just six months. For 45 years, the United States, Britain and France saw questions like the size of a postwar Germany's army, Allied occupation rights, and both their own and Germany's relationship with the Soviet Union as vital national interests, not to be left to the Germans to decide. Now a lot of that is changing.
 
One reason is that the United
States decided, a year ago last May, that if there was to be a special American relationship with any European leader these days, it should be with the one who had the most clout - Mr. Kohl - not the increasingly insular and out of touch Mrs. Thatcher. The issue then was a new system of short-range American nuclear missiles to replace the Lance rockets stationed in West Germany.
Mr. Kohl didn't want them, Mrs. Thatcher wanted him to take them, and Mr. Bush took her breath away by suddenly coming down on the side of the Germans.
She hasn't been the same since, partly because the past year has been one of deep trouble for her Conservative Party in British public opinion polls. Personal pique about Mr. Bush's backing for Mr. Kohl's positions played a part, too; Mrs. Thatcher notoriously cannot abide Mr. Kohl's girth, manner or fondness for such un-Thatcherite terms as ''social partnership'' to describe the relations between labor and management. But when the Chancellor went to London in April and again for the NATO summit this month, she put on her nicest smile and agreed to let him have his way, more or less, on having the European Community draw up a road map to European economic and monetary union, and an economic aid plan for the Soviet Union. At Houston, the United States, Britain and Japan decided to let the Germans go ahead with financial aid for Soviet economic reform, even while declining to provide aid themselves.
Today and tomorrow, Mr. Kohl will try to convince the beleaguered Mr. Gorbachev that a united Germany can help the Soviet Union stave off economic collapse, and that the $2.9 billion in credit guarantees and the $736 million in payments for Soviet occupation costs that Bonn has already agreed to provide this year are only the tip of the iceberg. A united Germany will need vast amounts of Soviet oil and gas - and will pay in marks -to replace East Germany's dependence on Soviet-designed nuclear power plants and sulfurous soft coal for electricity, Mr. Kohl's entourage in Houston suggested.
 
A Green Light
 The Chancellor also got the green light at the NATO summit in London to offer Mr. Gorbachev a ceiling on a united Germany's armed forces - probably considerably lower than 400,000 troops, according to Western diplomats here, less than the current West German level.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d seems to have made a calculation some time before the East-West meeting in Ottawa last February that Mr. Kohl was on the right side of history. ''Between Christmas and Ottawa, it became clear that this thing was going to happen, much faster than anyone had realized, because East Germans were emigrating at the rate of 2,000 a week and demanding unity on the streets in Leipzig,'' a Western diplomat said, ''and there was a Bush-Baker calculation about the importance of Germany in Europe and the importance of Kohl being re-elected as Chancellor.'' Mr. Kohl stands a fair chance of being elected as the first postwar Chancellor of a united Germany in the national election next Dec. 2, though his Social Democratic opponent, Oskar Lafontaine, has made it clear it will be a bitter fight. American policy in previous West German elections has been neutrality, but Mr. Kohl seems to have little doubt about whom George Bush would prefer in this one. In London this month, Mr. Kohl was effusive about American support for his policies and expressed the view that Mr. Bush's incumbency was something like an act of Divine Providence for the Germans in their hour of fulfillment. The French and the British are not so effusive, though President Francois Mitterrand has stood cheek by jowl with Mr. Kohl and kept to himself the reservations he and many of the French are known to have about the rush to unification by the end of 1990.
The true British feeling may be imagined from unusually explosive remarks by Mr. Ridley, which were published in The Spectator in London this week. They were not defused one bit when Mr. Ridley said he regretted and unreservedly withdrew the remarks. ''This is all a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe,'' he said of the push for European economic union. ''This rushed take-over by the Germans on the worst possible basis, with the French behaving like poodles to the Germans, is absolutely intolerable.''
One bemused diplomat noted that if Mrs. Thatcher had managed to keep out of the doghouse after a bad start with Mr. Kohl earlier this year, by finally going along with quick unification in the spring, Mr. Ridley's remarks would probably put her back in. That the British worry at all about what the Germans think of them these days speaks volumes about the change in thinking that the prospect of German unity is bringing all over Europe.

HEADLINE: On the Road, Again

BYLINE: By Noha Applebaum; Noha Applebaum teaches professional writing at Harvard University.<

 BODY:
A recent Midwestern drive presented more than expected sights like the Gateway Arch, Sears Tower and Blue Water Bridge. The roads between scheduled stops revealed a four-decade evolution in American motoring. The Interstate highways enter the 1990's, like many of us who travel them, pushing middle age. Twenty-five years of growth pains have yielded to a steady state, with some key roads already graying. The mature highways are more predictable but less adventurous.
In contrast, my travels began as a child in the 1950's by watching thousands of miles of intimate two-lane U.S. roads whiz past the backseat of Dad's emerald Olds Super Rocket 88. My family crossed the country by four routes that touched 46 states by 1956, when President Dwight D. Eisenhower signed the Interstate Highway Act and I was 10.
My 20's overlapped the Johnson and Nixon presidencies, mainly heady years of cheap gas and fast travel over the rapidly expanding interstate network. Until 1974, when oil embargoes made us crawl, 70 miles an hour was the norm, with speeds reaching front-end rattling legal highs of 80 on roads like the Ohio Turnpike. In 1979, with the interstates practically complete, my wife Beth and I defied President Carter's ''fuel allocation'' during a two-month, 10,000-mile jaunt rediscovering surviving older routes. 
Ten years and two children later brought my domestic travels full circle last summer. Now the father, I drove a 3,000-mile circuit from Boston to St. Louis to see how families experience America's highways in the early Bush years.
Some things never change. Seen through the windshield, Illinois remains a blur of corn and soybeans topped by a brawny city the quintessence of America. Flat fields lining I-55 (once fabled Route 66) are measured still by earthy truck stops like the Phillips 66 an hour south of Chicago. Their loudspeakers blasted country radio USA 99 while the cashier produced the first Gold Bond stamps I'd seen in decades.
But digital technology colors travel today. In the 50's, we relied on cash; in the 60's, traveler's checks. Now, it's computers. The card that springs fresh 20's from my neighborhood bank also taps 23,000 A.T.M.'s in 4,800 North American cities. I felt slightly criminal while first typing my code in the Super Duper Market in Batavia, N.Y. Only robbers once boldly entered stores in alien towns to demand cash. But when the machine paid out $300, traveler's checks instantly became as archaic as slide rules.
Other technologies have improved our comfort in the car. Before Air Conditioners (B.A.C.), we cooled by ice and water, even for desert crossings. A few cubes rolled in a wet towel provided a cold, if dripping, pack to wrap around the neck. With the car's windows open wide, 60 m.p.h. winds produced true air conditioning. Ice water was so vital B.A.C. that Stuckey's roadside empire and South Dakota's legendary Wall Drugs sprung up oasis-like around it. Now compressors cool hot heads.
And sealed windows let us hear hi-fi casettes. Well-timed blasts of ''Sesame Street'' faded to the backseat mercifully soothed a restless 3-year-old Teddy. But we sadly neglected the radio's 50,000-watt beacons of Middle America and transient snippets of otherwise covert culture still receivable by twisting the knob far right on the AM tuner or to the left on FM.
Our hermetically-sealed, temperature-controlled, musically programmed car fostered more insidious dangers. I attributed my own ennui near Syracuse to over-familiarity with I-90 until I noticed Rachel had buried her head in a book in the back seat. Although any parent of a 9-year-old welcomes reading, I thought it decidedly uneducational for her to ignore new sights.
Then I suddenly realized the paucity of adventure in a backseat view of the interstate highway. Even a twice-read Nancy Drew held more mystery than this kind of travel. At that epiphany, we exited the interstate, flung open the windows, ejected the tape and sat Rachel up front. After a dose of Route 20, her face lit up. She smelled fields fresh from a shower, saw horses up close, felt the pull of the twisting road and thrilled as rolling hills unwound before the windshield.
Interstates can't compete with these esthetics. Their design, in fact, obscures even natural wonders. As we neared St. Louis, I piqued Rae's interest with a tale of my awesome first Mississippi River crossing. Swollen by floods, its waters seemed a mile wide in May 1956. But strain all she could, my daughter saw not one muddy drop under the broad concrete bridge designated I-70, I-55 and U.S. 40. Like magicians, the engineers had made the mighty Mississippi disappear.
Speed remains the prime virtue of superhighways. During the Reagan Administration, states west of New York and Pennsylvania legally liberated throttles to 65, nearly matching the 1960's pace. Better still, today's drivers rarely need to detour around unfinished stretches.
But as the interstates have reached full growth, some roads show early decay. Question: What was 80 the day it was born, is still less than 20 years old, but seems prematurely middle aged? Answer: I-80 as a route across Pennsylvania. Heeding warnings, we rerouted around it.
Would we had skipped other graying interstates. Reconstruction of I-55 south of Chicago funnelled miles of traffic to one lane of stop-and-go frustration with no way to pass. Such tedium makes some interstates slower than the routes they superceded. The most primitive old highways required waits for honest junctions, crossings by seemingly endless freight trains and, however rarely, even flocks of sheep. But when stuck behind a timid driver or heavy truck, the 1950's motorist could often pass through the lane of oncoming traffic.
Bottlenecks from current reconstruction underscore the practical as well as esthetic wisdom of preserving, not replacing, historic highways as escape routes. Besides, some roads have aged gracefully. The granddaddy of Eastern superhighways, the Pennsylvania Turnpike, not only predates I-80; it could outlive it.
Even old routes show a new style of roadside service. Across America, the hegemony of Howard Johnson's has yielded to a seeming Babel of competition. But the plethora of new logos only masks one standard fast-food menu, ethos and mountain of packaging. Still, any alternative is easily tastier, cheaper and faster than was HoJo's in its dotage. And to save even more time, travelers can now theoretically buy every breakfast, lunch and dinner at a drive-through without once leaving their car to meet an embodied, unamplified human voice.
Motel chains offer a like uniform impersonality in lodging. Without reading their signs, who could tell if we slept in a Regal 8, Motel 6 or Econolodge? Many chains offer swimming pools, and all provide ''free'' color TV. Still, I'd return to the days when we fed motel TV's with silver quarters if those coins would also awaken the bed's ''magic fingers'' massage machine.
Chains for food and rooms often link. I have seen the future, and its name is Breezewood, Pa., also known as the Town of Motels, Turnpike Exit 12, a community of countless gas stations, restaurants and motels assembled in a grotesque commercial parody of an American village.
Authentic local color gets ever harder to find. On the last day of our drive, we resolved to break the chain-food habit. Leaving I-80 for U.S. 46, I spied an old-fashioned New Jersey diner in Little Ferry. Visions of coconut custard pie danced in my head at the sight of this architectural gem complete with 1940's Art-Deco stainless steel and neon. Inside, my eyes panned from the round corner booth, past the long row of red spinning stools. It looked good.
Too good. Above the formica counter where a sign should have announced the blue-plate special, hung instead the joint's own T-shirts. They proclaimed that we had wandered into Rosie's Diner, a location for filming TV ads that was sold earlier this year. Framed autographed stills from paper-towel commercials lined the chrome walls above postcards touting ''the most famous diner in the world.'' Leaving the interstate had brought us no closer to genuine discovery. Madison Avenue had gotten there first.
