HEADLINE: Practical Traveler;
Getting Cash Abroad: Bank Cards Make It Easy

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
When my family and I first traveled to England in 1965, we carried an engraved-letterhead note from our bank in New York that would have done credit to Edith Wharton. It introduced us to a bank in the City of London that would cash one of our New York checks, in case we ran through our $10 ''tip pack'' of British currency and our traveler's checks. It all seems so Victorian now; the methods of getting money overseas are modernizing rapidly. In the latest wrinkle, the electronic cash machine, with the help of satellite technology, is following its users overseas.
The entree is a cash card linked to either of two international networks, Cirrus or Plus. These networks are putting their labels and decals onto overseas automatic teller machines (A.T.M.'s) almost as fast as they can stick them down. Both networks are already strong in Canada and Mexico, the two favorite destinations of United States travelers, but the systems have carved out markets elsewhere: Plus is strong in England and has no presence in France; Cirrus is strong in France but in the first week in July had no machines in England. 
How do the systems work? You use the same bank card that you use at home, punching in your numerical identification. The message transmitted by your card and the data you enter are relayed by satellite to the United States and back while you stand at the machine. If there is money for you to withdraw, you get it. You request the amount you want in the currency of the country: so many pesos, francs or pounds. Both Plus and Cirrus say the conversion rate is the one in effect at the time of the transaction, and may be different the next day. This rate is described as a ''wholesale'' rate.
One big catch is that you do not know what the rate is until you get home and see from your bank statement what your money cost in dollars. Both organizations, however, are unequivocal that their network rates are better than the rates that people who walk into banks would get, because they are bank-to-bank rates. A colleague verified this in London on July 3. The rate at Plus machines was 100 for $176.60; at the Midland Bank it was $189 if cash was used, $183 if travelers checks were used. Your bank at home may, however, charge you an A.T.M. transaction fee of 25 cents to $2.50 but you should have found out about this in advance.
The cash card is not a credit card, and it is issued only by a bank where you maintain an account. You are not charged interest for the transaction, which is not the case when you use a credit card for a cash advance. Your bank card may also enable you to get a cash advance on your credit card, or your credit card may allow you to get money from your bank account, but this must be established with the bank before you leave, and you must have a personal identification number to punch in.
The back of the card displays logotypes for the networks through which you can get access to your own money, for instance NYCE, M, MAC, Pulse or Yankee 24, as well as Cirrus and Plus, the two systems now operating overseas.
Plus, which was created in 1982, went overseas in 1986 with 100 machines in Japan. This June it had machines in 11 countries or islands outside the United States. Cirrus, also founded in 1982, began to appear overseas in January. In June it had machines in five foreign countries.
Banks usually provide booklets listing the locations of the A.T.M.'s you can use in the United States and elsewhere. If your experience is like mine, you need to ask the bank for it. According to Cirrus, many member banks are still ordering only a few booklets. But you need them overseas, because finding a machine in a country with only 200 is a lot harder than finding one at a restaurant on I-95. Be sure the book you take is recent, because growth is giddying.
Cirrus publishes its booklet three times a year; the most recent edition is dated May 1990, and another is due in October, according to Kim Ross, a spokeswoman for the organization. The May directory lists 35,000 machines in 6,000 cities, mostly in the United States and Canada, with 800 locations in France, 500 in Mexico, 14 in Japan and 30 in Chile. According to Ms. Ross, Cirrus is expanding by 3,000 to 4,000 machines this summer, mainly in Europe: England, Scotland, Italy, Belgium and Spain.
Plus publishes its book twice a year. The most recent, also dated May, listed 33,000 machines, once again mostly in the United States and Canada. Elsewhere, it lists 1,340 in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, 200 in Mexico, 200 in Hong Kong, 160 in Puerto Rico, 113 in Japan, 50 in Australia, 25 in Singapore and a few in the Virgin Islands, Bermuda and Guam. Machines in Colombia and Ecuador are being tested, Eric Goldman, a spokesman, said. Growth in Continental Europe is a goal for the mid-90's, Mr. Goldman said. Transaction Fees If you plan to use a cash card overseas, it is worthwhile to ask your bank about its transaction fees. Before he went to England early this year, Spartacus Bernstein of Brooklyn opened a savings account at Chase Manhattan specifically to get a Plus card, which he used frequently. Chase did not charge him a fee or commission on any of his withdrawals, he says. But Ms. Ross of Cirrus reports that overseas use of that card is so new that officials at the network do not have information on whether overseas fees are being levied by banks that do not charge fees for domestic use of the card. ''It's a case where the consumer can bargain,'' Gerri E. Detweiler, the education coordinater of the BankCard Holders of America, a consumer group, said in recommending shopping around. ''If you want to do it, talk to banks and find out what you can get.''
As with credit cards, Ms. Detweiler pointed out, there is no requirement that notice of a transaction fee be posted on the machine, so unless you know before you go, you may be surprised. The Plus and Cirrus networks are financed by payments from participating banks, so the question for the consumer is whether the cost is being passed along or absorbed by the bank. It is more likely to be absorbed by the bank when you maintain a minimum balance - savings account, regular checking, securities or whatever.
Ms. Detweiler gave an urgent warning about keeping cash cards or credit cards safe: Do not write your personal identification number on any document that you carry with the card, even if you disguise it. And if you have picked your own number and have selected an ''easy'' one, like your birthdate or your license plate or phone number, you should probably start over again with a random number and then memorize it.
BankCard Holders of America publishes a leaflet, ''Traveling With Your Credit Card,'' that reviews basics such as credit limits, exchange rates and steps to make sure your bill does not go unpaid while you are gone. It is free to members but is available to nonmembers for $1 from the association, 560 Herndon Parkway, Suite 120, Herndon, Va. 22070. Overseas Restrictions Another limitation on getting cash overseas was encountered by Mignonne B. Bouvier of Portland, Me. While in France this spring Ms. Bouvier was carrying American Express travelers checks and at two branches of the bank Credit Lyonnais she was unable to cash them and was not told why. ''I am bilingual; therefore it was not a question of misinterpretation,'' she wrote. She asked if the bank had a new policy and if so, why no notice was posted to prevent Americans from standing in line a long time to no purpose.
According to Marie Laure Meunier, at the bank's headquarters in Paris, only branches of Credit Lyonnais that have a foreign-exchange window can cash travelers checks in another currency. The two branches she went to, in Lourdes and on Place Victor Hugo in Paris, did not. However, Ms. Meunier said, had Ms. Bouvier been carrying Visa travelers checks in dollars, she could have cashed them because the bank has an agreement with Visa providing for this.
Most bank branches in Paris do exchanges and are able to cash travelers checks, according to three big banks, B.N.P., Societe Generale and Credit du Nord. But look for a sign for foreign exchange before you get in line.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

China Introduces Round-Trip Air Ticketing BEIJING
To make independent air travel more predictable, China's national airline has begun to issue round-trip tickets and to accept round-trip reservations. As of July 1, air travelers have been able to reserve and purchase round-trip tickets to 16 large cities, including most major tourist destinations. Round-trip tickets to smaller cities in China apparently will not be available.
The policy change helps resolve one of the greatest frustrations for independent travelers in China: the risk of flying somewhere and not being able to come back, because it was possible to reserve or purchase only one-way tickets. The first order of business upon landing somewhere was often to dash for the airline office and make a reservation for the return trip. Sometimes, it turned out there was no seat out for a week or two. Planning with any certainty was impossible. 
Tour groups have been immune from this problem, and they will continue to be able to have confirmed round-trip tickets to all destinations.
The Chinese cities for which round-trip tickets are now offered are Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Dalian, Canton, Xiamen, Nanjing, Wuhan, Guilin, Xian, Chengdu, Shenyang, Harbin, Changchun, Haikou and Shantou.
It is not clear how smoothly the new policy will be implemented, nor whether round-trip tickets will be offered only on the national carrier, Air China, or also on the regional airlines that have been established in recent years.
Buyers may need to be persuasive. A reporter who tried to book a seat from Beijing to Shanghai and back again - with the outward journey on Air China and the return on China Eastern Airlines - was initially told that round-trip tickets were possible only when the entire journey was on Air China. But after a bout of pleading, the clerk produced the round-trip ticket as requested, with the return on the regional airline. Air China employees in New York and San Francisco said they would sell tickets for domestic flights in China only if flights between the United States and China were made on Air China.
Even though foreigners pay higher prices than local Chinese, air fares are still very inexpensive. On the one-hour 45-minute trip between Beijing and Shanghai, for example, the fare for foreigners each way is just $80 economy and $104 first class. Round-trip tickets are simply double the one-way fare. NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF
 
Icebreaker To North Pole
Breaking the ice will not be metaphor but reality this summer when passengers from the West will be allowed to board the Soviet atomic icebreaker Rossia for a summer trip to the North Pole. The voyage, for $24,500 a person, is scheduled for July 30 to Aug. 15, departing from the northwestern Soviet city of Murmansk. The Rossia, about 500 feet long, can travel through ice up to eight-feet thick, though in the summer, most ice should already be broken up, according to Mountain Travel of El Cerrito, Calif., which is selling spaces on the ship.
The Rossia will have two helicopters on board that will allow visits to such remote spots as Novaya Zemlya and Franz Josef Land, archipelagos in the Arctic Ocean. A featured speaker of the voyage will be Peter Wilkniss, director of polar programs for the National Science Foundation in Washington. The ship has a pool, sports center, theater and a Swiss-Italian chef.
Information: Mountain Travel, 6420 Fairmount Avenue, El Cerrito, Calif. 94530; 800-227-2384.
 
Corporate Car Coverage Cut
American Express has dropped collision-damage coverage it provided on cars rented with some of its corporate green cards. The coverage is still offered on rentals with the personal green card and all the company's premium cards. The coverage was withdrawn March 31 for companies that had more than 10 corporate cards, an American Express spokeswoman said, because larger companies already insure their employees who rent cars.
American Express began offering collision damage coverage with its gold and platinum cards in November 1987 and with green cards in January 1989. The company said it had no plans to drop the coverage that it provides on rentals with its personal cards when the rental company's collision damage waiver is refused by the renter.
 
A Potpourri of Tours
FRANCE. ''In the Footsteps of Eleanor of Aquitaine'' is an escorted tour to the Loire Valley and Paris, Sept. 21 to Oct. 7, sponsored by the Colonial Dames of America as its centennial celebration. The program has been arranged by Eileen Hughes Travel, 411 East 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-758-1505. Bordeaux, Poitiers and Chambord are among the stops, to visit abbeys and other sites associated with Eleanor and with Joan of Arc and Catherine de Medici. The cost per person, double occupancy, is $5,575 plus about $890 for round-trip air fare from New York to Paris and Bordeaux and a $250 donation to the Colonial Dames; membership is not required. Hotels, most meals, with wine, and buses included.
IRELAND AND ENGLAND. The American Craft Museum in New York is sponsoring a tour of the crafts of the Irish countryside, Dublin and London. It is open to nonmembers of the museum. Scheduled for Oct. 12 to 21, the tour will include viewings of private collections, and meetings with craft artists, and is timed to coincide with the Chelsea Crafts Fair in London. The cost, including air fare, accommodations, some meals and a guide, is about $2,650 a person, double occupancy, plus a $100 contribution to the museum. Information: the American Craft Museum (212-956-3535) or Academic Arrangements Abroad (212-514-8921 or 800-344-3746).
BRAZIL. A decorative fiber arts and crafts tour to Brazil, visiting Sao Paulo, Manaus and other cities is scheduled from Oct. 24 to Nov. 8., with stops at workshops, markets and artisan fairs. The trip is available through Brazilian Views, 201 East 66th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; 212-472-9539. The cost, $3,712 a person, includes air fare, hotels, breakfasts, guide and tour transportation.

HEADLINE: Homeless In America

 BODY:
The Better Homes Foundation, a nonprofit organization serving homeless families, has been in contact with more than 1,000 programs that deal with issues regarding the homeless. Many of these programs find ''substance abuse'' a growing problem. However, this does not mean that substance abuse causes family homelessness.
The root cause of homelessness is poverty and the lack of decent, affordable housing. The danger in isolating a single, psychosocial factor such as substance abuse is that policy makers could use it to ignore the housing crisis.
We have been down this road before, with the mentally ill who are homeless. If people can be thought of as crazy, then economic and housing issues for them can be more easily ignored. If we label families substance abusers, and blame them for their difficulties, we, as aJU society, can more easily abdicate our responsibility for housing them. Rather, we should acknowledge the complexity of the problem and work toward developing an integrated solution.
 
ELLEN L. BASSUK, M.D.
President
Better Homes Foundation
 Newton Center, Mass.

HEADLINE: On Language;
Empowerment And Denouncement

BYLINE: BY William Safire

 BODY:
The Energizing word among ''bleeding-heart conservatives'' (an oxymoron that Jack F. Kemp, the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, uses to describe himself and his followers) is empowerment.
The voguish political noun, coined in 1849 to mean ''the gaining of power,'' has particular resonance among blacks. In 1978, the conservative Heritage Foundation attributed popularization of the word to the Students for a Democratic Society in the 1960's, which, said a Heritage release, ''condemned the 'Establishment' and sought 'empowerment' for 'helpless minorities outside the system.' '' The assumption is that the word grew out of the S.D.S. slogan ''power to the people.'' 
As political empowerment was largely achieved, the word was applied to the need for economic clout. In 1976, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., then head of the National Urban League, said, ''That goes to economic security, income maintenance, economic empowerment - the real basic issues of equal opportunity.''
Everybody got into the empowerment act. Voter-registration groups pushed electoral empowerment; pediatricians espoused parent empowerment; after the Reagan re-election in 1984, the political pollster Pat Caddell, who had been a Gary Hart adviser in the Democratic primaries, opined sadly: ''The issue was the empowerment of a generation. . . .''
Feminists have also made it their own: in a piece about the campaign to maintain Mills College in California as a women's undergraduate school, Amy Pyle of The Los Angeles Times wrote, ''Empowerment -buzzword of the recent protests - actually has been the theme at Mills for some time.''
The word was used by some black conservatives eager to move beyond integration to equal opportunities. Many liberals saw this as a denial of their achievement, or as self-help rhetoric unhelpful to entitlements and were slow to pick it up. ''The issue was black empowerment, not integration,'' Robert L. Woodson, a black critic of social welfare bureaucracies, insisted in 1985; he helped popularize the word among conservatives.
In a 1990 Rose Garden awards ceremony, President Bush said, ''Each of these seven Americans provides a definition of the word that I have learned to respect so much, learned from Jack Kemp - empowerment.''
Since Mr. Kemp has apparently become ''Mr. Empowerment,'' at least in the Bush Administration's corridors of power, I called him to get his short definition of the term. Not a man given to brevity, he worked on it for a while, cutting his definition down to this: ''Giving people the opportunity to gain greater control over their own destiny through access to assets of private property, jobs and education.''
This is a word that has crept up on lexicographers; because empower, the verb, has deep roots in the language, its usage as a political noun in recent decades was not noted. ''We didn't regard it as anything that needed watching,'' says Cynthia Barnhart, a dictionary editor at Barnhart Books. ''Then all of a sudden it started coming in.''
Now we're all keeping an eye on it; obviously, empowerment is potent.
 
Denouncing Denouncement
 
THE SENATE ETHICS Committee's special counsel, in charging Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota with, among other lapses, padding his expense account, called for a punishment of denouncement.
This word is the noun form of the verb to denounce, which has a niche between ''to criticize'' and ''to censure,'' and is closest in synonymy to ''publicly to condemn, usually in a loud tone of voice.'' Denouncement was first used in 1544, and nobody can deny the noun its place in the backwaters of our vocabulary.
However, I rise here, Mr. President (that's how you talk in the Senate), to reprehend, proscribe, reprobate and even damn its use by my distinguished colleagues when another word has triumphed over it in common English usage.
The more familiar noun form of denounce is denunciation. It beat denouncement in fair usage combat, just as renunciation has whipped renouncement; why does the Senate (rooted, like senile, in the Latin senex, ''elder'') insist on dredging up the archaic alternative?
One word, one meaning, is my motto; when you use an alternative form to mean the same thing, you have wasted valuable space on the hard disk of your memory, and you have blocked the development of a different meaning.
For example, to pronounce spawned the noun pronunciation, meaning the sound of words, as well as the noun pronouncement, which means ''declaration, usually pompous.'' Another example: to announce has given us Annunciation, capitalized, meaning ''the revelation of the Incarnation to the Virgin Mary,'' as well as the more prosaic announcement.
Therefore, let us asperse, bad-mouth, revile, vilify and disparage denouncement; if we are to denounce anybody, a clear denunciation is in order.
 
Callous, My Foot
 
Dr. Scholl's Uses Gimpy English.
''Callous Removers'' is what the company calls its product to remove the hardened, thick skin properly spelled callus.
''We're asked this question every six months or so,'' says Joanne Brown, the Scholl Inc. public relations director. ''The noun spelling is callus, but we use the adjective in Callous Removers, and the adjective is spelled with an o.''
A lame excuse. First, the label sent to me by Charles Dahle of Greenwich, Conn., says to apply the ''adhesive side onto the callous.'' That means the adjectival spelling is being used mistakenly for the noun.
Second, the too-confident flack is stubbing her toe on her parts of speech: In callous removers, the word callous is not an adjective describing the noun removers; only hardhearted bankers who repossess cars might be called callous removers. In the Dr. Scholl misusage, callus - with a u, no o - is an attributive noun modifying removers.
Callus, from the Latin callum, ''hard skin,'' means just that - hard skin. Callous, same root, gives a figurative extension to the numbness: ''insensitive, unfeeling'' is the meaning.
After my yearly bout with manual labor, what I proudly show on my hand is a callus; pitilessly giving Dr. Scholl's a boot for its insolecism is being callous.
 
The Double Is
 
We have been observing the increased reduplication of is, as in the locution of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff: ''The fact is, is. . . .'' This construction, more prevalent than linguists suspected, is an unnecessary attempt to give a verb to both parts of a sentence.
Members of the Squad Squad immediately complained about the word reduplication, contending that should mean ''three or four usages,'' or a repeat repeated.
Sorry, this is not like iteration and reiteration; in linguistics, logic does not always prevail.
Reduplication is the word used to describe the formation of words like willy-nilly, higgledy-piggledy, hocus-pocus and razzle-dazzle. (Those are second-order reduplications, because the second part of the term rhymes with but does not exactly duplicate the first.) Pure redupes are the perfectly repeated tom-tom and the slang term for ''hurry,'' chop-chop.
Is is is both a reduplication and a mistake. Maurtiz Johnson of Delmar, N.Y., writes with the suggestion that the White House chief of staff may be signaling the positive in Spanish: ''The real explanation is simply a sibiliant palindrome, viz., 'Is is is Sununu's Si! Si! Si!' ''

HEADLINE: IS HE A MATCH FOR THATCHER?

BYLINE: BY CRAIG R. WHITNEY; Craig R. Whitney is The Times's bureau chief in London.

 BODY:
The last time Neil Kinnock, the British Labor party leader, came to the White House, in March 1987, he had his work cut out for him, trying to convince President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Anglo-American special relationship and the NATO alliance would actually be strengthened if Labor won the elections that year.
There he sat, spinning webs of Welsh eloquence around Labor's impossible defense position - unilateral nuclear disarmament and the forced withdrawal of American nuclear submarines, cruise missiles and bombers from England. The President consulted his cue cards, muttered that he was ''concerned'' about the effects of such a policy on the alliance, and let Weinberger poke holes in Kinnock's argument by asking skeptically whether Labor would be willing to multiply British defense spending on conventional arms to make up for the nuclear deterrent. 
What George Bush, who was also present at that March 1987 meeting, thought of Kinnock is not known, but there is little doubt that official Washington hoped that its loyal friend Prime Minister Thatcher could keep this Welsh windbag well clear of 10 Downing Street. Only Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware seemed to be impressed, lifting whole sections of Kinnock's rhetoric for his Presidential primary speeches, and paying for it with his candidacy. Kinnock hasn't been back to United States since then and a lot of things have changed. When Bush sees him in the White House on Tuesday, he will be well aware that Kinnock could indeed soon take the place of Maragaret Thatcher, increasingly unpopular after 11 years in the Prime Minister's office. At 48, he is 16 years her junior.
Most important, Kinnock has changed his party, and perhaps he's also changed himself. The former ban-the-bomb activist has tossed out the socialist militants who dominated Labor when he became leader in 1983, and gotten the rank and file to give up the unilateral disarmament policy. He no longer thunders about renationalization of the inefficient state industries privatized by Thatcher, but instead talks about how Labor can manage the market economy more efficiently than the Conservatives can, and make England a better member of the European Community to boot. With Thatcher nattering on about not surrendering the sovereignty of the British Parliament, and inflation at 9.7 percent running double that of West Germany or France, Kinnock makes an increasingly plausible argument.
His left-wing enemies say he's surrendered to Thatcherism. But Labor's new moderate policies reduced the center-left Liberal Democrats and Social Democrats - who had attracted droves of alienated Labor voters in the 80's - to such a marginal role that the Social Democrats disbanded their party early last month. This spring, Labor moved past the Conservatives (a.k.a. Tories) in the public opinion polls, soaring 20 to 25 points ahead. A lot of this is more Thatcher's doing than Kinnock's. She has been forcing the country to take its medicine for so long that many people have just gotten sick of her. What tipped the polls in Labor's favor was her most recent tug - the ''poll tax,'' a new per capita levy for local services that the Government calls the ''community charge,'' which replaced property taxes levied on only about a third of the electorate.
The Government's idea was that everybody over 18 - dukes and dustmen alike - should pay about the same amount of tax, set by local authorities across the country at rates that average $612 per person. The blow was doubly painful for homeowners who had followed Thatcher's advice and bought flats from the Government in the glory years of privatization. Then the Government jacked up interest rates to control inflation, sending variable-rate mortgage payments soaring to 15 percent and beyond. Thatcher characteristically ignored the warning signs and bashed ahead, arguing that angry voters would blame high-spending local authorities, many of them dominated by Labor. As protests mounted in March and militants turned rallies into riots, voters blamed the Prime Minister instead. Kinnock skillfully distanced Labor from the anarchism, and several weeks later his party swept to victories in parliamentary by-elections in the Conservative stronghold of mid-Staffordshire. After rioters swinging scaffolding poles and wooden clubs battled with police in Trafalgar Square, setting fire to parked Porsches and construction sites in the worst violence in Central London in 90 years, Thatcher even wobbled slightly and seemed in slight danger of being overthrown as party leader by her own disgruntled supporters.
She recovered somewhat in the May 3 muncipal elections. Though the Conservatives lost nationwide, they won important symbolic victories in the London boroughs of Westminster and Wandsworth, where they had managed to set two of the lowest poll tax rates in the country. They even took over control from Labor in the London borough of Ealing, where Kinnock has a corner brick house with a red door, a home that is reportedly worth $340,000, five times what he paid for it at the beginning of the Thatcher real-estate boom in 1981.
The victories enabled Thatcher to do what she does best, which is to wag her finger and say, ''See, I told you so.'' For the time being, most of the steam has gone out of the Conservative revolt, led by the silver-maned, 57-year-old Michael Heseltine, who walked out of Thatcher's Cabinet as Defense Minister in 1986 after a policy dispute. Labor's popularity dipped three months ago, but at the end of last month, the major polls still showed it was leading the Conservatives by about 49 percent to 38.
Barring an unforeseen personal crisis in the Thatcher household (her 75-year-old husband reportedly would like his 64-year-old wife to retire), or a suicidal full-scale mutiny among Conservative MP's, the next contest will probably be between Thatcher and Kinnock, sometime between now and June 1992, before the writ of the current Parliament runs out. In a negative campaign, Thatcher's unpopularity could be Labor's bigger electoral asset, just as Kinnock's inexperience could be the biggest thing going for the Tories.
Even among the British chattering classes, dominated by intellectuals who loathe Thatcherism and everything it stands for, it's hard to find many enthusiastic Kinnock supporters, though they acknowledge that Labor wouldn't have adopted its new moderate policies unless he had forced them through, Most political commentators dismiss Kinnock as a fuzzy-minded lightweight who has never held a Government job and has no grasp of policy details, a lazy debater who is regularly zapped by Thatcher's laser blasts in the House of Commons.
''Today's party, if the past could be forgotten, would not choose Neil Kinnock as its best shot,'' Hugo Young, The Guardian's political columnist, wrote in January, suggesting that many Labor members wished they could start all over and pick somebody like John Smith, an astute Scottish lawyer and the shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer. Unlike Kinnock, he has been a Cabinet minister. But experts do not think the Laborites will scuttle Kinnock, unless they want to disavow the whole process of change that has finally made them electable again.
Kinnock's problem isn't affability. When he lets himself go - increasingly seldom in these statesmanlike days of dark blue pin-stripe suits and rep ties - he's the kind of easygoing ordinary guy you'd feel comfortable having a beer with in the neighborhood pub. At Labor Party congresses, he used to greet people with, ''Hi, kid.''
Much of his time these days is spent closeted with his principal handlers: his press secretary, Julie Hall, and Peter Mandelson, Labor's media director, who adopted the Swedish Social Democrats' red rose as the party's new, soft image, to erase Arthur Scargill and his militant coal miners from the voters' minds after a decade of strikes, runaway inflation and steady national decline. Everybody knows what Thatcher stands for, but people aren't quite sure what Kinnock really believes; he has stood for so many contradictory things over the years. A campaigner for nuclear disarmament in the 60's and 70's, he now says Britain's independent nuclear deterrent is a useful means of encouraging the Soviet Union to keep cutting down its own and an essential part of the British strategic partnership with NATO and the United States.
His preference for 100 words where 10 would do when explaining his views raises suspicions that this is a man who either doesn't know or isn't saying what he really thinks. ''Throughout the late 1980's,'' as The Economist charitably put it not long ago, ''Mr. Kinnock had to blur his vision of where he wanted to lead the Labor Party, knowing that if he showed his hand too clearly or too early he would split the party, or be defeated, or both.''
In a sense, this is a man who's been trying hard all his life to be somebody else. The son of a coal miner from the poverty-stricken brick valleys of Tredegar in South Wales, Kinnock says his father ''would have been very disappointed if I hadn't been upwardly mobile.'' Unlike Thatcher, the grocer's daughter from Grantham, Kinnock didn't go to Oxford, a failure that English class snobbery seems to hold against him almost as much as his Welshness. ''What should one expect from a graduate in industrial relations at University College, Cardiff, in a thin year?'' Hugo Young once wrote.
This sort of gibe hurts Kinnock. He has sent his own son, Stephen, to Cambridge (his daughter, Rachel, attends the Hounslow Borough College), but he does not like journalists to observe his private life, or even his regular monthly forays to his constituency in South Wales. Julie Hall will tell you that Kinnock likes to sing (tenor) with a pickup Welsh male choir in London, and that he loves to watch (and sometimes even play) rugby, but she won't help you go to a game with him or even let you take tea with him in the House of Commons.
In the past, his wife, Glenys, whom he met at Cardiff University, added to the controversy. She is a strong political personality in her own right, though Kinnock and his advisers bridle at the suggestion that she is an eminence grise. But some of the things she has said make one wonder what the breakfast table talk about the ''special relationship'' with the United States would be like in a Kinnock 10 Downing Street.
In a letter to The Independent that was published just before the recent elections in Nicaragua, Glenys Kinnock wrote, ''The workers and peasants will acknowledge the achievements of the past 10 years and they will hope that the international community will at last feel able to end the isolation and stop the war.'' After the ''workers and peasants'' resoundingly repudiated the Sandinistas, neither she nor her husband, who had often described the Sandinistas as paragons of democracy compared with the United States-supported contras, had anything to say publicly about the results.
In asides at Labor gatherings, Kinnock often jokes that you probably never thought you'd hear him praising Ronald Reagan, whose breakthrough with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on nuclear arms negotiations he credits with making possible Labor's shift away from unilateral disarmament.
Kinnock's admirers say such changes of position are the finger-in-the-wind responses of an astute politician who saw firsthand how the leftist leadership of his mentor, Michael Foot, led his party to electoral disaster following Thatcher's popular victory in the Falklands War.
Kinnock's allies in the struggle are all handpicked aides who owe their party jobs to him. Among the closest are Larry Whitty, 47, party general secretary; Mandelson, a 36-year-old media specialist, whose grandfather Herbert Morrison was a Labor Party great of 50 years ago, and Charles Clarke, Kinnock's 39-year-old chief of staff.
The team was in place well before Kinnock's first try for the Prime Minister's office in his campaign against Thatcher in 1987, but Kinnock made the mistake then of thinking that he could win without any fundamental review of party policies. The election results, which gave the Conservatives a 101-seat majority, stunned him.
The two-year policy review that followed had to be undertaken, all the aides agreed, because it was clear from their polling that Labor could never win a national election as a party committed to unilateral nuclear disarmament, nationalization of industry and high income taxes - reduced by Thatcher to a maximum rate of 40 percent.
The ''old'' policies of the 80's were officially junked at the annual Labor conference in Brighton last October, but Kinnock had clearly signaled a year earlier where he was headed: ''The economy that we are faced with is a market economy, and we have got to make it work better than the Tories make it work.''
Many on the left though this kind of talk was betrayal. Kinnock explains it as dire political necessity. Smoking Capstan tobacco in a silver-stemmed pipe in the opposition leader's private red-carpeted office at the east end of the Palace of Westminster, behind the House of Commons chamber, Kinnock told me: ''For some sections of the movement, even defeat isn't enough to warn them about the inadequacy of what they were doing. What we needed to do was not to invent a new persona but to identify the things best about the Labor Party and then to insist, ruthlessly if necessary, that the best things were applied to the present and the future. I want the message to go through the movement and out to the public that we are constantly willing to take into account changing realities and constantly have the nerve to make the changes and say that we have.''
LABOR'S NEW domestic policies are sweet reason and responsibility: ''I will not spend money that the Government hasn't got,'' Kinnock declared on BBC television three weeks ago. A little earlier, he had said: ''It's no use using a slogan of full employment. In our commitment to training and education, and investment in the essential economic infrastructure, we are saying more about full employment than we could possibly say simply by using a convenient but less than fully illuminating phrase.''
Labor, he promised, would abandon Thatcher's illusion that the private sector, left to its own devices, could solve all economic problems. What it would do, he says in the same breath, would introduce a Government-business partnership. Asked how this was different from Conservatism as represented by such non-Thatcherites as Heseltine, Kinnock responded, as he often does, epigrammatically: ''We are committed to working with the market, not to worshipping the market.'' Even this fine-honed evasion would have sent his Welsh idol, the great Labor orator Aneurin Bevan, into fits.
Trying to explain Labor's tax policies in a BBC television interview in mid-June, Kinnock was slightly imprecise and had to be corrected later by John Smith. Kinnock had said that 14 out of 15 working taxpayers would not have to pay more under Labor; Smith explained that what he meant was 14 out of 15 working taxpayers paying the basic rate of 25 percent. But at the upper end of the scale, for the taxpayers who have benefited most from Thatcherism, Labor would raise the rate from 40 percent to 50 percent.
When asked about his alternative to the poll tax, which the Government currently has under review, Kinnock waffled: ''We've got our alternative, which as we've said very directly and very honestly is a tax, a local tax that is based on property and related directly to the ability to pay. We don't know precisely what our alternative is going to be an alternative to.''
Lack of specifics is a luxury a party in opposition may be able to afford, but a party in Government can't, and his critics say Kinnock is too often all at sea when it comes to details. In May 1989, just as the new Labor defense policies were being unveiled, Kinnock flew off the handle in a BBC radio interview with a political commentator, James Naughtie, who had been trying to get him to say exactly how Labor's handling of the economy would differ from the Government's.
Speaking into a microphone in a House of Commons studio at the other end of the line from his interviewer, Kinnock spluttered to a stop. Fuming, he went on to coin a new synonym for ''skewered'' - ''I'm not going to be bloody kebabbed'' - leaving the clear impression that he really didn't know.
Kinnock's short fuse is an old rap his opponents have long used against him. Before Christmas of 1986, indulging a well-known passion for Indian curry at a restaurant with his wife and friends, he became involved in an incident that the Conservatives said indicated that he would ''crack'' under pressure.
Two young men, apparently not admirers, spotted him and rushed over and hit him on the head with rolled-up newspapers. ''I got hold to the big one by the lapels and pushed him up against the wall and clipped him a couple of times,'' the stocky, 5-foot-10 Kinnock told Independent Television News later, maintaining that his response showed he was cool, collected and tough on crime.
''He's cracked,'' said John Gilbert, a Labor M.P., ''and once a man has cracked he'll crack again.''
In mano-a-mano with Thatcher in the twice-weekly Prime Minister's Question Time in the House of Commons, now seen in the United States on C-Span, Kinnock often looks cowed. Standing two swords' lengths across the dispatch boxes from the Prime Minister, when he rises to ask a question he usually does not look directly at her but leans down into the microphone, exposing his red-fringed bald pate to the glare of television lights and keeping his head bowed like a schoolboy expecting a scolding.
He seems to pull his punches. ''The reason is,'' he told me, is ''that she is a woman nearly 20 years older than myself, and even if I were to try - and I don't - to treat her as if she was a fella, it wouldn't work. If it's not chromosomic it's certainly something that I've got from my upbringing.''
In his first five years as opposition leader, Kinnock's performances were often dismissed as wordy hot-air balloons that Thatcher had no trouble in puncturing. But early last year he began keeping his questions to the point and sharpening them with wit, an effective weapon against the humorless Prime Minister. By autumn, Kinnock had one-liners refined to an art: ''When I hear the Prime Minister feeling sorry for the rest of the world, I understand why she has taken to calling herself 'we' - it is less lonely,'' he said, and brought down the House. This spring, he noted that Thatcher's recently appointed Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, was obviously trying to wield a new broom. ''But that will not be terribly convincing as long as the broomstick is ridden by the Prime Minister,'' he cracked.
This sort of thing gets laughs but does not help establish Kinnock's gravitas. ''I don't believe for one moment that this country wants its national leader to be a jolly jester, a funny fellow, a cheeky chappy,'' said Thatcher's Home Secretary, David Waddington.
Kinnock's main task, Mandelson and Clarke believe, is to establish his seriousness as a credible Prime Minister. ''We have to fully and finally destroy the myth of Tory competence,'' Mandelson says. ''Beyond that, we have to get rooted in people's minds our alternative approach to Government, which is to coordinate, to lead, not, as Thatcher says, to keep hands off the economy. That's what Neil's got to be used for - encapsulating, with key messages, key arguments, key words.''
Mandelson will give up his post as communications director and run for a seat in Parliament, after the next party conference in October, but is expected to continue to play the key role in defining Labor's public image. The main internal issue at the conference, where party policy is set by delegates outnumbered by blocs of hundreds of thousands of votes controlled by the trade unions, will be a move by Kinnock and the leadership to whittle the bloc vote down from 90 percent to 70 percent, with the prospect of a further cut to 40 percent.
Clarke confirmed that a spate of trips to European capitals by Kinnock earlier this year was aimed at positioning him to exploit the splits in Conservative ranks caused by Thatcher's uncompromising opposition to European unification, which Kinnock is trying to get his party to embrace before the next election. So far, all he's been able to do is elicit a pledge that Labor will be ''strong in Europe,'' a far cry, though, from the days when the party was calling for Britain to get out of the European Community altogether.
In front of large, friendly crowds, hands gripping the lectern, torso moving with the melodious Welsh lilt of his voice, Kinnock uses the power of emotion to bring his listeners along. In an election campaign, he will need to convince British voters that he can be as effective an executive as Thatcher has been. His supporters say he's demonstrated that he can be just as ruthless, by watering down the power of the big unions that dominated Labor and nearly brought the country to economic standstill in the late 70's and early 80's.
Although the national mood has gone sour on Thatcher, she will try to turn it around before she calls the next election. The Conservatives have been most unpopular when mortgage rates were high. Thatcher could bring them down, perhaps, by taking the pound sterling into the European exchange rate mechanism once inflation starts to fall and pegging it more closely to the stable West German mark. If inflation and mortgage rates are low enough by the middle of next year, some of her advisers say she might call a snap election then.
Whenever it comes, the election could be decided more by negative factors than positive ones. If the voters are indeed tired of Thatcher and no longer buy her rap against Labor as the party of strikes, socialism and soaring inflation, they may elect Kinnock. If they are still unsure of what Kinnock really stands for, they may leave him where he's already had a longer continuous run than any other figure in modern British political history - leader of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition. The only thing clear now is that it's no longer unthinkable that Kinnock could become Prime Minister.

AND BEAR IN MIND
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
EVERY SPY A PRINCE: The Complete History of Israel's Intelligence Community, by Dan Raviv and Yossi Melman. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) A fascinating account of an intelligence establishment to which nearly supernatural powers are often attributed, but which has suffered from fits of arrogance, complacency and clumsiness much like all the others.
 
LYING TOGETHER, by D. M. Thomas. (Viking, $17.95.) The final novel of the author's ''Russian Nights'' quintet purports to be an improvisation by characters from the other four; the engaging, witty result grapples with big issues like meaning and truth.
 
AN OPEN ADOPTION, by Lincoln Caplan. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Part research paper, part thriller, this case study broadens to examine a form of placement in which biological and adoptive parents are well known to one another.
 
MY LIFE AS A DOG, by Reidar Jonsson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) The uncannily deft narrative about a boy's coming of age (basis of the 1985 film), finally translated from the Swedish.
 
REBUILDING THE HOUSE, by Laurie Graham. (Viking, $17.95.) An affecting record of loss endured and life reconstructed after the death of the elder partner in a remarkably fortunate transgenerational marriage.
 
WRESTLING WITH THE ANGEL: A Memoir of My Triumph Over Illness, by Max Lerner. (Norton, $18.95.) The experiences of a New York intellectual, now in his 80's, with three mortal diseases, which he has so far beaten with luck, pluck and modern medicine.
 
TAKING HEART, by A. C. Greene. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A veteran essayist and commentator examines the experiences of the first patient in a new heart-transplant center - himself.

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: THE PATTERN IN 'THE YELLOW WALLPAPER'

BYLINE: By MARY BETH NORTON; Mary Beth Norton is the Mary Donlon Alger Professor of American History at Cornell University.

 BODY:
TO ''HERLAND'' AND BEYOND
The Life and Work of Charlotte Perkins Gilman.
By Ann J. Lane.
Illustrated. 413 pages. New York:
Pantheon Books. $29.95.
Ann J. Lane begins her remarkable biography of Charlotte Perkins Gilman with the words, ''This is the story of my Charlotte.'' Later in the preface she describes the ''dialogue'' she has had with Gilman, and identifies other dialogues as well: between Ms. Lane and her readers, between Gilman's life and Gilman's work, between the old and the young Charlottes. 
In adopting such a personal, reflective biographical mode Ms. Lane -a professor of history at the University of Virginia - has joined other feminist scholars who are currently experimenting with innovative ways of telling the tales of women's lives. Although standard, chronological studies of individual women continue to appear, many feminists have become dissatisfied with conventional approaches to writing biographies of female subjects. They have accordingly begun to develop new methods of storytelling. Some of them even become explicit presences in the works they produce, a strategy rarely - if ever - adopted by male authors of books about men.
Thus near the end of the book Ann Lane directly describes an interview in 1978 with Gilman's daughter, then 93 and living in a California nursing home. ''She seemed unable to comprehend the point of my visit,'' Ms. Lane tells her readers. ''Why would I want to write a book about her mother? . . . Since it was clear that Katharine Chamberlin had her wits about her, I concluded that her reluctance to understand my visit had to do with her reluctance to acknowledge the growing respect for her mother's work.'' Ms. Lane then goes on to discuss what Chamberlin told her in that and subsequent interviews and to relate their content to what Chamberlin wrote about her mother in an autobiography and in correspondence with archivists interested in her mother's papers. Her personal encounter with Chamberlin becomes for Ms. Lane a key datum in her search for the woman she calls ''my Charlotte.''
Although ''To 'Herland' and Beyond'' proceeds in roughly chronological fashion, its chief organizing principle is not time but rather the primary relationships in Gilman's life. With two exceptions, the chapters focus serially on Gilman's successive interactions with other persons named in the chapter titles - Gilman's parents, her two husbands, three close female friends, a doctor who treated her, her daughter. This unusual plan works exceedingly well, as Ms. Lane returns repeatedly to similar themes that link the chapters while also exploring the development of each relationship over time. It is in this creative organizational scheme that the author's dialogue with Gilman is most fully realized.
Who then was the woman with whom Ms. Lane has held such an extended dialogue? Charlotte Perkins was born in 1860, to a lesser branch of the Beecher family - her father's mother was the sister of those famous siblings Catharine and Henry Ward Beecher and Harriet Beecher Stowe. Charlotte had little to do with these prominent relatives as she was growing up, however, for her parents separated when she was very young, finally divorcing in 1870. She and her brother were raised in genteel poverty by their mother, living in a succession of relatives' homes, boarding houses and other temporary lodgings.
The young Charlotte, who wrote fiction and poetry and kept a journal, revealed in her writings an intense conflict between her desire to be useful in the world - to have a career, though in what area was unclear - and her strong attraction to conventional married life. That conflict remained unresolved until her second marriage in 1900. Ms. Lane demonstrates how, during a lengthy epistolary courtship with her first cousin Houghton Gilman, the mature Charlotte came to understand that marriage and career could indeed be combined under the right circumstances. Before then, she had endured an unhappy first marriage, during which the birth of her daughter Katharine induced the deep depression that nearly drove her insane and led her to abandon her husband and daughter. Although the latter act caused a scandal of major proportions, she went on to forge a satisfying public career as a prolific author and lecturer.
It was her fascination with Gilman's writings, Ms. Lane tells her readers, that first interested her in this often-tormented woman. The feminist Utopian novel ''Herland''; ''The Yellow Wallpaper,'' a short story describing a woman's descent into madness, based partly on Gilman's own experiences; and theoretical works like ''Women and Economics,'' which have gained new admirers for their trenchant, gender-based analysis: all reveal an original and creative thinker. Gilman, Ms. Lane admits, was both a racist and an elitist. Yet her insistence on placing women at the center of her inquiry makes her stand out among her male and female contemporaries and renders her ideas relevant nearly a century after they were first expounded.
Given Ms. Lane's motives for embarking upon this biography, it is ironic that the dialogue between Gilman's life and work, alluded to in the title as well as in the preface, is the least satisfactory of the dialogues in the book. The two chapters not focused on relationships are entitled simply ''Work: Part I'' and ''Work: Part II.'' On the whole, they merely summarize the contents of Gilman's major writings - sometimes at great length, as in the 21 pages devoted to ''Women and Economics'' - and to no apparent purpose. Only in the discussion of ''The Yellow Wallpaper'' does Ms. Lane adequately connect the themes of Gilman's life with the themes of her writings. Readers are left to puzzle about this unfinished dialogue as they recognize in Gilman's work certain emphases that seem to resonate with Gilman's life experiences. What does Ms. Lane think about such resonances? To what extent did Gilman's work reflect or transcend the limitations of her personal experiences? Ms. Lane leaves such questions unasked and unanswered.
Even so, Ann Lane has performed her own useful public service by exposing to our eyes her longstanding dialogue with Charlotte Perkins Gilman. As Ms. Lane informs us in her preface, the nature of that dialogue changed while she worked on the book. I suspect that readers will find the same thing happening to them as they read.

HEADLINE: NOT ITS FINEST HOUR

BYLINE: By CRAIG WHITNEY; Craig R. Whitney is the London bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:

AN AMERICAN LOOKS AT BRITAIN
By Richard Critchfield.
496 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $22.95.
Almost everyone agrees that something has been deeply wrong with Britain for many years, but what? Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher thinks it's ''socialism,'' the postwar consensus on cradle-to-grave welfare. The Labor Party thinks it's Thatcherism, which, fading at the edges after 11 years, has begun to reveal that economic and social malaise didn't stop with the North Sea oil boom. There must be some explanation for the increasing vulgarity and sheer bloody-mindedness in so much of British life, evident in everything from riots in Trafalgar Square to the complete boorishness evinced even by the most refined of the Queen's subjects once they get behind the wheel of an automobile. 
Richard Critchfield, a distinguished American foreign correspondent for the old Washington Star and a contributor to The Economist and other publications, who spent years reporting from the villages of former British colonies and from other cultures in India, Africa, Latin America and Asia, has come up with two familiar answers in this idiosyncratic book which is, as he acknowledges in his introduction, really about British culture rather than about Britain.
The first is that the British governing class has never recovered the faith in God, country or itself that it lost between 1914 and 1945. The second is that, nevertheless, it has basically refused to move aside and let anybody else run the country in its place.
The idiosyncrasy of Mr. Critchfield's approach is his explanation for the paradox: the British elite holds on because it is the arbiter of one of the most powerful instruments ever devised by the human race, the English language. What is wrong with Britain, he suggests, is that it has fallen in love with the sound of its own voice, which he lets us hear in all its eloquence in a book that is full of extended direct quotes, the British talking as only the British can about Britain.
To ''arrive'' in British society today, Mr. Critchfield amply demonstrates, one still has to have gone to Oxford or Cambridge and speak in their plummy tones. Moreover, one has to sound like that to be taken really seriously by people in most of the rest of the world, who consider American and English two different languages.
''Britain's educational system perpetuates the class and cultural divisions that hold the country back,'' he writes. ''There is nothing new or original about this perception. The British themselves have been complaining about it for thirty, forty years. Nonetheless, not much changes.''
One wonders (the British would never say ''you wonder'') why. This book does not really provide an answer, because Mr. Critchfield himself has been hypnotized by the British razzle-dazzle with words; he charms and fascinates us even as he falls under the spell. A whole section on the loss of empire and its importance to understanding contemporary Britain, for example, turns into an account of the making of ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' the dramatic television series adapted from Paul Scott's ''Raj Quartet'' that was shown on ''Masterpiece Theater'' in the 1980's.
Ultimately, the author says, words without faith are empty, and it is when he wonders whether the British really believe in anything anymore that he comes closest to explaining what has gone wrong. ''The great continuing theme of English letters going back to Matthew Arnold's 'Dover Beach' has been the loss of spiritual faith,'' he writes. ''Any society's loss of faith - in life, in the world, in the spiritual, in itself - can affect everything: how hard people work, how inventive they are, how much initiative they take, in short, their enterprise.''
In a leap of faith, he concludes that the British will recover their nerve, perhaps finding a new creed to take them into the next century in a real commitment to science and technology. The British, who usually find little merit in criticisms from mere foreigners, would do well to read his exhortations.

HEADLINE: BEFORE APARTHEID, AND POSSIBLY AFTER

BYLINE: By LORNA HAHN; Lorna Hahn, executive director of the Association on Third World Affairs in Washington, has written extensively about South Africa.

 BODY:

A HISTORY OF SOUTH AFRICA
By Leonard Thompson.
Illustrated. 288 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $29.95.
An old Zulu proverb warns that ''those who meet will meet again.'' Sure enough, thanks to massive pressures for change, South Africans who only recently met as jailer and prisoner, oppressor and oppressed, are today meeting again - as leaders trying to negotiate a new form of government. President F. W. de Klerk, the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and their colleagues have undertaken a herculean task. As Leonard Thompson's admirably objective history of South Africa makes clear, whites have held racist attitudes ever since Dutch settlers first landed at the Cape of Good Hope in 1652; blacks - the term now commonly used to include ''coloreds'' (those of mixed blood) and Indians as well as Africans - have endless grievances to be redressed; and people within all ethnic groups have differing concepts of how the country should be governed. Nevertheless, in reading between Mr. Thompson's copiously documented lines, one finds grounds to hope that reason, compromise and reconciliation will prevail. 
Unlike many historians of the country, Mr. Thompson, the director of the southern African research program at Yale University, begins ''A History of South Africa'' by discussing the cultures of the country's original inhabitants: the San hunter-gatherers (usually called ''Bushmen'' by Europeans), the Khoikhoi pastoralists (dubbed ''Hottentots'') and the many communities of farmers. In so doing, he destroys many shibboleths about Africans being unproductive, uncompetitive or generally ''uncivilized''; he also shows that their governments, although headed by authoritarian chiefs, depended heavily upon the consent and participation of the governed. ''The Basotho,'' he notes, ''had two sayings that summed up the underlying tension: 'Morena ha a fose' (The chief can do no wrong) and 'Morena ke batho' (No people, no chief).'' He also says African justice focused on restoring harmony to the community rather than on exacting retribution.
Neither ethnic background nor skin color was a barrier to full membership in African societies. The Xhosas, for example, incorporated not only other black Africans but also the lighter-skinned Khoikhoi. ''The limits of Xhosadom were not ethnic or geographic,'' Mr. Thompson writes, ''but political: all persons or groups who accepted the rule of the Tshawe [the ruling family] thereby became Xhosa.'' Likewise, when the conqueror Shaka built his formidable Zulu kingdom in the early 19th century, ''every inhabitant, whatever his origins, became a Zulu.'' Even Europeans were no exception, the author tells us; among the Xhosas there were two clans, the Lungu and the Mholo, who traced their descent from the European survivors of shipwrecks. The 19th-century English trader John Dunn became not only a Zulu chief and adviser to the king but also the husband of 46 Zulu women.
The Africans' willingness to accept others was not, unfortunately, shared by ''the white invaders'' - first the amalgam of Dutch, French and Germans who became the Afrikaners, then the British who gained the Cape Colony during the Napoleonic Wars and subdued the rest of what is now South Africa by the turn of the 20th century. Coming from Europe - where, Mr. Thompson writes, ''ethnic chauvinism was already deeply embedded in the popular psyche'' - the early settlers soon became dependent on the labor of both indigenous blacks and slaves imported from Indonesia, India, Ceylon, Madagascar and Mozambique. Racial differences thereby became virtually synonymous with class differences, thus reinforcing white attitudes of superiority and setting a pattern of relations that endured until only recently.
Despite the social cleavages, however, interracial contacts took place from the start: with women in short supply, there were marriages between European men and freed slaves and numerous other liaisons, so that, in the author's words, ''it has been estimated that approximately 7 percent of the genes of the modern Afrikaner people originated outside Europe.'' The British, although pressed by humanitarian groups to free all slaves and accord blacks better legal treatment, extended the segregation, pass requirements and other humiliations started by the Afrikaners. And although they granted qualified franchise to the blacks in the Cape Colony, ''no black person ever became a member of the parliament or cabinet, and laws were passed to check the increase of the black members of the electorate, who never numbered more than 15 percent of the total.''
While the British were building their empire, Afrikaners built independent republics, the Transvaal and the Orange Free State. Here they adamantly denied political rights to blacks, yet were egalitarian and democratic among themselves, even borrowing some ideas from the United States Constitution. Unlike the Nazis, with whom they are sometimes compared, they had no tradition of standing armies or all-powerful leaders, and hence no history of coups. Always survivors, they surrendered to the hated British after the Boer War rather than face complete destruction, and such Afrikaner heroes as Jan Smuts proceeded not only to cooperate with the British but to become leaders of the new Union of South Africa. And while most Afrikaners - and the British as well - were developing rationales for racism, a few indicated that they might not be committed to it irrevocably. Smuts' colleague J. H. Hofmeyr even told Parliament in the 1930's of his hope for ''the ultimate removal of the colour bar from our constitution.'' Such precedents, cited by Mr. Thompson, suggest why Mr. de Klerk today is willing to gamble on a new survival strategy and why he believes the majority of Afrikaners will follow him.
With the election in 1948 of the militant Afrikaner National Party, which advocated apartheid as the way to handle the recent heavy influx of Africans, segregation became an ideology. Classified into racial groups, compelled to live in areas, use facilities and perform jobs designated for their group, people were to have as little contact as possible with members of other groups. Africans were to be resettled in 10 tribal ''homelands,'' which, when granted independence, would presumably rid the country of its main race problem. As Mr. Thompson carefully demonstrates, however, the apartheid system was doomed almost from the start. While the Government was shipping as many Africans as possible to the homelands, the growing economy was becoming ever more dependent on Africans - not just for menial labor, but for skilled and professional manpower and consumer power as well. As the homelands became ever more overpopulated and impoverished, more Africans migrated to the urban areas. The gross inconsistencies and injustices, increasingly opposed by whites as well as blacks, spurred the growth of the anti-apartheid movement.
Mr. Thompson traces the history of the African National Congress from its founding in 1912 as the South African Native National Congress, showing why it turned to violence in 1960 and why some members, weary of relying on white support, broke away in 1959 to form the Pan-Africanist Congress. He discusses such later movements as the Azanian African People's Organization and the Zulu-based Inkatha, touches on the Communist Party - for many years the only multiracial organization around - and gives an excellent analysis of the crucial role of trade unions in bringing governmental concessions. These internal forces, assisted by mounting outside pressures, compelled the Government by 1986 to reverse many basic apartheid policies and to begin exploring arrangements in which Africans might at last be treated as full citizens. The book ends with the election of Mr. de Klerk in 1989, and with the conclusion that the outcome remains in doubt as to whether fundamental change from above, piecemeal peaceful change or revolution will finally end the apartheid state.
There are a few pertinent facts that Mr. Thompson neglects to mention. For example, a reference to the traditional system of values known as African humanism, with its belief that all people are children of God, would have helped explain the remarkable absence of rancor among most Africans. The British colonel C. F. Stallard, whose theory between the world wars that Africans were merely ''temporary sojourners'' among whites foreshadowed the ideology of apartheid, deserves at least a footnote. And there could have been some mention of the sense of remorse that has been sweeping Afrikaners in recent years. But these are very minor omissions amid the wealth of material that Mr. Thompson has so ably presented. ''A History of South Africa'' will be most useful in contemplating the country's future.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
High-End Sales Are Down in Greenwich

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
In northeast Greenwich, 26 stately pleasure domes have been built at Conyers Farm, a 1,500-acre enclave resembling a contemporary Xanadu. Maintaining its private, pastoral quality is a set of covenants under which no more than 60 families may live on minimum lots of 10 acres, protected in perpetuity by deed restrictions.
Since it opened in 1985, four or five parcels a year have been sold at prices starting at $155,000 an acre. But with sales down to zero in 1990, the developer has changed brokers in an effort to stimulate interest. 
Greenwich's high-end properties, starting at $1.5 million, have been remarkably resilient through the general economic slump, but now''sales are down by 50 percent from the same period last year,'' said Peter Helie, president of William Pitt, a real estate agency based in Stamford that is affiliated with Sotheby's International Realty in Manhattan. The firms are now handling sales jointly at Conyers Farm.
Marketed as an equestrian community, this development of rolling hills, woods and meadows is patrolled by private security guards and electronically operated gates 24 hours a day. It has a polo field, grandstand and clubhouse with an indoor tennis court. Polo matches are open to the public on Sunday afternoons in the summer for a fee of $15 a car, and prizes are frequently given for the most imaginative tailgate picnic.
Lots on the shores of Converse Lake, a 100-acre body of water in the middle of the property, have an asking price of $250,000 an acre. The most recently sold lakeside lot of 10 acres brought $2.25 million last year. Homes range in size from approximately 13,000 square feet to 22,000 square feet, custom built for sums that begin at $3 million.
Some residents have purchased more than one 10-acre lot and spent up to $2 million on horse barns, paddocks, fencing and pasture, in addition to the cost of their homes. Some of them have sons who are members of the United States Olympic Equestrian Team.
Ivan Lendl, the tennis star, bought five lots. He retains two and is offering the other three for sale at slightly higher prices. Because he bought multiple lots he is exempt from a requirement to build a house within two years or sell the land. Other restrictions control fencing, landscaping, tree removal, buffer areas around waterways, garbage storage, television antennas, business use of property, siting of houses and architecture.
Assessments for security, snow-plowing, maintenance of the 6.5 miles of common roads, landscaping, trees and the clubhouse are around $5,800 a year.
Peter Brant, a polo enthusiast and owner of Bato Company and Riviere du Loup Newsprint Ltd. in Greenwich, bought the property for $18 million in 1980.
For the past 20 years, he has lived at White Birch Farm, a 200-acre spread facing Conyers Farm on North Street, with a polo field and training track. Last spring he was convicted in Federal Court in Bridgeport of charging $1.5 million worth of personal items to business accounts and was sentenced to three months in the Federal Correctional Institute in Danbury, starting Sept. 17.
He was also fined $200,000 and required to perform 500 hours of community service. Mr. Brant has an unlisted phone number and Joan Caldwell, his property manager, said he could not be located for an interview.
Miss Caldwell said his difficulties ''are not likely to affect his business, the real estate development or his personal finances.''
''Mr. Brant came to us because we can provide a worldwide source of buyers at our 56 offices in 27 countries,'' said Thomas B. Anderson, senior vice president for the metropolitan New York area at Sotheby's in Manhattan.
Jesse Sammis 3d, a principal in Sammis & Chadsey, a Greenwich real estate firm that formerly handled Conyers Farm, is independently marketing 10 resales by six lot owners. ''We closed on a 10-acre lot for $1.8 million at the end of June,'' he said.
Some 50 out of 95 lots have been sold since 1985. Two disputes over architectural designs, subject to review by a committee of the residents' association and a paid architectural consultant, resulted in litigation, ''but were settled out of court,'' said Miss Caldwell. Owners who failed to build houses, she said, ''negotiated with the result that we bought back some properties; others were sold on the open market.''
''Conyers Farm is the nicest place to buy in town,'' said Stanley J. Klein, president of Empire Realty, a Greenwich firm that tracks local sales and trends. ''It's a mix of old and new money, hard work and inheritance. Only these days a lot of people with that kind of money are buying 1,000 acres in Vermont for a million and a half.''
Conyers is the old English spelling of Converse, the surname of Edmund Converse, a founder of United States Steel and Bankers Trust of New York, who assembled the land in the early 1900's and named it Conyers Manor. An English country house and 40 outbuildings that he constructed were part of a working dairy farm and fruit orchard for more than two decades. The manor house burned down many years ago and some of the outbuildings have been restored as homes, guest houses and horse barns by Conyers Farm residents.
In 1936, Mr. Converse sold the property for $800,000 to the founder of Schenley Distillers, Lewis Rosenstiel, who shocked Greenwich in the early 70's by attempting to downzone the property from four acres to quarter-acre lots. When he sued the town for rejecting his scheme to build hundreds of moderate-cost housing units, state courts struck down his plan as an overwhelming burden on municipal resources.
Because there is no town water or sewage in north Greenwich, residents must dig wells and install septic systems. Fire protection is available from central Greenwich and nearby Banksville in New York State, where 300 acres of Conyers Farm lie.
To protect the water supply and prevent erosion of pastures, horse owners must submit a waste removal plan and horse management plan to the town's Planning and Zoning Commission. Residents are allowed one horse on 20,000 square feet or 20 horses on 10 acres. More than six horses on three or more acres requires special approval from the Planning and Zoning Board of Appeals.
''Problems for some people are opportunities for others,'' said Mr. Sammis. ''Lots of people are still making money and there is nothing else available where you can get this much property surrounded by other large properties in a prestigious community 45 minutes from Manhattan.''
