HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Office Leasing;
Law Firms Top Financial Houses in Rental Activity

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
In one of the biggest deals of a slow year, the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy has signed a 20-year lease for at least 330,000 square feet at One Chase Manhattan Plaza in lower Manhattan, with options that could bring its space to 750,000 square feet - or fully one-third of the tower.
The transaction, which was announced last Monday, exemplifies the fact that law firms have become the most prominent players in the Manhattan leasing market, because they still need room to accommodate the tremendous growth that began in the 80's or simply because they have reached the end of their old leases in a buyers' market.
From January to May, legal-service concerns signed leases for more than 773,000 square feet in mid-Manhattan and lower Manhattan, almost 14 percent of the 5.7 million square feet leased during that period, according to the latest statistics from the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage. Financial-service concerns signed leases for 550,000 square feet, or nearly 10 percent. This continues a trend that began last year, when law firms first overtook financial houses. 
Other key players in the current leasing market are banks, which signed leases for 711,000 square feet of space from January to May this year; accounting firms, which took 636,000 square feet and insurance companies, which took 581,000 square feet.
''Today, the law firms are still in a growth mode,'' said Edward S. Gordon, president of the real estate concern that bears his name, which represented Chase Manhattan Bank, owners of One Chase Manhattan Plaza, in the Milbank transaction.
Three years ago, in contrast, the giant securities firms and financial houses were responsible for 28 percent of the 15.9 million square feet of space leased, Cushman & Wakefield figures show. The legal service industry accounted for only 10 percent and accounting firms for 3 percent.
Leading the deals so far this year has been the Milbank lease in the Chase Manhattan headquarters tower, at Nassau, Liberty, William and Pine Streets.
''This new lease reflects the significant growth that Milbank has enjoyed in the past few years,'' said Floyd Brandow, chairman of the firm's space committee, ''and is a renewal of our commitment to the Wall Street area, where so many of our clients are and where we have had our offices for the past 124 years.''
By this fall, the firm plans to have expanded from six to 10 floors in the 60-story tower. Mr. Brandow disclosed nothing about the rent that Milbank would pay other than to say that ''we have negotiated an attractive lease.'' Although Milbank explored moving to mid-Manhattan, he said ''nothing persuaded us to leave this building or this area.''
In another large deal, Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell & Wehyer has signed a 20-year lease for 150,000 square feet at 750 Seventh Avenue, a 35-story tower by Solomon Equities that is now under construction at 49th Street. And Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker has signed a 23-year lease for 150,000 square feet in the Mobil Building at 150 East 42d Street.
''The law firms have been the most exciting part of this market,'' said Ira Schuman, a senior vice president at the Julien J. Studley real estate concern, which represented the Wilson Elser firm. ''It doesn't reflect current activity at law firms. It reflects the pent-up expansion that's been taking place over the past six or seven years. It's not that the legal business is so fabulous that people are now taking enormous amounts of space. But they are reflecting past demand. That's the phenomenon we're seeing.''
Pent-up demand was one thing that prompted Davis Polk & Wardwell, which has 250,000 square feet at One Chase Manhattan Plaza, to sign up for almost 500,000 square feet at 450 Lexington Avenue. That tower, under construction between 44th and 45th Streets, is being developed by Gerald D. Hines, Fred Wilpon and the Prudential Insurance Company.
''We're very crowded right now,'' said Colin E. Harley, one of the partners at Davis Polk who negotiated the new lease. ''We long ago ran out of space. Not only do we have to accommodate that growth, but we have to anticipate future growth.''
Mr. Harley said Davis Polk found that ''our present landlord was taking a very tough position on rent and the midtown proposal was less expensive.''
Growth and the cost of space were two of the principal reasons cited by the firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, which has signed a lease for 340,000 square feet (some of which it will sublet) in the former J. C. Penney Building, 1301 Avenue of the Americas, between 52d and 53d Streets. The firm now occupies less than 200,000 square feet in its headquarters at 140 Broadway, between Cedar and Liberty Streets, and an office at 101 Park Avenue, at 40th Street.
Expansion is not the only reason for the flurry of leasing activity. ''It depends on which firm you're talking about,'' said James S. Vanderslice, a senior vice president at Cushman & Wakefield, which represented the Olwine Connelly firm. ''Sometimes, it's making an attractive economic deal. Sometimes, it's getting into a state-of-the-art building that fits in with the needs of the firm. Sometimes, it could be floor layouts.'' Nearing the end of its lease at One State Street Plaza, the firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton began a search that ended last month with a move into 253,000 square feet at One Liberty Plaza, on Broadway, between Liberty and Cortlandt Streets.
No matter all the talk about the extremely high vacancy rates in Manhattan, the partners at Cleary Gottlieb found that there were very few buildings in the city that came close to meeting their needs, which included floors that were large enough to accommodate an essentially horizontal operation, but not so large as to be overwhelming.
Speaking about the leasing by law firms, Mr. Schuman, at the Studley brokerage, said: ''What it does do is put a premium on the large spaces. It's meaningless to have a 15-percent vacancy rate if it's all in small units. That's one of the paradoxes of this office-space market, which is that the very best space is still in short supply. The very best space still commands $50-plus rents.''
But Mr. Schuman also said he expected less activity among law firms in the future than there had been in the past two years. ''I think they will not take as aggressive a position as they have in the past,'' he said. ''I see law firms very, very seriously reconsidering how they use their space internally and giving serious thoughts to doubling up their associates.''
Although Davis Polk is taking steps to provide private offices for younger lawyers who are now doubled up, Mr. Harley agreed that the general trend was to less, rather than more, expansion. Indeed, he said, his firm took a 20-year average when attempting to calculate its future needs - factoring in the lower growth rate of the 1970's - rather than relying strictly on the more recent pace.
Of the legal profession generally, he said: ''I don't think there's much lateral hiring activity out there anymore because of concerns about the business slowing down this year. I doubt that you'll see many firms continuing the growth they had in the 1980's.''
''All the majors seem to have made their deals,'' said John M. Cefaly, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield. Looking ahead, he said: ''I think there's a question as to where the market is headed. That's what people are waiting to see. There are a lot of tire-kickers out there, a lot of of people looking for bargains. I don't see any one particular industry leading the charge. It seems to be pretty well spread out.''
And, after all, it is possible to invest leasing statistics with too much significance, as Mr. Gordon pointed out. ''If you were to look at the trends of the last 20 years or even longer,'' he said, ''you're seeing - constantly - new industries, businesses and professions moving into the forefront. It would seem to be a constant movement of business, almost like shifting sands. Lots of people are looking for so-called trends. I'm not sure there is such an animal.''

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Passing Along Costs
 
Question: I own an occupied, rent-stabilized apartment in Riverdale. Recently, new windows were installed throughout the building and I have started paying an assessment that will last for the next year to cover the costs of that project as well as other scheduled improvements. The assessment has put me in a negative cash-flow position. I would like to know if I can increase my tenant's rent to cover a portion of my share for these costs? . . . J. P., Yonkers, N.Y. 
 
Answer: No. The only legal way that such costs can be passed along to tenants is through a major capital improvement rent increase granted by the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which has jurisdicition over rent-regulated housing.
According to Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the agency, an individual apartment owner is not an eligible applicant for an M.C.I. increase. Mr. Viola said that in the case of a co-op that still has rental tenants, any application for such an increase would have to come from the sponsor of the conversion or the co-op board. But while a sponsor holding rent-regulated units might make such an application, it is not likely that a co-op board would do so because it would hold no benefit for resident shareholders.
 
A Noisy Neighbor
 
Question: I live in a co-op and my problem is a noisy neighbor above me who rents his apartment. He stomps about the apartment and moves furniture at all hours. The managing agent has spoken to him aobut putting down carpeting but he says he can't afford it. Is there any New York City law that says he must cover his floor? . . . R. V., Brooklyn
 
Answer: No. There is no statute requiring a residential tenants to carpet their floors. However, many co-ops, condominiums and rental buildings have house rules requiring that tenants cover a certain amount of floor space with rugs or carpeting.
While any legal challenge to a tenant's refusal to comply would not carry the weight of the law, your building's manager, as the agent of the co-op board, would have the right to insist that your upstairs neighbor stop disturbing you. Since your co-op apparently does not have a carpet rule, you might write to the board and suggest that one be adopted.
 
Mortgage for a Co-op
 
Question: Does a co-op board's interview committee have the right to turn down a prospective purchaser based on financial qualifications, even if the buyer has met the bank's requirements for a mortgage? . . . P. C., Peekskill, N.Y.
 
Answer: Yes. According to Stuart Saft, an attorney who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, one reason the financial criteria of some co-ops are stiffer that those used by many banks is that the co-op's concern goes beyond a shareholder's ability to meet his mortgage obligations.
''It is conceivable that the bank could grant a loan to someone who could meet initial maintenance costs,'' he said, ''but not handle a substantial hike if the board decided it was necessary.''
Mr. Saft said that most co-ops where the majority of residents are owners require that buyers make cash down payments of 25 to 50 percent of the purchase price. However, he said some co-ops will accept an arrangement whereby the buyer fills the gap between the mortgage amount and the board's cash requirement with borrowed money. ''What is important to the co-op,'' Mr. Saft said, ''is how high a lien the bank will have against the building, not how the borrower comes up with the cash to meet its requirements.''

HEADLINE: New York City's Property-Tax Squeeze

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In what may lead to a larger battle over New York City's property tax system, the City Council has approved tax rates for the current fiscal year that hold down increases for the owners of cooperatives, condominiums and rental apartments.
The limits, adopted in last-minute negotiations on the city's $28 billion budget as the fiscal year began on July 1, are far from a windfall. Struggling with severe economic problems, the city has imposed $263 million in new property taxes, and bills will increase for almost all owners, including apartment owners.
But behind the decision to cut the rate on apartment properties this year, according to political analysts and Council members, is mounting opposition to the city's tax structure, a complex system shaped by years of political arm twisting and infused, according to its critics, with glaring inequities.
At the heart of the system, employed since fiscal 1983, are four classes of property, with tax bills based on different formulas for each. The classes are one- to three-family homes, apartment buildings (including cooperatives, condominiums and rentals), utility property, and other types of commercial property. 
In adopting the new rates for the 1991 fiscal year, the City Council accepted changes that reflect growing political strength among co-op and condominium owners. The tax rate on their class of property, which also includes rental apartment buildings, was lowered slightly to 9.154 from 9.229 in the last fiscal year.
The rate is the percent of every $100 in assessed value that will be billed as tax. All other rates were increased: to 9.840 from 9.452 for one- to three-family homes; to 15.079 from 12.903 for utility properties, and to 9.924 from 9.539 for commercial buildings.
Pressure to lower the rate on co-ops, condominiums and rentals came largely from the City Council's Manhattan delegation, whose constituents include a larger share of co-op and condominium owners than those in the other boroughs.
LONG before the New York City system was established, groups representing homeowners, large landlords, corporate tenants and developers all claimed to be paying an unfair share of the tax burden.
But research in recent months by several groups and government agencies has produced solid evidence of wide inequities. Calls for reform are being heightened by the slowdown in the city economy, which is putting a financial squeeze on most taxpayers, and more particularly by the weak real estate market, in which many owners fear that their property values have declined at the same time their tax bills have risen.
Beneficiaries of the system include the owners of one- to three-family homes in some wealthy neighborhoods, according to a recent report by Edward V. Regan, the New York State Comptroller. In one example, it found that the owners of a brownstone in the prosperous Brooklyn Heights neighborhood were likely to be paying about half as much tax in proportion to the value of their homes as those in the nearby Fort Greene section.
Co-op and condominium owners pay far higher taxes. City records show that those who own two-bedroom apartments are likely to be paying as much or more than those with one- to three-family homes. Taxes on commercial property, which have risen faster than on residential property, are prompting some business people to warn that buildings will be abandoned and many small merchants forced out of business.
''Ten years ago the assumption was that people in one- to three-family homes paid their property taxes and voted, and those in apartment buildings were renters who didn't care,'' said Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos, a Manhattan Democrat-Liberal who sponsored the reduction in rates. ''That attitude has changed, and we have only seen the beginning of advocacy on this issue.''
Tax rates are only part of the equation for setting taxes. Since tax assessments have been rising on almost all properties, even a slightly lower rate will not prevent higher tax bills this year.
Indeed, many critics maintain that constraints on the city's tax assessment procedures have created greater problems than the tax rates.
Under the same state legislation that established the city's four classes of property, assessment increases are limited sharply for one- to three-family homes.
The result is that the assessed value of the one- to three-family home was held down during the real estate boom years of the 80's. A study by Dean Michael Mead, an analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, found that the average small residential property was now assessed at only 9 percent of its market value, while larger apartment buildings and commercial properties were at 45 percent of their market value.
That means a one-family home in the city with a market value of $200,000 would be assessed at $18,000. Calculating its tax at the 1991 rate of 9.9840, its bill for the year would be $1,797.12. In contrast, a co-op or commercial property worth $200,000 would be assessed at $90,000. The co-op, with a tax rate of 9.154, would have $8,238.60 in tax, and the commercial property, with a rate of 9.924, would have $8,931.60 in tax.
For most buildings that have received large assessment increases, city rules require that corresponding tax increases be phased in over five years. That means that few co-ops, condominiums, rental buildings or commercial properties are paying the full amount dictated by tax rates and assessments, but that the bills will rise to the maximum during the subsequent years.
''I am glad the City Council is finally focusing in on things, but a lot of abuses still have to be remedied,'' said James Manolatos, the sponsor and president of a 52-unit co-op at the corner of Prospect Park Southwest and 11th Avenue in Brooklyn. He said the entire building's assessed value, $250,000 in 1984, has been raised every year since to $938,250 for fiscal 1991.
Tax bills on the co-op have soared. Based on the latest assessment, the owners of a typical one-bedroom co-op in the building will pay a tax bills of $1,277 this year, he said, more than some one- to three-family homes in the neighborhood. And in a response that is being echoed in many co-ops and condominiums, shareholders in the building have held meetings, phoned City Hall, written letters to Albany and sought other ways to protest. ''There is a groundswell,'' Mr. Manolatos said. The rapid growth in co-op and condominium ownership during the 80's has made their owners a far more powerful politcal force. An analysis by the Real Estate Board of New York found that more than 290,000 co-op and condominium apartments had either been built or converted from rentals since 1983.
The city's landlords, who have always lobbied heavily for lower property taxes, are not likely to reduce their efforts. Last week, when the New York City Rent Guidelines Board approved rent increases of 4.5 percent on one-year leases and 7 percent on two-year leases, some landlords contended that the increase would not be enough to cover their higher property taxes.
''It's a disaster,'' said John J. Gilbert 3d, president of the largest owners group, the Rent Stabilization Association.
Nor are landlords and co-op and condominium owners the only ones making their displeasure known. ''The system is grossly unfair and badly administered, and there has got be a serious effort to make it better,'' said Eugene Russianoff, director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit concern that analyzes city policy.
No one is predicting an immediate overhaul of the system. Any change would probably mean shifting a heavy share of the tax burden to homeowners who form a powerful political constituency.
Nonetheless, senior officials in the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins say property tax reform is a high priority.
''THE inequities have gotten worse and worse, and we intend to look at the whole question of property taxes,'' said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President.
Carol O'Claireacain, the Commissioner of the Department of Finance, has said repeatedly since her appointment to the post by Mayor Dinkins in January that she intends to create a committee of business people, tax experts and community representatives this year to review the entire property tax system and recommend changes.
Neither she nor other senior Finance Department officials were willing to elaborate on the proposal last week, or describe what the priorities of the committee would be. Kip Bobroff, a department spokesman, said the officials were seeking a broad review of the system and intended to avoid the ''tinkering'' that, according to critics, has contributed to its problems.
Mr. Mead of the Citizens Budget Committee found that the four-class system, from its inception, has been employed as a means of avoiding more fundamental changes in the way New York City property is assessed and taxed. The system was mandated by a 1981 state law enacted after the New York State Court appeals upheld lower court rulings that found the state's assessment process illegal.
Before 1981, state law required all properties to be assessed at full market value, but the law was ignored. Although assessment increases were made frequently for commercial property, the report said assessments on small residential properties changed little during the 1960's and 1970's.
By the early 1980's, complying with the requirement for full market-value assessments would have shifted a heavy tax burden on small-home owners. One study commissioned by City Hall estimated that their taxes would have doubled.
That prospect was untenable, not only because elected officials at City Hall and in Albany considered small homeowners a powerful voting block, but because of fears that a large tax increase would spark a renewed exodus to the suburbs of affluent families from neighborhoods of detached one- to three-family homes in the city.
The 1981 law eliminated the requirement for full-market-value assessment by establishing the four classes of properties. It also made the City Council responsible for assuring that the distribution of the tax burden between the four classes remained roughly constant.
Every three years, the New York State Board of Equalization and Assessment was to review the system and make sure the distribution was in order.
The law also set limits on assessment increases for some property owners. Assessments on one- to three-family homes could be raised only 6 percent a year, or 20 percent over five years. Apartment buildings with four to 10 units would have assessment increases limited to 8 percent a year or 30 percent over five years.
There were no limits placed on the assessment increases for larger residential buildings and commercial properties, but the law required that large increases in any given year be phased in over five years. The result is that most of these property owners receive city assessments broken out as ''transitional'' and ''actual.'' The former is the amount that the current tax bill is based on, the latter is that amount on which their bill will be based after the phase in period is complete.
AS a result of the complex system of tax classes and assessment limits, some property owners had their bills held down during one of the greatest booms in New York City property values. Commercial property owners and those with co-ops, condominiums and rental apartments in large buildings found their assessments surging, and years of further increases are assured as the transitional assessments catch up with the high actual assessments.
''With the disparity in tax burdens firmly entrenched'' by the 1981 state law, said Mr. Mead, ''city tax policy in the ensuing years has widened the gap.''
The report found that the market value of one- to three-family homes in the city had risen faster than any other class of properties, by 175 percent from 1983 to 1989, but the assessed value of that property for tax purposes rose only 22 percent.
In contrast, the report said the market value of commercial property rose 132 percent during the same period, while its assessed value rose 74 percent, and the market value of co-ops, condominiums and rental apartments rose 95 percent, while their assessments rose 46 percent.
Since the four-class system was enacted, the way it is administered has also proven flexible. Although the State Board of Equalization and Assessment was to conduct its first three-year review of the system in fiscal 1987, that review was postponed through later legislation to fiscal 1990.
Anticipating the state review of the system - and changes that would have to be made to bring the system in line with the class distribution that had been established in 1983 - a City Hall commission estimated that tax bills on one- to three-family homes would have to be increased 42 percent, or an average increase of $506 a year.
That posed another unpalatable prospect for elected officials. In response, in a measure sponsored by Mayor Edward I. Koch last year, a two-year moratorium was placed on any major redistribution of the tax burden among classes. It also requires future adjustments to keep the distribution in line with where it stood in the 1990 fiscal year, instead of the 1983 fiscal year.
The moratorium on redistribution was in effect when the City Council approved the new tax rates on July 1. But it will expire before property rates are deliberated next year.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: GEORGETOWN;
Plan for Factory Site Alarms Neighbors

BYLINE: By JAMES LOMUSCIO

 BODY:
WHEN Margaret Popper and her family moved from suburban Wilton to working-class Georgetown five years ago, they did not view the move as a step down. The 1860's Victorian house she and her husband, Neal, had purchased was the most beautiful house she had seen, Mrs. Popper said. Tree-lined Church Street, with a Methodist church dating back to the 1700's, had little traffic.
Main Street was welcoming. The mile-long street had a barbershop, market and restaurants. The community of just under 1,000 people had everything she wanted, Mrs. Popper said. Her house was also within walking distance of the Gilbert & Bennett Manufacturing Company complex. Gilbert & Bennett, a manufacturer of metal fencing and one of the nation's oldest companies, had been on the site since 1818. 
''The factory never bothered me,'' Mrs. Popper said. ''I remember my first night in the house. I heard this hum. It was the factory, and it made me feel comfortable. It reminded me of the town I grew up in in upstate New York.''
Today, the hum of the factory is gone. Only a quiet breeze rolls through the old brick factory, the corrugated-metal outbuildings and the wooden shacks. Now Mrs. Popper and other residents of this community - which includes corners of Wilton, Weston, Ridgefield and Redding - are worried about what will replace the factory.
 
300 Condominiums
The residents said they fear that a large commercial structure will replace the factory on the 52-acre site. Gilbert & Bennett, which closed the factory a little more than a year ago and moved its manufacturing to Georgia, now proposes to put an estimated 300 condominium units and about 140,000 square feet of commercial space on the site.
While the Georgetown Chamber of Commerce has applauded the plan, a group calling itself the Concerned Citizens of Georgetown views the proposal as an attempt to build an entirely new community.
''The grand scheme of things is that it is the creation of a new Georgetown with little regard for the community around it already,'' Mrs. Popper said. ''The fact is that they never recognized that there was a community here already.''
Corning Townsend, whose house sits on the Redding side of Church Street about 100 feet from the Gilbert & Bennett site, said the development would bring in high-priced shops that would be out of the range of local customers.
''I would love to see it stay the way it is,'' Mr. Townsend said. ''I would love to see anything here, anything but to turn this area into another Westport and New Canaan. Economically, it just isn't attractive to Georgetown.''
Another concern is increased traffic. Alan Davis Associates, of Norwalk, found that the proposal would mean about 11,000 cars coming into the area daily.
''And there would be no peak for traffic,'' ' said Elizabeth Edwards, a Georgetown lawyer who lives on West Church Street in the Wilton quadrant. ''This would be a constant stream.''
 
'Almost Like a Colony'
Because the Gilbert & Bennett property is in Redding, Georgetown residents in other towns have little say in the matter, Mrs. Edwards said. Redding officials ''will essentially be making decisions that will affect those of us in other towns,'' she said. ''We're almost like a colony. Lately, I've been thinking about how colonists must have felt during the Boston Tea Party.''
Paul Gossling, president of the privately held Gilbert & Bennett, said he expects to bring his latest proposal before Redding's zoning commission late this month. If all goes well, he said, the proposal might be approved by early 1991 and the development could be completed by 1993 or 1994.
''The governmental process has to go slow, because Redding's Zoning Commission is only used to somebody coming in and asking for an approval to put a new deck on their house,'' Mr. Gossling said. ''This totally overwhelms them.''
Redding's First Selectman, Hank Bielawa, said he supports the development plan. While he found Mr. Gossling's first proposal, which had as many as 365 condominiums and 200,000 square feet of commercial space, too ambitious, Mr. Bielawa said he has no problems with the scaled-down version.
''I think it will be good for the Georgetown community,'' Mr. Bielawa said. ''After all, the alternatives are not very appealing. You'd wind up with an empty factory sitting there with broken windows and transients living there, whereas instead you could have a nice community with shops that would be in keeping with the community.
''They plan to retain all the historic landmarks and buildings. It's not a decimation of the history of Georgetown but an incorporation of it.''
Mr. Gossling said the 150-year-old red brick factory building would be restored and used for stores and offices. The metal outbuildings would be torn down, he said, to make way for brick condominiums and stores. He said his initial plan to put in a movie theater had been put aside because of community concern that it might generate too much traffic.
Adam Lubarsky, owner of the Georgetown Saloon on Main Street, has also given his support to the project. He called it ''development in a controlled fashion.''
Mr. Lubarsky said Georgetown had been locked in a ''time warp'' compared with the rest of Fairfield County. Main Street has no sewers, and the rotary-dial telephones still require a dime to get a dial tone, he said.
''A lot of my customers, even those from out of state, when they come in here feel the same way,'' Mr. Lubarsky said. ''They feel like they're in the middle of Colorado or Nebraska.''
Still, traffic worries local residents and officials in several towns who say they are worried about more cars using roads like Roues 7 and 57.
The officials also talk of environmental concerns. While Georgetown merchants support Gilbert & Bennett's plan to put in sewers and a sewage-treatment plant, environmentalists argue that the plant would hurt the Norwalk River, into which it would empty, and ultimately Long Island Sound.
 
Open Space Around Pond
But Mr. Gossling said the sewage-treatment plant ''would be cleaner than anything in that water already.'' He also said the development would reclaim the 14-acre factory pond, which is in the center of the Gilbert & Bennett property.
Before the metal outbuildings were constructed around the pond in the early 1960's, many Georgetown residents used it as a fresh-water beach. Though Mr. Gossling did not promise that swimmers could use the pond again, he said the waterfall behind it and about 13 acres around the pond would be set aside for open space.
Mr. Gossling said his critics were wrong to say that the proposed shops would be too exclusive for what Georgetown residents might want.
''We're trying to give the community what it doesn't have now,'' he said. ''We're talking about usable shops, like cleaners, a bank and hardware store. We're not talking about Saks Fifth Avenue.''

HEADLINE: Special Museums From Subs to Nuts: Enough Already?

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
THE American Silver Museum, in Meriden, was supposed to open this summer, but the building is locked shut. The museum has run out of money, and while it seeks more support, some people in the state wonder whether Connecticut already has too many specialized museums.
The latest vacation guide published by the state lists more than 140 museums of all kinds, including institutions like Yale University's Peabody Museum of Natural History and the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. The vast majority, though, are small museums that cater to special interests. These include museums that pay homage to carousel horses, circuses, submarines, fire engines and even nuts. They dot the state, from the 18th-century Ogden House in Fairfield to the Museum of Fife and Drum in Essex.
Tourists can visit the nation's first law school, the Tapping Reeve House and Law School in Litchfield. And visitors to eastern Connecticut can learn about the state's textile heritage at the Windham Textile and History Museum in Willimantic. 
 
Silver in a Vault
The American Silver Museum would like to join these ranks, but its opening has been indefinitely postponed. The building is nearly completed, but $500,000 more is needed, said Brenda J. Vumbaco, one of the museum's organizers. The museum's staff is working temporarily in the Connecticut National Bank building in Meriden, and the museum's collection of silver is stored in the bank's vault.
The focus of the museum would be national, Ms. Vumbaco said. ''It would be the only museum in the country devoted to silvermaking. What the museum is to be is a living memorial to the silver workers and their families all over the country,'' she said. Ms. Vulbaco estimated that the museum would eventually draw 50,000 visitors a year.
The latest plan to provide the museum with the needed funds was rejected by the Meriden City Council in April. John Quine, a member of the council, said he voted against it, in part, because he is concerned that Connecticut has too many museums.
''If you look at a map of Connecticut, there's dozens and dozens of museums,'' Mr. Quine said.
''There's more museums than you can shake a stick at. I just don't think this museum will draw in the numbers to pay the tab, and, with that, they can't survive,'' he said.
But a spokeswoman for the State Department of Economic Development, Barbara J. Beeching, said she believes that having more museums attracts more tourists.
''We think the Silver Museum will be a very popular place to visit,'' she said. ''Here is a little bit of Connecticut history that's begging to be brought to life. The casual traveler who comes in and wonders what to do would find this very intriguing.''
But harsh economic times are ushering in a difficult era for museums, and more of them may end up in the silver museum's situation, said Wilson H. Faude, executive director of the Old State House in Hartford, a historic museum that is the state's largest tourist attraction, he said.
''For years, nonprofits such as museums have thought there would always be a corporate godfather to bail them out, that they didn't have to be run like a business,'' Mr. Faude said. ''Those days are gone.''
 
Cannons and Purple Hearts
Despite this, there are new museums hoping to join Connecticut's already crowded field.
In the final stages of preparation is the Military Museum of Southern New England, which is to open in Danbury early this fall, said Dolores Levy, a member of the museum's board. The museum is leasing a building, but, Mrs. Levy said, ''eventually we hope to get a larger building, because we have so much equipment.'' The collection includes ''about a dozen cannons, a lot of wheeled vehicles, amphibious vehicles, rifles and uniforms,'' she said.
The collection of medals and documents of the Purple Heart Museum in Enfield is temporarily housed in the municipality's Old Town Hall Museum, but an architect will soon be selected to construct a permanent building. Once that is done, a national fund-raising campaign will begin, said Anthony Porto, chairman of the Purple Heart Museum Inc.
''We anticipate busloads of people coming in from everywhere,'' he said. ''This will be the only national Purple Heart Museum sanctioned by Congress.'' The museum is to honor recipients of the Purple Heart, the medal given to members of the armed forces killed or wounded in action.
But starting a new museum is risky, said Claudia Finkenstein, who operates the New England Carousel Museum in Briston, which opened last year. About 15,000 visitors each year come to seeits collection of carved antique carousel horses. But the first months were very slow, said Mrs. Finkenstein, who, with her husband, William, raised the funds to open the museum themselves.
 
'Doing Very, Very Well'
''At first, people had no idea we were here,''Mrs. Finkenstein said. ''It was harder than I thought it would be. You really have to try to publicize as much as you can, but when you open up, you're on a limited budget.''
The Windham Textile and History Museum opened last fall in Willimantic, and so far it is ''doing very, very well,'' in part because of aggressive marketing, said the museum's director, Laura Knott Twine.
''We knew right from the beginning that we had to base our support on the community, state and regional grants and businesses, so we wouldn't be putting all our eggs in one basket,'' she said. ''It would be wonderful to find someone out there to give us a million-dollar endowment, but we're not counting on it.''
Established museums are also scrambling for funds, said Joyce Stoffers, managing director of the American Clock and Watch Museum in Bristol.
''The economy is our greatest concern,'' she said. ''In the past, we've gotten some state funding, but there is a concern over how much of that will be available in the future.''
To try to compensate, the museum is starting an aggressive new membership campaign. This includes more advertising, as well as the creation of a special clock-shaped brass-plated bookmark to be given to new members, Ms. Stoffers said.
 
An Individual's Interest
At the Connecticut River Museum in Essex, twice yearly fund raisers help finance the museum's $200,000 annual operating budget, said Kathleen Fajen, the business manager. The museum is dedicated to the history of the Connecticut River, but the fund raisers have broader themes, she said. There is an annual benefit auction, which includes items like antiques and trips. A jazz cabaret will be held on July 21.
Some museums stem solely from an individual's interest. The most celebrated of these is the Nut Museum, which features nut-oriented artwork, including ceramics, jewelry, paintings, sculpture and masks. It is operated by Elizabeth Tasjian, who started it 18 years ago in her 100-year-old Victorian mansion in Old Lyme. She has been a guest on the Johnny Carson show eight times, she said. Ms. Fajen credits the success of her museum to her sense of humor. ''I know there is a double meaning in the word 'nut,' '' she said. ''I didn't realize that at first, but then I realized that some people consider nuts not only the kind that grow on trees, but also the two-legged variety. So I went along with it. I didn't stubbornly hold with the vision I had expected it to be.''

CORRECTION-DATE: July 22, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about museums in Connecticut misstated the ranking of the Old State House in Hartford, by number of visitors. It is the state's sixth-largest tourist attraction, not the largest.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Easing the Task of Buying Lumber

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
BUYING lumber can be confusing. For example, any piece of lumber that is less than two inches thick and eight inches wide is called a strip; any piece less than two inches thick but more than eight inches wide is called a board.
Pieces of any width that are more than two inches thick, but less than five, are called dimension lumber. Those whose smallest dimension (thickness or width) is at least four inches are called a timber. 
Yards typically stock only standard-sized lumber used for house construction. Those from evergreen trees - pine, fir and spruce, - are classed as softwood; those from deciduous trees - oak, maple and walnut - are classed as hardwood.
Lumber dimensions are always given starting with the thickness in inches. This is followed by the width in inches and then by the length, usually in feet.
The thickness and width by which lumber is designated are nominal dimensions (those to which pieces are sawed at the sawmill). Nominal dimensions do not take into account shrinkage during drying or trimming necessary for smoothness.
With softwood, lumber having a nominal thickness of one inch actually measures about a quarter-inch less; that with a nominal thickness of two inches or more actually measures about a half-inch less.
Softwood with nominal widths of two through five inches has an actual width about a half-inch less; that with nominal widths greater than five inches has an actual width about three-quarters of an inch less.
For instance, if you ask for a 1x4 strip (a standard softwood size), the piece you get will measure only about three-quarters of an inch thick and about 3 1/2 inches wide.
Nominal thicknesses for hardwood are usually expressed in quarters of an inch. For example, hardwood lumber designated 4/4 is nominally an inch thick.
Nominal thicknesses of hardwood differ from actual thicknesses by about 3/16th of an inch for smoothed lumber up to 1 3/4 inches thick, and by about a quarter-inch for smoothed lumber that is thicker. Differences between nominal and actual widths can vary, and so specify the actual width you need.
Lengths for lumber are always actual. If you ask for a 10-foot-long board, that is what you will get.
Lumber is graded according to quality and appearance. Most softwoods are classed as either Select or Common. Select grades are:
* B and Better (or 1 and 2 Clear), pieces free of any but minor blemishes.
* C Select, which allows for some minor blemishes, including small knots.
* D Select, which allows pieces to have imperfections on one side that can be covered by paint, and larger, less-easily disguised imperfections on the other.
The grades of Common lumber are:
* No. 1 (or Select Merchantable), which allows minor blemishes and tight knots less than two inches in diameter.
* No. 2 (or Construction), which allows tight knots and blemishes up to three inches in diameter (none may be near edges).
* No. 3 (or Standard), which allows pieces to have either several coarse or loose knots accompanied by other major blemishes, or a single large defect surrounded by good wood.
* No. 4 (or Utility), which allows pieces to contain more knots and blemishes than No. 3 and even some holes.
* No. 5 (or Economy), the lowest grade of usable lumber.
For trim, molding and other interior woodwork, one of the Select grades is usually the best. For most other home repairs, No. 2 Common is usually sufficient. Lumber for structural use - rafters and joists, say - carries additional grading. Check first for the grades specified by local codes.
Hardwoods are graded primarily by the percentage of unblemished wood in a board. The finest grade is FAS (Firsts and Seconds); such boards must be at least six inches wide and eight feet long, and more than 81 percent of the surface must be defect-free.
The next grade is Select. These boards must be at least four inches wide and six feet long, and have one side comparable to FAS. The remaining grades are:
* No. 1 Common, lumber narrower and shorter than Select and at least 66 percent unblemished.
* No. 2 Common, for which the boards must be at least 50 percent unblemished.
* No. 3A Common, for which the boards must be at least 33 percent unblemished.
* No. 3B Common, for which the boards must be at least 25 percent unblemished.
Lumber is usually sold by nominal volume, called board feet. One board foot equals a cubic foot (144 cubic inches). To find the number of board feet in a piece of lumber, multiply its nominal thickness in inches by its nominal width in inches and then multiply this number by the board's length in feet.
Finally, divide the product of all three numbers by 12.

HEADLINE: ART;
Bluemner's Vision of Landscape In Drawings and Watercolors

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: CROSS RIVER

 BODY:
REBUTTING criticism of the 1913 Armory Show, one of the participants, Oscar Bluemner, contended that art was still ''largely misunderstood'' in America. Art is not meant ''to amuse or instruct,'' he said, nor is it to be taken as ''imitation of nature.'' Its purpose, rather, is to elevate and liberate by making ''articulate the life of its time.''
Were he alive today, the painter would find the situation grander but essentially the same. And he might agree with his friend, Paul Rosenfeld, who said that in leaving his native Germany for the United States, ''Bluemner would seem to have exchanged a milieu potentially sympathetic to his peculiarities of temperament'' for one that was far less so. 
But none of this will be apparent to viewers of the Bluemner show at Nardin Fine Arts unless they come primed - especially by Jeffrey Hayes's catalogue to the Barbara Mathes Gallery retrospective of 1985, from which the quotes above were taken.
Spanning the period 1909 to the early 1930's, the 36 works at Nardin are drawings and watercolors and, most of them postcard-sized or smaller, they are dotted over the walls in no particular order.
Many of the works follow a formula whereby the center of interest is a road or river winding into the distance and the image is framed by trees or, when the scene is urban, by buildings. Some bear the imprint of Symbolism mixed with Cubism and a few imply a visionary agitation that recalls a much younger artist, Charles Burchfield.
There is repetition enough to suggest obsessiveness but on the whole the selection reveals little of the man whom Rosenfeld described as ''a shaggy German in baggy clothes'' and a ''rank boheme'' with a Rabelaisian sense of humor. Nor are there signs of the romantic bent on reconciling Far Eastern art with that of the West and given to ecstatic pronouncements directed at the materialistic philosophy of Herbert Spencer: ''Ultimately, the painter feels the unknown absolute.''
Bluemner, born in 1867, trained as an architect, and it was in this capacity that he left Germany for Chicago, in 1892. He was dissatisfied with the conservatism of German culture and had high hopes for art and architecture in a new country that he felt would be hospitable to new ideas. But after a stint designing for the World's Columbian Exposition of 1893, the young man fell upon hard times and, moving to New York City, was reduced to peddling calendars in the street. He would have gone home if he had had the money.
Then the economy picked up and his fortunes with it, so that by 1900, Bluemner, married and the father of a son, was again employed as an architect.
He was also sketching landscape around the city and, less than a decade later, was consorting with Alfred Stieglitz and the vanguard group around the 291 Gallery. Even more important, however, was his trip to Europe, which was financed by a court ruling in his favor over plans for the Bronx County Courthouse that had been stolen from him by a former partner.
Bluemner took in a lot of art while abroad, including exhibitions of Post-Impressionism and Futurism and - in the Berlin of 1912 - had his first one-man show. Theories of color were in the air and he was developing some of his own, which involved the frequent use of red - not for nothing was the artist nicknamed ''the Vermillionaire.'' Two years after the Armory came a solo exhibition at 291 but by this time anti-German sentiment was making itself felt and Bluemner, although a citizen, withdrew to the quieter setting of Bloomfield, N.J.
The artist remained in New Jersey until the death of his wife, in 1926, when he joined his son in South Braintree, Mass., and it was there that he produced the startling Arthur Dove-like watercolor of a November moon - a smaller version of the one reproduced in the retrospective catalogue. Looking like an orange fruit with a crescent of red along the lower edge, the orb hangs above black roofs in a rust-colored sky streaked with mauve clouds. Its companion, a smaller white moon with the ''man'' clearly visible, has a hazy yellow aureole and is suspended in a dark purplish sky.
Other remarkable efforts from this period include the gouache, ''Brookline,'' where houses looking like blocks of pink and white adobe cluster behind a green tree, and a tiny street scene that is a newspaper clipping enhanced by pencil and an explosion of white light.
Still, not all the noteworthy works were done in Massachusetts: for example, there is ''North Bloomfield'' (1922), a stylized view of houses and trees in gentle pinks and grays, together with a bold charcoal sketch of the waterfront at Port Elizabeth, N.J. (1925). Of interest, too, is the 1920 gouache of a red hut and black tree standing on white ground with a railroad in the distance. It is called ''The Scales House Soho.'' Could this mean that New Jersey gets credit for the first American Soho as well as the first baseball game? Bluemner enjoyed good critical notices but evidently not the luck needed for total success. Coming one after another, the death of his wife, the Depression and physical illness all took their toll. In 1936, he produced his last painting, an atypically detailed self-portrait that is not in the show; early in 1938, he committed suicide. Mr. Hayes does not say if it was death by vermillion but he quotes a letter written a few weeks earlier in which the artist says he will someday eat his stock of that color and ''stretch out on all fours like a cat,'' adding that ''the exit'' should be made ''with a nice bow, quick and short.''
The show remains through next Sunday. Nardin is in Yellow Monkey Village on Route 35, and its hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday.

HEADLINE: Manhattan Chefs With Stylish Cuisine Find a Home on L.I.

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:
FOR some prominent chefs from New York City, restaurants and food shops on the Island are providing safe harbors in the economic storm.
With fewer new restaurants opening and more empty pages in the reservation books of established places in Manhattan, chefs are lighting stoves elsewhere, especially in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. This spring, Brendan Walsh, who was once the chef at the trend-setting Arizona 206 on the Upper East Side, opened Coyote Grill in Island Park. Len Allison, the chef and owner of Hubert's, also on the Upper East Side, is spending the summer cooking at the Chequit Inn on Shelter Island.
And for the last two months, Michel Fitoussi has been running the kitchen at Cafe Blueberries, a catering shop in East Norwich. In his 25 years as a chef, he has cooked at the Palace, once New York's most expensive restaurant, as well as at Regine's and most recently with Jean-Jacques Rachou at La Cote Basque, waiting for a position to materialize in a new hotel. It never did. 
''This is a very good job, and for me the pressure is off,'' Mr. Fitoussi said. ''I'm cooking great good, but I can also have a life with my family.'' Mr. Fitoussi, whose children are 3 and 8 years old, lives in Kings Point.
The move to the Island by many chefs is largely a response to a downturn in business in the Manhattan restaurant trade - a reflection of a troubled economy. Restaurants say they have been particularly hurt by the shrinking amount of expense-account money that coprorations and other businesses are making available to employees. Other patrons, unwilling to pay higher prices for meals, are staying away; reservations are less difficult to come by these days. As a result, many chefs are having trouble finding work.
 
'I Do Not Miss Manhattan'
''I'm a chef and the most interesting thing for me is to be cooking,'' Mr. Walsh said. He left Arizona 206 to open his own restaurant in lower Manhattan, but when the deal soured he began exploring other options, finally making an arrangement to open Coyote Grill with John Vitale, who owns Paddy McGee's, a bar and restaurant next door.
''I do not miss Manhattan,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''I've been too busy. There's been too much work.'' He has been turning out 250 to 300 Southwestern-style dinners a night in the informal, bustling waterfront restaurant that has been a hit from the moment it opened its doors.
On Shelter Island, Mr. Allison said his spending the summer at the Chequit Inn is ''an experiment.''
''Last summer was a disaster for Hubert's,'' he said, ''so I knew I wanted to try something else. I've always wanted to be in a resort area near the water, but Shelter Island is simpler than being in the Hamptons.'' He described the pace at the inn as ''more relaxed and comfortable'' than at his Manhattan establishment.
The allure of the Island for New York chefs and restaurateurs is nothing new. More than 25 years ago the esteemed Henri Soule, chef and owner of Le Pavillon, once one of New York's greatest restaurants, created a summer outpost at the Hedges Inn in East Hampton.
A decade ago, Bruce Bozzi, an owner of the Palm Restaurant in Manhattan, opened a branch in The Huntting Inn in East Hampton and subsequently took over the Hedges Inn as well. Dean and DeLuca also opened in East Hampton around that time, and although that store closed, Joel Dean, one of the partners, is still a co-owner of Dean & Company in the village.
Peter Luger in Great Neck and H.S.F. in Bridgehampton are two other New York restaurants with Long Island locations. George and Helen Studley, the owners of La Colombe D'Or on East 26th Street in Manhattan, owned the Long Wharf in Sag Harbor until last year. That restaurant has now been taken over by Howard Steins, owner of a midtown Manhattan club called Au Bar. Mr. steins has reopened the Long Wharf as Aussi, a restaurant and club.
And Pino Luongo, who owns Sapore di Mare in Wainscott, was once involved with Il Cantinori in Manhattan and now owns Le Madri on West 18 Street and Seventh Avenue.
 
Opening in St. James
It has been more than six years since Guy Reuge, who worked at Tavern on the Green and Le Plaisir, relocated to St. James and opened Mirabelle. In some respects he fore shadowed the current trend.
''I wanted to open my own restaurant,'' he explained. ''Le Plaisir had just closed and things were not going so great for me, like with some of the chefs now. I had this opportunity because my wife's family was here and willing to help finance the restaurant. It would take a lot to convince me to go back to New York now.''
Geography can be as important a factor as the economy. One reason Mr. Bozzi opened the Palm in East Hampton is because he vacationed there. And like Mr. Fitoussi, Mr. Reuge has young children and appreciates being able to work on the Island close to where he and his family live. The same holds true for Mr. Walsh and Mr. Allison. ''The lifestyle has a great deal of appeal,'' said Mr. Walsh, who has rented a house near his Island Park restaurant.
The chance to work near his home and family also inspired Tony Russo of Lake Grove to open a branch of his Italian prepared-food business in Glen Cove four months ago. He is an owner of A. Russo and Sons, a food shop that was started by his grandfather and is still thriving in the East Village of Manhattan.
''I live here, and it was becoming harder and harder to get up at 5:30 in the morning to travel into New York every day,'' Mr. Russo said.
He said he had been delighted to find that his clientele is more sophiticated than the customers in the Manhattan store and that he can carry a wider range of products.
''The really know all about the esoteric regional stuff like special cheeses, and meats,'' he said. ''They're not just interested in mozzarella and pasta. I have had to hire a kid who speaks Italian.''
 
Customers 'Not as Aggressive'
At the Coyote Grill, Mr. Walsh said his particular brand of spicy Southwestern food had also found an appreciative audience. And at the Cafe Blueberries in East Norwich, Mr. Fitoussi said: ''The clientele here is the same as the New York clientele. The difference is that the people are not as agressive or uptight.''
Greater culinary sophistication has made it possible for chefs like Mr. Reuge, Mr. Fitoussi and Mr. Walsh to succeed, and it is also why a club like Glen Oaks in Old Westbury hired as consultants Richard Lavin, a Manhattan restaurateur, and Harriette Rose Katz, a Manhattan party palnner to revise the menu. And it is why David Liederman, owner of both Chez Louis and Broadway Grill in Manhattan, is now in his second season as consultant to the Montauk Yacht Club.
 
Plenty of Local Suppliers
Not only do those dining out on the Island have a keener food sense today, but the farmers and fishermen are more willing to cater to those tastes, supplying chefs and restaurants with a bountiful harvest of local foodstuffs.
''I found small purveyors who will supply me with the kind of things I need to supplement the basics I can get from major sources,'' Mr. Allison said.
Pino Luongo and Mark strausman, his chef at Sapore Di mare in Wainscott, have cultivated a number of local sources for produce, fish and even game and baked goods.
And while big distributors and whosesalers might not be willing to make daily deliveries to restaurants on the Island, the small producers go out of their way to serve the restaurants.
Perhaps the hardest part of running a restaurant on the Islands finding a staff comparable to those in Manhattan. ''We can't draw on the same pool of reasonably well-trained waiters that you have in Manhattan,'' said Mr. Walsh.
The uneveness of the business, with a crush of reservations on weekends and slower nights midweek at restaurants throughout the Island, also complicates staffing.
In vacation areas the problems are even more severe. ''If you use college students, they all quit by mid-August,'' said Mr. Bozzi of the Palm in East Hampton. His solution is to house some of his help, especially the people who come to the Island for the season from his Maimi restaurant. Mr. Luongo and Mr. Allison have done the same thing. ''We're lucky to be able to provide housing,'' Mr. Allison said. Costs Increasing The costs of doing business, including insurance, taxes and wages, have also increased, making profits on the Island narrower today than they were a few years ago, said Mr. Reuge of Mirabelle in St. James. But it's still less expensive and easier than opening a new restaurant in Manhattan. ''With the tightened market and the competition, young chefs may now be more willing to be on the Island,'' Mr. Reuge added.
''It all comes down to the fact that this is a business and you have to go to the market where your business is going to thrive,'' Mr. Walsh said.
Still, despite the relative health of the business on the Island and the influx of well-known chefs, the area remains in Manhattan's shadow. In the suburbs of other cities like Washington, Chicago, Minneapolis or San francisco, however, fine restaurants are treated with as much respect as those in the cities, especially by the press. But some chefs and restaurateurs on the Island feel that the New York press and dining public has yet to cross the rivers and discover what chiefs are accomplishing 45 minutes or so from midtown, not only to the east but also in Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey.
''I resent that we don't get the same recognition we would if we were in the city,'' said Mr. Reuge. ''That's the hardest part.'' But if the current trend continues, it's likely to happen before long.

HEADLINE: OUR COSTLIEST WAR

BYLINE: By JAMES AXTELL; James Axtell, the Kenan Professor of Humanities at the College of William and Mary, is the author of ''The Invasion Within: The Contest of Cultures in Colonial North America.''

 BODY:

THE RED KING'S REBELLION
Racial Politics in New England, 1675-1678.
By Russell Bourne.
Illustrated. 273 pp. New York:
Atheneum. $22.95.
Popularizing history is a tricky business at the best of times, but particularly in these days of professional specialization. To sell their books but not their souls, popularizers must steer between the rocks of half-baked research and the shoals of academic prose. The best have been either readable professors like Garrett Mattingly and Samuel Eliot Morison or scholarly journalists like Allan Nevins and Barbara Tuchman. They all did their homework but wrote for the elusive general reader rather than the professoriate. 
The publication most responsible for popularizing America's history has been American Heritage, a Nevins brainchild. The accessible magazine and the highly visual American Heritage books have put our history within reach of every library-card-carrying citizen in the country. So it is a good omen that Russell Bourne, the former editor of American Heritage Books, has written a short, eminently readable retelling of the bloody tragedy known as King Philip's War.
The war was the deadliest and costliest, proportionately, in American history, worse than the Civil War or Vietnam in terms of lives lost, communities destroyed and economic dislocation. It had no winners, only losers. Named for the unregal chief of the Pokanokets, a Plymouth Colony tribe, the conflagration engulfed all of New England between 1675 and 1678, when it burned itself out in Maine.
Philip (or Metacom) was the younger heir of Massasoit, the Wampanoag sachem who befriended and allied himself with the Pilgrims in a treaty in 1621. For Mr. Bourne, this treaty inaugurated an exemplary era of good feelings, a period of ''biracial harmony'' when Native Americans and newcomers lived side by side with equity and cooperation. But he never examines its provisions, which were, in fact, tipped heavily toward the English, the self-appointed policemen of America's allegedly lawless forests.
The only reasons for Plymouth's relatively benign behavior in the early decades were the Pilgrims' demographic disadvantage and their lack of interest in converting the Indians to Christianity. After the great migration of 1630-42, their pugnacious Puritan neighbors to the north operated from no such weakness. When English land lust, sharp trading practices and disdain for Indian sovereignty pushed the New England Indians to the wall by the 1670's, Philip's local insurrection ignited discontent the length and breadth of New England.
A heedless attack by the settlers on the neutral Narragansetts, the most populous and powerful tribe, drove them and the rest of the region's tribes into furious resistance. Canonchet, the able Narragansett chief, became the field commander of the uprising. Before it was over, the war had claimed 9,000 victims (two-thirds of them Indian) and destroyed most or all of nearly 50 English towns. Homelessness, starvation, crushing taxation and our earliest veteran problem preyed on New England for years afterward.
Mr. Bourne blames the breakdown of political accommodation on both sides for the war. Men of the caliber of Roger Williams and Massasoit were replaced by hotter heads whose basic distrust of the other culture precipitated pre-emptive acts of aggression rather than bold initiatives of peace. Maj. Richard Waldron, for example, disarmed the Indians on the New Hampshire-Maine border out of fear that they might be seduced into war by the ''rebels'' just south of them. The only result was winter starvation for many Indians, who depended on their guns for hunting, and the destruction of Maine's coastal towns in angry reprisal.
Any student of the war has an unbeatable cast of characters to direct: Benjamin Church, the most effective and most principled Indian fighter in the colonies; Mary Rowlandson, the minister's wife who, captured by One-Eyed John (Monoco), sewed her way to freedom; Weetamoo, the mercurial and much-married ''queen'' of the Pocassets; Stone-Wall John, the Indian mason who built impressive walls around the Narragansett swamp fort; Thomas Gardiner, arrested for treason for suggesting that Massachusetts caused the Eastern war by disarming the Abnakis; and Mugg Hegone, the Abnaki war captain, who planned to capture a navy of English fishing boats and attack Boston. Mr. Bourne makes a lively job of it. Actors on both sides of the buckskin curtain come alive as engaging, fallible human beings, not cardboard stereotypes.
But ''The Red King's Rebellion'' is only a mixed success as popular history. Mr. Bourne, descended from the minister who founded the town of Mashpee, where his converts, or ''praying Indians,'' lived, aimed at a ''personal narrative'' of the war rather than a new interpretation. Yet his text is pockmarked with dutiful bows to the ''competing professionals'' who have fought over his historical turf. The reader is subjected to confusing references to ''conservatives,''
''revisionists'' and ''scientists'' (or ''ethnohistorians,'' his favorites), and surprisingly Mr. Bourne comes to a revisionist conclusion that ''an ineluctable sense of guilt'' is our major legacy from the war.
This gets us no farther than do his discredited references to New England's ''theocracy'' (the Puritans practiced strict separation of church and state), Indian ''braves'' (only on the 19th-century Plains), ''French and Indian Wars'' (not from French or Indian viewpoints) and particularly the ''racial'' nature of the conflict between ''red and white.'' The meeting of Native Americans and the English was a cultural encounter in which boundaries were permeable and values transferable; race played no part until after 1689.
Nevertheless, this is a good and largely reliable rendition of a cautionary tale that cannot be heard too often by modern Americans, especially after Vietnam, Grenada and Panama.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1169 words

HEADLINE: Focus: The Lake Erie Waterfront;
A Shrinking Supply of Developable Land

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

DATELINE: SANDUSKY, OHIO

 BODY:
After several years of rapid construction in the resort areas along Lake Erie, little waterfront property remains for additional development. As a result, attention is turning to a tiny cluster of islands off the shore here.
Since the mid-80's, planners and developers along Ohio's 265 miles of Lake Erie shoreline, especially in small towns like Vermillion and Huron west of Cleveland, have been looking to the lake's ecological recovery to drive a thriving second-home and leisure-time economy.
Now, after a tenfold increase in condominiums in Ottawa County alone since 1980, developers are looking to the islands to continue the trend. 
This renewed interest in the recreational potential of Lake Erie comes on the heels of the much-heralded rebound of the lake's water quality. Improved sewage treatment in major waterfront cities, the decline of the area's heavy industries and their accompanying waste and several years of high water levels worked through the 1980's to reduce phosphorus pollution. No longer is Lake Erie covered with thick blue-green algae, nor is it the subject of national jokes.
''It's not as though Lake Erie were just now being rediscovered; that happened a few years ago,'' said Lucius McKelvey, president of R. I. Resort Properties, the Cleveland developer of Rattlesnake Island, one of the smaller of the lake's islands. ''The problem today is that the lakefront is getting overpopulated.'' For the most part, the eight Put-in-Bay Islands in the offshore cluster have remained far removed from the condominium and hotel fever on the mainland. Much of the island property is farmland. With lake-effect weather providing milder winter temperatures, the islands have an ideal climate for grapes and have been farmed as vineyards for more than a century. North Bass Island is home to a winery; the island is owned by Paramount Distilleries, a Cleveland producer.
In contrast, as the island's port-of-call for summer tourist boat service from Sandusky and the nearby Marblehead Peninsula, the town of Put-in-Bay on South Bass Island is anything but sleepy. During the summer, Put-in-Bay's 410 year-round residents are visited by an estimated 10,000 tourists a day. On South Bass, the second-home market is flourishing, and interest has begun to spread to the other islands in the group.
TWENTY lakefront home sites on 65-acre Rattlesnake Island were put on the market earlier this year, ending the island's halof century as a privately owned hunting and fishing preserve. Averaging one-half-acre each, with Lake Erie frontage ranging from 150 to 280 feet, the lots begin at $175,000.
And under a proposal unveiled late last year by Johnson Island Inc., 200 single- and two-family homes are planned for 148 interior acres of the 300-acre JohnsonsIsland. The plan also includes a marina with 825 dock slips on an abandoned 20-acre limestone quarry to be linked by a man-made channel to the lake.
Concern about the impact of growth on the islands has prompted area planners to reconsider zoning regulations drafted in the mid-60's, as well as the capacity of roads and utilities.
''We are not geared to consider resort and condominium properties,'' said Walter C. Wehenkel Jr., director of planning for the Ottawa County Regional Planning Commission. ''And as we run out of lakefront on the shore we are going to see more and more pressure put on these islands.''
New construction on nearby Marblehead Peninsula and Cawtawba Island north of Sandusky has prompted the county to add a $37 million sewer system. Additional sewage and water treatment plants would have to be added to meet the demand of further island growth.
''There's always the question of where the land would come from,'' said Charles Herndon, chairman of the Kelley's Island Planning Commission. ''No one wants a sewage plant in their backyard.''
The expense of ferrying building materials is a drawback to island construction. Even passenger service is limited to summer tour boats out of Sandusky and a car ferry from the tip of Marblehead Peninsula from April through November.
Resistance from each of the islands' small group of landowners has been the biggest obstacle for developers thus far. The proposal for Johnsons Island, for instance, has been submitted for approval four times in efforts to overcome islanders' objections. Carl Zipfel, a developer from Strongsville, dropped plans for 200 condominiums as part of the new Bay Cliffs residential development after the plans were rejected by the zoning board.
Now, while the Ottawa County Planning Commission has granted preliminary approval for Mr. Zipfel's latest plan of single-family homes and duplexes, he has also agreed to set aside 22 acres for purchase by the state or Federal Government to meet the concerns of preservationists interested in the island's history as a Union fort and prison for Confederate soldiers in the Civil War.
As the island's primary tour-boat port and closest major city, Sandusky has much to gain from continued growth. The demands of the new summertime population have helped the city's economy by creating new service sector jobs.
The city has begun work on an overall waterfront plan to guide future developments. Thus far, public marinas, condominiums and a shoreline park have recently replaced out-of-date and unused industrial properties and warehouses along the city's waterfront.
City planners are also confronting lake frontage as a diminishing resource. ''We are looking at the possibility of relocating some remaining industrial users to free up more lake-front property,'' said Gary Boyle, Sandusky's planner.
With 40 undeveloped acres, the $50 million, 110-acre Harbor condominium community in eastern Sandusky is one of the few residential developments on Ohio's shore with remaining waterfront land. Begun in 1983, the Harbor's 188-unit complex is one of the largest of the area's recent second-home developments. In addition to residences, a 237-room Radisson Hotel opened in mid-1988 and a $1 million, 90-acre wetlands preserve was completed last year.
Condominium units range from 800-square-foot studios at $100,000 in the five-story Marina Tower, to 2,000-square-foot, three-bedroom villas on the lakefront for $270,000. Each of the Harbor's residences also includes a boat slip.
In response to a continuing demand for second homes from boating enthusiasts across the state and from local executives who maintain winter homes in Florida and summer homes near their offices, another 69 single-family-home lots ranging inprice from $135,000 to $330,000 are to be offered later this year. Construction is set to begin in mid-1991. Each lot will have access to the water after the addition of three man-made channels.
''There is no doubt that the islands are a major attraction,'' said Jack Brubaker, site manager for Northill Corporation, the Fort Wayne, Ind., developer of the condominium community. ''If you dock in Cleveland there is no place to go in the lake but out and back.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Put-in-Bay, Ohio, on South Bass Island, has a thriving second-home market. (Roger Mastroianni for The New York Times)
