HEADLINE: Little Progress Is Seen OnEnvironment Goals

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THREE years after Connecticut developed a comprehensive environmental plan setting out goals for the year 2000, a state environmental panel has reported little progress toward meeting them.
''The current rate of progress will not allow us to reach the '100 percent of target,' or anywhere close, by the year 2000,'' concludes a report released this month by the State Council on Environmental Quality.
Beach closings, one measure of coastal water quality, rose to 70 in 1989 from 57 in 1988 and 48 in 1987, the report said.No major parks have been acquired, it said, and meeting the goal for farmland preservation will take the state almost a century, at the present rate. 
''Something is going to have to change to meet all of the goals,'' said the executive director of the council, Karl J. Wagener.
 
'A Lot of Frustration'
The director of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, Suzanne Y. Mattei, was a member of the original Environment 2000 panel, appointed three years ago by Gov. William A. O'Neill. ''There's a lot of frustration,'' she said. ''There was nothing in that document that could not be accomplished. We can set the goals that we want, but we're not going to be able to meet them, unless we have a governor and a legislature committed to meeting them.''
Another member of the committee, John E. Hibbard, director of the Connecticut Forest and Parks Association, said: ''As a society, we're often short-lived in our commitments. Back in the 1960's, we set a lot of goals, too. We were going to clean up the water and separate the sewers from the storm drains and clean up Long Island Sound.Did we reach them? But I think 1990 is a good year to look at these goals again.''
The 20th Earth Day in May helped to renew interest in the environment, Mr. Hibbard said, and the lack of progress toward meeting the goals in the first three years of the 12-year state plan could galvanize the public, and spur Connecticut to increased environmental efforts.
State Rep. Mary M. Mushinsky, Democrat of Wallingford, co-chairwoman of the legislature's Environment Committee, said the plan was forged in what turned out to be the last very good year for the Connecticut economy, at a time when people thought there would be more money for environmental programs.
''But it's been downhill since then,'' she said. ''And it doesn't look very rosy for the next couple of years. So if we don't want to lose ground, we've got to come up with innovative funding, and I think the public will support us in that.''
 
Set a Precedent
The first steps were taken this year, with the General Assembly's approval of user fees that go directly to the state Department of Environmental Protection, Ms. Mushinsky said. The money this year will pay only to maintain the department's staff, she said, but the action has set a precedent, breaking an unofficial prohibition against so-called dedicated funds.
Now it is up to the Connecticut lawmakers to come up with fund-raising mechanisms like California's gasoline tax, which is dedicated to environmental programs, she said.
The Environment 2000 plan, first released in September 1987, set out goals in 42 areas that were to be met by 2000. The council's report on progress, making its way now through the environmental community, cites a number of areas where advances have been limited.
For instance, one goal of the plan was separation of combined sewer and storm-drain systems in some cities. The combined systems overflow in heavy rains, dumping raw or partially treated sewage into streams.No systems have been separated since 1987, the report noted, and at current financing levels, reaching the goal will take more than 20 years.
Some 550 miles of the state's 880 miles of rivers and streams are classified as swimable and fishable, the report said, but that has not changed since the goal of 100 percent was adopted, and about 5,000 acres of lakes remain polluted by excessive nutrients from septic systems, lawn fertilizers and agricultural runoff.
Of 54 stations that test for heavy metals in five major rivers, 20 showed some improvement, but the majority, 31, showed no improvement, and 3 stations recorded worsening conditions.
 
Wildlife Restoration
There are some bright spots in the report. Wildlife restoration programs seem to be succeeding, it said, with populations of piping plover, osprey, bald eagle, deer, turkey and otter showing improvement. Black ducks have shown some decline, and the D.E.P. is trying to bolster their population, it said, ''but existing development will likely preclude a recovery to their past population levels.''
And even where improvement is noted, a delicate balance has been achieved. The number of days when Connecticut air met Federal standards for smog has increased, for instance, but the State Department of Transportation projects that between 1970 and 2000, the number of vehicle miles traveled will increase from 45 million to 75 million, wiping out the gains made with cleaner, more fuel-efficient cars.
The D.E.P.'s Environment 2000 liaison, Hugo Thomas, said the department cannot force people to stop driving their cars or watch to make sure every backyard mechanic is not dumping motor oil down a storm drain.
''We're frustrated that so many of these things are beyond our control,'' Mr. Thomas said. ''But at the same time, we're developing some very good documentation to show we need better programs.''
Ms. Mattei said some environmentally conscious legislation would have no cost attached and could even save money. For instance, laws governing the filling of inland wetlands now require consideration of a number of factors, she said, but if the regulations were made simpler, fewer of the cases would end up in court.
 
'Wishy-Washy Laws'
''We need laws that set much stricter standards,'' Ms. Mattei said. ''A very clear law is actually going to save money. But what we have are a lot of wishy-washy laws.''
Ms. Mattei said she hopes that the governor and legislators elected this year will bring new ideas and new vigor to the environmental movement.
''I don't think it's too late,'' she said. ''Most of the goals we should be able to accomplish. But it means a concentrated effort from now through the turn of the century.''
Mr. Hibbard said the $100 million proposed to acquire parkland is insufficient to meet the goal of Environment 2000, which is 140 acres of public recreation land for each 1,000 residents. The state, with about 3.1 million residents, has some 310,000 acres of public recreation land, the report said.
Mr. Hibbard said $400 million to $500 million will be needed for buying parkland, and a like amount will be needed for farmland preservation.
''We need to redouble our efforts in the next decade, if we are going to approach these goals,'' he said.
Ms. Mushinsky said that if public support grows for the environment, as the advocates predict, the programs could advance.''To do an effective program, we're going to need a new funding source,'' she said. ''And I think the public supports user fees for the environment, when they know that's where it's going.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: Courts Are Undoing Efforts To Aid Minority Contractors

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
As a result of a recent Supreme Court decision, courts around the country are dismantling state and local programs that set aside contracts for companies whose owners are members of minority groups.
The businesses' owners, most of them black or Hispanic Americans, say they have suffered substantial economic losses because of the ruling.
In the wake of the January 1989 decision ruling that a Richmond, Va., ordinance was unconstitutional, lower courts have struck down such programs in San Francisco, Atlanta, Philadelphia, Birmingham, Ala., Jacksonville, Fla., and Dayton, Ohio, and at the state level in Michigan.
 
Law Violated 14th Amendment
In the Richmond decision, the Court voided the local law stipulating that work valued at 30 percent of the value of city construction contracts had to be awarded to businesses with minority owners. It said the ordinance violated the Fourteenth Amendment, which says no state may deprive any person of equal protection of the laws. 
Before adopting racial or ethnic preferences, the Court said, a city or state has to show evidence of discrimination ''with some specificity.'' Societal discrimination is ''too amorphous a basis for imposing a racially classified remedy,'' it said.
The Court has upheld a set-aside program established by Congress at the Federal level, and last month it sanctioned the Government's preference for minorities in awarding licenses for television and radio stations. The Court said the Federal Government had ''unique remedial powers'' far exceeding those of cities and states.
 
Consultants Benefit
The Richmond decision is proving to be a boon for consultants and statisticians who help local governments catalogue and document past discrimination. To address the Court's objections, many local governments have commissioned studies of racial, ethnic and sexual discrimination in the marketplace for construction, supply and other goods and services.
White contractors in Columbus, Ohio, are already challenging the fairness and objectivity of such studies, and similar protests are expected elsewhere.
To avoid lawsuits, many agencies, like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, have voluntarily suspended the use of minority set-asides, which involve the solicitation of bids exclusively from companies with minority owners. The New Orleans school board, citing the Richmond case, repealed its set-aside program four months after the Court's decision.
Some cities, including Minneapolis, have abandoned numerical goals in dealing with such companies and have adopted preferences for ''emerging small businesses,'' defined without reference to race or ethnic background. Many states and cities, including South Bend, Ind., are re-evaluating their affirmative action programs in light of the Court's decisions.
 
A 'Devastating' Impact
''The impact of the Richmond decision on state and local government programs has been devastating,'' said Anthony W. Robinson, president of the Minority Business Enterprise Legal Defense and Education Fund, a legal group that represents minority contractors.
It ''opened the floodgates to additional litigation'' and has caused a substantial loss of income for black and Hispanic contractors, he said.
Richmond adopted its set-aside program in 1983 and suspended it under court order in 1987 after a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond. Michael K. Jackson, an assistant city attorney, said last week that the proportion of the total value of city contracts going to businesses with minority owners declined to 11 percent last year from 32 percent in 1986.
E. R. Mitchell Jr., a black contractor in Atlanta, said the value of his work in progress, $13 million in January 1989, has dropped to $5 million currently, forcing him to lay off workers.
 
'We Lost Business'
''We have lost business with the City of Atlanta, the Atlanta School Board and Fulton County,'' Mr. Mitchell said. ''Some general contractors decided that because of the Richmond decision, they do not need to seek out minority subcontractors or minority joint venture partners on their projects. Some local government agencies that did not have set-aside plans in the past are afraid to adopt them now because they fear that a white contractor will sue them.''
At least 11 lawsuits challenging such programs have been filed against local governments by members or local chapters of the Associated General Contractors of America, which represents 32,000 companies in the construction industry. Michael E. Kennedy, special counsel for the association, said: ''The lower courts are faithfully following the Supreme Court decision in the Richmond case. The net effect is to strengthen the competitive-bid system because they reject efforts to inject irrelevant factors, like race and sex, into the award of public contracts.''
Rebecca Doggett Andrade, director of minority and small business development for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said: ''Before awarding a contract, we ask contractors for a good-faith commitment to use the services of minority businesses. But we no longer have the ultimate penalty: denial of the contract for failure to do so.''
Over and over, in cases filed by white contractors, lower courts cite the City of Richmond v. Croson as a reason for holding set-aside programs unconstitutional.
 
Ordinances Fall
The Georgia Supreme Court, citing the Richmond case, struck down a set-aside program in Atlanta, saying the city had produced ''no evidence of discrimination against black contractors.''
In Florida, Federal District Judge John H. Moore 2d struck down Jacksonville's set-aside program, saying it ''suffers from the same constitutional infirmities that the Supreme Court found in the City of Richmond plan.''
The chief judge of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia, Louis C. Bechtle, recently struck down a 1982 city ordinance that set aside 15 percent of city contracts for minority businesses and 10 percent for companies owned by women.
He said the Philadelphia ordinance ''suffers from the same defects as the Richmond plan'' in that it was not based on ''specific identified evidence'' of discrimination and was not ''narrowly tailored'' to remedy such bias. Different Standard for U.S. The Federal programs meant to address racial discrimination ''are subject to a different standard than such classifications prescribed by state and local governments,'' Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote last month in a case involving affirmative action programs of the Federal Communications Commission. The court upheld those programs, which give a preference to blacks and other minorities seeking licenses to operate radio and television stations. And in 1980, the Court upheld a Federal law under which minority-owned businesses were given at least 10 percent of certain Federal grants for the construction of public works.
But those decisions did nothing to save many state and local set-asides.
Judge Alex Kozinski of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco gave one reason for making such distinctions in a decision striking down a San Francisco ordinance that reserved city contracts for minorities and women.
Members of Congress, he said, represent a much broader ''spectrum of interests'' than do the members of a state or local legislative body, so there is less ''likelihood of oppression'' when Congress establishes a program favoring one race or ethnic group over another.
A few set-aside programs have been upheld. Ronald C. Sims, a member of the King County Council in Seattle, said, ''We tried to anticipate what the Supreme Court would rule, and we repeatedly adjusted our ordinance so it could withstand a legal challenge.''
Immediately after the Court decision in the Richmond case, King County retained a consulting firm to augment findings of racial discrimination it had compiled since 1986. In addition, the county set separate numerical goals for different categories of work, like architecture, engineering and construction, so it could not be accused of having a rigid quota.
The effort paid off. In December 1989, Federal District Judge William L. Dwyer in Seattle upheld the county's program giving preference to women and minority groups in letting contracts.
In revising their affirmative action plans, many other local governments have shortened the list of intended beneficiaries to include only groups that have experienced discrimination in their markets.
The Richmond ordinance, like the Federal public works law, gave a preference to businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic Americans, Orientals, Indians, Eskimos and Aleuts. The Court criticized the ''gross over-inclusiveness'' of the Richmond plan, saying, ''There is absolutely no evidence of past discrimination against Spanish-speaking, Oriental, Indian, Eskimo or Aleut persons in any aspect of the Richmond construction industry.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1828 words

HEADLINE: Data Verify Economy's Malaise: 16 States in or Near a Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The national economy has become so sluggish that 16 states, with more than a third of the nation's population, are in a recession or close to one, an analysis of employment data shows. And throughout the country, people are talking of stagnant wages, falling real estate prices, deeply indebted corporations and jobs that are getting harder to find.
But the economic statistics collected by the Federal Government do not confirm that a national recession exists. Instead of a classic recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of a decline in output and a surge in unemployment, the statistics portray an economy that has been expanding for nearly nine years and continues to do so, although slowly. That has left a number of economists searching for ways to characterize the hardships that afflict the American economy.
 
Problems Amid Prosperity
''There are many problem areas and only a few pockets of prosperity, none very inspiring,'' said Clair Asklund, an expert in regional economics at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting firm. ''Most of the country is slipping back from the lively 1980's into nothing exciting economically.'' 
Sindlinger & Company, which asks nearly 800 households a week questions about their incomes, has found a rising level of frustration in the answers. Nine of 10 people surveyed said their incomes were being squeezed because insurance premiums, taxes and other fixed costs had risen faster than wages or the opportunity to work more hours.
''This is not a recession peopled by the unemployed,'' said Albert Sindlinger, owner of the firm, noting that the nation's civilian unemployment rate is 5.2 percent. ''This is the employed becoming ever more squeezed.''
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, came back from a trip through the Midwest during the Fourth of July Congressional recess with a similar assessment. ''People are making it,'' he said. ''They are getting along. But there is no spark left.''
 
Losing the Touch
The United States, in sum, has temporarily lost its golden touch, economists, public officials and executives say. Even the most prosperous states, principally those in the Northwest, seem unable to generate the sort of boom times that brought quick wealth almost overnight to many companies and their executives in the 1980's.
The Boeing Company, in Seattle, is probably the nation's most visible example of a boom company, with a huge backlog of orders for commercial airliners and its round-the-clock operations. To make the planes, Boeing built a big factory and greatly expanded its work force, injecting wealth into the region. But the expansion is over and, despite the order backlog, Boeing has announced layoffs because of a cutback in its military business.
''We are beginning to see a slowdown in growth in the Northwest, partly because of Boeing,'' said Carolyn Sherwood-Call, an expert on West Coast economies at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. With more than 100,000 employees and many suppliers, Boeing has a big impact on the region.
Exactly what is happening in the nation's various regions is hard to track. The Commerce Department reports the performance of the national economy by calculating each quarter whether the gross national product has increased or shrunk, but no similar figures are kept for the states or regions.
The national G.N.P. measures the value of the goods and services produced in the United States each year, a sum that exceeds $5 trillion. It has been growing lately at an annual rate of 1.5 to 2 percent - sluggish, but enough to avoid a classic recession.
 
Measure of Recession
Because the Government does not calculate G.N.P. state by state, some economists use job growth within a state to measure economic performance. If the number of jobs rises over a 12-month period, a state's economy has expanded by this criterion; if the job total shrinks, the state is in recession.
Various surveys tend to confirm state-by-state assessments based on job-growth figures. Marcia Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Offices, for example, said 25 state governments have had to draw on savings to cover expenditures in the 1990 fiscal year, which ended June 30, because weak economies produced less-than-anticipated tax revenues. Her list includes most of the states that the job data show to be in recession or close to one.
By the measure of job growth, Michigan and five New England states - Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont - are clearly in recession. Michigan is suffering because the auto industry has been in a slump. New England has been hurt by the collapse of the construction industry and by stagnation in three other former engines of growth: military contracting, computer manufacturing and financial services.
 
On the Borderline
Connecticut, Maryland, New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania are not doing much better than the New England states, suffering some of the same problems. Jobs in these states and five others - Alabama, Illinois, Louisiana, Missouri and Wyoming -are increasing at a rate of less than 1 percent a year, which Mr. Asklund of DRI/McGraw-Hill describes as ''teetering on recession.''
For the nation as a whole, job growth over the past year has been 1.8 percent.
The differences among state economies are not simply regional: sometimes strong states are neighbors of weak ones. Jobs in Ohio and Wisconsin, for example, are growing by more than 2 percent annually because these states are home to electronics companies and machine tool manufacturers that are benefiting from the one major bright spot in the national economy: strong exports and a related demand for new machinery.
Illinois, on the other hand, while benefiting from the strong exports of a company like Caterpillar Inc., is being dragged down by Chicago, where layoffs at big department stores, banks and other financial institutions have hurt the city. And Chicago has not done as well as Indianapolis and Des Moines in attracting new companies, said Robert Schnorbus, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. He blames Chicago's higher housing costs and wage levels.
Similarly, Nevada is a boom state, largely because of a burst of construction in Las Vegas. But next door in California, economic growth has begun to slow, with cutbacks in military spending forcing layoffs among aerospace companies and the construction industry losing steam.
 
Anecdotal Evidence
The surveys and statistics aside, anecdotal evidence of hard times is proliferating.
Don Sweeney, an economist at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, for example, reports that long-distance telephone traffic is stronger than ever, thanks to discounted rates. But equipment sales, which provide 40 percent of A.T.&T.'s revenue, are falling, largely because the customers for switchboards, phone lines and the like are corporations suffering from the weak economy.
The story is similar among airlines. George James, chairman of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, said that airlines have been forced in the last six months to introduce more discount fares. This has reduced the average revenue for each passenger for the first time in several years, he said.
The sluggish economic growth has reduced corporate profits and slowed the growth of income for many Americans. Less income, in turn, has meant lower tax revenues for many cities, leading them to cut spending for roads, sewers, airports and other projects that are a huge source of income for the private sector. That has helped to push up the unemployment rate in the construction industry to more than 10 percent.
 
Capital Spending Cutbacks
In a survey of 570 cities released last week by the National League of Cities, 37 percent reported having reduced capital spending in the just-ended fiscal year. More than half cut operating spending and either froze or reduced the number of city employees.
Yet despite all these problems, the national economy has not been dragged down into a traditional recession, in part because the economy is more resistant to recession than in the past, not only in the United States but also in other industrial nations.
The usual trigger for a recession is an unexpected pileup of unsold goods - an accumulation that often develops when corporations become too optimistic about future sales. The bloated inventories dissolve the optimism, prompting nervous executives to cancel orders for goods and supplies. The canceled orders, in turn, force layoffs at factories and the unemployment rate rises. The unemployed, as well as frightened workers who still have their jobs, cut back on purchases. And the economy contracts.
But a different pattern has emerged in this slowdown, leading many economists to suggest that Corporate America, with the help of various computer techniques, has temporarily cured itself of its tendency to let inventories balloon. The Eaton Corporation, a Cleveland manufacturer of axles, transmissions, engine valves, construction equipment and machinery, illustrates the new style.
 
Inventory Controls
''We never have more than a two-day supply of parts and materials on hand,'' said Adrian Dillon, Eaton's chief economist. ''The downside of this tactic is that we might not be able to meet the demand if the economy suddenly accelerated. But we're operating in anticipation of hard times, not a boom.''
So far, Commerce Department data have shown no unusual surges in inventories - with two glaring exceptions: new autos piled up in dealers' lots early this year, forcing cutbacks in production and layoffs, and a huge stock of unrented apartments and office buildings, built in the 1980's, has compounded the construction industry's problems.
In recent speeches and in Congressional testimony, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has cited the new inventory controls as a major factor that reduces the odds of a traditional recession. Partly for this reason, the Federal Reserve has been reluctant to use its power over interest rates to lower them and stimulate the economy by encouraging credit-financed spending.
The Bush Administration has been pushing for this stimulation, and Mr. Greenspan finally said last Thursday that the Federal Reserve might push down rates slightly - not to stimulate the economy, he said, but to offset credit restrictions imposed recently by banks.
Mr. Greenspan has also acknowledged that the old inventory problem could return.
''We should not presume,'' he said in a recent speech, ''that the extraordinary changes that have occurred in inventory management in recent years have fundamentally altered inventory purchasing patterns in a manner that will eliminate, henceforth, any concern we may have of inventory excess and inventory-induced recession.''

PUB-DATE: July 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1011 words

HEADLINE: Report by World Bank Sees Poverty Lessening By 2000 Except in Africa

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
The first major study of the world's poor in a decade says that poverty is likely to decline by the year 2000, except in sub-Saharan Africa.
There, the number of impoverished people is expected to rise by 85 million and to continue to account for more than 40 percent of the region's population.
The report, being issued on Monday by the World Bank, the largest provider of aid to developing countries, found that 1.1 billion people - a fifth of the world's population - still live with annual incomes of less than $370 a year. The bank draws its poverty line at that amount, below which people are deemed unable to buy adequate food, shelter and other necessities. 
But the report foresees a decline by nearly a third in the number of the world's poor in the next 10 years. It bases its forecast on the World Bank's projections of somewhat faster economic growth in developing countries, a continuation of historical trends of moderate growth in industrial countries, declining interest rates and slowly improving commodity prices.
 
Fewer of the Very Poor
The report said that if those projections hold up, there would be 825 million people living in poverty in the year 2000, down by 300 million from 1985. Put another way, 18 percent of the world's population would live in poverty, a decline from 32.7 percent in 1985.
The study on poverty, issued as the World Bank's annual ''World Development Report,'' is the most thorough compendium of data on the world's poor. Earlier World Bank reports on poverty have been widely used by policy-makers in both developed and developing countries.
The report refocuses the bank's attention on poverty after a decade of dealing with global debt problems. It also marks a shift in tone, calling the prevalence of poverty ''staggering'' and ''shameful,'' given the general economic advances of recent decades.
But in contrast with earlier studies, it does not argue that more foreign aid is the answer.
Rather, the bank, which provides $20 billion a year in loans and grants to developing countries, looks at the quality of aid, criticizing some of its own earlier projects and emphasizing that aid has to be better directed. It says that both donors and receivers of funds must show a greater commitment to reducing poverty.
 
Gargantuan Projects
''Enormous sums have been spent for purposes that have nothing whatever to do with reducing poverty -military expenditures, for example, and lavish 'cathedrals in the desert,' '' said the report, referring to projects that it deemed to have little useful value.
The new tone reflects the influence of the Bush Administration and the American-appointed president of the bank, Barber B. Conable Jr., a former upstate New York Republican Congressman, who has inveighed against third-world military spending and is generally known for a practical, no-frills leadership style. As the biggest stockholder of the 152-nation, Washington-based institution, the United States has named the chief executive since the World Bank was founded in 1945.
The study was published within days of the conclusion of the economic summit meeting in Houston, at which leaders of the seven richest industrial countries gave scant attention to the problems of the poor. The summit agenda focused on global trade issues and economic help for the Soviet Union.
The study said there has been some progress against poverty in developing countries that have taken part in the overall economic growth that has taken place since the 1960's.
Indonesia is cited as a case in point. Over the last two decades, that country has reduced the incidence of poverty from almost 60 percent of the population to less than 20 percent. And in China, which accounts for a quarter of the people in the developing world, life expectancy rose from 52 years to 69 in the 25-year period ending in 1985.
 
Why Africa Is Different
The report said conditions in Africa were expected to run contrary to the worldwide decline in poverty because that continent faces such intractable problems as high population growth, weak basic installations, and wars that have devastated Liberia, Mozambique, Ethiopia, Somalia and the Sudan.
The study projected that 265 million people, or 43.1 percent of the population of Africa south of the Sahara, would live in poverty in 2000. In 1985, 180 million people, or 46.8 percent, lived in that condition.
It said that while Asia's share of the world's poor would decline to 53 percent by the end of the century from 72 percent in 1985, Africa's would double, from 16 percent to 32 percent.
Reacting to the report, John W. Sewell, president of the Overseas Development Council, a Washington-based policy research group specializing in development issues, said:
''This report puts poverty back on the policy agenda. In the crisis atmosphere of debt, recession and adjustment of the 1980's, development and poverty alleviation were too often overlooked.''
 
More on Arms Than Healing
In calling for a better allocation of aid money, the new report was critical of the way poor countries are using their resources.
It noted that in 1986, the latest year for which figures are available, the developing countries spent $159 billion on their armed forces - about five times what they received in aid. In 1984, they spent almost as much on arms imports as on all their health programs.
''The continued provision of aid needs to be carefully examined if it seems that developing-country governments are not serious about reducing poverty,'' the report said. Restating earlier policies, Mr. Conable outlined a two-tiered strategy to combat global poverty. The first element is the pursuit of a pattern of growth that insures productive use of the poor's most abundant asset: labor.
The second builds on the 1980 report's suggestion of increasing basic social services to the poor in education, health care and family planning.
A copy of the report can be obtained for $14.95 from the Publications Department of the World Bank, 1818 H Street, Washington D.C. 20433.

HEADLINE: Rail Line Makes Debut In the Land of Freeways

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 15

 BODY:
With a mixture of fanfare and skepticism, Los Angeles this week opens the first leg of a multibillion-dollar, 150-mile commuter rail line intended to help save this car-choked city from a future of paralyzed roads and unbreathable air.
The line, which begins regular runs at 5:30 Monday morning, covers a 22-mile, 22-station run between downtown Los Angeles and Long Beach in about one hour.
The same ride by car can be somewhat quicker or much, much longer, depending on traffic.
Over the next two decades, at a projected cost of $5 billion, new branches of the rail line are to link communities from the Pacific beaches to the San Fernando and San Gabriel valleys and tie into a system of public transportation that is to include buses, car pools and a subway. 
Transportation officials say that in addition to easing congestion on the freeways, where the average speed has slowed to 35 miles an hour, the rail system will help Los Angeles meet Federal air quality guidelines. Will Anybody Ride? The question asked here is: Will anybody ride it?
Only 3 percent of all trips in Los Angeles today are made on public transportation, said Sharon Neely, director of transportation policy at the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission. Most of those are on a fleet of 2,000 buses.
Skepticism is fueled by doubts that people here will give up their cars that are a symbol of Los Angeles culture. Adding to the doubts are a general mistrust of public transportation in an area that has had no rail system since the Red Line was abolished and the freeways were built, as well as fears of crime on a line through areas infested with street gangs.
 
Rail Line Called Anachronistic
Some urban planners say the rail line is anachronistic because it will link downtown areas at a time when Los Angeles, already a city without a single core.
Even if the new system efficiently serves commuters between downtown Los Angeles and downtown Long Beach, the planners say, most of them will be left with considerable commuting challenges at either end of the line.
''There is no Manhattan in Los Angeles,'' said Jonathan Richmond, a transportation consultant at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Los Angeles has a very free-flowing, dispersed life style. People are going from anywhere to everywhere in a vast urban land area.''
The Long Beach line, known as the Blue Line, has cost $877 million, more than double some projections when work began in 1984. Construction was financed mainly by a half-percent county sales tax voters approved in 1980.
Each of the $1 million electric-powered, rubber-tired cars, built by Sumitomo Corporation of America/Nippon Sharyo of Japan, can carry 230 people seated and standing, with space for two wheelchairs, the transportation commission said. #5,000 to 7,000 Riders Expected Like other officials, Ms. Neely projected a very slow start for the line with 5,000 to 7,000 tentative commuters riding the Blue Line on its first day.
She said that figure should rise to about 35,000 by next summer, when some final portions of the line are completed in Long Beach and downtown Los Angeles. When the rail network is in full operation, the Blue Line is projected to carry some 54,000 passengers a day.
Planners project that the sale of tickets - $1.10 for a one-way fare -will pay only about 5 percent of the $33 million annual operating budget at first.
Ms. Neely said educational programs were under way to persuade people that public transportation can work.
People are also apprehensive about safety. The Blue Line passes through the heart of the hard-core gang territory of Los Angeles, and even before it opened, the police said they had arrested nearly 300 people along the line on charges ranging from vandalism to theft to possession of narcotics.
Capt. Frank Vadurro of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, who is in charge of the line's security, said about 15,000 gang members, or nearly one-fourth of the county's gang population, live within a mile of the line.
''Of course, the gangs will view this system as part of their turf,'' Sheriff Sherman Block was quoted by The Los Angeles Times as saying.
 
A Third of Budget for Security
Fully one-third of the operating budget, $12 million a year, will be spent on security, which is to include 118 full-time sheriff's deputies. Painters will try to keep up with graffiti.
Skepticism here has been fueled by a recent study of commuter rail projects conducted by the United States Department of Transportation that found they are often more expensive and less successful than projected.
Don H. Pickrell, the author of the report, said he doubted rail transport in Los Angeles could fulfill the hopes that have been raised for it. Dr. Pickrell is an economist with the Transportation System Center, the research division of the Department of Transport.
His study found that construction costs in Buffalo were 59 percent higher than projected for its rail system, In Portland, Ore., the costs were 28 percent higher, and in Sacramento, Calif., they were 17 percent higher.
Operating costs were 45 percent higher than expected in Portland and 12 percent higher in Buffalo, though they were 10 percent lower than expected in Sacramento.
Besides higher costs, Dr. Pickrell found that average weekly ridership was 66 percent below expectations in Pittsburgh, 54 percent below in Buffalo and 30 percent below in Sacramento.
But the study said the 33-mile San Diego Trolley is so popular that the city plans to triple its length.
Once the entire system in Los Angeles is in place, he said, ''it will offer a pretty high level of transit service to some specific communities and for people making some specific types of trips.''
But he said a cheaper, quicker and more urgent need was to make automobile travel less attractive by reducing affordable parking and moving toward some system of tolls at rush hour.
Ms. Neely of the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission said the problems of urban sprawl were being taken into account with plans to connect the rail system to other forms of public tranportation and a car-pool plan. Once the rail system is in place, she said, people will see that in comparison with congested freeways, ''it's safe, it's clean, it's convenient, it's quiet and it's reliable.''
And if habits do not change, she said, the average speed on freeways in Los Angeles is expected to slow to 17 miles an hour by the end of the decade.

HEADLINE: Drama Is Past Tense in Georgia Race

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 15

 BODY:
Near the end of a debate on Saturday between the five Democratic contenders for governor, former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta said he wanted to sum up what distinguished him from his opponents.
''I think basically their dialogue is about dividing up your tax dollars, and I want to bring in new investment,'' Mr. Young said.
It was not the dramatic clarion call that those who remember Mr. Young as a civil rights leader and outspoken delegate to the United Nations might have expected to hear. But its low-key approach was revealing in a race that has failed to generate much excitement, for all its symbolic resonance. 
Mr. Young seems assured of a spot in an Aug. 7 runoff, probably against Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller, after the primary on Tuesday. Mr. Miller is leading the field in all major statewide opinion polls.
 
Dearth of Interest
But despite the attention the race has generated, Mr. Young's effort to become the first black governor of a state in the Deep South has been a low-key affair.
''I just don't see a lot of interest out there,'' said Charles Schroder, executive director of the Democratic Party in Georgia. ''There is no fire in this race.''
Georgia's Secretary of State, Max Cleland, is predicting that 900,000 to a million people, or a third of Georgia's registered voters, will turn out. ''So far it appears that Georgia voters are giving it all a rather cool reception,'' he said.
On the surface, this would seem to be a campaign rich in history and conflict.
There is Mr. Young's candidacy, juxtaposed with a quirky comeback effort by Lester Maddox, the former segregationist Governor. Mr. Maddox now bills himself as the only true conservative in the race but he says the issue of segregation is irrelevant in today's politics.
And the race pits two moderate-to-liberal candidates, Mr. Young and Mr. Miller, against two conservatives, State Senator Roy Barnes and State Representative Lauren McDonald.
But if polls are to be believed, the race may end about where it began, with the two early leaders, Mr. Miller and Mr. Young, controlling about two-thirds of the votes.
A poll made public by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution on Saturday showed Mr. Miller with 36 percent of the vote, up from 32 percent in June, and Mr. Young with 30 percent, down from 31 percent in June.
Mr. Barnes had 16 percent of the vote, Mr. McDonald, 5 percent and Mr. Mattox 4 percent. Nine percent were undecided in the telephone poll of 829 likely Democratic voters. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The race has seen few dominant issues and no riveting personalities. Mr. Miller, who has outspent all other candidates, has balanced liberal issues like a call for a lottery to finance educational programs with conservative causes like advocacy of Marine-style bootcamps for first-time drug offenders.
Despite his liberal national image, Mr. Young has stressed his record on economic development as Mayor of Atlanta, promising to create jobs and increase exports in the state. He also hopes to gain support from women, with the most outspoken abortion rights stand among the candidates.
The Journal-Constitution poll showed Mr. Young with 70 percent of the black vote. But there are no signs of a huge black turnout, and the poll shows Mr. Young with the support of only 14 percent of white voters. It shows Mr. Miller defeating Mr. Young 47 percent to 37 percent in the runoff, which will be held if no candidate gains more than 50 percent of the vote on Tuesday.
 
Liberals and Conservatives
To some analysts, the most interesting aspect of the election might not be race and Mr. Young's candidacy, but what it shows about the relative strength of liberal and conservative candidates in the Democratic Party in the South.
Mr. Barnes, in particular, had hoped that Mr. Young and Mr. Miller would divide the liberal vote, putting him into the runoff. Instead, despite trailing only Mr. Miller in spending on television advertising, his campaign has struggled to catch hold.
That has led to widespread speculation about the future of white conservative candidates, who have been the backbone of the party in Georgia and throughout the South.
Merle Black, a political science professor at Emory University, said the real message of the Georgia primary, like earlier ones in Texas, Alabama, South Carolina and North Carolina, is that it is increasingly difficult for conservatives to win Democratic primaries in the New South.
''Barnes, Maddox and McDonald are going after phantom voters,'' he said. ''Their voters are much more interested in the Republican primary than the Democratic one.''
But others disagree. Loch Johnson, a political scientist at the University of Georgia, notes that the dominant Democrats in Georgia include Senator Sam Nunn, Gov. Joe Frank Harris and Tom Murphy, Speaker of the State House of Representatives, all products of the party's conservative wing. And he said all the Democrats were running essentially moderate campaigns.
 
Hopes of Republican
Nonetheless, the big winner on Tuesday may be State Representative Johnny Isakson, who is viewed as a shoo-in to win the Republican nomination for governor in a state that has not sent a Republican to the governor's mansion this century.
''If the polls are to be believed, the Democrats are going to nominate a liberal or an ultra-liberal,'' said Mr. Isakson's campaign manager, Jay Morgan. ''That gives us our opportunity just as it has in every other Southern state when the Democratic party leadership and activists led it into nominating a liberal.''
Some analysts say a victory by Mr. Young could enhance the chances of a Republican governor. But, aside from that, they say Mr. Isakson will be facing an uphill fight in perhaps the most Democratic state in the South.

HEADLINE: Another War - the One on Poverty - Is Over, Too

BYLINE: By Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, is chairman of the Senate Finance Subcomittee on Social Security and Family Policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The New York Times headline on July 7 was exuberant: ''NATO Allies, After 40 Years, Proclaim End of Cold War.''
On June 6, another headline announced an end of sorts of another war: ''White House Spurns Expansion of Nation's Anti-Poverty Efforts.''
The article reported: ''After considering a variety of ambitious options, the Bush Administration has decided against proposing any major new program or strategy to combat poverty. . . .''
It said that an interagency group convened by the White House ''to rethink the nation's anti-poverty efforts came up with a dozen broad alternatives.'' But the President's Domestic Policy Council concluded, in the Times's words, that ''the options were too expensive or would stir up too much political controversy.'' 
It is 26 years since Lyndon B. Johnson, on Jan. 8, 1964, proposed that the sitting Congress be known as the one ''which declared all out war on human poverty.'' Subsequent Presidents thought to leave their mark on the enterprise.
President Bush's team consulted with the best, and was itself made up of able and committed officials. One unattributed quotation was less than felicitous. ''A White House official summarized the upshot this way: 'Keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier.' ''
Three things have changed from the time the war on poverty began. First, there is no money. The Reagan deficits are doing their intended work, providing an automatic obstacle to any new program. A Bush Administration official said: ''The members of the Domestic Policy Council wanted to do something about poverty, but we realized we didn't have any cash.'' Big surprise, but let it pass.
Second, ''results'' are hard to come by.
The White House group considered a number of high-risk proposals and concluded there was no assurance of results. It judged that a major new ''investment in children'' would have a big payoff in the long run but was ''not likely to show an immediate reward.''
The ''easy'' war on poverty tasks have been accomplished. Medicare and Social Security eliminated large-scale poverty among the aged within a decade of President Johnson's declaration.
However, child poverty has worsened and is now the No. 1 problem. In 1960, 67 percent of black children lived with two parents; the proportion is now down to 32 percent. The trend is the same for Hispanic and white children. The locus of poverty today is neither regional, nor racial. It is the female-headed household. What is lacking is not money but what the sociologist James H. Coleman has called ''social capital'' - that fund of family and friends that pays ''dividends'' throughout one's lifetime.
Programs addressed to the manifestations of the central problem, the fractured family, rarely fulfill the hopes with which they are begun. As far back as 1978, the sociologist Peter H. Rossi formulated his ''iron law'' -''the expected value for any measured effect of a social program is zero.''
It has proved politically wiser to set goals than to start programs. Thus, Mr. Bush has set a series of educational goals for the year 2000. There is no possibility these can be achieved. ''Graduation rate . . . no less than 90 percent.'' ''First in the world in math and science.''
Ronald Reagan set precisely the same goals in 1984 for 1990. Nothing happened, but nobody got mad. By contrast, people get personal about studies of poverty programs. Third, there is not much reward. Over time, an adversarial style has developed in the poverty debates that warns the prudent policy maker not to get involved.
The White House group considered setting national standards for child support. ''Government funding would fill any gap between the minimum benefit and the amount paid by the absent father,'' the Times reported.
The sum of $3,500 for each child was discussed. But had the proposal gone forward, the air would be filled with denunciations of the $3,500 standard as barbarously and deliberately inadequate. By deciding to do nothing, the White House has spared the President from being denounced for doing too little.
So there it is. The metaphor of war has lost all its militance and urgency. What we, in fact, face is more like peacetime reconstruction after the devastation of family life in the period 1960 to 1990. Moreover, we have in place legislation that could be the instrument in this reconstruction over, say, the next 20 years: the Family Support Act. (I was the principal sponsor in the Senate and Thomas J. Downey was in the House.) The act redefined welfare. Absent fathers were to provide child support. Young mothers were to find work. There is real money behind this law. A billion dollars and more in Social Security entitlement funds. Every year. Guaranteed. It is the kind of money that lets you plan for, well, 20 years.
Typically, it took the New York State Legislature 18 months to enact legislation enabling the state to take the money. The sticking point was whether the new money would pay for four years of college rather than two. As of last week, the bill was signed, and now we shall learn if we have the social energy to implement it.
And there are things going for us. Demography - at last! - is on the nation's side. The most important fact about poverty in the 90's is that the birth rate plunged in the 70's. The size of the welfare population should soon drop by a third or more. Teen-age mothers-to-be were simply not born. Growth in the labor force will drop to 1.2 percent; white males will constitute less than 20 percent of new entrants. Everyone will be needed. We are short of young people. Here, then, is the proposition. As of now, it can be assumed that half the children born in New York City in 1990 will be on welfare by 2010. If we can cut that to one-quarter, we will have won a peacetime victory more momentous than all that war-on-poverty talk. For my part, I may skeptical. Prove me wrong.
